"Complete Guide to Mecha Design"
and looked at Cirilla. She smiled helplessly and said, "I thought you had gone back to Mulado. School starts the day after tomorrow, after all."
This past month had really tested Arix’s patience. All she wanted was to quietly study mecha, but Cirilla always dragged her into fights, calling it ’training together.’
Cirilla looked at her with the expression of a bossy cat looking at a foolish servant and retorted, "All military students need to receive professional trainings before the school really starts. Our military training will last a month, right at Hecaris. Why bother going back to Mulado just to come back? Look, I’m not here to fight today. Wait... drop that sad face of yours, okay?"
After a month of spending time together, Cirilla had come to understand Arix quite well.
Besides mecha, which could always catch her interest, Arix was like a lazy fish in other matters, the kind that only let water bring them to anywhere.
Hearing this, Arix breathed a sigh of relief. She immediately put on a smile and asked, "So, what brings you here? Is it good news or bad?"
"Of course it’s good news," Cirilla said haughtily, then continued, "There’s a mecha auction this afternoon. Are you interested?"
"Interested? What kind of mecha is up for auction?" Arix perked up immediately at the mention of mecha.
"I don’t know exactly. All I heard is that Master Gunder just made a new mecha, and it’s a Star-Class," Cirilla said, her eyes sparkling with excitement.
"Star-Class! It will be an exclusive mecha then." Arix gasped.
"Exactly, an exclusive mecha," Cirilla’s eyes shone with excitement.
Each exclusive mecha was an important strategic asset for the Alliance. Usually, they didn’t allow anyone but soldiers to pilot them.
Even military students of the Alliance had to get a recommendation letter from the military academy and approval from the Alliance corps to purchase their own exclusive mechas.
The AI chip in an exclusive mecha, like that in common mechas, had superb computing capabilities; however, the exclusive mecha’s chip boasted an attractive independence— to pilot it, one must bind their psychic power with it.
Once bound, unless the owner died, the exclusive mecha could not be bound to another person.
For a mecha pilot, owning an exclusive mecha was like having a faithful partner who would never betray you and could be relied upon to fight side by side on the battlefield.
Arix had ranked in the top ten in her last exams, which normally meant she would be rewarded with a Comet-Class common mecha. However, she hadn’t yet received any news about this common mecha, making the dream of owning an exclusive mecha seem even more distant.
Arix sighed, accepting her reality. "An exclusive mecha would be great. But without the school’s recommendation and the corps’ approval, even if I bought one, it would just sit around as a doll. Still... it would be nice to just go and take a look."
"I actually have an old one. Unfortunately, my family thinks I’ve been spending too much and started controlling my allowance. I can’t afford a new one," Cirilla sighed too.
Thinking she needed to invite other friends, Cirilla didn’t linger much longer. She agreed to pick up Arix at 14:00 that afternoon and left in a hurry.
After watching Cirilla leave, Arix didn’t go back to her book but instead picked up Cassian and started petting him.
"Ow," Cassian made a comfortable sound with his soft, milky voice. He nuzzled against Arix’s fingers touching him.
"Croissant, do you know about the therians of the Empire?" Arix asked casually.
Cassian stiffened for a moment, then quickly relaxed. Pretending not to understand, he guiltily licked his fur.
Arix felt the little body under her fingers stiffen briefly. Her eyes drooped, and she felt she already knew the answer.
Although Arix spent almost every day with Cassian, she wasn’t the one who uncovered this secret.
A few days ago, Drexel accidentally saw Cassian tidying up her room. He secretly collected a few of Cassian’s hairs and sent them for testing, only to confirm that this cute little puppy was indeed a therian.
Drexel’s face turned green with anger, and he stormed off to tell Arix about it.
Although surprised, Arix took it well. Whether puppy or therian, he was still Croissant, the one who cheered her up every day, and that was enough for her.
Cassian was silent for a while, realizing his identity might have been discovered.
He felt uneasy for a long time.
But when he looked up and saw Arix smiling at him as always, he gathered the courage to jump down from her lap.
When Arix could see Cassian clearly again, there was a little boy with silver hair in his place. He looked at her nervously with big golden eyes and said in a soft voice, "Arix, I didn’t mean to deceive you."
Arix was so charmed she felt she could barely breathe. She touched her forehead, trying hard not to faint from his cuteness.
After a moment, she gently said to Cassian, "It’s okay, I’m not mad. Croissant... I mean, you’re a therian, so you must have your own name, right?"
"Cassian, not Croissant. I’m not a piece of bread," Cassian said, still harboring some resentment towards his old name, emphasizing it a bit.
Arix coughed awkwardly and changed the subject, "The Empire is very strict about protecting young ones, how did you end up all alone in the Alliance?"
"A month ago, I fell into a wormhole. When I woke up, I saw you. Also, I’m not a youngling; I’m already 18 years old. The reason I look like this is because my psychic power hasn’t fully recovered yet. Give it some time, and I’ll be back to normal," Cassian insisted firmly on his age.
Arix was amused by Cassian’s serious little expression. She chuckled affectionately, "Alright, I know you’re not a youngling. Are you happy now?"
Cassian nodded contentedly. He sat close to Arix, curiosity sparking in his eyes, "How did you figure out I was a therian? I thought I hid it well."
"Guess," Arix teased, winking playfully.
Cassian took the challenge seriously and thought hard, but he couldn’t figure it out. He really couldn’t pinpoint when he might have slipped up in front of Arix.
Seeing Cassian’s brow furrow as if he were an old man, Arix laughed and interrupted, "Okay, stop thinking about it. It’s not important. It’s lunchtime now, and it’s a good opportunity for me to introduce you to everyone."
With that, Arix naturally took Cassian’s hand and started walking towards the dining hall.
She didn’t notice that Cassian’s cheeks were slowly turning pink behind her, his eyes sparkling with an enchanting light.

chapters.title: Chapter 22: Prince Cassian
chapters.content:
Chapter 22: Prince Cassian
In the dinning room, Drexel was sitting next to the dining table. As soon as he saw Arix, he couldn’t help but tease, "Finally, we can eat, Arix. You know what they say, ’If you’re not eager to eat, something’s wrong with your brain.’ And once again, you’re the last to arrive."
Arix hadn’t even had the chance to retort when Fleur tapped Drexel on the back of his head. "How can you talk to your sister like that? You don’t act like a brother at all, always thinking about eating. Arix, come sit next to mom."
After scolding Drexel, Fleur immediately turned to Arix with a kind expression.
"Alright, thanks, Mom. You’re always the best to me," Arix said mockingly, then turned his head to provoke Drexel with a look.
"You!" Drexel was nearly choked with anger. But when he saw Fleur giving him the stare, he could only swallow his saliva meekly.
Kellan, who was watching the whole scene, rolled his eyes, showing his disappointment in his own brother.
Thaddeus was smiling for a while until he noticed a little kid hiding behind Arix, which made him ask with some confusion, "Arix, who is this child?"
"Dad, this is Cassian. He used to be Croissant, that little dog," Arix stepped aside, revealing Cassian to everyone.
Thaddeus, initially calm, froze upon seeing Cassian’s appearance — silver hair and golden eyes, symbols of the Empire’s royalty, yet here in the Alliance. Then it struck him that just recently, the crown prince of the Empire had gone missing.
Thinking this, Thaddeus trembled as he picked up a cup from the table and took a sip of water to maintain his composure. However, the twitching at the corner of his eyes betrayed his inner turmoil.
"Croissant, wasn’t that your little dog?" Kellan asked in surprise.
Hearing the crown prince of the Empire being referred to as a dog, Thaddeus nearly choked on his water.
Thaddeus managed to swallow his water and quickly told Kellan, "Kellan, he is a wolf."
Drexel looked skeptically at Cassian. "Whether a dog or a wolf, this little guy is clearly a therian and even pretended to be a pet. Could he be a spy sent by the Empire?"
Arix glared at Drexel and snapped, "How could Croissant possibly be a spy? If the Empire sent a kid over, are they sending a spy or just sending him to death?"
"You always pick on your sister. How could a little kid be a spy?" Fleur scolded Drexel. She walked over, picked up Cassian, and comforted him, "Your name is Cassian, right? You’re so pretty. We won’t bother with this naughty boy, let’s go eat."
Cassian blinked his adorable puppy eyes and sweetly said, "Thank you, Mrs. Kering. You are very pretty too."
Fleur was instantly charmed by Cassian’s cuteness and smiled even more brightly, "Good boy."
Arix snorted triumphantly at Drexel. He then sat next to Fleur and they started discussing what living essentials to buy for Cassian.
Drexel, with a pout, watched the three of them having a good time. Seeing his mother and sister fuss over the "little wolf," he couldn’t help feeling jealous and went to complain to Thaddeus, "Dad, aren’t you going to do something? This kid’s background is totally unknown."
Thaddeus, holding his cup of water, glanced at his naïve son and finally advised, "Don’t offend him, just treat him as if a VIP has come to our home."
"What?" Drexel was completely baffled.
After the meal, Arix told her parents she would go out with Cirilla in the afternoon. Then she went back to her room on the third floor to take a nap.
Cassian wanted to follow, but Drexel, with a sneer, stopped him.
With a forced smile, Drexel said to Fleur, "Mom, he doesn’t have a room yet, right? Shouldn’t we prepare one for him?"
It then occurred to Fleur that Cassian didn’t have a place to stay. She quickly instructed the housekeeper, "Evelyn, prepare a room for Cassian, pick the one next to Arix’s. Make sure the furniture is soft, and the style is simple and elegant... actually, I’ll go with you to choose."
As Fleur left, Drexel was satisfied. He gave Cassian a smug, fake smile, "Don’t thank me, now."
After saying this, Drexel hummed a tune and walked out of the dining room.
Kellan looked at Cassian, who seemed ready to bite, and gave a helpless smile before following Drexel out of the room.
Cassian, frustrated, watched Drexel leave and then sat back down, politely calling out to Thaddeus, "Mr. Kering."
Thaddeus responded and, seeing that only he and Cassian were left in the dining room, unleashed his psychic power to enclose the space.
"Mr. Kering, what’s this?" Cassian, surrounded by psychic power, wasn’t nervous, just puzzled.
"Your Highness," Thaddeus stood up, placing his right hand on his chest, performing a greeting from the Empire.
Cassian was surprised, but seeing Thaddeus perform the royal gesture of the Empire, he quickly returned it. Then he smiled and said, "Mr. Kering, you don’t need to be so formal, just call me Cassian."
Thaddeus nodded with a smile and asked curiously, "Your Highness, how did you suddenly come to the Alliance, and to be with my daughter?"
Cassian briefly explained, "I owe Arix my thanks for saving me... It all happens..."
After listening, Thaddeus reflected on Arix’s luck. The little dog she had casually saved turned out to be the crown prince of the Empire. If their family were in the Empire, they might have been rewarded with a title.
Then, Thaddeus asked Cassian, "Your Highness, when do you plan to return to the Empire? Do you need help contacting anyone there?"
Cassian fell silent upon the question. He thought for a moment, and then replied, "Thank you for your kindness. I will contact the embassy in two days to arrange my return to the Empire. I’ll be in your care for these next couple of days."
"It will be an honor, Your Highness. I’ll leave to attend to some official matters now; please make yourself at home," Thaddeus responded.
If anything were to happen to Cassian, his family could become pariahs in the Alliance.
Cassian nodded to Thaddeus, watching him leave. He looked in the direction where Arix had gone for a long time before finally turning his gaze away.

chapters.title: Chapter 23: Mecha Auction
chapters.content:
Chapter 23: Mecha Auction
Arix woke up, yawned, and checked the time; it was already 1:30 PM.
After quickly getting ready, Arix prepared to go to the front door to wait for Cirilla.
But just as she opened his bedroom door, she saw Cassian alone, leaning on the hallway windowsill, boredly watching the garden below.
"Cassian, what are you doing here all by yourself?" Arix walked over and picked him up gently.
Cassian wrapped his little arms around Arix’s neck, nuzzling her like a kitten, "Can I go to the auction with you, please, Arix?"
Arix, utterly charmed, quickly surrendered, "Alright, alright, we’ll go together."
"You’re the best," Cassian said with a sweet smile.
"You little rascal." Arix affectionately scratched Cassian’s nose. She then took Cassian’s hand and they went downstairs to the living room.
In the living room, Fleur was knitting a sweater. Hearing footsteps, she stopped her knitting. Then she turned her head and asked softly, "Cassian, Arix, did you just wake up?"
"Yeah, just woke up. Mom, where’s Drexel?" Arix asked casually.
Thaddeus and Kellan were soldiers in the Alliance, likely at the military base now. Only Drexel and Arix were military students.
"He’s still sleeping in his bedroom, let him be; the rascal must have been up all night playing in the Connective Pod," Fleur said with a hint of disdain.
Arix laughed. She checked the time and said to Fleur, "Mom, I’m meeting a friend soon, Cassian and I will head out now."
"Go ahead. I had your dad transfer 5 million astrocredits to your account. If you or Cassian find anything you like, buy it. If it’s not enough, ask your dad to send more," Fleur instructed.
"Thanks, Mom, we’ll be going then." Arix, surprised by the generous spending money, smiled in delight.
"Bye, Mrs. Kering," Cassian waved his little chubby hand.
"Goodbye, Cassian. Have fun with Arix," Fleur said with a tender smile, waving back.
After they left, Drexel peeked his head over the second-floor railing, pleading, "Mom, can I have 1 million too? I want a new Connective Pod."
Fleur’s gaze was as sharp as a cold knife, and she fiercely spat out a word, "Scram!"
Drexel quickly pulled back his head, grumbling under his breath, "Fine, don’t give it then. I’ll just borrow from Arix."
"If I hear you’ve asked Arix for even a penny, you can forget about seeing a single credit for the next term," Fleur’s chilling voice came from downstairs, as if she had read her second son’s mind.
Drexel, feeling wronged, considered running away from home. However, realizing he still had a functioning Connective Pod in his room, he reluctantly called down, "Alright, I get it."
Fleur snorted coldly as she continued to knit the sweater for her beloved daughter.
...
At the grand entrance of the Kering family home, Cirilla called out from her Lev, spotting Arix and Cassian.
"Arix, over here!" Cirilla shouted as she rolled down the window and stuck her head out.
Arix smiled and greeted her. She led Cassian to the back seat of the Lev.
"Is this kid a family of yours?" Cirilla asked, glancing back at Cassian as she sat in the driver’s seat.
"Yes, he’s my cousin, his name is Cassian," Arix replied, keeping it simple.
"He looks pretty adorable. Buckle up, we’re about to take off," Cirilla said. Then she started the Lev, lifting it into the air.
She sped forward.
"Cirilla, I didn’t know you were so rich. This Lev, I remember, costs around a hundred million astrocredits," Arix remarked, impressed by the understated luxury of the interior.
"That’s nothing compared to Elio’s Lev. His starts at a billion," Cirilla replied nonchalantly.
"A billion? That’s enough to buy a Comet-Class mecha," Arix swallowed hard, hardly believing that a Lev could cost as much as a mecha.
"What’s a billion for a Lev? Lasair once sold five top-level luxury Levs made from Supergiant-Class insectoid shells. Each one cost hundreds of billions. Only the admirals of the four major families and the president of the Alliance could afford them, and Elio himself owns one," Cirilla said, slightly envious of Elio’s notorious wealth in the Alliance.
Arix almost turned green with envy, not so much for the Levs, but because Supergiant-Class insectoid shells were top-tier materials for building mechas, and Lasair was so wealthy that they could afford to use them for Levs.
"If you like, I can give you one in the future," Cassian mentioned. He recalled that Lasair had once gifted a Lev to the Empire to expand their business, and it had since been collecting dust in his garage. "If you want it, I’ll give it to you when we get back to the Empire."
Arix smiled at the offer and patted Cassian’s hair, taking his words lightly, "Sure, thanks, Cassian."
Cirilla heard Cassian’s grand statement and took it as the innocent boast of a child, laughing along with Arix.
After a while, they arrived at the auction venue. Cirilla parked the Lev in the parking lot and led Arix and Cassian to the auction entrance.
Twelve young women dressed in kimonos were standing in two rows at the entrance.
Another man in a suit bowed respectfully to Cirilla and her companions, "Honored guests, hello, please show your invitation."
Cirilla nodded and pulled a pure black invitation with golden sakura blossoms from her pocket. She then handed it to the attendant.
Upon seeing the sakura emblem on the invitation, the attendant became even more respectful.
He opened the invitation, glanced at it, and then he handed it back to Cirilla with both hands, saying, "It’s an honor to see you, Miss Rinn. Please come in. Miss Ame, please take the young ladies and the gentleman to the VIP box."
"Okay, thank you. Everyone, please follow me," said Ame, one of the girls in kimonos. She walked in front of Cirilla’s group, bowing slightly.
"Arix, let’s go," Cirilla said, looking at Arix.
"Okay," Arix replied, holding Cassian’s hand and following the others.

chapters.title: Chapter 24: The Auction Starts
chapters.content:
Chapter 24: The Auction Starts
As soon as Arix walked into the auction, the first thing that caught his eye was a luxurious corridor.
The wide corridor was adorned with a crystal chandelier every five meters, casting a soft, gentle light.
On either side of the corridor, the walls were embedded with a row of glass cabinets filled with exquisite antiques and limited-edition luxury items, and most surprisingly, rare mecha materials.
Arix looked calm and collected, but inside, she was dying to press her face against the glass for a better look at these rare mecha materials.
"Here we are, everyone," said the kimono girl named Ame, as she gently pushed open the door to a private room.
She then bowed slightly, making a welcoming gesture with her hand.
’So soon? I’m not ready to say goodbye to the materials yet,’
Arix thought, disappointed.
Arix looked mournfully at Ame, her heart storming with silent cries.
Feeling the intensity of Arix’s gaze, Ame tightened up, anxiously lowering her head. She wondered what she had done wrong to upset the guest and worried about a possible complaint that could cost her this hard-earned, well-paying job.
Arix, who had worked part-time jobs in her past life, understood the girl’s feelings all too well.
Feeling a bit guilty, she quickly pretended to start a casual conversation with Cirilla, "Cirilla, let’s come back after the auction and take another look at these collections. I haven’t had enough yet."
"Huh? Okay," Cirilla agreed, a bit confused but nodding obediently.
"Arix, I’ll come with you too," Cassian said sweetly.
"Thank you, Cassian," Arix said, pinching Cassian’s cheek before taking her hand and walking into the room.
Just as Ame was about to close the door, Arix turned and smiled at Ame, "And thank you too, Miss Ame."
As the door finally closed, the previously anxious Ame stood frozen for a moment before her eyes softened and she whispered softly, "You’re welcome, miss."
The VIP box was on the second floor of the auction house.
As Arix stepped inside, the first thing she noticed one of the four walls was a massive one-way window.
In front of the window, there was a couch and a low coffee table.
On the coffee table, besides some fresh fruits, there was an opticomputer that introduced the auction items. Guests could simply sit on the couch, click on an item on the opticomputer, and the item would appear as a holographic projection, displaying its details in mid-air.
At that moment, a young man was lounging on the couch, boredly watching the bustling auction scene outside the window.
He turned his head towards Cirilla and Arix as they entered. "Sis, is she the friend you mentioned earlier?" he asked curiously, looking at Arix.
"Yes, this is Arix, she’s the daughter of Uncle Thaddeus, and this little guy next to her is her cousin, named Cassian," Cirilla introduced.
"So you are Uncle Thadeus’s daughter? Hi, I’m Adrian Rinn, Cirilla’s twin brother. It’s an honor to meet you," Adrian said as he stood up and reached out his hand, his smile radiating like a morning sun.
"Thank you," Arix replied, smiling back as she shook his hand.
Seeing their hands shake, Cassian, who had been left aside, suddenly felt unhappy and stared intently at their clasped hands.
His eyes twinkled for a moment before he pretended to be weak, swaying Arix’s hand, "Arix, I’m so tired, my legs hurt."
Thinking Cassian was just tired from walking, Arix let go of Adrian’s hand and lifted Cassian onto the couch, gently massaging his calves.
"How’s that? Feeling any better?" Arix asked with concern.
Looking into Arix’s caring eyes, Cassian’s face heated up a bit, and his voice turned sweet, "It doesn’t hurt anymore, thank you, Arix."
Adrian, observing the adorable interaction between Arix and Cassian, couldn’t help joking with Cirilla, "Sis, my legs hurt too, why don’t you give me a massage?"
"The kind where I break your leg?" Cirilla replied with a cold smile.
Adrian’s smile froze, and he sheepishly pulled his head back. Then he quickly changed the subject, "The auction is starting."
The lights over the auction stage downstairs suddenly brightened, and the noisy auction hall quieted down in an instant.
Everyone, from the VIPs in the private boxes to the masked ordinary attendees below, turned their attention to the stage.
The sound of high heels clicking echoed through the hall, and as the footsteps drew nearer, a spotlight shone on the backstage area, revealing a beautiful and curved woman stepping forward.
With a proper smile and graceful movements, the woman approached the small lectern at the front of the auction stage.
She scanned the crowd and spoke with an elegant voice, "Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, welcome to today’s auction hosted by the Lasair Corporation. My name is Amara. I’ll be your host today. Without further ado, let’s present the first auction item."
As Amara finished speaking, a kimono girl approached from backstage, carrying a wooden tray to Amara’s side.
She then presented the item to the audience below.
Amara turned on the giant screen behind her, and it displayed the item being auctioned. Simultaneously, the coffee table in the private boxes started playing a holographic image of the auction item.
As the auction went on, Amara introduced the first item with elegance, "Our first item up for bid is a Star-Class Insectoid Crystal. This Insectoid Crystal is a primary material for Psychic Wares. Its excellent condition makes it highly likely to succeed in crafting Psychic Ware. Interested Psychic Ware Masters should be ready to bid. The starting bid is 500,000 astrocredits, with increments of at least 50,000."
After her introduction, Amara began to call out the bids as customers in the hall raised their placards to show their offers, and prices appeared on the floor-to-ceiling window of the second-floor private box.
"Number 82 bids 550,000. Do we have a higher offer? Good, Number 79 bids 600,000... Number 62, 900,000. Any further bids? Good, 900,000 once, 900,000 twice, and a bid from VIP box number 8—1 million. Any higher? Going once at 1 million, going twice at 1 million, and sold for 1 million astrocredits to the guest in VIP box number 8. Congratulations! The item will be delivered to your room shortly."
With the successful bid concluded, Amara then moved on to introduce the next item up for auction.

chapters.title: Chapter 25: An Invasion
chapters.content:
Chapter 25: An Invasion
In the VIP box, Adrian frowned and said, "It’s been almost half an hour, when will it be the turn for the bio-mecha?"
Arix checked the opticomputer on the coffee table and comforted him, "Just three more events to go."
Cassian scrunched his brow, feeling an unexplainable sense of crisis urging him to leave with Arix, but looking down at the noisy auction below, he thought he might be overthinking it.
"Cassian, what’s wrong? Are you feeling okay?" Arix, noticing Cassian’s troubled expression, pulled him into a hug, concerned.
Cassian pursed his lips and just held onto Arix, silent.
He knew Arix was really looking forward to the last auction and didn’t want to disappoint her because of his own feelings.
After looking at Cassian for a while, Arix still felt worried and said to Cirilla, "Cirilla, Cassian feels unwell, I’m going to take him home."
"Arix, I’m fine, the bio-mecha is almost up. Let’s wait to see it before we leave," Cassian said, shaking his head reluctantly.
"Yeah, Arix, the next one is the exclusive mecha. It’s a pity to leave now," Cirilla also tried to persuade them.
But Arix, seeing Cassian’s pale face, could no longer care about the mecha. All she felt was worry. "No, let’s see it some other time."
"Alright then, you and Cassian head back first. Adrian, you escort Arix home. I’ll stay and handle the auction of the bio-mecha," Cirilla said.
She had the task of securing this Star-Class bio-mecha for her family. Thus, she could only ask Adrian to send them home.
"No problem." Adrian had already been impatient, so he agreed quickly.
Arix thanked Cirilla, then followed Adrian out of the box.
Outside the box, in a corner unnoticed by the three, a fist-sized wormhole was rapidly expanding.
From the depths of the hole, a dense, harsh buzzing of insectoids could be heard.
Back in the box not far from the wormhole, Cirilla was alone, intently watching the auction podium downstairs, oblivious to any anomaly.
Meanwhile, the atmosphere at the auction had reached its peak with the appearance of the bio-mecha.
People shouted and raised their bids frantically, unaware that danger was approaching.
Arix and Adrian exited the auction venue and reached the parking lot. Just when they were about to get into the car, a piercing alarm sounded from the auction hall.
"What’s happening?" Arix hadn’t figured out what was going on when Adrian, looking terrified, suddenly yelled, "Sis!"
Adrian then said hurriedly, turning pale, "Go ahead, Arix. I need to go back and save my sister!"
Without waiting for Arix’s response, he ran back toward the auction hall, too fast for Arix to stop him.
Arix’s expression darkened. Even though she didn’t know exactly what had happened, Adrian’s reaction told her that Cirilla was in danger.
"Arix, there might be a wormhole inside the auction hall," Cassian finally understood what that vague sense of crisis was.
After all, he had once fallen into a wormhole and survived by the skin of his teeth; he was not mistaken about that feeling.
"How could this be? This is the center of Hecaris," Arix’s face turned pale instantly.
Wormholes are narrow tunnels in the universe connecting two different times and spaces, inhabited by at least one Star-Class insectoid and countless Planet-Class or lower insectoids.
The appearance of such a wormhole in the planet’s center city could bring a disaster akin to the end of the world.
"Cassian, I need to go and block that wormhole. Stay in the car and don’t run around! Wait for me to come back," Arix put Cassian in the car and instructed firmly before she turned and ran toward the auction hall.
She came from a family of soldiers; she could not abandon ordinary people in danger, especially when a friend was inside.
Cassian reached out his hands, trying to stop Arix, but his short, chubby arms couldn’t even catch the edge of her coat as she turned.
Watching her running farther away, Cassian’s pupils suddenly contracted, and he yelled frantically, "Arix! Come back!"
Arix, who had already run into the auction hall, didn’t hear Cassian’s shouts amid the chaotic screams for help.
At that moment, she was running against the crowd into the auction hall.
Finally, she saw Cirilla and Adrian standing in front of the wormhole. They were releasing all their psychic powers to form a barrier, seemingly trying to block the wormhole.
But the wormhole was too large, and many insectoids were still escaping through the gaps.
Fortunately, there were some people that Arix could detect a military demeanor in front of the auction podium. They were also fighting desperately to prevent the insectoids from escaping the hall, tearing the insectoids that crawled out from the cracks.
Even Amara, who looked elegant and beautiful, was slashing insectoids with a dashing grace. However, the incessant attacks from the insectoids gradually made her struggle. It did not diminish her beauty; instead, it added a worn charm to her appearance.
The stunning sight of a beautiful woman in battle stirred up the blood of all the males present, and they showed no fear even in the face of the endlessly crawling out insectoids.
"I’d die here today and it’d still be worth it with Amara by my side. What do you say, Hank?" a man roared with bravado.
"Hah, I wonder if I could take Amara out for dinner after this is over?" Hank, somewhat familiar with Amara, didn’t forget to flirt with her even amidst the fight.
Amara responded with a charming smile and solemnly announced to everyone, "After this is over, I, Amara, will treat all the brave men here to a dinner party, and we won’t go home until we’re drunk as a skunk."
"Alright! Amara, you have my word. We’ll definitely get rid of the bugs and drink with you like a fish," Hank laughed heartily.
He then focused back on the incessant insectoids in front of him and roared, "Everyone, did you hear that? Lady Amara will take us to a party after this is over. How can you not give it your all? Charge!!"
"Go!"
"Kill them all!"
A resounding echo of agreement burst forth around him.
Some were struck down or even killed by the insectoids, but not a single person stepped back.
They understood that behind them were countless unarmed civilians. If they retreated and were defeated, allowing the insectoids a chance to escape, it would cause irreparable disaster to countless civilians outside.

chapters.title: Chapter 26: Cassian Grew Up
chapters.content:
Chapter 26: Cassian Grew Up
Arix barely opened her eyes, shocked at the horrific scene in front of her. She bit her lip to hold back her sadness.
She quickly ran to the side of Cirilla and Adrian, who were completely exhausted from using up all their psychic power.
"Arix?" Adrian looked at Arix with a tired face, surprised.
"Arix! Why did you come back?" Cirilla was still holding up a psychic power barrier, her eyes wide with disbelief.
"Why didn’t you run away?" Arix asked back instead of answering.
Cirilla said, irritated, "How did you... You trying to make me mad or something? I told you to leave! Do you really love us that much that you want to die with us here?"
Arix laughed bitterly. She turned her gaze back, her expression serious. She stared at the wormhole, "Leave the rest to me, you guys can rest up."
With no further delay, Arix began to harness all the psychic power within her psychic world. The power slowly formed a massive psychic barrier, which soon enveloped the wormhole completely.
Inside, the trapped insectoids screeched in frustration.
Their sharp, cold-gleaming limbs attacked the psychic barrier relentlessly, but all their efforts were futile.
"That’s power of a Supergiant+?" Cirilla, who had already withdrawn her psychic energy, watched Arix’s silhouette in awe.
"Wow, sis, Arix is really kicking some ass," Adrian said admiringly.
Cirilla, for once not objecting, responded with mixed feelings, "Well, she’s just getting started, I guess."
Once the insectoids escaping the wormhole had been dealt with, people in the auction hall almost all collapsed to the ground, gasping for breath.
Several severely wounded individuals passed out, and those who could still stand all turned their attention to the young girl sealing the wormhole.
"Who is this girl? She’s quite something. The supergiant-class siblings couldn’t fully seal it, but she managed it alone," Hank said, gasping and clearly impressed.
Hank’s friend, wiping blood from his mouth, raised an eyebrow at Hank, "You really don’t know?"
"Just spit it out. Don’t beat around the bush like that—it’s annoying," Hank grumbled, frustrated with the evasion, especially coming from a tough guy like his friend.
Unoffended, Hank’s friend just sighed, "It’s no wonder you’ve been just a small squad leader in the Fifth Legion for a decade; you don’t even recognize Admiral Kering granddaughter. You should really try to pay more attention to your higher-ups."
Hank’s eyes widened in disbelief as he processed the information. "From the admiral’s family? That explains her incredible power. She truly is a credit to Admiral Kering’s lineage."
Around them, people continued their praises, but Arix, still maintaining the psychic barrier, couldn’t hear any of it.
In just 20 minutes, her psychic power was almost depleted, leaving her with nothing but the harsh ringing in her ears and a mind clouded with pain.
Just when Arix was about to give in, a powerful surge of psychic power forcefully merged with hers.
Relieved that the seal held, she thought Cirilla had helped her, and she wanted to thank her.
When Arix turned around, however, she saw a strange young man with silver hair standing behind her, looking at her intently.
"You are...?" Arix hesitated, then ventured, "Cassian’s elder brother?"
Cassian let out a laugh and stared intently into Arix’s eyes, saying, "Who do you think I am, Arix?"
Arix blinked, taking a closer look at the handsome face in front of her. Then she suddenly realized something and blurt out, "Cassian? How did you grow up?!"
Cassian, satisfied, lightly tapped Arix’s forehead and said, "This is my true form, Arix. Do you like it?"
His silver hair reflected a soft sheen, and in sharp contrast were his bright, golden eyes, which were very piercing.
His thick, arched eyebrows and prominent nose exuded a masculine aggression, making it hard for Arix to connect him with the cute little boy she once knew.
Lastly, his red lips, like jelly, looked sweet and soft. His entire face displayed nobility and elegance.
Arix almost gawked. Blushing, she turned her head away and muttered softly, "Yes, yes, got to admit he’s quite handsome."
Cassian’s smile deepened, his gaze softening as he looked at Arix.
Adrian’s admiring followed Cassian from his strong, heroic entrance to the now increasingly sentimental atmosphere.
He looked somewhat bewildered and asked, "Sis, did he come to rescue us, or is he here to romance Arix?"
Cirilla, speechless, glared at her naive brother and smacked the back of his head. She then scolded, "Shouldn’t you be more concerned about where this guy with Supergiant+ psychic power popped up from?"
"Isn’t he just from our Alliance?" Adrian rubbed the back of his head, feeling wronged.
"Really? You think the Alliance is just lucky like that? To have one Supergiant+ after another?" Cirilla sighed, still trying to enlighten her only brother, and reminded him, "Think about it, among all the galaxies, who else has silver hair, golden eyes, and Supergiant+ psychic power? Think carefully."
Adrian pondered for a moment, then it struck him like a bolt of lightning. He trembled like a leaf and pointed at Cassian. His voice trembled as he asked, "Sis... are you saying he is..."
"OK, that’s enough, no need to say it out loud. Let’s pretend we don’t know," Cirilla quickly interrupted Adrian, not wanting to cause trouble for her family.
Adrian swallowed, his curiosity itching like a cat scratching at him, but he couldn’t help asking, "If Cassian is from the Empire, does that mean Arix might become his luna someday?"
As soon as he said tat, Adrian felt some piercing glare.
Adrian, looking up, realized it was his sister glaring at him. Cautiously, he asked, "Sis, what did I say wrong now? The current royal family of the Empire are werewolves, right? They emphasize their own culture, calling the emperor ’alpha’ and the empress ’luna,’ right?"
"You must be a spy sent by the Empire, my dear brother," Cirilla said, as if she were looking at a patient beyond cure.
As a member of the Alliance, the thought of marrying off the Alliance’s only Supergiant+ to the Empire made her consider severing ties with Adrian.
Adrian looked even more confused.
Cirilla sighed, "Adrian, my dear Adrian... God favored Arix so much that He gave Arix extra lucky and talent, yet you... my poor little thing, He must hate you so much that he totally muddled the creation."
She finally gave up on trying to cure her brother’s naivety. Now she realized why all the elders of the Rinn family opposed him becoming the family heir.

chapters.title: Chapter 27: Ether Crystal
chapters.content:
Chapter 27: Ether Crystal
A wormhole appeared in the center of Hecaris City, and news of it spread terrifyingly fast across the entire Alliance.
While all the people of the Alliance prayed for Hecaris, far away in the Empire, Duke Glendale also received the news.
"Oh, you’re saying a wormhole has appeared in the Alliance," Duke Glendale remarked. His expression wasn’t exactly gloating, but his tone was definitely a bit gleeful.
"Yes, Your Grace, we have a spy at the auction site; the information is absolutely accurate," confirmed Kasem, the Duke’s trusted butler.
Duke Glendale’s smile grew wider as he feigned sympathy, "Hecaris is where the Fifth Legion is stationed, and a wormhole appears right under their noses? This really isn’t going to look good to the people of the Alliance, Kasem. You know what to do, right?"
"Understood, Your Grace. I will have our spy bribe the media to promote the Fifth Legion properly," Butler Kasem replied respectfully.
After finishing his statement, Kasem turned to his opticomputer, located an account, and sent an encrypted message to the Alliance.
Duke Glendale smiled contentedly. He elegantly picked up a cup of hand-ground coffee, and sipped it lightly, occasionally making a satisfied sound of appreciation.
Just then, an irritating emergency alert sound came from Butler Kasem’s opticomputer.
Duke Glendale frowned and gestured for Kasem to check the message.
Respectfully nodding, Kasem accessed the opticomputer, and opened the urgent message.
"The crown prince has been found at the auction site in Hecaris. Need backup!"
The content nearly made Kasem buckle at the knees.
"What is it about this message that’s so urgent? It must be interesting," Duke Glendale commented leisurely, taking another sip of his coffee.
"Duke, Prince Cassian is in Hecaris, at the auction site where the wormhole appeared," stammered Butler Kasem. His limbs trembled with fear and his voice quivering with disbelief.
"What the..." Duke Glendale spit out his coffee. His movements was too hurried, and he even knocked over his coffee cup.
At that moment, Duke Glendale had no time to care about the spill. He urgently commanded, "Hurry up, contact our embassy in the Alliance to protect the prince, hurry."
"Yes," Kasem replied. He steadied himself before quickly left the mansion to deliver the instructions to the embassy in the Empire.
While he was alone, Duke Glendale thought for a moment and decided that, to make everything under his control, he had to make a trip to the Alliance himself.
Meanwhile, in the Alliance, inside the auction hall...
"Arix, I’m here to save you!" shouted Drexel. He was in a combat suit and rushing into the auction hall in a panic, his cries echoing wildly.
However, when Drexel saw that Arix was unharmed, his cries suddenly stopped.
Drexel stood there, still a bit stunned, and foolishly asked Arix, "You’re okay, Arix?"
The scenario didn’t match his expectations—wasn’t Arix supposed to be waiting for him like a sitting duck in distress?
Arix, sensing the curious gazes of the crowd, gave a wry smile and said, "Why are you here?"
"I came with Dad and some guys from the Fifth Legion; they’re right behind me. I was worried, so I rushed in," Drexel explained. After checking Arix from head to toe to make sure she was unharmed, he finally let out a sigh of relief.
Drexel quietly observed Cassian. He was surprised to discover that this man would merge his psychic power with Arix’s—a level of trust that only come with deep connections.
"The Fifth Legion’s here," shouted a friend of Hank’s suddenly, drawing everyone’s attention towards the doorway.
Two rows of Alliance soldiers appeared, clad in deep blue uniforms and armed with rifles. They stood tall and formidable like solitary oaks on a mountain peak.
Thaddeus raised his left hand, and the well-trained troops stopped. He then approached the wormhole, accompanied only by a soldier holding a dark wooden box.
"Arix, Dad’s proud of you," Thaddeus said affectionately, patting his daughter’s head.
He then turned to Cassian, pausing before thanking him, "Thank you for protecting the Alliance and Arix."
Cassian responded with a humble smile, "No need for formalities, Admiral Kering."
Thaddeus nodded and then instructed towards the wormhole, "Fergus, put it in."
"Yes," Fergus responded, then politely smiled at Arix and Cassian, "You can both withdraw your psychic powers now."
Arix and Cassian exchanged a glance and nodded together.
The moment their psychic powers dissipated, Fergus opened the wooden box and swiftly threw a stone with anti-gravitational properties into the wormhole.
"Dad, what’s that?" Arix asked curiously.
"The bane of wormholes, an Ether Crystal. You’ll learn about it at the military academy, but take a good look now; practical opportunities are rare," Thaddeus explained with a smile, patting his daughter’s head.
"Okay," Arix replied, her eyes fixed on the wormhole with the curiosity of a child.
Just as the insectoids inside the wormhole thought their chance had arrived with the psychic barrier gone, they realized the wormhole was rapidly shrinking. In a matter of moments, the vast wormhole completely closed.
After the wormhole disappeared, not only Thaddeus and his team breathed a sigh of relief, but everyone else also felt a massive weight lift from their shoulders.
"Now we can relax," said Hank, who had been tense the whole time. His relief was so profound that he fainted from the sudden release of stress.
It was only when Hank collapsed that his friend noticed a large gash across Hank’s abdomen.
Hank, dressed in black and deliberately hiding his injury, had prevented anyone from detecting anything amiss until now.
Hank’s friend carefully checked Hank’s pulse, relieved to find it still beating. And then, he also collapsed onto the ground, exhausted.
Not just Hank, but many others in the hall were also severely injured. The sight of the Alliance soldiers seemed to have allowed them to finally let go of their burdens, resulting in many collapsing or fainting.
Thaddeus, deeply moved by the scene, solemnly removed his military cap and saluted everyone, "All medical expenses for those here will be fully covered by my Fifth Legion. For those who tragically lost their lives in this disaster, I will request that they and their families receive the same treatment as martyrs and their widows. Additionally, on behalf of all the people of Hecaris in the Alliance, I thank you, heroes."
"When the people of the Alliance face trouble, it is our duty to help," cried Hank’s friend. He was supporting the unconscious Hank and wiping away tears as he led the chant.
"When the people of the Alliance face trouble, it is our duty to help," echoed the voices of those still awake in the hall, their declaration ringing loud and heartfelt.

chapters.title: Chapter 28: The Duke’s Confession
chapters.content:
Chapter 28: The Duke’s Confession
Thaddeus and the Fifth Legion had been guarding the auction house, and they only left after the medical staff arrived.
Thinking of Fleur, who was anxiously waiting at home, Drexel decided to follow Thaddeus.
Arix said goodbye to them and stayed behind to help the injured with Cirilla and Adrian. They didn’t stop until the medics had taken all the injured away.
"Arix, our butler has come to take me and my brother. We’re leaving now, but I’ll see you at military training the day after tomorrow," Cirilla said after checking a message on her opticomputer.
"Okay, see you then," Arix replied, smiling and waving.
After Cirilla and Adrian left, Arix realized she was alone with Cassian, which made her feel a bit nervous.
"Arix, why won’t you look at me?" Cassian asked, trying to appear innocent.
"It’s nothing... I’m just not used to you growing up so fast," Arix replied, turning away in embarrassment.
Arix had always been drawn to beauty. When she was eight, she would often follow handsome boys, worrying her family until the boys had to call the police to bring her back.
Her fixation on looks caused trouble, and the elders tried to cure her by making her look at pictures of handsome men for a month.
At first, Arix enjoyed it, but she soon grew tired and eventually nauseated, begging for the ordeal to end.
The elders thought they had cured her, but they had only made her more selective.
Cassian raised an eyebrow and leaned closer, his voice husky, "Arix, don’t you like that I’ve grown up?"
His expression and his handsome face overwhelmed Arix, making her feel breathless.
Cassian laughed upon seeing her react, and Arix, confused, touched her nose. She noticed a hint of crimson on her fingertips.
...
"Ow!" Arix howled, turning away to quickly pull a handkerchief from her spatial button to wipe the blood.
Though she cleaned the blood, she felt a deeper stain on her soul.
She knew the blood was from the recent fight, but Cassian might have thought it was excitement that caused her nosebleed.
Embarrassed by the thought, Arix stubbornly kept her back to him, refusing to turn around.
Cassian watched her with a hint of amusement in his eyes. He was about to continue teasing when he was interrupted by shouting from the entrance.
"Prince Cassian, Your Highness!" A middle-aged man called out loudly from the corridor of the auction hall.
Arix breathed a sigh of relief and moved further away.
Cassian turned to see Duke Glendale rushing into the hall.
Upon seeing Cassian unharmed, the Duke joyously clung to his legs, wailing, "Your Highness, I’ve found you at last. You have no idea how hard this past month has been for me. I couldn’t eat or sleep, thinking you might be suffering, my heart felt as if it were being sliced."
Kasem, the butler, arrived with the Empire’s legion shortly after. He bowed his head, struggling to suppress a smirk at the Duke’s dramatics. Although the Duke claimed hardship, he had continued to indulge in fine wines and foods, even entertaining a bevy of beauties the previous night.
Despite his disdain, Cassian noticed the genuine fatigue marked by dark circles under the Duke’s eyes. Feeling a pang of sympathy, he sighed, "I understand, you’ve had a hard time this month. Please wait outside for me, and do not come in without my permission."
Duke Glendale ceased his wailing. He rose and gave Arix a knowing look. Then he puffed up his chest and promised, "Your Highness, rest assured, I won’t let anyone in."
After casting a meaningful glance and a sly smile at Cassian and Arix, Duke Glendale left the hall with Kasem.
The hall fell silent until Cassian gathered his courage to speak. "Arix..."
"Cassian, you’re leaving, aren’t you?" Arix, already aware, stopped pretending and asked casually.
Cassian remained silent for a moment before nodding. "Yes."
"When are you leaving?" Arix asked, her voice tinged with sadness as she hung her head.
When Arix felt her loneliest, Cassian had entered her life. His presence over the past month had helped her adjust to her new circumstances.
It seemed she had rescued Cassian, but in reality, his arrival had given her strength. Even though she had always known they would have to part ways because Cassian was a therian from the Empire, she was still unprepared when the moment actually arrived.
Cassian noticed Arix’s unusual sadness and sighed. He gently pulled her into his arms to offer comfort. Feeling his tender touch, Arix’s eyes immediately filled with tears.
After a moment, Arix asked softly, "Will you come back?"
Cassian paused before replying with certainty, "I will, Arix."
"Will you be in danger in the Empire?" she asked, her concern palpable.
Looking into her clear, sky-like eyes, Cassian felt a stir in his heart. He reached out to touch the corner of her eye gently and reassured her, "Don’t worry, I’m safe in the Empire."
"That’s right, you’re the only prince of the Empire," Arix said, her voice tinged with desolation. She realized Cassian no longer needed her protection.
Cassian did not elaborate on his safety but smiled and released Arix, looking at her reluctantly. "Arix, I have to go."
Arix watched him silently for a long time before finally nodding and advising, "Okay, here’s my opticomputer number, make sure to contact me once you’re in the Empire."
"Alright, I’ll remember, Arix. But I have take you home first, then I’ll go," Cassian insisted, not wanting her to go home alone.
He took her hand and walked her out, only departing for the starship after ensuring she was safely back at the Kering family’s place.
Arix leaned quietly against the door after he left, remaining there until the outside was silent.
Then, she walked back inside, feeling a bit lost.
It was late at night, and Arix felt bored. She lay by the bedroom window, occasionally checking her opticomputer.
After a sigh, she dropped her arm again.
"Why hasn’t he contacted me yet?" Arix muttered, slightly annoyed.
It had been 10 hours since Cassian returned to the Empire. Yet, apart from the occasional ad pop-up on her opticomputer, there were no friend requests.
Ding!
"You have a new friend request."
Arix’s mood instantly brightened, and she tapped on her opticomputer with a smile. On a 3D virtual screen, she quickly accepted the new request.
Suddenly, a puppy avatar appeared among her opticomputer friends. Seeing this avatar, Arix laughed—it was Cassian as a child.
Ding!
"Your friend Cassian is requesting a video call."
Arix accepted, and Cassian’s upper body, clad in a golden robe, appeared on the 3D virtual screen.
"Arix, I’ve arrived home," he said, his voice warm.
Arix’s ears tingled at his voice. "Yeah, I know. Why did you contact me so late?" she asked, feigning indifference.
Cassian instantly recognized her act. Arix was just being like a child.
He sighed. If Arix were here, he’d probably pinch her nose for so naughty.
"Arix, I’ve missed you," Cassian finally admitted. His voice booming, make Arix’s ear itch.
Arix’s face turned red instantly, and in a fluster, she aimed the virtual screen at the ceiling, too embarrassed to let Cassian see her anymore.
So handsome, and with such a great voice, Cassian was tempting her to commit a crime!
Cassian, noticing the screen now facing the wall, couldn’t help laughing. He looked at the clock—it was 11 PM—and smiled at Arix through the opticomputer, "Arix, it’s late. You should go to sleep."
"Mm, goodnight, Cassian," Arix said sweetly, and then she quickly ended the video call.
Cassian was about to say more, but the screen went dark. He laughed, both disappointed and amused, "She just hung up like that? Not even a goodbye."
That night, Arix slept soundly and even had a beautiful dream.
In the dream, she walked hand in hand with a handsome man whose face she couldn’t see, along a beach under a clear blue sky with a gentle breeze.
As they walked, their mood heated up. Arix and the handsome man gazed into each other’s eyes and slowly closed their eyes, about to kiss.
Just then, thunder boomed in the sky, waking Arix with its deafening sound.
Bang! Bang Bang!
Drexel’s loud banging and shouting echoed through the bedroom door," Arix, are you up yet? The military training starts tomorrow, hurry up and come with me to the mall to buy some supplies."
Startled from her sleep, Arix grasped for breath. Remembering her near-kiss with the Prince Charming in her dream, she grabbed a pillow and hurled it at the door, yelling, "Drexel! I swear I’m having a heart attack!"
"Arix, the sun is already up; how will you handle military training being so lazy?" Drexel sighed dramatically.
"Get lost!!" Arix roared.
"Alright, I’ll wait for you downstairs." Feeling it unsafe to linger, Drexel quickly retreated.
In her bedroom, Arix glanced at the time on her opticomputer—it was only 8 AM. Frustrated by her interrupted dream, she bit her blanket. After calming down, she set the blanket aside and got up to wash and dress.
As soon as Drexel reached the bottom of the stairs, Fleur grabbed his collar and scolded him, "I told you to wake her up, not give her a shock. Why did you have to knock so loudly?"
"I get woken up the same way by Kellan; why don’t you scold him?" Drexel complained.
Kellan rolled his eyes, "You stay up all night playing games. If we don’t knock loudly, how would you ever wake up?"
Drexel’s nightlife was all about gaming till dawn, and he slept like a log during the day.
Honestly, Kellan hated having to wake him up.
Thinking about the upcoming military training, where all electronic devices had to be handed in, Kellan looked at Drexel with a smirk.
Out of arguments, Drexel weakly said, "Mom, I’m sorry. I’ll be gentler next time."
Fleur was about to lecture more but stopped when she saw Arix coming downstairs. She let Drexel off with a warning, "If I catch you doing this again, I’ll cut your allowance."
Turning to Arix, Fleur said gently, "Arix, are you awake? Have some breakfast, then we’ll go shopping."
"Mm, thanks, Mom," Arix replied with a sleepy yet sweet hoarseness.
Drexel, observing the blatant double standards, muttered to Kellan, "Look at Mom, she’s so harsh with us but so gentle with Arix."
Kellan blinked and seriously said to Drexel, "Drexel, I think you can remove ’us.’ Mom has never been harsh with me either."
Drexel paused to think for a moment, then was speechless. It seemed Fleur really was only harsh with him. With a look of betrayal, he glared at Kellan.
With a snort, he started eating. Seeing him finally quiet down, Kellan felt the air freshen around him. He began eating in a good mood.

chapters.title: Chapter 29: Making the Headlines
chapters.content:
Chapter 29: Making the Headlines
They finished the meal in a good mood. Just as Arix was about to leave, Fleur stopped her.
After transferring a large sum of money into her account, Fleur finally pushed her out the door.
"Just go. Buy yourself something nice."
Drexel was waiting by the door to drive Arix. Seeing this, his eyes turned green with envy.
He raised his hand to check his bank account on his opticomputer. His balance showed only 100,000 astrocredits, which Fleur had just transferred to him.
Drexel suddenly felt a chill in his heart.
His eyes quickly darted around, and then, trying to butter Arix up, he said, "Arix, do you have so much money you can’t even spend it all? Maybe I can help you spend some?"
Arix raised an eyebrow. Although she really couldn’t spend all that money, she wouldn’t complain about having too much—no one would.
Just at that moment, Arix remembered her potion shop on the interstellarnet, which really could use someone to help manage it.
Over the past month, besides reading beginner’s books on mechas, Arix had also been learning about potions. She had made a bunch of potions below Planet Class.
To make space, Arix had put them up in her online store, and actually sold quite a few.
But what bothered Arix the most each time she sold potions was handling the sales and packing the parcels. She thought if someone could take care of these chores, it wouldn’t be too bad. And since Drexel was her brother, he was definitely trustworthy.
Thinking this, Arix looked at Drexel.
Feeling her stare, Drexel got a bit nervous until she spoke, "How about a job? Manage my online store, mainly handle sales and shipping, I’ll pay you 5 million a month, or you can take 10% of the profits."
"Of course!" Drexel immediately agreed without hesitation. But then something occurred to him, and he cautiously asked, "Arix, when did you start an online store? It’s legit business, right?"
"It’s a potion store," Arix said with a resigned roll of her eyes.
Only then did Drexel remember. Arix’s talent for potions was indeed impressive. He had seen her make insecticide potions before, and they were quite astonishing.
"Tsk tsk tsk! That’s my sister," Drexel said, giving her a thumbs up.
"So, do you choose 5 million, or 10% of the profits?" Arix asked, raising an eyebrow.
"I’m not dumb, of course. I’ll take the 10% share. Heh, does that make me your partner too?" Drexel, never having been in a real business before, laughed excitedly.
"Yeah, I’m the big boss, and you’re my right hand. When we get home, I’ll log into the Connective Pod and give you authorities."
Finding someone to manage her store made Arix quite happy. Now she could focus on studying potions and mechas.
"Alright, let’s hurry up so we can come back early." Drexel courteously opened the car door for her, helping Arix into the car first.
Then he sat in the driver’s seat, started the Lev, and sped off toward the mall.
Twenty minutes later, Drexel parked the Lev at the designated spot and then led Arix into the mall, named the Lasair’s.
"What are we looking for?" Arix asked Drexel. She wasn’t very familiar with what to prepare for military trainings in this world.
Drexel opened his chat history with Varden and started listing items, "I know this! I asked Varden before coming. He said we need to get face wash, shower gel, fresh towels, sunscreen..."
As Arix listened, she realized these were all familiar items. She felt a bit sentimental that the items for interstellar military training were no different from a regular camping trip.
The two found a department store. As soon as they entered, they noticed many military students, apparently also preparing for training.
The store was full of high-tech items that quickly caught Arix’s attention. Excited, she pulled Drexel around the store, exploring here and there.
While they were shopping, many military academy students recognized Drexel and Arix. After all, Arix was among the top ten new students, and Drexel was a notable figure from the Hecaris Military Academy.
"Look, it’s Drexel Kering and Arix Thalis! Why are they shopping together? Oh my gosh, are they seeing each other?" one student thought he had discovered big news. He quickly took a sneaky photo of them being close together and uploaded it to the Interstellarnet Headlines.
"I always felt there was something special between them. It’s confirmed, confirmed! If they’re not a couple, I’ll eat noodles with my nose," another girl whispered excitedly.
Her friend, with a dreamy expression, added, "A wealthy heir and an orphan from Planet Waste, what a perfect match. Tell the court, I’ve ruled, they must marry soon."
Someone behind them protested unhappily, "Arix is just an orphan from Planet Waste; she’s not worthy of Drexel. Please stop making random matches; only a lady like Cirilla is suitable for him."
The self-declared "judge" disdainfully retorted, "Look at your face, it’s all twisted with jealousy. Even if Arix comes from a humble background, she’s among the top ten newcomers. If you were that impressive, my ruling might favor you too."
Meanwhile, Arix kept sneezing. Drexel looked over with concern, "Are you catching a cold? Should we buy some medicine?"
Arix sniffed and frowned, "No cold, but I feel like someone is cursing me."
"Arix, we’re in the age of science now. How can you still believe in such superstitions?" Drexel said, chuckling as he playfully ruffled her hair.
However, after Drexel ruffled her hair, Arix felt her symptoms worsen a bit.
Arix shivered slightly. Now uncertain if she might actually have a cold, she said to Drexel, "Let’s finish shopping and head back."
"Okay, we just need to get sunscreen. Let’s grab that and go. You head to the checkout and wait for me," Drexel replied, also showing concern for Arix. He hurried off toward the sunscreen display.
Ding!
"You have a message from Cassian."
Just as Arix reached the checkout, her opticomputer chimed with a notification.
Hearing it was from Cassian, Arix smiled slightly and opened the message on her opticomputer. A photo of her and Drexel together popped up in the conversation.
Arix was puzzled for a moment and sent a question mark in response. Then she started typing, "What does this mean? Drexel and I are just shopping. How do you have our photo?"
"Arix, check out the top news on interstellarnet. You’re in for a surprise," the message read.
Feeling confused, Arix logged onto the Interstellarnet Headlines. The headline that greeted her nearly made her blood boil.
Shock! Drexel Kering’s Girlfriend Revealed?!
How Arix Thalis Captured the Heart of a Wealthy Heir! Insights from Love Experts.
How Cinderella Pulled Off a Real-Life Fairytale! A Step-by-Step Guide Unveiled.

chapters.title: Chapter 30: A Hipster
chapters.content:
Chapter 30: A Hipster
The Kering family hadn’t told the public about Arix’s identity before, because they feared it would put her in danger. The Kering family’s daughter, the only Supergiant+ in the Alliance—these two identities would make all the powers of the galaxy want to get her.
So, in the eyes of most people in the Alliance, Arix was still that girl from Planet Waste, Arix Thalis.
At the family banquet of the Kering family, only the top families of the Alliance were present. They might know Arix’s true identity, but in terms of her true power, the Kering family only claimed she was a Supergiant.
The five noble families knew Arix’s real strength, but they understood the Kering family’s concerns. Therefore, they also kept silent in agreement.
So, Arix never expected that one day she would become famous because of a scandal with her own brother.
Arix was both annoyed and amused. She scrolled down the virtual screen for a while, seeing almost all the photos of her and Drexel playfully fighting in the shop.
Each photo captured a special closeness. Those images, coupled with suggestive texts, almost made her believe them if she weren’t the person involved.
"Orphan girl from Planet Waste and the grandson of Admiral Kering"—this sensational story had topped the hot search of the entire interstellarnet within just half an hour.
"You have a message from Cassian."
Arix hadn’t even opened the message, but she knew Cassian must be laughing at her on the other end.
"How about that, Arix, surprised?"
Arix quickly replied, feeling itchy with irritation, "Noooooo!"
"Haha, aren’t you starting military training tomorrow? Remember to contact me over the weekend."
"Then you should work harder to win my calls. Got to go, Drexel is here."
Not far away, Drexel was approaching fast, sparks flying. When he saw Arix close her opticomputer, he curiously asked, "Arix, who were you chatting with?"
"Cirilla asking me what to buy for military training; I just replied to her," Arix fibbed.
She didn’t want Drexel to know she was chatting with Cassian. These two were like cat and mouse in a past life, naturally at odds.
"Oh, then go wait for me in the car, I’ll come after I pay."
Drexel just asked casually. He didn’t suspect anything and after giving his instructions, he went to queue up at the checkout.
Arix breathed a sigh of relief and went back to wait in the car.
Before long, Drexel, carrying several bags, put them in the trunk. He seemed quite pleased with himself. As he sat in the driver’s seat, he said, "Arix, do you think I looked cooler today? A lot of people in the supermarket were secretly watching me."
After saying that, Drexel even flirtatiously flicked his hair in the car mirror.
Speechless, Arix didn’t know what to say and finally covered her face and said, "Dude, maybe you should check the Interstellarnet Headlines."
Drexel looked at Arix, surprised. Then he suddenly turned excited and exclaimed, "Even the headlines are discussing how cool I am? I need to check this out."
Arix hesitated to speak. The story had already blown up; Drexel would find out sooner or later.
So, she decided not to respond, just silently shut her mouth.
Drexel, his eyes wide with anticipation, turned on his opticomputer. However, as soon as he opened the news, his smile froze. His eyebrows furrowed deeply, and his face grew darker by the second.
Arix, watching Drexel’s reaction, nervously swallowed. She cautiously said, "Drexel... maybe we shouldn’t look. It’s all baseless rumors, it’s upsetting. Right?"
"No, part of them are true," Drexel said seriously.
Arix, visibly shocked, stuttered, "So you think... No... this isn’t right, we are siblings, it’s not supposed to be like this!"
"Arix, face the reality. They’re right, and it is true that I’m way out of your league. I’m just too cool to be with you," Drexel smirked arrogantly and even proudly tilted his chin up.
Arix’s fists clenched. She looked at Drexel with a dangerous glint in her eyes and said, "Is that all you took from reading this long?"
"What else is there? Isn’t it all about how you’re not good enough for me? I think it makes sense," Drexel dangerously continued.
Arix, unable to hold back her irritation, scoffed coldly, "Since you’re so great, it’s a shame to have you work for me in my store. I might as well talk to Kellan about it."
Only then did Drexel let out a wail, hastily admitting his mistake, "Arix! I was just joking. I’m sorry, okay?"
Arix then grunted in satisfaction.
Drexel didn’t dare say more. He sat like a wronged baby girl.
Soon after, they boarded the Lev and returned to the Kering family.
Once back at the Kering family, Drexel, as if on fire, dragged Arix onto the interstellarnet.
"Welcome to the Interstellarnet."
As their psychic powers connected to the interstellarnet, a familiar, gentle female voice rang in their ears.
Arix and Drexel appeared together on the bustling streets of the interstellarnet for the first time. Seeing each other’s avatars, both made faces of disgust.
Drexel merely disliked Arix’s unisex attires, and he thought she was not girly enough. Arix felt that Drexel’s outfit was an assault on her eyes.
"Drexel, what on earth are you wearing?" If Arix didn’t know they were in the interstellar, she might have thought it was a hippie revival.
Drexel was in an explosive hairstyle, colorful attire, and smoky makeup that looked half-dead. He wore a rainbow undershirt with a blue Mack shirt. Worst of all, his pants were bright pink.
"Ouch, my eyes, my eyes!" Arix cried out in mock agony.
Drexel strutted around like a proud rooster, constantly flaunting what he believed to be the most unique parts of his outfit in front of Arix. "Hmph, you country bumpkin. This style was once the trendiest thing in the ancient times."
"If it is that trendy, why haven’t I seen you wear this offline?" Arix asked curiously, covering her eyes.
Drexel’s smile stiffened. He was too embarrassed to reveal the truth, so he quickly changed the subject. "Let’s take care of the shop first. We need to get up early tomorrow for trainings. Let’s finish this and then rest early."
"Alright then," Arix replied as she opened the shop’s control panel. She clicked on the shop option in her personal information, took Drexel to the shop, and gave him the highest administration authority. With that, she handed over the entire potion shop to Drexel to manage.
Then, she logged off to video call Cassian.
After all, tonight was their last chance for a while, as all electronic devices for military freshmen would be surrendered for a month. They’d only get them back on weekends. It would be much harder to stay in touch after tonight.

chapters.title: Chapter 31: The Training Begins
chapters.content:
Chapter 31: The Training Begins
The next morning, Arix washed up and casually turned on her opticomputer.
The sound of coins being deposited echoed one after another.
"Your account has received 50,000 astrocredits, from your store."
"Your account has received 80,000 astrocredits, from your store."
"Your account has received 5,000 astrocredits, from your store."
Then Arix remembered that she had handed over her potion online store to Drexel the day before, but this endless list of transactions...
’He didn’t stay up all night, did he?’
she wondered, frowning.
She left her bedroom with a serious look on her face. When she reached the living room, she saw Drexel already eating breakfast.
"You’re awake! How about it? Did you see?" Drexel asked, excitedly raising his eyebrows.
"Don’t tell me you stayed up all night," Arix said, sounding slightly upset.
She didn’t want Drexel spending too much time on the online store. It could distract him from his studies.
Drexel grinned proudly and then pulled a miniature delivery robot from his Space Button.
"Is this a delivery robot?!" Arix first looked at the small robot in surprise, and it took her a moment to grasp Drexel’s point.
Then Arix felt a bit stupid. She had been too busy recently, her mind always muddled. She had been packing and shipping for a month and hadn’t even thought of using a delivery robot.
"Arix, could I get my share of the profits from yesterday? I bought this robot and still owe a good buddy over 800,000 astrocredits," Drexel asked shyly—a rare sight for someone usually so bold.
"Sure." Arix was speechless at her own foolishness, but she firmly transferred 5 million astrocredits to Drexel.
Upon hearing his account had received 5 million, Drexel immediately smiled broadly. "Haha, Arix, go ahead and have your breakfast. I’ll wait for you in the car."
"Okay, I’ll be right there," Arix said, her mood gloomy.
After breakfast, their driver took them to the entrance of the Hecaris Military Academy.
After getting out of the car, Arix told the driver to be safe. Then she and Drexel entered the school together and went to the training ground to wait for assembly.
Many new students who had already arrived at the training ground started whispering to each other upon seeing Arix and Drexel.
"Hey, look, it’s Arix and Drexel."
"She’s not as bad as they say online, I think they look quite good together."
"Exactly. In this year’s exam, Arix is the only one from our academy in the top ten of the whole Alliance. The others are just jealous."
"It’s a shame about her background, though. It would be great if she came from a better one."
Drexel leaned closer to Arix and whispered, "Arix, are you sure you don’t want to explain now? I’m so handsome, some crazy fan might go after you."
"The military training has already started; we can announce it after it’s over. It’s better to explain when everyone is together, otherwise, it’s too much trouble to explain to each person separately," Arix said nonchalantly.
Drexel raised an eyebrow and grinned, "Okay, that works. It’ll help me block some of the admirers. After all, girls only get in my brain and slow down my mecha driving."
"Any girl who gets in your brain is terribly unlucky," Arix rolled her eyes at Drexel’s narcissistic comment.
"Wow, look, a warship!"
As someone shouted in surprise, a huge black warship appeared in the sky. It quickly cut through the clouds and stopped in front of the training ground.
The shape of the warship was somewhat like the luxury cruise ships Arix had seen in her last life. However, she knew there was no comparison: a cruise ship was for sightseeing and could sink at any moment under wind and waves; this one was built for battle, capable of withstanding attacks from the most advanced weapons.
The freshmen waited for a while until four people slowly walked out from the middle of the warship’s deck.
The first was President Gunder of the Hecaris Military Academy; the other three, dressed in dark blue uniforms with golden trim, were new to the students.
"Hello, everyone, I am President Gunder. We will be conducting a month-long military training. The three instructors behind me will score you based on your performance during the training. After the training, they will sort you into classes based on your scores. I believe every student wants to be in the best class."
Although Gunder’s expression was kind and gentle, his tone was firm and commanding.
"Yes!" all the new students shouted together.
"Then show your best! Now, all students, board the warship," Gunder said with a satisfied smile.
Gunder gestured with his hand from back to front, and the instructor immediately activated a program on the opticomputer.
Instantly, a boarding ladder unfolded segment by segment, reaching out to the training ground.
All the new students of the Hecaris Military Academy watched the warship in awe, then they orderly boarded the ship one after another.
After confirming all the new students had boarded, Gunder spoke again, "To protect the location of the Fifth Legion base, you need to hand over your opticomputers and Space Buttons. During this time, the school will assign you a digital bracelet numbered from 1 to 1000. The bracelet will record your number and score. During military training, it is strictly forbidden to hide any electronic devices or anything unrelated to the military. Violators will be severely punished and a record of the violation will be left in their files."
The new students murmured their dissatisfaction, but almost all of them obediently handed over their opticomputers and Space Buttons to the instructors. They then received the black iron-colored bracelets from the instructors.
The students, having surrendered their opticomputers and Space Buttons, looked at the instructors with mournful expressions, as if they had just lost their boyfriend or girlfriend.
The instructors ignored these looks. They ruthlessly carried two large bags and approached the next student.
When it was Arix’s turn, she had already removed her opticomputer and Space Button. She handed them over to the instructor voluntarily, so the instructor nodded at Arix with a smile.
However, the situation took a turn when it came to Drexel next door. Arix turned to look and saw Drexel and an instructor pulling on the opticomputer as if they were in a tug-of-war.
"Let go!" The instructor’s veins bulged from the effort. He didn’t want to be mocked by other instructors, so he kept up the struggle with Drexel.
Drexel said nothing, but his eyes, almost tearful, vividly expressed his extreme reluctance.
At this point, several other students sneakily watched Drexel and the instructor. Seeing the situation escalating, Arix couldn’t help but facepalm.
Then, she quickly kicked Drexel behind the knees, causing him enough pain to release his grip.
The instructor breathed a sigh of relief and quickly put the opticomputer into the bag. He moved faster than before as he went on to the next student.
Seeing that the spectacle was over, the surrounding new students turned their attention away. Drexel looked completely deflated, like a frosted eggplant.
Arix knew how severe Drexel’s gaming addiction was and how painful it was for him to be separated from his opticomputer. She patted Drexel’s hair, offering silent comfort.

chapters.title: Chapter 32: The Instructors
chapters.content:
Chapter 32: The Instructors
The three instructors collected everyone’s opticomputers and Space Buttons into a bag. Then they stood next to Gunder and nodded at him.
After receiving the signal from the instructors, Gunder smiled with satisfaction. He looked back at the newcomers and praised, "Good, everyone is acting cooperatively. The next part of your journey will be with the instructors. Please welcome the three instructors now."
The students clapped respectfully.
The highest-ranking instructor among them, a lieutenant, stepped forward amid the applause. His handsome, youthful face, coupled with his impressive physique, caught the eyes of many girls. Some bold ones even started whispering among themselves.
The guy, Ortiz, after he positioned himself, made a silencing gesture to the students. Once the students quieted down, he spoke out loudly, "Hello, everyone, I am your chief instructor, Ortiz. On my left is my vice, Bauer. On my right is instructor Virtanen."
Bauer was a typical military man. His ordinary features, weathered by experience, gave off a rugged charm. The uniform added an indescribable sense of integrity to him. It felt like safety, as if having him around meant having someone to take on the world for you.
Instructor Virtanen was the one who had been "tug-of-warring" with Drexel earlier. He was thin and carried an air of a scholar about him. He seemed a bit shy as well. He now stood behind Ortiz, secretly sizing up each student.
After introducing his partners, Ortiz continued, "First, on behalf of all the officers and soldiers of the Fifth Legion, I welcome the students training at the Hecaris Military Academy. Since you’ve chosen the military academy, I assume you are ready to bravely forge yourselves, face hardships, and strengthen your resolve, right?"
"Yes, sir," the newcomers responded weakly, intimidated by the thought of the grueling month ahead.
"You haven’t started to suffer yet, but let me make it clear—you know what you are enduring this for? It’s so that later you can protect the people from the insectoids and defend the Alliance! Now tell me, can you do it? Louder!" Ortiz shouted loudly.
"Yes, sir!" The newcomers’ spirits were ignited. Like newborn wolf pups, they puffed up their chests, and they shouted with flushed faces.
"Good, now everyone go back to your cabins to rest and wait for further instructions. Also, the number on your room corresponds to the number on your bracelet. If you have any questions, you can ask the robot butler in your room. Dismissed!" Ortiz instructed.
After watching the students enter their cabins, he turned to Gunder with a look of deep respect.
"Ortiz, you are getting better at this," Gunder said warmly to the trio, his eyes carrying a hint of nostalgia.
He clearly remembered how these three had once stood here receiving his own lectures. They too had been timid kids, terrified of the insectoids. Gunder was now proud as he saw them as capable soldiers able to stand on their own.
"Sir, you flatter us," Ortiz responded modestly, but his face couldn’t hide a trace of excitement.
"Sir, just speak your mind, what’s there that we can’t discuss?" Bauer, the oldest of the trio and more worldly-wise, was the first to sense that Gunder had something more to say.
