Gunder, his thoughts exposed, decided not to beat around the bush anymore. "This batch of newcomers includes a girl named Arix. Keep a close eye on her."
"Is there a problem with her? Is she a spy sent by the Empire’s warmongers?" Ortiz asked sharply.
Gunder, who treated Arix as if she were a priceless treasure, was annoyed by Ortiz’s assumption and knocked him on the forehead. Then scolding Ortiz, he said, "Let me finish! You start guessing before I’ve even explained. Let me tell you, not only is Arix’s background impeccable, but she is also of great importance to the Alliance."
"So what do we do?" Ortiz, rubbing his head and not daring to interrupt further, asked meekly.
"I want you to elevate her physical power to Star Class before training ends," Gunder said firmly, his eyes serious.
"Isn’t that asking too much of the girl?" Virtanen, who had access to the recruits’ data, had just reviewed Arix’s profile and knew her current level was only Planet Class.
The idea of boosting Arix’s physical power to jump a whole class in just one month was almost absurd. If anyone other than Gunder had suggested this, Virtanen might have laughed it off.
Ordinarily, even the diligent need at least three years of training to possibly break through. Even with shortcuts, like using a Star-Class booster, it would still require at least three months of training to be effective.
After all, using a Star-Class booster wouldn’t be as straightforward as the lower-class boosters, where you might experience a breakthrough just by consuming one.
To break through to Star-Class and above, even with a potion, one still needs to combine it with extensive training to stand a chance.
Boosters below Planet Class force a breakthrough. Boosters for Star-Class and above, however, are primarily for assistance.
Most people only use them when they are on the brink of advancing to the next level, to reduce the risk of failure.
"Sir, may I ask why?" Bauer looked directly at Gunder. He knew Gunder was a dependable person. If he spoke so, there likely were hidden complexities regarding Arix.
Gunder wasn’t one to hide things unnecessarily. He shared what he could, "Arix’s psychic power is incredibly strong, but her physical condition is at the other extreme. If she hadn’t taken a Planet-Class Booster before, she might now only be able to survive in a healing pod, or worse, she might not have survived at all."
Given the life-threatening stakes for the student, the three instructors nodded solemnly. "Rest assured, we know what to do."
"Alright, no need to be so tense. Things aren’t as bad as they seem. Arix has been nurtured this month with all sorts of rare treasures by her parents, and she’s almost reaching Star-Class. She just lacks an opportunity, and that’s where you come in. I can’t help any further, I’ll be leaving now," said Gunder. After his words, he stepped onto the boarding ladder and returned to the Hecaris Military Academy.
After Gunder had left, Ortiz and the others discussed among themselves for a while. They finally made a decision together before returning to their own cabins.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: The Sisters
chapters.content:
Chapter 33: The Sisters
The warship travelled very fast. In less than an hour, the students arrived at the Fifth Legion’s base.
As they disembarked from the warship, they realized that their training location was not at the base of the Fifth Legion but in a smaller base next to it. There was a 20-meter-high wall separating the two bases.
Standing at the training base, the students’ view was blocked by the wall. Yet, from time to time, they could still see mechas and destroyers assembling in the sky above, then majestically flying out from the legion base.
Even though the students could only watch these awe-inspiring scenes from afar, they were thrilled enough to scream and cheer.
Arix was among one of the excited students. She clutched Drexel’s arm and shouted, "Look, that’s a Star-Class mecha, isn’t it? It’s just as cool as I imagined."
"It’s okay," Drexel replied, his eyes filled with envy. "You haven’t seen Grandfather’s Supergiant-Class mecha, right? It’s named Mercury. That’s really something."
"Supergiant-Class mecha? I’ve heard that mechas of this class might eventually evolve into legendary mechanical beings called Omnic. Legends say they have nearly godlike powers," Arix said, her eyes sparkling with excitement.
"That’s just a legend, after all. So far, I’ve never actually seen any mecha turn into a mechanical being," Drexel said dismissively.
"Humph, I think I’ll definitely be able to create a god-level mecha with a mechanical life someday," Arix retorted with high spirits.
"Being confident is good, but being overconfident can lead to your downfall. Take it easy, we’re not like the villains on TV with absurd talents," Drexel said, not believing her one bit. He couldn’t help but lecture Arix, feeling she was almost boasting too much.
Arix rolled her eyes and huffed. Seeing that everyone had already disembarked from the warship and gathered, she didn’t want to say more, so she stopped paying attention to Drexel.
"Meet at the training field at 8 AM tomorrow, and you have free time today. As usual, based on your numbers, find your dorms. Six people per room. As for the dorm leader, you can recommend someone and report it to Virtanen tomorrow. I now declare you dismissed," Ortiz instructed after everyone had gathered.
Then he and Bauer turned and left.
After the instructors left, other new students who had arrived at the base earlier boldly approached to find people they knew from before.
Two pretty girls approached Drexel.
Watching the sisters in front of her, Arix raised an eyebrow. She watched the trio with a gossip-hungry gaze, and then she especially took a few good looks at Drexel, eagerly anticipating some drama.
"Drexel, did you really get a girlfriend?" asked Azura, one of the two girls, blinked her eyes cutely.
The girl next to Azura didn’t speak, but her eyes were curious. She seemed nervously intrigued as she looked at Drexel.
Her name was Calista. She had been kidnapped by traffickers ten years ago. During the three days she was held captive, she witnessed the tragic fates of many girls.
The traffickers wanted to sell her for a good price, so they didn’t harm her to avoid leaving scars. Otherwise, she would have suffered the nightmare torment like the other girls.
In that hell, she waited desperately for three days. Just when she was about to be sold and had resolved to end her own life, someone burst into the room, interrupting her as she was about to commit suicide with a shard of glass.
Initially, Calista numbly looked up when she heard the door being smashed open. But soon, she realized that the intruder was just a boy not much older than her. A spark of hope flashed in her eyes, and she let go of the glass shard, feeling a vague sense of anticipation.
Drexel quickly realized that Calista was not his missing sister. Although disappointed, he calmed his urgent feelings. He gently reassured the frightened girl, "Don’t be scared. The army is coming soon."
After saying that, Drexel hurriedly moved on to the next room holding abducted children, still hoping to find his sister.
Shortly after he left, Calista was rescued along with many other children by soldiers who arrived soon after.
Later, when her father came to pick her up, Calista saw that boy again. This time, she gathered the courage to tug at her father’s sleeve and asked curiously and timidly, "Dad, who is that boy?"
Her father looked in the direction his daughter was pointing and was surprised to see Rear Admiral Kering and his son. He smiled and stroked Calista’s hair, saying, "That’s Rear Admiral Kering and his second son, Drexel."
"Are they also looking for someone?" Calista asked, pursing her lips carefully.
"Yes, I heard Rear Admiral Kering’s daughter is missing. I’ve seen that child; she’s a lively little girl. I hope the Kering family finds her soon," her father replied, ready to take Calista home.
As her father led her away, little Calista prayed for Drexel, hoping he would soon find his sister.
As Calista recalled the past, she felt somewhat dazed.
Over the years, she had often seen Drexel on TV and in the news. Today was the first time she had met him in person again.
Meanwhile, Drexel, the hero of the hour, hadn’t even noticed Calista. Perhaps he had long forgotten that he had once inadvertently saved a little girl.
When Azura asked him that question, Drexel initially wanted to say no. But seeing Arix’s annoyingly smug expression, his eyes narrowed, and he flashed a mischievous smile.
"Yeah, isn’t she right beside you?" Drexel said, throwing a flirtatious glance at Arix.
Calista looked towards Arix upon hearing Drexel’s words. She noticed that although the girl was thin, she had beautiful features and actually matched Drexel quite well.
"Ah, so that’s Drexel’s type," Azura didn’t say much, but her gaze at Arix was a mix of challenge and disdain.
Clearly, Azura was a die-hard fan of Drexel and had already seen Arix as an enemy.
Arix, innocent in this conflict, twitched her mouth and glared fiercely at Drexel.
In the next moment, Arix pretended to be affectionate and looped her arms through Drexel’s. Under the cover, her fingers fiercely pinched the soft flesh of Drexel’s waist as she sweetly said, "Oh, I just love Drexel so much right now."
Her voice grew sweeter as her pinching grew fiercer.
Drexel winced from the pain, feeling like that patch of flesh might bruise. He wanted to concede to Arix, but with two other girls there, he couldn’t swallow his pride.
After a while, once Arix’s own hand hurt from the pinching, she finally let go, satisfied. Mimicking Drexel’s earlier flirtation, she threw him a coquettish look, saying, "You chat with the girls; I’m off to the dorm."
Drexel, in too much pain to speak, managed to weakly wave his hand, trying not to break his persona.
Arix then gave Azura and her friend a gentle, fake smile, feeling quite pleased with herself as she walked towards the dormitory area.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: New Roommates
chapters.content:
Chapter 34: New Roommates
There are a total of 11 buildings in the dormitory area of the training base, including one for the instructors.
Each of the five military academies has exactly two buildings, with one for male and one for female students.
Arix followed the signs to the girls’ dorm. After scanning her surroundings, she stepped into the dorm building. Using the number on her bracelet, she found the room next to the door marked with her number.
The room was small, and the only furniture was three metal bunk beds and a large cabinet with six doors. It was so simple that even Arix was a bit shocked.
Arix stared at the dorm room, almost overwhelmed. She had not expected that in the interstellar era, military dormitories would still be as rundown as before.
She had imagined that the training dorms of the interstellar era would be high-tech individual rooms for everyone, each with a completely private sleeping pod. But the current setup seemed reasonable, after all, this was military training, not a holiday trip.
She had a guess that this place was a relic from a previous era, now just used as a temporary training site.
By the time she arrived, there were already four girls in the dorm. They were all grudgingly wiping their metal bunk beds, so engrossed in their task that they nearly didn’t notice Arix come in.
Arix walked to her assigned bunk bed, which was the lower one near the window. Because the window was open, there was more dust on her bed than elsewhere.
"Hello, I’m Maya Byrne. You haven’t picked up your supplies yet, right? You need to go to the bedmaker to get them, otherwise you can’t clean," Maya said kindly, smiling at Arix.
Arix turned to the owner of the voice. This girl had a gentle and delicate appearance, though her clothes were washed to the point of fading white. Her life might be tough. However, her difficult circumstances seemed not to affect her at all; she still maintained kindness towards everyone.
Arix liked this girl. She smiled back and said, "Yeah, thank you. I’ll go get the supplies now."
"No problem, I haven’t finished getting mine either, I’ll come with you," Maya replied to Arix and then turned to the other three roommates and asked, "Rei, do you guys need anything else? I can bring it up."
"No, we got everything," Rei shook her head, and the other two also indicated they had nothing left to get.
"Okay, got it," Maya said. She led Arix to the end of the corridor on the first floor, where they started to line up outside a room.
Arix didn’t ask further and quietly lined up behind Maya. She watched as new students entered the room; a few came out with blankets, but most left empty-handed.
After puzzling for a moment, Arix looked carefully and finally understood why some students were leaving the room empty-handed, while others carried bedding and such.
Those entering without a Space Button in hand left with one, whereas those carrying training supplies apparently couldn’t afford to buy a Space Button.
A square Space Button costs 100,000 astrocredits. Most of the new students at the Hecaris Military Academy came from Planet Waste. For them, 100,000 astrocredits was like asking an ordinary person to buy a sports car—not something everyone could afford.
As the line slowly shortened, it was soon Arix and Maya’s turn. Maya reported her name and number to the bedmaker and requested two sets of training uniforms before stepping outside to wait for Arix.
"Name and number?" the bedmaker asked in a procedural manner.
"Arix, number 69," Arix replied. She stood quietly, waiting for the bedmaker to verify her information on the opticomputer.
The bedmaker quickly confirmed her details and took out a Space Button from a box nearby and handed it to Arix.
"Whatever you store in the Space Button will only be returned after training," the bedmaker said with a serious, expressionless face.
"Okay, thank you," Arix replied, putting the Space Button on her finger before leaving the room. She and Maya then returned to their dormitory.
Upon returning, Arix saw that another person had joined them—looks like the last roommate had also arrived. But seeing who it was, Arix couldn’t help but be amused.
"Is it really you?!" Calista was even more surprised than Arix, her doe-like eyes wide open.
"Ah, I didn’t expect it to be you either. Seems like we’re meant to be," Arix couldn’t help laughing, finding it funny to end up in the same dorm as Drexel’s little fan.
Although surprised, Calista shyly nodded her head in a polite greeting.
Maya, with her big sister vibe, smiled warmly, "Now that everyone’s here, let’s introduce ourselves. I’ll start. My name is Maya, from the Department of Combat, Planet Zythera. My psychic power is at Planet Class, and my physical strength is at Subgiant Class. Nice to meet you all."
Everyone had a good impression of Maya and exchanged pleasantries.
"My name is Rei Ishihara, from the Department of Combat. I come from the same planet as Maya. My psychic power is at Planet Class and my physical power at Subgiant Class. Please take care of me," Rei was bright and cheerful, resembling a superhero from a comic book.
"My name is Leyla Öztürk, from the Psychic Ware department. My psychic power is at Subgiant Class, and my physical strength at Star Class. I’m delighted to meet you all," Leyla said with a gentle smile, carrying an ethereal aura.
Leyla was arguably the most beautiful among them, with an elegant demeanor.
"I’m Lilou Chevalier, from the Department of Combat. My psychic power is at Star Class, and my physical condition is also at Subgiant Class. Pleased to meet you all," Lilou said. She was wearing glasses and appearing somewhat aloof, giving off a loner genius vibe.
"I’m Calista, from the Department of Chemistry. My psychic power is currently at Star-Class, and my physical strength is also at Star Class. I’m very happy to meet all of you," Calista said, sneakily glancing at Arix but quickly looking away.
Arix noticed Calista’s fleeting look and couldn’t help but smile. She found this girl named Calista genuinely adorable. She seemed like an innocent deer in the forest, terrified yet unable to resist peeking out to observe others.
Arix chuckled at her own thoughts and began her introduction, "My name is Arix Kering, and I’m a student in the Department of Manufacture. My psychic power is at Supergiant Class, and my physical power is at Planet Class. Nice to meet you all."
After finishing her introduction, Arix winked at Calista, causing her to shyly lower her head in embarrassment.

chapters.title: Chapter 35: Hard-working Girls
chapters.content:
Chapter 35: Hard-working Girls
Calista’s cheeks turned bright red under Arix’s gaze. She flicked her eyes nervously for a moment before it suddenly dawned on her.
"Wait, aren’t you a Thalis?" Calista asked with wide eyes.
"Arix, don’t tell me you married into the Kering family and even changed your last name..." Rei thought she had uncovered a shocking secret, so she excitedly sat next to Arix and chatted eagerly, pulling her arm.
"So, the leading lady from the Interstellarnet Headlines these past few days is our roommate," Leyla said, looking at Arix with a rare hint of surprise on her graceful face.
The girls’ stares made Arix unusually flustered, and she turned red as she began to explain, "Okay, stop teasing me. You are my roommates, so I won’t hide it anymore. Drexel is actually my..."
"Boyfriend!" Rei interrupted excitedly.
"Fiancé." Leyla joined in the fun.
Calista didn’t say anything, but her sparkling eyes were filled with curiosity.
Seeing such an innocent Calista, Arix finally felt a pang of conscience.
No longer keeping them in suspense, Arix blinked innocently and revealed, "Drexel is my older brother, the kind with blood ties. So, now you understand."
Arix’s words plunged the dorm into silence.
Even the cute and well-behaved Calista looked at Arix with a serious doubtful expression.
Maya chuckled, breaking the silence. "So, the two of you fell in love only to find out you were long-lost siblings? Come on, I thought we’re way above that cliché romance."
"I’ll never trust love stories on the Interstellarnet again," Leyla said with hollow eyes. Then, as if she had seen through all worldly desires, she picked up a cloth and began to wipe her bed racks.
"You’re certainly a naughty girl," Rei said with admiration, blinking.
She then thought of the people on the Interstellarnet who were constantly arguing that Arix didn’t deserve Drexel. She really wanted to see their faces when they learned the truth.
Rei silently sympathized with them before picking up a basin and heading to the dormitory’s washbasin. Her stride seemed to carry the taste of seeing through life’s vicissitudes.
"You should have cleared up the rumors earlier. After all, Drexel has quite a few crazy fans who might hurt you out of jealousy," Lilou advised, pushing up her glasses.
Arix nodded. She had been indifferent about it, but Lilou’s words made her start to worry.
The rumors online would naturally be dealt with by Arix’s family. But the rumors within the military academy, since everyone was without their opticomputers at the moment, would have to wait until Arix could clear them up in person.
Thinking this, Arix relaxed and started to join in cleaning the dorm with everyone. By the time the dorm looked brand new, it was already time for lunch.
Arix and her new roommates took a quick shower and headed to the cafeteria together. It wasn’t far from the dorm, and they arrived after a short walk.
The cafeteria was decorated simply and cleanly, with students orderly picking up their meals from the serving area. They then carried their trays to the dining area to eat and chat.
Arix too picked up a tray and chose some of her favorite dishes from the wide variety available. She then walked over to the dining area.
"Arix, hi!" Varden was also in the dining area, eating with some classmates. He greeted Arix as he saw her.
Arix smiled and greeted Varden back. Then, she and her roommates found a quiet spot to start their meal.
"Arix, who was that handsome guy greeting you? And you two seemed really close," Rei said teasingly.
Arix rolled her eyes at Rei and said dryly, "He’s my cousin, the kind with blood ties."
"Another one ’with blood ties’? Are all handsome guys in the world tied with you by blood?" Rei was stunned.
"Why, you think my cousin is handsome? Want me to introduce you?" Arix joked, raising an eyebrow.
"Ah! No need," Rei blushed and coughed awkwardly.
Arix laughed at the silly situation.
Midway through the meal, Rei suddenly remembered what the instructor had said. She looked up at her roommates and asked, "So, who’s going to be our dorm leader?"
"I can’t, I have much training to do and have no time for that," Lilou was the first to decline.
"I can’t either, I need to preview the Psychic Ware textbooks for freshmen," Leyla declined second.
"I need to preview the potion textbooks for freshmen too," Calista said apologetically.
"I need to preview the mecha manufacturing textbooks for freshmen as well. But Rei, I think you’d be great for it, why don’t you be our dorm leader?" Arix said with a mischievous grin.
"Arix! If I become the dorm leader, you’ll be the first one I’ll hassle," Rei pretended to be angry and glared at Arix. Then she turned to Maya with a very gentle smile.
"Maya, it looks like the role of dorm leader is meant for you, don’t refuse, it’s decided then," Rei smiled sweetly, leaving no room for Maya to object.
Arix and the others also felt Maya was very suitable, and so they all nodded in agreement without saying a word.
Maya, the person in question, could only smile helplessly and touch her forehead.
Thus, the decision for Maya to become the dorm leader was sneakily settled right there.
In another building of the training field, in the instructor’s office...
Virtanen was sitting at his desk, flipping through the dormitory information sheets. When he reached Arix’s page, he took a closer look, double-checking to make sure he was seeing things correctly.
Virtanen then looked up at Ortiz with a bit of uncertainty, "Ortiz, did you change Arix’s roommates?"
"Yes, I changed them. I arranged for the girls with the best physical conditioning from Hecaris Military Academy to be Arix’s roommates," Ortiz didn’t hide anything.
"Hmm? Any particular reason for that?" Virtanen asked, curious.
Ortiz revealed a meaningful smile and said, "Competition is a good thing. Now that she’s surrounded by the best, I believe even if Arix were as weak as a tiny hamster, she would still enhance her physical condition through competition."
"That’s a great idea, typical of Ortiz." Virtanen’s eyes lit up, seeing the potential in the plan, and he gave Ortiz an admiring thumbs up.
Bauer, puffing on a cigarette, didn’t say anything, but those who knew him understood that his silence was an approval of the strategy.

chapters.title: Chapter 36: Training Starts
chapters.content:
Chapter 36: Training Starts
The next morning in the dormitory, Maya woke Arix first, then continued to rouse the next person.
The girls, sleepy and yawning non-stop, gradually got up and changed into their training gear. Then they headed to the sinks to start freshening up.
After breakfast in the cafeteria, Arix and her group walked to the training ground. By this time, the square was already filled with many early students.
The students from the five military academies naturally clustered together. Centered around their own academies, they intuitively formed five groups, each keeping to themselves.
Where there are people, there is isolation and scheming.
There was also a hierarchy of disdain among the military academies. For instance, students from the Ceres Military Academy looked down on those from the Mulado Military Academy for being pretentiously aloof; whereas the Mulado students were envious of the Ceres Academy’s abundant resources.
Similarly, the wealthy students of the Snorri Military Academy scorned the poorer students from the Hecaris Military Academy. However, the Hecaris students had no respect for those from The Snorri Academy who solved problems merely with money.
The students from The Koros Military Academy were generally ignored by the other four academies, as they were known to be battle-crazed and best left unprovoked.
While waiting for the instructor, even Arix received several scornful looks from the wealthy Snorri students.
Looking at this group with their noses in the air, Arix’s fingers twitched slightly. It took all her willpower to resist the urge to stick her fingers up their nostrils.
Fortunately, at that moment, the instructors for the five military academies arrived, and Arix nearly broke her demure demeanor. She breathed a sigh of relief.
The three instructors responsible for the Hecaris Military Academy arrived as well.
Ortiz blew his whistle hanging around his neck first. The piercing sound drew all students’ attention towards him.
"All students, follow my command. Each dorm forms a line, with the dorm leader at the front. The first row should form three teams, with 18 people in each line. The last fifty-five teams, align with those in front. Execute immediately!" Ortiz commanded loudly and sternly.
"Yes, Sir!" responded the students from The Hecaris Military Academy, and in a short while, they were neatly arranged in three vertical rows.
"Good, today is the first day of training. This morning, we’ll start with something simple, like a 20-kilometer weighted cross-country," Ortiz said, then turned to Virtanen and Bauer. "The weight rings can be distributed now."
"Okay," Virtanen and Bauer nodded. They locked heavy weight rings around the limbs of every student present.
Arix’s limbs were fitted weight rings, each weighing roughly 50 kg. She felt that, perhaps, the weights carried by each person seemed to vary.
After all students from the Hecaris Military Academy had their weight rings on, Virtanen and Bauer reported back to Ortiz.
Ortiz, seeing students murmuring doubts, spoke sternly and seriously, "The weight rings are custom-made according to each of your physiques. So, stop wondering why others’ weights differ from yours."
His words brought a moment of realization to the students, and they all quieted down.
After pulling a fast one on the students, Ortiz whispered to Virtanen, "You set Arix’s weight rings to Star-Class, right?"
Virtanen didn’t respond verbally but gave Ortiz an ’ok’ gesture.
Satisfied, Ortiz smiled and joined the other two instructors in the back of an off-road vehicle. He shouted to the students, "Now, all of you, follow me."
"Yes, sir!" the students from the Hecaris Military Academy shouted energetically. They then started running behind the off-road vehicle.
Students from the other four military academies watched as The Hecaris Military Academy’s students followed the off-road vehicle out of the training base. Then, they too began their own training exercises with their respective instructors.
Outside the base, The Hecaris Military Academy’s students had already run 5 kilometers following the off-road vehicle.
A small group managed to keep up at first. As time passed, however, their legs grew increasingly sore and weak, and breathing became more difficult. Still, they clenched their teeth and struggled to keep up with the vehicle.
Arix was among them. Her physical condition was below average among other students, and the instructors had given her "special attention" with the weight rings—a situation that made it nearly impossible for her to keep up with most. She gradually found herself falling behind the group.
"Ortiz, it looks like Arix is falling behind," Virtanen said worriedly, looking back.
"Just this little distance and she’s struggling? She’s supposed to have Planet-Class physical power, after all," Ortiz frowned, clearly disappointed.
Virtanen explained, "I heard she was only Moon-Class a month ago. It seems she only reached Planet Class through a Planet-Class Booster." He regretted setting Arix’s weight rings to Star-Class.
Hearing this, Ortiz’s frown deepened. He dropped a "I’ll check on her" and started running towards the back of the group.
Some of the students had been slacking off, but seeing the instructor coming towards them, they suddenly found their legs no longer hurt and sped up.
Ortiz squinted slightly, silently memorizing the faces of these students. He decided to increase the weight of their rings next time.
However, his current concern was Arix. Ortiz suspected she was slacking, but she genuinely looked like she was running for her life.
With this thought, Ortiz, feeling unusually guilty, touched his nose. Then, with a determined look, he made his way to the back of the group and started shouting, "Speed up! If we encounter an insectoid, even chickens would outrun you!"
"Running this slow, you might as well go home and farm! At least you won’t starve to death then!"
"Come on! Say it loud: "Lose skin, lose flesh, never fall out! Bleed, sweat, but never shout!"" Ortiz roared.
"Come on! Say it loud: "Lose skin, lose flesh, never fall out! Bleed, sweat, but never shout!" The students at the back, nearly crying, chanted the slogan.
"Such a quiet voice, didn’t you eat? Use all your strength!" Ortiz yelled.
"Come on! Say it loud: "Lose skin, lose flesh, never fall out! Bleed, sweat, but never shout!"
This time, the chant was deafening. Not just the students at the back, but even those at the front joined in, as if to motivate their fellow classmates.
Arix was also shouting. She clenched her lips tightly, pushing herself to her limits to keep up with the main group, determined not to fall behind.
Ortiz, observing Arix’s twisted but determined face, didn’t find it ugly at all. Instead, he felt a genuine sense of relief and approval from deep within.

chapters.title: Chapter 37: Drexel’s Anger
chapters.content:
Chapter 37: Drexel’s Anger
13miles...
17 miles...
...
Arix didn’t know how long she had been running, but now she felt totally exhausted. Even the air she breathed felt like it had blades, painfully scraping her throat.
Her mind was slowly going blank. Then suddenly, Arix stumbled, losing her balance. Just before she passed out, she thought she heard Drexel’s voice, filled with panic.
"Arix!"
Drexel was close by. He had initially come back to laugh at his sister but instead saw Arix collapsing. His heart seemed to stop for several seconds.
Drexel ran to her in panic. He caught Arix as she passed out and pulled her close to his chest. Then he frantically started checking on her.
"Let me handle this, Drexel. I’m a student of the Department of Chemistry, and I’ve learned some medical stuff," Calista said as she pushed through the crowd of students. She got to Arix’s side and immediately started examining her.
First, she checked Arix’s eyes, then felt her carotid artery. After a moment, she breathed a slight sigh of relief, "Her heart is just beating fast; she’s not in any life-threatening danger."
After saying that, Calista began to check Arix’s limbs. However, as she lifted her hand, her expression suddenly froze. Her eyes widened in disbelief.
"This is outrageous!"
Calista stared intently at the weight ring on Arix’s wrist, her lower lip bitten tightly, her eyes slightly reddened with anger.
"Why are you crying? Didn’t you say my sister is not in serious danger? Do we need to find a handsome guy to give her mouth-to-mouth resuscitation?" Drexel, relieved that Arix wasn’t in mortal peril, still had the mood to joke.
Calista, face cold, didn’t respond. She grabbed Drexel’s hand, placing the hand wearing the weight ring in his, and then swapped it with her own weighted hand.
Drexel was initially confused by Calista’s actions. However, when Calista’s hand also rested in his, he suddenly realized something. His voice hoarse, he asked, "What’s your physical power level?"
"I’m Star-Class," Calista replied. Her eyes blazed with anger, her tone chilly.
According to the rules, Star-Class weight rings are 100 kilograms, and Planet Class rings are 60 kilograms. Calista knew that only three instructors could tamper with such things.
Drexel had thought of it too; if it weren’t for the reality right in front of him, he would never have imagined that his precious sister was being sabotaged right under his nose.
"The instructors are here." A student suddenly shouted.
Then the three instructors walked through the crowd and also saw Arix, unconscious.
Ortiz stepped forward, intending to take Arix to the medical room. But as soon as he reached out, an extremely angry Drexel forcefully slapped his hand away.
Before Ortiz could react, he saw a girl blocking Drexel.
Calista firmly grabbed Drexel’s arm, which was bulging with veins. She motioned for him to look at a tree branch nearby.
There was a all-direction surveillance camera recording everything without any blind spots.
Drexel’s expression darkened, and he regained some sense of calm. He said to the instructors with a forced smile, "You don’t have to do this. She’s my sister. I’ll handle it."
With that, Drexel no longer paid any attention to the three instructors and carefully picked up the unconscious Arix. He then headed towards the medical facility at the training base.
Calista also ignored the instructors and hurried to follow Drexel, helping support the unconscious Arix.
Ortiz, left with nothing to do, stood awkwardly and touched his nose. He then shouted to the students still discussing Arix’s collapse, "Training’s over, head back now. Anyone who doesn’t go back gets extra training."
With these words, the students scattered almost instantly, leaving the area deserted.
"Ortiz, you might want to be careful from now on. That young man’s furious gaze was hardly concealed," Virtanen cautiously said.
"What?" Ortiz was displeased upon hearing this and immediately retorted, "Why me alone? Aren’t you two also instructors?"
"You’re the head. Even if you’re not guilty, if a student has a health issue, it’s on you," Bauer pointedly said.
Ortiz was speechless.
...
At the instructors’ dorm at noon, just as Ortiz entered his room to rest, he heard the door lock behind him. He sighed resignedly, then turned to see Drexel and said, "Was it so urgent that you couldn’t even wait until evening?"
"You knew I would come, so it was indeed you bullying my sister," Drexel stated firmly. His eyes narrowed dangerously, his eyebrows raised thoughtfully.
"What do you mean ’bully’? I was actually doing this for Arix’s own good," Ortiz replied with a bitter smile.
Drexel laughed coldly, his gaze even icier as he retorted, "Maybe you should visit the medical room too. After all, I’m also doing this for your own good!"
Drexel emphasized his last words. Just as he was about to attack, his arms were seized by the two instructors who had appeared behind him.
"Good thing we arrived in time. Seems my lock-picking skills haven’t a bit rusted yet," Virtanen said somewhat shyly.
Drexel turned his head and noticed that the door he had just closed was now open. He chuckled without any hint of panic, "One or three, it doesn’t matter. Come at me all together."
"I admire your vigorous state and protective spirit, kid. Seeing you makes me realize that I’m really getting old," Bauer remarked, puffing on a cigarette.
Virtanen, seeing his teammates were unreliable, stepped forward to mediate and explain, "You’ve misunderstood. We aren’t trying to make things difficult for her. It’s actually because President Gunder specifically ordered us to elevate Arix’s physique to Star-Class by the end of the training. That’s why we were paying extra attention to her training."
Although Drexel was still angry, his mind had begun to cool down.
Bauer, seeing this, released his hold on Drexel and walked alone to the windowsill, puffing on his cigarette.
"You should know Arix’s situation best. If her physique doesn’t improve, she’ll face even more harm due to her psychic powers in the future. So, do you still think I’m trying to sabotage her?" Ortiz took a cigarette from Bauer, lit it, and spoke in a calm voice.
Arix’s overwhelmingly strong psychic power was like a double-edged sword. While it protected her, it also constantly threatened her life.
Drexel finally calmed down completely. He suddenly realized that the concerns the instructors had for Arix might not be less than his own.
It seemed he had been mistaken this time.
With this thought, Drexel bowed deeply to the three instructors as an apology. With a heavy heart, he turned and left the instructors’ dorm.
Ortiz’s face wore a look of enduring grievance throughout the ordeal, but he remained silent and watched as Drexel departed.
However, the moment he reached to close the door, the look of grievance on Ortiz’s face disappeared instantly, and he expressed a sense of relief, "Thank heavens. But why is he and his sister so different? Why does his physical strength completely cloud his mental power?"

chapters.title: Chapter 38: She Wants It Both
chapters.content:
Chapter 38: She Wants It Both
Bauer was leaning against the window, comfortably smoking a cigarette.
From the corner of his eye, he caught sight of Ortiz looking scared and started to mock him, "Come on, you’re a lieutenant of the Fifth Legion. How can you be afraid of a military academy freshman? If this gets out to the legion, you’ll be the laughing stock."
Ortiz didn’t care about Bauer’s mocking and retorted lazily, "If we keep this between us, no one will know."
"Coward," Bauer rolled his eyes in disgust.
"Coward or not... That depends on who it is. We all know that there’s a high chance Drexel will be the admiral of the Fifth Legion in the future. Try being brave against him..." Ortiz replied unwillingly. Then he thought of something else and added with relief, "Luckily, he’s young now and easier to fool, or else we couldn’t have settled today’s matter so easily."
"Could it be that there really was a problem with the weight ring today?" Bauer frowned seriously.
"Logically, we were correct, but Arix just can’t be dealt with by usual standards," Ortiz said with a gloomy face. He forwarded the information he had just received on his optic computer to Virtanen and Bauer, then continued, "This is from the medical room, just sent over. Arix’s health report. Take a look."
After both had carefully read the information, Bauer, speechless, rubbed his forehead and said, "It looks like President Gunder has set a trap for us, and we just walked right into it."
Virtanen’s face looked bitter as he complained, " A body neglected for over a decade, nourished well for just one month, and then trained for another month to rise to Star-Class? If there were such a good deal in the world, let me be the first to know."
"Stop dreaming. It’s not even dark yet, and you’re already dreaming so sweetly," Ortiz shot Virtanen a glance.
Bauer, somewhat skeptical, frowned and said, "But Ortiz, are you sure there’s no mistake with this medical report? She’s been malnourished for over ten years? If we consider interstellar law, that’s enough to charge the Kering family with child abuse."
Ortiz sighed, "One hundred percent correct. I asked Marlone, and he said his niece Arix has been drifting on Planet Waste all these years. It was only a month ago that she was found and brought back to the Kering family. Otherwise, her physique wouldn’t just be at Planet Class. But given the living conditions on Planet Waste... her merely being malnourished is actually the best outcome."
"What about her psychic power? If she really was just at Planet Class, even Moon-Class physically, she should have died a long time ago. She couldn’t have survived until now," Bauer asked curiously.
"Oh, I heard that a month ago she only had Moon-Class psychic power. Then, someone made her drink poison. They intended to destroy Arix, but it ended up fully awakening her Supergiant-Class psychic power instead," Ortiz explained. He found the story increasingly melodramatic, as it resembled the plots of s he read on the interstellarnet.
The main character doesn’t die on Planet Waste, doesn’t die from poisoning, meets a noble benefactor, enrolls in the military academy, finds her biological parents—it was like a checklist for a protagonist.
"Ortiz, did you think of something?" Virtanen noticed Ortiz was silent for a while and asked in confusion.
"I’m thinking that maybe we underestimated Arix," Ortiz muttered.
"We definitely underestimated how fragile Arix is. High-intensity training seems unsuitable for her now. For now, let’s stick to the normal training regimen for someone with Planet-Class physique, and we’ll see about the rest later," Bauer decided firmly.
Ortiz wanted to say more; he actually thought Arix seemed very much like a protagonist. So, he felt even if they pushed her to the limits in training, she’d likely be fine. After all, most protagonists are like weeds, always bouncing back.
But in the end, he wisely kept these thoughts to himself. After all, a novel is just a novel, not to be confused with reality.
The medical room was bustling now.
This time, many students had gotten injured during the weighted cross-country run. However, most of them had minor injuries like sprained ligaments or twisted ankles, which were quickly healed with a scan from the treatment device.
Those with slightly more severe injuries, like Arix, just needed to spend half an hour in the healing pod before being transferred to a regular bed. Students who had just woken up and didn’t want to stay in the hospital could even go back to their dorms directly.
Drexel, who was looking after Arix in the hospital, politely saw off five girls who had come to visit Arix. Then he sat back down beside the hospital bed, continuing to peel the fruit in hand.
Arix was on the hospital bed, and now her fingers twitched for a bit. She slowly opened her eyes and turned her head to see Drexel, who was focused on peeling the fruit.
"Drexel..." Arix called out in a hoarse voice.
Drexel looked up with a bit of surprise, "You’re awake! Do you feel uncomfortable anywhere?"
"Water," Arix’s voice was hoarse and weak.
"Oh, right, right, just a second." Drexel hurriedly got up, put down the fruit, and clumsily poured a glass of water. Ta carefully handed it over.
Arix sat up, leaning her upper body against the headboard, and took the water from Drexel. She drank the whole glass and finally felt her throat ease.
"Thanks, I’m fine now," Arix said with a gentle smile towards Drexel.
Drexel took back the empty cup and hesitated for a moment before carefully asking, "Do you know everything that’s been going on?"
"What do you mean? About my psychic power or the tampered weighted ring?" Arix said nonchalantly.
Arix was well aware of her own condition. A mismatch between her physique and psychic power? She thought she just needed more training. That was also why she didn’t speak up, even though she knew something was off with the weighted ring.
Drexel was a bit flustered; he was a bit surprised that Arix knew everything.
"So, what are you thinking now? How about we skip the hardship? After the training ends, let Mom and Dad get you some supplements to improve your physique," Drexel said, worried about Arix’s condition but reluctant to see his sister suffer through the training.
Arix looked at Drexel, who was obviously distressed, and smiled. She reached out and grasped Drexel’s wrist, comforting him with a laugh, "Alright, stop worrying. You’re frowning too much and the wrinkles are starting to grow."
"How can I not worry? You’re my only sister," Drexel said this, but his heart felt a bit more at ease. He then asked, "So, what do you plan to do next?"
"I guess I’ll just follow the instructors’ training plans. Then, I’ll take those supplements you mentioned," Arix said casually.
Drexel rolled his eyes and muttered, "Here I am worrying about which option you should take, and it turns out you want to take them both?"

chapters.title: Chapter 39: Sweet Roommates
chapters.content:
Chapter 39: Sweet Roommates
Arix had rested for a while in the hospital room. When she felt her strength had mostly returned, she and Drexel left the medical room together.
Not long after they left the medical room, Arix noticed quite a few freshmen from various military academies, secretly watching her and Drexel, some openly, some covertly.
"Ah, look, it’s Arix and Drexel."
"Wow! It looks like what they said on the interstellarnet is true. They must be seeing each other now."
"I’m 100% sure it is true. I heard this morning during the training, Arix just fainted, and Drexel was super nervous and rushed her straight to the medical room. He was so anxious that even the doctor got scared, thinking that the one he was holding must be dead."
"Haha, what a scene. Too bad we were also on training at that time, or I would have definitely come to watch."
Having listen to all the gossip about herself, Arix felt utterly disheveled.
She now regretted why she hadn’t debunked the rumors earlier. Now she felt so embarrassed.
"Maybe I should just go back alone." Arix looked at her rumored "boyfriend," almost unable to face herself.
"I’ll walk you to the dorm building then leave," Drexel said, looking at her like he was dealing with an unreasonable child, his face full of indulgence.
Drexel now was like a mama bear protecting her cub. He couldn’t leave without making sure his cub was safe.
Arix bit her lip, hesitating. In the end, she could only frown and let Drexel walk her to the dorm building.
After saying goodbye, Arix, as if scared of something, dashed back to her dorm.
Drexel stayed where he was, watching Arix’s retreating figure with a satisfied smile, "It seems Arix has indeed recovered."
Arix returned to her dorm to find that none of her roommates were there.
She looked up at the clock on the wall, only to realize it was already 3 PM. By this time, the afternoon training had probably started for an hour.
Arix wasn’t worried. Drexel had told her earlier that he had already requested a half-day sick leave for her. She could indeed take it easy this afternoon.
Thinking this, Arix walked towards her bed in a good mood. She saw a bunch of snacks placed next to her pillow.
She knew it was definitely her lovely roommates’ doing.
Arix’s lips curved. She sat on her bed feeling warm inside, took out a potion book from her Space Button, and started to enjoy reading while munching on snacks.
Time flew by quickly, and as the red sunset began to reflect in the dorm window, Arix’s roommates finally came back.
"Arix, you’re back," Calista greeted her weakly. She was not in a good state, but she perked up a bit seeing Arix.
"Why do you all look like this?" Arix exclaimed in surprise. She stared in astonishment at her roommates, who looked as if they had been up for several nights.
As soon as Rei entered the dorm, she collapsed onto her bed and groaned, "Don’t even ask—it was psychic power training this afternoon. We spent practically the whole time either falling on our faces or on our way down."
"Why do we need to wear weighted rings during psychic power training? I’m starting to get a bad feeling about this. Are we going to wear these rings in all future training sessions?" Leyla lamented, sitting on her bed as if drained of all her energy.
"The likelihood is above 90%, I figured," Lilou added solemnly.
Arix, the first victim of the weighted rings, gasped at Lilou’s comment and soon joined her roommates in their despondency.
"Fine, there’s no way that we can stop it. Let’s shower first, then we’ll lie down and rest," Maya suggested, breaking the increasingly heavy mood. She took her toiletries from her locker and headed to the communal bathroom in the dorm hallway.
The girls groaned in resignation and followed her with their towels.
When they returned, they were clean and refreshed, yet all collapsed on their beds, unwilling to move.
Before long, Arix noticed the dorm had fallen completely silent. She looked up to see her roommates had all fallen asleep.
Shaking her head with a smile, Arix got up, turned off the lights, and let the girls sleep soundly.
The next morning, the wake-up whistle sounded from downstairs.
Arix and her roommates quickly washed up and dressed. After breakfast in the cafeteria, they arrived at the training field at 8 AM.
Today’s training was weighted cross-country running. To Arix’s surprise, the weight of her rings had been increased to 60kg.
She looked puzzled at Virtanen, who was distributing the rings, and asked, "Are you sure you didn’t make a mistake with mine?"
"No mistake, this is the correct ring for your Planet Class physique!" Virtanen confirmed hastily, his eyes darting away nervously.
Then, like a chick evading a hawk, he quickly finished distributing the rings to Arix’s row and hurried away, looking guilty.
Arix, filled with questions about the instructor’s behavior, said nothing and faithfully followed the team, starting to run.
Initially, Maya and the others were worried about Arix, so they slowed down to run alongside her. Seeing no issues, they eventually picked up the pace and ran ahead.
Ortiz and his two colleagues kept a discreet watch on Arix. Seeing that she was managing well, they breathed a sigh of relief almost simultaneously.
"It seems that gradual progression is the right approach," Ortiz remarked with relief.
"Yeah, let’s keep it this way for the time being," Bauer agreed.
"But what about the afternoon’s psychic power training? Could there be any issues there?" Virtanen suddenly chimed in, his question hanging awkwardly in the air.
The air in the vehicle turned silent, clearly indicating Virtanen had brought up an inappropriate topic.
Feeling the intense stares of the other two, Virtanen shrank into a corner of the vehicle, his demeanor as guilty and pitiful as a dog who had chewed the wrong tube.
"Ortiz, my fists are getting itchy, and you’re going to be blind for the next ten minutes, right?" Bauer said, his voice light but his eyes locked intensely on Virtanen in the corner.
"Oh, what a coincidence, I was thinking the same," Ortiz added with a menacing grin as he approached Virtanen.
"Wow!! Don’t come over here!" Virtanen’s pleas and screams filled the vehicle but were soon drowned out by the others’ laughter.

chapters.title: Chapter 40: Psychic Power Training Center
chapters.content:
Chapter 40: Psychic Power Training Center
The morning training session ended perfectly. After the instructors dismissed everyone, the new students either headed to the cafeteria or went back to their dorms.
Arix declined to join Maya for lunch. She went back to her dorm alone and quickly took a shower.
Then, she took a tube of nutrition fluid from her Space Button. She dealt with lunch quickly, then collapsed on her bed, too exhausted to move.
The fatigue, both physical and mental, quickly sent Arix into a deep sleep.
When Maya woke her up, Arix saw her roommates looking fresh and chatty, gossiping animatedly.
At that moment, Arix felt a pang of jealousy.
All of them were new students, yet her roommates seemed to have much more physical stamina than her. They were able to chat so relaxedly after the intense morning session, which felt like a blatant show-off.
"Arix, wake up. It’s almost 2 PM. We need to start the afternoon session of psychic power training," Maya reminded her.
From the moment Maya became the dorm leader, she was destined to worry about everyone in the dorm, especially Arix. After all, Arix was the only one who had been sent to the medical room so far.
The incident of Arix entering the medical room had spread among the students at various military schools. Her roommates tactfully didn’t mention it, fearing it might hurt Arix’s feelings.
But the other students had no such reservations. They seemed to discuss it almost all the time—while eating, sleeping, and even in the restroom.
For instance, at cafeteria tables...
"Hey, did you hear? Arix from the Hecaris Military Academy fainted yesterday. She fell so badly that she bled from her arm."
Or on dorm beds...
"Arix knocked herself out during training yesterday, and even split her head open. Thankfully you weren’t there; the blood everywhere was terrifying."
And in restroom stalls...
"I heard Arix spun around three full circles before hitting the ground when she fell. It looked so dramatic, even Drexel Kering was stunned for seconds before he ran to take her to the doctor."
Arix had no idea that her simple fainting due to physical exhaustion had been turned into numerous exaggerated stories, making her quite famous across the military academies.
Now, as Arix shakily got up and rubbed her sore, numb knees, she and her roommates headed to the training ground. She felt many new students secretly sizing her up along the way.
Arix thought it was still because of the rumors about her and Drexel. She tried to maintain a poker face, but deep down, she was really panicking.
She noticed that more and more people were paying attention to her. Just yesterday, only a few gossip lovers were interested, but today, even students from other military academies were joining in on the buzz.
Thankfully, as soon as the instructors arrived, everyone quickly averted their gaze, otherwise Arix would have been so embarrassed that she might have dug a hole right through the training field with her cringe.
As soon as the Hecaris Military Academy students saw the instructor, they quickly lined up in the formation they had learned the day before yesterday.
They stood erect, with chests puffed out and an air of confidence, nothing like their previous chatty selves.
Ortiz surveyed all the students of the Hecaris Military Academy and began, "This afternoon we’ll continue with psychic power training. I want to emphasize something just before that. Yesterday, some students brought Psychic Wares into the training room. Do you think such hidden cheating is beneficial for your future?"
"No!" the students shouted in unison.
The instructor’s and classmates’ thunderous words made the few students who had Psychic Wares on them blush. They silently removed their Psychic Wares and quietly stashed them into their Space Buttons.
Ortiz noticed these actions and finally allowed a slight smile to appear, "Good, now everyone follow me to the psychic power training field."
The psychic power training field was located at the very back of the training base. Compared to the other more basic fields, this one finally had a bit of a star-age style.
Before entering the training field, the students had to line up and pass through a security gate.
Next to the gate stood a soldier from the Fifth Legion, who used an opticomputer in conjunction with the gate to check the students.
Each time a student paused in front of the security gate, a ray beam would scan them from head to toe to ensure they carried no dangerous items.
When a student was cleared, a mechanical voice from the soldier’s opticomputer would announce, "Inspection passed. No dangerous items carried. Clearance granted."
"I wonder which psychic power training center we’ll go to today. The pain from yesterday’s Gravity Training Center is still haunting me," Rei moaned as he queued up.
"As long as it’s not the Hypnosis Training Center, I think I can handle anything," Lilou commented. She disliked the feeling of being hypnotized, as if her psychic world was stripped bare, leaving her feeling utterly insecure.
"In that case, the Control Training Room is the best. You just need to use your psychic power to control objects and attack," Leyla sighed.
Unlike her roommates, who had been beaten down in the psychic power training rooms, Arix perked up the moment she saw the psychic power training field, her spirits instantly lifted.
Arix much preferred the high-tech psychic power training grounds to physical training sites.
Her love for high-tech was akin to Cirilla’s excitement when facing someone stronger than herself. No hardships could deter their relentless pursuit of pushing their limits.
Even without seeing the full extent of the psychic power training field yet, Arix was already bubbling with excitement.
"Arix Kering, inspection passed. No dangerous items carried. Clearance granted."
"You may enter now," said the nearby soldier coldly.
"Thank you," Arix responded politely. She smiled with anticipation as she walked toward the psychic power training room.
The psychic power training field was indoors, divided into five separate training centers. Instructor Virtanen was currently standing at the entrance of the Gravity Training Center, logging each student’s entry with his opticomputer.
Seeing that it was the Gravity Training Center, Arix felt a bit sorry for Rei.

chapters.title: Chapter 41: Shocks Everyone
chapters.content:
Chapter 41: Shocks Everyone
There was no line before the Gravity Training Center. Just as Arix was about to walk straight in, Virtanen stopped her with his hand.
Arix looked at Virtanen, puzzled, as she hadn’t seen him stop any other students just before her.
Virtanen felt a bit awkward under Arix’s gaze. He coughed and said casually, "Arix. Remember, safety first, and don’t push yourself too hard."
"Okay," Arix replied obediently. She was a bit confused but sensed no malice from the instructor.
"Go ahead," Virtanen said.
He watched Arix enter the Gravity Training Center, silently cheering her on and whispering to himself, "After all, whether I sleep in the bed or the hallway tonight depends on you."
As soon as Arix entered the training area, it felt like stepping into a huge indoor training ground. The center featured a circular track about 3000 meters long. What was special, though, were the walls on both sides of the track made of a unique material that created light barriers, seemingly isolating the special environment of the track.
The light barriers made the scene on the track a bit blurry, but from the outside,people could still vaguely see.
At that moment, many students were moving forward on the track, their movements slow and difficult, like toddlers.
Every so often, a student would fall flat. They seemed to be struck down by an invisible meteor, crashing face down instantly.
Arix suddenly felt a phantom pain on her face. She swallowed before walking to the starting point of the track and politely greeted Ortiz and Bauer, "Sir, good afternoon."
Ortiz and Bauer, both gentle in demeanor, nodded back to Arix.
Then Ortiz and Bauer looked at each other for a moment. After a silent exchange of glances, Ortiz finally conceded defeat.
The defeated Ortiz covertly rolled his eyes at Bauer and looked at Arix, pretending to be stern. He said, "The main purpose of the Gravity Training Center is to enhance the resistance of your psychic barriers. The gravity will get stronger as you go further. If you feel it’s too much, don’t push yourself. Just remove your bracelet, and the gravity will drop down. Got it?"
"Uh-huh, okay," Arix replied obediently.
She felt that today, the instructors were a bit overly fussy, but she only dared to grumble about it internally, never aloud.
After putting on the weight ring provided by the instructors, Arix stepped onto the track of the training ground.
As soon as she stood on the track, Arix instantly felt a heavy pressure pushing down from above. It was as if the normal gravity had suddenly increased tenfold.
In simple terms, it was like a normal person wearing a 500 kg weight ring, making it extremely difficult to move.
Arix tried to walk. She found it difficult, but not yet to the point where she needed to deploy her psychic shield.
And since the instructors had said the gravity would keep increasing, Arix also wanted to see where her limit was.
As Arix walked into the training area, she initially resisted using her psychic shield, which quickly marked her as overly confident by her peers on the gravity track.
Most of the students secretly mocked her, recalling a previous student who had tried the same approach and had quickly depleted his energy, ultimately receiving a low score from the instructors.
Arix was unaware of the mocking glances from her classmates as she struggled to move her feet alone.
Unknowingly, she moved from the tenfold gravity area to the twentyfold gravity track.
As soon as she stepped in, the increased gravity crushed her unprepared, causing her to fall embarrassingly. She finally understood the hard falls her classmates had experienced.
As the students saw Arix’s fall, they immediately rejoiced in her misfortune.
"I told you she’d fall as soon as she hit the twentyfold gravity track, haha!"
"What a fool, totally overestimating herself!"
"And she’s supposed to be top ten among the freshmen. Turns out, without Drexel, she’d be nothing."
Amidst the laughter, Arix struggled to her feet. She glanced around at those who mocked her, silently adding them to her list for future payback. She would surely shock them with her power when the opportunity arose.
Arix refocused and drew on the psychic power from her inner psychic world.
The energy formed an egg-shaped shield around her, blocking the intense gravity from above.
As soon as the psychic shield was activated, Arix no longer felt the overwhelming pressure.
She looked around at her classmates with a smirk of triumph and then confidently walked away under their watchful eyes.
Though her physical power might have been lacking, her psychic power was unmatched in her class.
The students were stunned. They slowly realized that although Arix might physically seem weak, her psychic abilities were possibly the strongest in the class.
Those who had just mocked her fell silent, the somewhat capable ones quietly slipping away, while the truly weak could only stay put under the gravity, their faces red with embarrassment.
Meanwhile, in the instructor’s office, the trio were becoming impatient.
"Arix has been in there for about ten minutes now, I wonder how she’s doing," Ortiz expressed his concern.
"This kid is pretty stubborn, maybe you should go check on her. Don’t let her end up in the doctor’s again," Bauer, who had seen Arix’s stubborn streak, suggested with a hint of worry.
"Alright, I’ll go check on her. Wait for me here," Ortiz said. He got ready to enter, yet just then, Arix showed up on her own.
Watching Arix, who appeared not at all disheveled, Ortiz thought she hadn’t gone far at all. He frowned slightly in displeasure and asked, "How come you got out so quickly?"
"I finished, so I came out," Arix replied. She looked puzzled at Ortiz, who seemed unhappy.
"Hey, you little liar!" Ortiz simply didn’t believe Arix. No one knew the gravity track better than he did. Even someone with Supergiant-Class psychic power would need an hour to complete the course.
But Arix had only been gone for, at most, about ten minutes.
Since Arix was a girl, Ortiz didn’t think it was appropriate to scold her too fiercely. So he said more gently, "Your brother, Drexel, hasn’t come out yet."
"Oh, I saw him. He even told me to wait for him so we could go to the cafeteria for dinner together," Arix said, blinking.
Ortiz was momentarily at a loss for words. This kid really was stubborn. It seemed he needed to show some proof.
With that thought, Ortiz used his opticomputer to send a message to a colleague in the surveillance room, asking them to send him Arix’s scores from the Gravity Training Center.
The colleague was efficient. Almost three seconds after the message was sent, they sent over Arix’s scores.

chapters.title: Chapter 42: A "Friend"
chapters.content:
Chapter 42: A "Friend"
Ortiz received the message and looked up at Arix again, shooting her a "you’re in big trouble" glare. Then, he opened the report.
Training Report
School:
Hecaristhe Hecaris Military Academy
Grade:
Freshman
Name:
Arix
Training Program:
Gravity
Score:
Supergiant+
Ortiz rubbed his eyes and looked again. He turned the virtual screen towards Bauer, doubting much, and said, "Dude, check this out, I think my eyes are playing tricks. I didn’t know there could be a ’+’ after ’Supergiant’."
Bauer glanced down at the score report. Then, he looked up deeply at Arix before starting to comfort his poor colleague, "Ortiz, it’s real."
Ortiz’s legs trembled. Thankfully, Bauer was there to steady him, preventing any embarrassment in front of his student.
"Sir, if there’s nothing else, I’ll head out now," Arix felt the instructors were acting a bit weird, but whether it was good or bad, she figured it was best to slip away.
"No, there’s something. You’re coming with me to another training center now," Ortiz said with eyes fixed on Arix, his tone utterly serious.
’Is this a special extra lesson for me?’
Arix raised an eyebrow.
Then, she thought about waiting for Drexel and plus, she was also curious about the other training centers. So, she nodded and agreed, "Alright."
"Bauer, keep an eye on the students," Ortiz told Bauer. Then he led Arix to the first Hypnosis Training Center.
Hypnosis is about using one’s psychic power to invade someone else’s psychic world, thereby hypnotizing their consciousness.
The training aims to strengthen one’s willpower and increase the chances of resisting invasions by others’ psychic powers.
The only caution in this training is that the invader’s psychic power level must not be lower than the invaded’s, or else it could lead to a severe backlash.
As soon as Ortiz and Arix entered the hypnosis room, they saw a captain talking with the hypnosis center instructor.
"Pritchett, got a moment? Help me test a student," Ortiz casually called out.
"Sure, come on over." Pritchett was amiable, always ready to help a colleague.
"Okay..." Ortiz hadn’t noticed the man next to Pritchett at first. But after a brief glance, his next words got stuck in his throat.
’Damn, why is Kellan’s rival here? Is it too late to take Arix back now?’
Ortiz thought despairingly. He quietly moved to shield Arix behind him, trying to hide.
Ortiz swallowed and averted his eyes, saying, "Captain Cantet, what brings you here?"
"Just here for some business with Pritchett. What about you, you came here to give this student some extra training?" Cantet said teasingly, raising an eyebrow—it was clear he noticed Ortiz’s attempt to shield.
He was curious to see what Ortiz was up to.
Ortiz stumbled over his words for a moment. Then, as if suddenly remembering something urgent, he blurted out, "Ah, I just remembered I have another thing to do. Pritchett, I’ll test this tomorrow. Sorry, Captain, I have to go now."
He turned and immediately tried to pull Arix away, but Cantet’s leisurely voice halted them in their tracks.
"Wait a second," Cantet said. He walked up to Ortiz and Arix, giving Arix a careful look.
Squinting and stroking his chin, he asked nonchalantly, "This young lady looks like she’s Kellan’s sister, right?"
’No!’
Ortiz was about to object when Arix spoke up behind him.
"You know my brother?" Arix asked, curious.
Ortiz knew he should contact Kellan immediately. Just as he slightly raised his wrist equipped with an optic computer, however, Cantet saw through his intentions. Smiling, he placed a hand on Ortiz’s shoulder.
Cantet turned and warned Ortiz with a glance. Then, turning back to Arix with a smile, he said, "Yes, your brother and I learn lessons from each other often."
Hearing this, Ortiz opened his mouth but ended up covering his face, saying nothing.
Cantet was known for his sugar-coated barbs, a fact acknowledged by everyone in the fifth legion. Only he could make regular brawls sound so elegant and refined.
"You’re a friend of my brother? I’m Arix," she said politely.
"Good, are you here for a test today? Let me help you, and I think Kellan would be very glad." Cantet’s smile was disarming, but his mind was already plotting to hypnotize the girl and dig up some dirt on his rival.
"Thank you, that’s very kind," Arix, seeing the guy dressed in her military uniform, dropped down all her guards. With her instructor present, she never imagined that the man in front of her was a wolf in sheep’s clothing.
"Here, sit down and close your eyes," Cantet instructed Arix to sit in a special chair. He eagerly extended his psychic power into the psychic space of Arix’s mind, attempting to hypnotize her consciousness.
However, as soon as Cantet’s psychic power neared Arix’s consciousness, a massive psychic force erupted from within her psychic world, instantly striking back at Cantet’s psychic world.
Thud...
The sound of a body hitting the floor startled Arix awake. She opened her eyes to see her brother’s "good friend" lying on the ground.
The room was soon filled with medical personnel, but they weren’t there for Arix. Instead, they carried away Captain Cantet.
Pritchett, the instructor, concerned for Cantet, followed them out.
In the end, only Arix and Ortiz remained in the vast hypnosis room, staring at each other in an awkward silence.
After a long pause, Arix cautiously ventured, "Sir, what if I say I did nothing and he just passed out by himself? Do you believe me?"
"Arix, do you know that Captain Cantet’s psychic power is Supergiant-Class? Even he suffered backlash," Ortiz stared intensely at Arix. He then delivered a striking question, "So, how powerful is your psychic power, exactly?"
Arix hesitated, then murmured softly, "Can I choose to keep that a secret?"
Ortiz looked at Arix with mixed emotions and finally closed his eyes and waved his hand.
"Sir, does this mean I can go? Are we not testing anymore?" Arix asked, looking both pitiful and innocent.
"Go ahead, we’re not testing today. Or do you want to send another captain to the medical center?" Ortiz replied, glaring at Arix with irritation.
"Okay, thank you, sir. Goodbye!" Arix said, then scampered off as if on fire.
Today she had truly learned what it meant to have a fleeting thrill that could lead to severe consequences. Sending an officer to the medical center? It inevitably meant her parents might get called.
And that was what Arix found most mortifying.
However, it seemed that Instructor Ortiz was intending to help clean up the mess for her, which touched Arix deeply.
She wished all the best for the poor captain, and the kind Ortiz.

chapters.title: Chapter 43: The Empire And The Alliance
chapters.content:
Chapter 43: The Empire And The Alliance
As soon as Ortiz got back to the Gravity Training Center, he wrapped his arms around Bauer and wailed, "I’ve had enough! Arix must be my jinx. Every time I run into her, something bad happens."
"What happened now? Did you land her in the medical center again?" Bauer asked curiously, as if it was to be expected.
"No, this time she sent someone else there," Ortiz said, sounding sad but oddly proud.
"Who?" Bauer asked, surprised.
As soon as he mentioned it, Ortiz’s face fell. He wiped his face and mumbled, "Captain Cantet, Kellan Kering’s arch-rival."
Cantet and Kellan were the top contenders for the next Rear Admiral. Their rivalry was well-known throughout the Fifth Legion.
Bauer’s mouth twitched as he gave Ortiz a thumbs up. He said sarcastically, "When it comes to courting disaster, you’re the best, Ortiz. You just might have offended two future Rear Admirals."
Ortiz cursed inwardly, "Damn, you think I wanted this? Who knew Captain Cantet would show up at the training base today, and just happen to go to the psychic training area, and of all places, the hypnotism chamber. And just at that moment, he runs into Arix."
Today was just one unlucky coincidence after another, like someone meticulously planned it all out.
Bauer thought of something and muttered, "Do you really think Arix’s psychic power is only Supergiant-Class?"
"What do you think?" Ortiz gave Bauer a look that said ’Figure it out for yourself.’
Bauer instantly understood his friend’s point. He said thoughtfully, "The Alliance has a bright future."
"The Alliance might have a bright future, but mine is bleak for now. I don’t even know if I can smooth this over," Ortiz said with a gloomy face.
"Why not tell her big brother?" Bauer felt it was better not to get involved in fights between big shots.
"No way!" Ortiz immediately objected. With a heroic expression, he declared, "I’ll protect my student myself. What would it look like if I ran to a student’s parents when facing trouble?"
Bauer rolled his eyes and said, "Good luck then."
...
When Cantet was sent to the Fifth Legion’s hospital, Kellan had already received the news. He immediately had his aide look into the situation, and when Kellan learned the truth, he burst out laughing.
His rival had really embarrassed himself.
"Captain, do you think Captain Cantet might make things difficult for Miss Kering? Should we keep an eye on the training base?" Kellan’s aide, Basell, asked.
"No need, Cantet likes to set traps for people, but he’s basically honest. I didn’t expect that this time, trying to set a trap for me, he’d fall into it himself," Kellan said, and laughed again.
As soon as Basell heard this, he laughed along, "It’s a good thing Miss Kering is so capable."
"Capable or not, she’s still just a kid. Alright, let’s stop talking about them," Kellan said with a laugh.
He looked at the virtual map of the Alliance on his desk, his expression turning serious. "Basell, let’s talk about the insectoids. I have a feeling they’ve been unusually active lately."
Basell looked at the map, covered with planets large and small, and zoomed in on the eastern section.
Then he said, "You’re right. Lately, the insectoids seem to be targeting the Fifth Legion. The Fifth Legion’s area of responsibility on the Alliance border has seen the most insectoid activity. And recently, a wormhole appeared in Hecaris. I’m afraid they’re up to something big this time."
Kellan thought for a moment, then suddenly asked, "Is there any news from the Empire?"
"Miss Kering saved their crown prince this time. Alpha Leonidas was originally a warmonger, but he has changed quite a bit. He probably won’t plan to wage war against the Alliance for the time being," Basell said, ending with praise, "All thanks to Miss Kering, the Alliance was helped a lot without deploying a single soldier."
Kellan smiled as he listened to Basell. He said, "The best outcome is for the Empire and the Alliance to coexist peacefully. Our ancestors fled from Earth during the apocalypse; without the help of the Empire, the original inhabitant country, there would be no Alliance today."
Basell listened quietly to Kellan’s words and didn’t respond. Matters like these were global in scope, and while a captain had the right to comment, he did not have the right to participate.
Kellan understood why Basell remained silent. He didn’t continue about the Empire and changed the subject, "I’ll ask my father to pay more attention to the insectoid issue. That’s all for today, you can go now."
"Yes, captain," Basell said. Then he turned and left Kellan’s office.
Kellan sat back in his chair and rubbed his temples, "I always feel like something bad is going to happen. I hope it’s just my imagination."
Meanwhile, Arix had just walked out of the psychic training area. She was planning to enjoy the scenery outside while waiting for Drexel, when Instructor Pritchett called her back.
"Arix, come with me. The legion’s investigative team has some questions about Captain Cantet, and please put on this bracelet," Pritchett said gently.
He handed her a simple bracelet.
Arix thought it was Captain Cantet who had reported her to the legion’s investigative team, and this bracelet was like handcuffs. After putting it on, she said weakly, "It’s on."
Arix followed Pritchett out of the training base, heading towards an increasingly secluded area. That’s when she realized something might be wrong.
"Sir, are we going the right way?" Arix asked warily, suspecting that Cantet might be seeking revenge.
"Don’t worry, we haven’t gone the wrong way. Actually, we’re already here," Pritchett’s mouth curled into a sinister arc, his normally clear blue and white eyes gradually turning into all-black compound eyes.
"You’re an insectoid! You’ve parasitized Instructor Pritchett!" Arix exclaimed, her pupils constricting in shock.
Arix was about to summon her psychic powers for defense, but she found that her usually responsive psychic power now seemed as if it were asleep.
"Save your energy. The bracelet on your hand was crafted from the finest materials to restrain psychic powers. You’re the first one to use it. Don’t you feel honored?" Pritchett, with his compound eyes, looked at Arix and sneered evilly.
Arix gave up on using her psychic power and turned to run. But she had only taken a few steps when she realized she was surrounded by a psychic barrier.
Seeing no escape, Arix faced the parasitized Pritchett and asked, "What exactly do you want to do?"
"What do I want to do? I am of course going to take you back to serve as a breeding vessel for our great future Queen," Pritchett replied.
Then, without wasting more words and with a cruel, bloodthirsty expression, the insectoid advanced toward Arix.

chapters.title: Chapter 44: The Most Miserable Insectoid
chapters.content:
Chapter 44: The Most Miserable Insectoid
Pritchett moved closer and closer, but Arix remained unfazed. Instead, a smirk crept onto her lips as she sneered, "Bugs are just bugs, after all. Not too bright, are you? If you get another chance, make sure to kill me first, or you’ll be the one to die."
Arix’s right hand, the one without the bracelet, gently touched her left elbow. Then, she twisted it fiercely.
RIP!
Arix grunted in pain as blood dripped from her left elbow to the ground.
Pritchett’s pupils dilated in shock, staring in disbelief as Arix tore off her own arm. She even left the bracelet intact, taunting him as it dangled before his eyes.
"Guess I’ll need to carry a surgical knife next time," Arix muttered, casting a pained glance at her severed arm. She then turned and shot Pritchett a vicious grin. "Now, who’s the prey now?"
"How did you..." Pritchett realized the danger and tried to flee.
But Arix, ever vengeful, didn’t give him the chance. Her psychic power, long prepared, erupted and wrapped Pritchett in a crushing grip.
Arix slowly walked up to Pritchett. She then reached out, and tore off his left arm as well.
"Ah! You crazy woman! If you’re going to kill me, just do it!" Pritchett howled in agony.
"Kill you? Why would I waste such a valuable specimen?" Arix sneered. "Rest assured, I’ll make sure the research institute keeps you alive, suffering for eternity."
With that, she used her psychic power to seal the blood vessels in her wound. She tucked her severed arm under her armpit and dragged Pritchett back to the training base.
As she walked, she muttered, "I wonder if my arm can be reattached later. Should I clone a new one instead? But that’s so expensive."
Listening to Arix, Pritchett spat out a mouthful of blood in fury and fainted.
Arix noticed he had become heavier. She rolled her eyes, and muttered, "This guy? And he thinks he can be a spy?"
...
Drexel was the first to notice Arix’s disappearance. He had just finished his training and emerged from the psychic power training field, only to find Arix missing. He nearly lost his mind with worry.
He couldn’t bear to imagine what would happen to their family if Arix couldn’t be found.
While Drexel was still frantically searching, the high-ranking officers of the Fifth Legion and the training base also received the news. They were thrown into a frenzy.
Arix was the only one in the Alliance with psychic power at Supergiant+ level. After returning to the Kering family, she had been hailed by many as the future hope of the Alliance.
If she was lost forever, it would not only devastate the Kering family but also deliver a heavy blow to the entire Alliance.
While everyone frantically searched for Arix, she was already on her way back, gasping for breath as she dragged Pritchett along like a dead pig.
