Cirilla was no longer angry. She believed that mean people would get their karma from fate, especially those who are foolish and unaware, doomed to tragedy. She coldly chuckled and advised, "Netta, as your classmate, let me give you a piece of advice: Don’t fall for Drexel, because you two will never happen."
With that, Cirilla no longer paid any attention to the foolish girl behind her and sat down with her brother.
"What does Cirilla mean by that?" Netta fumed, ready to cause a scene, but was held back by her companions.
"Netta, let it go. We can’t afford to offend Cirilla," one of her friends advised.
Another added, "Yeah, and after the term starts, she’ll be the Prima of the Psychic Ware Department. If she holds a grudge and docks our credits, we might have to repeat the year."
Netta understood this too—this was why her friends were able to hold her back successfully.
Fortunately, the military rank awarding ceremony began at that moment. Netta breathed a sigh of relief and sat back down.

chapters.title: Chapter 55: Becoming A Real Soldier
chapters.content:
Chapter 55: Becoming A Real Soldier
"Good afternoon, everyone. Today, we are honored to host a grand military rank awarding ceremony for our student, Arix," announced the instructor hosting the ceremony. He began clapping, and soon a thunderous applause filled the auditorium.
Amidst the applause, today’s guest of honor, Arix Kering, walked out from backstage. She ascended the steps to the stage, arriving beside the hosting instructor.
Dressed in a deep blue uniform of the Alliance with golden embroidery, Arix looked strikingly gallant.
Her black hair, tied back, revealed a delicate oval face.
Her eyes, deep and calm like sapphires, complemented her noble brows that hinted at her spirited nature.
Even her cute face carried an air of uncompromising resolve.
"Wow, so sassy."
"Go Arix! You’re the sassiest!"
"She’s so beautiful, how did we not notice this before?"
"Wait, did the instructor get the name wrong? Isn’t her last name Thalis?"
The crowd in the auditorium erupted into cheers at the sight of Arix’s dazzling and sassy appearance, as if their favorite idol had just appeared on stage.
Some even thought the instructor had mispronounced her name, but their voices were quickly drowned out by the roar of the crowd.
"Alright, quiet down now. Next, we’re going to welcome a very special guest to award the military rank to Arix. Please welcome Admiral Thaddeus Kering! Let’s give him a round of applause," the instructor announced, his voice cracking slightly with excitement.
The students thought they had misheard.
Seconds later, a man in an Alliance uniform, adorned with numerous medals of honor, walked onto the stage. As soon as he appeared, a gasp went through the hall, nearly lifting the roof off with excitement.
As soon as Thaddeus showed up, all the students in the reception hall went wild, jumping to their feet and screaming like crazy.
"Oh my gosh, it’s Admiral Thaddeus Kering, in the flesh!"
"Admiral Thaddeus, the eternal legend!"
"Admiral Thaddeus, look this way! I love you!"
...
Some students, overwhelmed by a social mania, ran from their seats to the stage, waving and shouting in an attempt to catch their idol’s attention.
In less than a minute, the whole hall was in chaos, and even the host officer couldn’t keep control.
Arix was still in shock from seeing her dad, but she was even more stunned by the crazed behavior of her fellow students.
It was scarier than any celebrity-chasing scene—especially that guy who, while screaming "I love you," blew kisses to his father.
As the situation got more chaotic, Thaddeus took the microphone from the officer. He cleared his throat and said, "Everyone, let’s calm down for a moment."
Thaddeus didn’t shout. He spoke in a normal tone, but the hall instantly quieted down.
The students gazed at Thaddeus with sparkling eyes, filled with fervor, admiration, and aspiration.
"Thank you all for your support, I’ve seen your enthusiasm. I’m honored to be here today to present my daughter, Arix, with her first military rank. She’s the star today, so I can’t steal her thunder. Otherwise, she might complain to her mom about me," Thaddeus said.
His mature and humorous words made the students below chuckle.
It was only then that some students fully realized what was happening. They finally understood that Arix really was a Kering and that Thaddeus was family.
This revelation caused quite a stir. Many students who had been following the gossip about Arix and Drexel were stunned.
Those who had been rooting for or against the pair were silenced at the same moment.
"Who started that rumor? They’re siblings, not a couple, isn’t that going too far?"
"Although I’m a bit disappointed, I’m here for this brother-sister vibe."
"That’s good too, Arix is still single. So we still have a chance."
"Hey! Keep it down. Admiral Thaddeus is still here."
...
Listening to the students’ discussions, Thaddeus’s expression remained unchanged, still showing his usual mild and gentle demeanor.
However, when he noticed a few guilty-looking students in the crowd, his eyes narrowed slightly.
A small smile played at the corners of his mouth as he said with a hint of amusement, "I’ve also heard some rumors about Arix and Drexel; I know they are mostly baseless and fabricated. I am very disappointed in the students who spread these rumors."
The room fell silent with his words. Most students had not participated in the bizarre rumors, but a few felt guilty and frightened by Admiral Thaddeus’s remarks.
Thaddeus’s tone grew more severe as he continued, his voice carrying an edge of sharpness and authority. "I hope you all remember this: by attending a military academy, you are already half a soldier. Your actions no longer represent just yourselves, but the entire Alliance military. Have you all got that?"
"Yes, sir!" All the students responded loudly, their voices echoing powerfully.
Thaddeus scanned all the students. Those who had looked evasive now showed expressions of remorse. Finally, he showed a genuine smile and said, "Alright, enough from me. Let’s give the floor to Arix. Please, a round of applause."
Clap, clap, clap, clap, clap!
This time, the applause was strong and unanimous.
Arix took the microphone her father handed her and cleared her throat with a smile. "Actually, Admiral Kering has already said most of what I wanted to say. But regarding the rumors, I must make a serious rebuttal. Someone said I’m not worthy of Drexel? I advise you to visit an eye doctor, and I’ll cover the medical bill."
The students burst into laughter; the previously suffocative air had been lightened by Arix’s humor.
"Arix, we support you!!"
"Yeah, Arix, you’re the best!"
"Exactly, and remember, Drexel doesn’t even have a rank yet!"
...
Arix looked at these lovely students, her smile widening.
She continued, "Thank you, everyone. What I want to say is, in this world, everyone deserves the best for themselves. Everyone has strengths and weaknesses. Don’t compare your weaknesses with someone else’s strengths; that’s only going to hurt yourself. If someone ever tells you you’re less than someone else, just tell them to MIND THEIR OWN FREAKING BUSINESS!"
The hall erupted in laughter again.
"I can just imagine the gossips choking on that!"
"Why didn’t I think of that before? Next time some busybody snoops into my private life, I’ll just throw that back at them! Haha!"
"Haha, way to go, dude."
...
The students in the reception hall erupted into laughter at Arix’s words. Amid the laughter, Arix handed the microphone back to the host officer.
"Alright, our opening remarks are over, now let’s officially begin the military rank awarding ceremony."
As the officer’s voice faded, the anthem of the Alliance played, and the students returned to their seats, settling down quietly and respectfully facing the stage.
During the anthem, a master of ceremonies emerged from backstage, holding a long tray covered with velvet. On the tray lay a military cap and a medal.
When the master of ceremonies reached Thaddeus’s side, Arix stepped forward to face Thaddeus and gave a military salute, her hand crisp and fingers together.
Thaddeus, with a proud look in his eyes, smiled and returned the salute. Then he carefully picked up the cap from the tray and placed it on Arix’s head, making sure it was straight.
Next, he picked up the medal and pinned it onto Arix’s uniform. His expression was stern and solemn as he said, "A military cap signifies duty; a uniform represents dignity; military boots carry sanctity; a soldier bears a mission. From today, you, Arix, are a Student Officer. With that rank comes responsibility. Arix Kering, on behalf of the Alliance, I ask you one final question: Are you willing to become a soldier of the Alliance?"
"Yes, sir!" Arix saluted sharply, her response unwavering.
"Good, everyone, salute to Arix!" Thaddeus’s eyes were slightly red. As a soldier, he felt immense pride for his daughter; as a father, he also harbored concerns about whether this young woman could safely navigate the harsh life of military service.
Everyone in the reception hall stood up and saluted Arix. Each person’s eyes carried blessings and admiration.
Once a soldier of the Alliance, Arix no longer belonged just to her own small world, but to the nation known as the Alliance.

chapters.title: Chapter 56: Exchanging Gifts
chapters.content:
Chapter 56: Exchanging Gifts
After the ceremony, the students left the hall one by one. Some students took advantage of the early evening to continue training at their favorite training grounds, while others returned to their dormitories. They needed to prepare for tomorrow’s competition.
After saying goodbye to her dad in the hall, Arix went backstage. She quickly changed back into her training clothes. After carefully folding her military uniform, she stored it in her Space Button like treating the most precious treasures.
After making sure everything was done, she walked out of the hall alone.
As soon as she stepped outside, Arix saw her dear brother Drexel. The guy was standing not far away by a small grove, waving at her energetically.
"Arix, come here." Drexel called out with a bright, mischievous smile, as if he had something exciting to share.
Arix raised an eyebrow, curious. Although she didn’t know what her Drexel was up to, she decided to go over and see.
As soon as Arix approached, she discovered that it wasn’t just Drexel; there were five familiar faces in the grove.
"Why are you all here?" asked Arix.
"Arix, aren’t you happy to see us?" Adrian bounded over to Arix like a big golden retriever, playfully asking with a mock sad look.
Arix’s eyes softened, and she smiled as she ruffled Adrian’s hair, "I’m very happy, just a bit surprised."
"Great, here, Arix, this is a gift I got for you, congratulations on your military rank." Adrian pulled out a mecha figurine from his Space Button and handed it to Arix.
"Thank you, I really like it." Arix accepted the mecha figurine, examining it with curiosity and a smile.
"Arix, here’s my gift. Knowing you like mecha, I prepared this Star-Class energy stone for you. I hope you become a mecha master soon!" Cirilla took out a small box, opened it herself, and displayed the Star-Class energy stone inside.
The energy stone, which is placed at the chest of a mecha, not only powers the mecha but also enhances its weaponry.
This simple black stone might look ordinary, but a Star-Class energy stone starts at a million dollars. Moreover, it’s usually not available for purchase as such resources are generally monopolized by officials.
Thus, this gift was truly a heartwarming surprise for Arix.
"Thank you, Cirilla." Arix joyfully accepted the energy stone.
Nearby, Varden took out a slightly larger box from his Space Button and handed it to Arix, saying, "This is my gift for you. Open it and see, I hope you like it."
Curious, Arix opened the box and was surprised to find a mini Space Button inside, along with a set of exquisite alchemy equipment.
"Thank you. I was just wanting a set of alchemy equipment, and now I don’t need to buy one." Arix laughed happily.
"Glad you like it." Varden looked at Arix affectionately.
"Arix, congratulations on being the first to receive a military rank. This is my gift for you, a platinum card for. That gives you a membership of all my family’s business. From now on, anything you buy from my family’s store comes with a 40% discount," Elio said as he handed Arix a black card with a golden Damsey logo on it.
"Wow, Elio, you got any more? Give me one too." Drexel knew that the Lasairs had stores throughout the Alliance and even in the Empire. From everyday needs to mecha battleships, there was nothing the Lasairs didn’t sell. So, even though it was just a card, its value was incredibly high.
Elio rolled his eyes at Drexel and said, "No more. I can only give out one card a year. If you want one, wait until next year."
"Alright, it’s a deal then!" Drexel immediately responded with a happy smile.
Arix blinked, surprised by how important this discount card was, and accepted the black gold card with a sense of gravity, politely saying, "Thank you, Elio."
"Hey, Elio, don’t forget about us. Remember to get us one too," Cirilla chimed in, clearly envious.
"What? You think these cards are wholesale? That everyone gets one?" said Elio as he looked at his eagerly anticipating friends in disbelief.
"You’re the heir to the Lasair family; if you can’t do it, no one can. Be generous... OK, forget about Adrian, he doesn’t need one, but the four of us are counting on you," Cirilla teased, raising an eyebrow and blinking with a smile.
Elio looked at his four companions and finally sighed, "I’ll ask my old man when I get back. If he agrees, I’ll do it. As for Shuai Shuai, I can at least give him a golden card with a 20% discount."
Elio then took out a gold card from his Space Button and handed it over.
"Thank you," Adrian said, delightedly accepting the golden card.
His big sister, Cirilla, is the family heir, and she would eventually receive a platinum card from Lasairfamily. As for Adrian, getting a gold card now was lucky enough, and he was happy to show off to his elders at home.
"Wow, Elio, always so generous," Drexel and the others gave him thumbs up, even Zephyr, usually as cold as ice, followed suit with a thumbs up.
"Alright, alright, let’s see what Zephyr has prepared for a gift," Elio, slightly shy, changed the subject.
Zephyr, his face as expressionless as ever, silently took out a delicate, small energy pistol for ladies from his space.
"Ah, knew it would be a gun," Elio said with a knowing look.
"Yep, Zephyr always likes giving guns. He gave me one for my birthday last time too," Drexel suddenly laughed, remembering something.
"My great-grandfather too! At his age, nearly toothless, he received a gun. You should have seen his face; I almost died laughing," Elio laughed heartily.
"And there’s my little cousin who was just born. Thankfully, it was a model gun. Otherwise, my aunt and uncle would have flipped out right there, haha," Cirilla also recalled, laughing so hard she was shaking like a leaf.

chapters.title: Chapter 57: The Heir’s Past
chapters.content:
Chapter 57: The Heir’s Past
"That’s all?" Zephyr’s eyes narrowed slightly. Even though his voice was steady, it sent a chill down the spines of Drexel and the others.
Suddenly, they realized that Zephyr’s weapon, which was originally a lady’s energy pistol, had be swapped by his own high-end energy gun. The gun’s muzzle casually pointed at them, as if it might accidentally fire at any moment.
The smiles on Drexel and the others froze, and a strong sense of danger made them instinctively shut off their mouths. Elio, who was the most afraid, made a zipping motion over his mouth and timidly gave a thumbs up, as if asking, "Is that enough, sir?"
Zephyr didn’t say a word but put the energy gun back into his Space Button. Then he turned to Arix with a stern face and said, "If it breaks, you can come to me to fix it. If you ever don’t want it anymore, you can give it back to me."
"Okay, thank you. I will cherish it," Arix promised solemnly.
"Um," Zephyr replied, his voice still emotionless.
For some reason, Arix felt that Zephyr was unusually gentle at that moment, but she quickly thought it might just be her imagination. Maybe it was just the joy of the day making everyone seem softer. Or perhaps his gentleness was only meant for the gun.
Laughing at her own thoughts, Arix shook her head and put everyone’s gifts into her Space Button. Then she pulled out a large bunch of various potions.
"Thank you for the gifts. These are the Planet-Class potions I made. I hope you don’t mind," she said as she handed out a bunch to everyone.
"Wow, Arix, you can make Planet-Class potions now? That’s amazing! Can I count on you for that from now on?" Adrian admired her with sparkling eyes, excitedly trying to hug Arix’s arm.
But Drexel noticed immediately. He blocked Adrian with his chest and bared his small fangs in a threatening way, his expression saying, "Stay away from my sister."
Adrian huffed and rolled his eyes at Drexel. Then he looked at Arix again, his eyes bright and shining, and asked with a sunny smile, "Arix, do you need an assistant of something? ’cause I can definitely do that."
Before Arix could answer, Drexel interrupted harshly, "No need! My sister has a brother, and that’s enough."
Adrian’s eyes widened in anger, ready to argue back, but then Cirilla grabbed him by the collar and dragged him away. "Enough, Adrain, stop it. You know Drexel is overprotective. Be careful, or he might hit the crap out of you, and I won’t be able to stop him," Cirilla said, patting Adrian’s head to calm him down.
"Whatever," Adrian muttered, his lips pouting, but at least he calmed down physically.
When Varden received the potions, his professional habits kicked in. He started examining each potion carefully.
There were about twenty potions, mostly Planet-Class healing potions, but also some for hair growth, cancer prevention, and even one for breast enhancement, which made Varden’s mouth twitch as he rubbed his forehead, unable to bear looking at them any longer.
Then he put all the potions into his Space Button.
The others weren’t as dramatic; their happiness stemmed more from Arix’s thoughtfulness.
After the gifts were distributed, everyone said their goodbyes, leaving only Arix and Drexel walking back to their dormitory together.
"Arix, are you happy today?" Drexel asked casually.
"Yeah, probably the happiest day since I came here," Arix responded, thinking of Thaddeus, Cirilla, Adrian, and a genuine smile spread across her face.
"By the way, you and Zephyr, being heirs of the five noble families, why aren’t you competing against each other but instead have such good relationships?" Arix finally voiced her long-held curiosity.
Especially during the exams, she had thought that the noble families would be sabotaging each other, but the brotherly love shown there had stunned her.
"Isn’t it normal for those big families to fight each other, struggling to be first or second?" she added.
Drexel recalled some distant memories with a bit of emotion, "Actually, it wasn’t this good at the beginning, especially Elio. He had all the airs of a young master. When we were kids, I’d beat him up every time I saw him."
Arix was speechless, now understanding why Elio targeted Drexel so much during the exams; their "love-hate relationship" had started from childhood.
"And what about Cirilla? How did you guys end up friends?" Arix asked curiously.
"Cirilla, the tomboy, liked to fight with boys since she was a child. Men often bond through fighting, well, I mean brotherly love," Drexel quickly clarified to prevent any misunderstanding from his sister.
"Oh, that’s just like Cirilla. If she were in ancient Earth, she would probably be like superwoman," Arix said with a hint of admiration, genuinely liking the kind of girl who could hold her own against men.
"Arix, admiration is fine, but don’t try to be like her. What girl acts so brashly? She doesn’t act ladylike at all," Drexel quickly cautioned, not wanting his cute and sweet sister to turn into a tomboy like Cirilla.
Arix huffed, not quite agreeing. Then she continued, "You haven’t told me about Zephyr yet?"
When Drexel mentioned Zephyr, he fell into a rare silence before speaking, "Actually, Zephyr has it tough. Although he became the heir of the Calix family due to his strong talents, but the current patriarch isn’t his dad and the guy has his own sons, so Zephyr’s position in the Calix family is probably not as glamorous as it seems. I remember when we were kids, he was a bit aloof but approachable, not like now, as cold as a fish."
"Could it be that he has been through too many bad things?" Arix asked, concerned.
She thought Zephyr was a good person with a cold exterior but a warm heart. Initially, she assumed he was just naturally reserved, but now it seemed there might be hidden reasons behind his demeanor.

chapters.title: Chapter 58: The Heir
chapters.content:
Chapter 58: The Heir
"I don’t know much, but there was one thing that really stirred things up between the Lasair and the Calix family," Drexel said with a smirk, remembering the chaos.
"It sounds like fun, tell me more," Arix said, excited to hear the gossip.
Drexel didn’t hold back, laughing as he recalled, "It all started ten years ago when Zephyr was chosen as the heir to the Calix family. The head of the Calix family was okay with it, but his wife always saw Zephyr as a thorn in her side, thinking he stole her own son’s place."
"Poor Zephyr, he must have been targeted a lot," Arix sympathized with Zephyr for a moment, likening it to an interstellar family drama.
Drexel suddenly chuckled, then ruffled his silly little sister’s hair, saying, "You’re underestimating Zephyr. Whenever the lady dared to bother him, he would turn around and trouble her son. Even if it was an accident, Zephyr managed to pin it on her son."
"Hah, good job, Zephyr," Arix gave a thumbs up, applauding Zephyr. "Keep going, Drexel, I feel like it’s going to get even more interesting."
"Later, the lady thought, why not go all out? She hired interstellar mercenaries through the black market, pretending to be space pirates to bomb the spaceship that Zephyr was on. Unfortunately, Elio was also on that ship, which really angered the Lasairs. You know, Lasair folks are not to be messed with. They immediately confronted the Calix family. If not for the leaders of the other three major families mediating on the spot, the two families might have developed a vendetta," Drexel explained, relieved for the Calix family.
"That lady must have ended up in misery," Arix wondered.
Drexel scoffed mockingly, "More than misery, I heard that overnight, her maternal family went from second-rate to bottom-tier, all because they declared they’d cut ties with her right away. And the lady herself, the main culprit, was exiled to a borderline planet. Even the pleas from the patriarch couldn’t save her."
Drexel knew so much because the incident had been huge, causing even the Kering family to tighten up their household to prevent someone like her from emerging.
"How did Zephyr and the others get rescued then? With the explosion’s power, if they were just kids at the time, the chances of surviving wouldn’t have been high," Arix asked.
"It was lucky for Zephyr; he happened to be with Elio, the Lasairs’ only son. Elio, god bless him, had many treasures. Not just a spaceship explosion, even a mecha explosion couldn’t have killed him," Drexel explained.
Anyway, those two boys were later found on a primitive planet, and after that, Elio’s haughty attitude changed a lot, probably because the week he was missing really took a toll on him," Drexel laughed without any sympathy.
"Ah, typical big families dramas. Isn’t it?" Arix remarked after hearing the story.
Drexel laughed at Arix’s serious demeanor and patted her head affectionately, "Don’t forget, you’re also from a big family. Alright, we’ve reached the dormitory. Go get some rest after you get back. Try to do well in tomorrow’s competition. You know, you’re the first freshman in our class to get a military rank. It would be embarrassing if you rank poorly."
"Whatever, you’re supposed to be the heir of the Kering family. If you don’t rank higher than your little sister, I’ll see who’s embarrassed," Arix replied with a glare at Drexel.
"Hey, you little rascal, let’s make a bet. If I rank higher than you, you increase my share of the potion shop’s dividends by 5%," Drexel challenged with a raised eyebrow.
"Huh, let’s do it. If you lose, I get your opticomputer during training," Arix laughed coldly.
"Deal," Drexel said. His fighting spirit was rising. He looked at Arix as though a majestic tiger looked down at a naughty younger sibling.
"No problem," Arix’s competitiveness was also ignited. Vita, Sophia, and Cupid appeared behind her.
Vita still looked kind but now carried an vibe of seriousness, as if to say, ’see who dares to mess with my kids.’ Sophia remained dignified, her entire Psychic Incarnation radiating confidence. Cupid, excited, was shaking his chubby body, eager to fight.
An invisible cloud of tension rose between Arix and Drexel. After a standoff, they both snorted in unison and returned to their dorms.
After Arix entered the building, Drexel paused, as if talking to himself, "Sheer, those three were Arix’s Psychic Incarnations, right?"
The white tiger in Drexel’s psychic world nodded its majestic head, and then a young voice rang out in Drexel’s psychic world, "Yes, they have awakened, which means your sister’s physical power is about to break through to the Subgiant Class. Otherwise, they would still be forced to sleep in Arix’s psychic world due to the limitations of her physical power."
Drexel smiled, relieved as if a weight had been lifted from his heart, "That’s good, I can rest easy now."
Sheer seemed to have recalled something. He joked, "Now that your sister’s Psychic Incarnations have finally awakened, it means she could also qualify to inherit the Kering family. That might shake up your position as the heir."
Drexel laughed affectionately yet helplessly, "You know, I’ve never really cared about that. I just don’t want my sister to be bound by the family obligations either. It’s a pity that our big brother hasn’t awakened his Psychic Incarnation; otherwise, I’d be more than glad to pass that burden to him."
"Do you think your brother knows you’re trying to set him up?" Sheer rolled his eyes.
"He wouldn’t mind," Drexel replied with a mischievous grin. Then he continued on his way to his dorm.
In each generation of the five noble families, there would be one person naturally awakening their Psychic Incarnation when they were born.
Only those who had awakened their Psychic Incarnation could control the ultimate mechas passed down through their families.
These individuals would be recognized by the five noble families as the heirs.

chapters.title: Chapter 59: Badge Collecting
chapters.content:
Chapter 59: Badge Collecting
The next day, the usual training ground was packed with military students due to the contest.
Surprisingly, many members of the Fifth Legion had also shown up.
Arix was standing among the students of the Hecaris Military Academy.
When she counted the number of soldiers, she was shocked to find that there were nearly a hundred people from the Fifth Legion.
She knew something must be off. They wouldn’t just send so many soldiers here to see students competing with each other.
Taking a deep breath, Arix prepared herself mentally. Her intuition told her that today’s competition would not be as simple as she thought; it would definitely be full of surprises.
"Arix, stay close to me during the competition, I’ll take care of you," Rei said seriously, with a hint of worry in her eyes.
"You can also come with me," Maya smiled as always, like a warm senior.
"I can help, too," Lilou pushed her glasses up and offered.
"If you don’t mind, you can join me as well," Leyla said, her delicate face lighting up with a smile. She just made the whole world brighter.
"And me too," Calista added, her eyes earnest and firm as she looked at Arix.
Rei and the others did not yet know that Arix’s physical power had improved, so they were all worried about her upcoming challenges.
Seeing her roommates caring for her, Arix felt a warmth spread across her chest. She assured them, "Thank you all, but my physical power has already broken through to Star-Class, so I will be fine in this competition."
At Arix’s words, all her roommates stared at her with wide, astonished eyes.
Rei gasped in amazement, her eyes sparkling with curiosity, "Wow, Arix, how did you improve so quickly? Do you have any tips for us?"
"There’s no secret really. I had some damage in my physical foundation, which got repaired at the legion a few days ago, and that’s why my physical power increased so quickly," Arix explained, tapping Rei on the forehead with her finger.
"Ah, I see," Rei realized, and then happily congratulated her, "Congratulations, Arix! You won’t have to worry about physical training anymore."
"Thank you," Arix said softly, touched by her roommates’ joy. Suddenly, she remembered something. Rei and Maya, both from Planet Waste, probably had some foundational physical issues due to their poor conditions.
Just to be safe, she decided to learn how to make Star-Class physical boosters after the training ended, planning to surprise them later.
With a smile, Arix joined her roommates in looking towards the podium, quietly waiting for the competition to start.
"The head of the instructors, please come forward," said the training base manager, Aden.
Ortiz and other instructors walked up to Aden and saluted. Then Ortiz said clearly, "Sir, everyone is present."
Aden nodded. Then he took out five sets of documents and handed them to Ortiz and the others. "Here are the documents for today’s contest. Please review them and carry out the instructions within half an hour."
"Yes, sir." Ortiz took the documents, looked them over himself first, and then passed them to Virtanen and Bauer.
"Isn’t this a bit difficult?" Virtanen said sympathetically after reading the documents.
"Who came up with these? Aren’t they afraid of being kidnapped by students in the restroom?" Bauer rarely agreed with Virtanen.
"I think it’s fine. They would have to face this sooner or later. We’re just speeding things up a bit," Ortiz raised his eyebrows, his tone carrying a hint of interest.
"Should we contact a psychologist first? I think a lot of students will have some mental issues today," Bauer seriously suggested.
Ortiz raised his wrist, showing his opticomputer and smiled. "I’ve already contacted them. I do have a bit of sympathy. Enough talk, now it’s time to collect the students’ Space Buttons. Let’s distribute these cards too."
After speaking, Ortiz led the instructors back to the Hecaris Military Academy’s side. They following the document, collecting Space Buttons and other items that could aid in the contest.
After collecting everything, they distributed a badge-collecting card to each student.
"Sir, what is this for?" a curious student asked, holding the card.
Ortiz’s mouth curved into a rare, kind smile. "Don’t worry, you’ll find out soon."
"Okay, thank you." The student was surprised to receive a smile from Ortiz and felt rather flattered.
He was even thinking to himself that the instructors seemed quite gentle today.
Once all the students from the five military academies were ready, Aden finally spoke from the podium. "Hello, everyone! Today is our weekly training contest. The contest is simple. You all see the card in your hand, right? The badge location on the back of the card will update to the next point after you collect a badge. The goal is to collect five badges to complete the contest. The faster you collect them, the higher your score. The first ten to collect all badges will receive an extra ten points. No more talking, I now declare the contest officially started!"
As soon as the competition started, the students scattered instantly, each heading to the locations indicated on the backs of their cards to collect badges.
Arix quickly ran towards the first badge point, which was the cafeteria.
Along the way, she passed a few students with the same goal, and she felt unusually calm, making her wonder if she had been overly concerned earlier.
It seemed like today’s contest wouldn’t have any surprises after all.
However, as soon as she reached the entrance of the cafeteria, Arix knew her worry is coming true.
At the door, there was a long table with ten large bowls filled with various disgusting things. Each bowl was attended by a chef who was energetically encouraging the students, "Taste all ten kinds of lovingly prepared dishes and get your badge stamped. What are you waiting for? Get moving!"
The chef at the first bowl on the left had a bowl full of live worms. Trying to suppress his excitement, he smiled benignly at the students, harmless as an old lady, "Eat up, eat up. It’s very nutritious, just a bit ugly, that’s all."
One student had psyched himself up for a while before he finally mustered the courage to approach. But as soon as he saw the greasy, sticky worms and smelled the earthy odor they emitted, he completely broke down and rushed to the side, retching.
His miserable state caused the surrounding students to step back in disgust. Some students even turned around and gave up on the cafeteria’s badge, deciding to collect the other badges first. They would later decide whether to sacrifice their dignity for victory or to give up winning to save their dignity.

chapters.title: Chapter 60: Disgusting Food
chapters.content:
Chapter 60: Disgusting Food
Arix was also struggling with the decision of whether to eat the ten disgusting dishes. If she didn’t, the devilish chefs wouldn’t give her a badge.
Thinking of this, Arix gritted her teeth and was about to go forward when she suddenly remembered Cupid from her psychic world.
Arix’s eyes shifted as she tried calling out to Cupid in her mind. "Cupid, can you hear me?"
Cupid, who was bored and spinning in circles in the psychic world, stopped and looked around. He thought Arix had come to play.
"Arix, where are you? I can’t see you," Cupid said, confused.
"Cupid, I’m not in the psychic world. I wanted to ask if you can eat real food," Arix asked, feeling a bit guilty.
After saying this, Arix felt so ashamed she wanted to hide. She felt like she was tricking a child and was overwhelmed with guilt.
"I can’t eat real things right now. Is someone bothering you, Arix? Do you want me to beat them up for you?" Cupid said fiercely.
"No one is bothering me. It’s just that there’s food here I don’t want to eat," Arix said, distressed because she really couldn’t bring herself to eat the worms.
"If you don’t like it, why eat it?" Cupid asked, tilting his head in confusion.
Arix was about to explain when Sophia, who couldn’t stand it any longer, interrupted, "If you don’t like it, why not let Cupid wrap it in psychic power, and you can spit it out when no one’s around?"
"Oh! That sounds like a god plan. Sophia, you’re brilliant," Arix exclaimed happily.
Then, without hesitation, Arix walked up to the first dish and said to the chef, "Chef, I’m ready to take on the challenge."
The chef was initially confused, but upon hearing Arix’s declaration, he quickly perked up and excitedly said, "Alright!"
He picked up a small plate, grabbed an earthworm with tongs, and passed it to Arix along with a knife and a fork.
Arix’s hands trembled slightly as she took the plate. She mustered all her courage to pick up the wriggling earthworm with the fork and said with a whimper to Cupid, "Cupid, are you ready?"
"Arix, no problem. Go ahead and eat; I promise the earthworm won’t touch you," Cupid encouraged her.
"Okay," Arix replied, then closed her eyes and quickly threw the earthworm into her mouth.
The moment the earthworm entered her mouth, Cupid wrapped it up and stored it temporarily in her stomach. Before Arix could even feel anything, Cupid had already finished the job.
"Cupid, you’re amazing," Arix said with sparkling eyes of joy.
"I know, right?" Cupid blushed with pride as he excitedly rolled around in the psychic world.
"Cupid, there are nine more to go. Can you still do it?" Arix asked nervously, looking at the next nine bowls.
"No problem at all," Cupid replied confidently.
"Alright, let’s get to the next one," Arix said. She walked to the next plate, staring at the bowl of cockroach soup and regretting ever having such clear sights.
Retching slightly, Arix used the same method—wrapping the food with psychic power before placing it in her stomach.
The next eight dishes were: witchetty grubs, maggot puree, roasted scorpion, bat soup, raw fish eyeballs, baby mice, and fried spiders.
The students watching were all shocked, not knowing that Arix was only pretending to eat. They truly thought she had swallowed the food.
"Is Arix really that... I can’t find the word... that perverish?" one student whispered.
"Isn’t she too harsh on herself?" another muttered.
"And she was the first woman to earn a military rank among us, truly terrifying," another commented.
Arix ignored the surrounding voices, fearing that even a second’s pause would ruin everything. After finally dealing with the last fried spider, she clutched her mouth, her face twisted as she handed over the card to the chef who had the badges.
The chef took the card and stamped it with a badge, somewhat moved, "You’re the first to complete the challenge here, congratulations!"
Arix didn’t want to say anything. She took her card and rushed to the bathroom as if her pants were on fire.
Those at the entrance of the cafeteria watched in admiration as Arix left. Soon, a few bold youngsters gathered their courage and stood in front of the first chef.
They finally dared to put the earthworms in their mouths. Whether it was psychological or not, they felt as if the earthworms were still wriggling inside their mouths.
Some people, upon experiencing the daunting challenge of eating disgusting food, broke down mentally. They vomited and then angrily tore off their digital bracelets, choosing to quit the competition.
After Arix had a severe bout of vomiting in the bathroom, she finally came out looking drained, as if a monster had sucked all the vitality out of her.
She leaned against a tree to catch her breath for a while. Then, she shakily picked up her card, and looked at the address for the next badge collection point.
Upon recognizing the location, she had a slight smile on her lips. She was surprised that it was an easy spot to earn a badge.
"Hypnosis Training Center, huh?" Arix murmured as if reminiscing, and then she headed towards the psychic power training ground.
As soon as she arrived at the Hypnosis Training Center, Arix was about to enter when she was stopped by an instructor.
"Sir, can I help you?" Arix looked puzzled at the instructor.
"You’re Arix, right?" the instructor from the Hypnosis Training Center asked.
"Yes..." Arix responded, slightly confused.
"Just hand me your card, and I’ll stamp your badge right away," the instructor said, relieved that he had stopped the correct person.
"Sir, isn’t it a bit improper for us to be so blatantly skipping the process?" Arix said, though her actions contradicted her words as she promptly handed over her card.
The instructor from the Hypnosis Training Center gave her a stiff, insincere smile, and quickly stamped the badge onto her card. As he handed back the card, his expression almost seemed to say, "The badge is given, now you can leave, and please never come back."
This wasn’t an exaggeration on the instructor’s part. Not long ago, Arix had made such a significant impact at the hypnosis room that a saying became popular there: "Hypnotizing others takes time, but hypnotizing Arix takes half of your life."

chapters.title: Chapter 61: Holographic Training Center
chapters.content:
Chapter 61: Holographic Training Center
Nowadays, no instructor would willingly attempt to hypnotize Arix.
This was especially true after the incident with Captain Cantet, who ended up spending several weeks in the military hospital recovering.
Additionally, the current competition at the Hypnosis Training Center was merely to identify if any of the students were spies.
Given Arix’s status as the sole legitimate heiress of the Kering family, the likelihood of her being a spy was virtually nil.
Consequently, the instructor at the Hypnosis Training Center simply turned a blind eye and stamped her card with a badge.
After receiving the card from the instructor, Arix walked away, touching her nose awkwardly as she did.
It seemed the story of Captain Cantet’s ordeal had spread throughout the Hypnosis Training Center. Otherwise, Arix, who considered herself quite likable, wouldn’t have sensed such evident disdain from the instructor.
Shrugging off the slight, Arix looked at her card, now adorned with two badges. She felt a bit consoled. Disdain or not, as long as she had her lovely badges, it was fine by her.
"Now, where’s the next badge?" Arix wondered aloud, flipping the card to check the location of the third badge.
Holographic Training Center
"Holographic? What kind of training is that?" Arix was puzzled but decided it was best to check it out in person. The Holographic Training Center was also located within the psychic training grounds, and she arrived there shortly.
To her surprise, Drexel was also there. Upon seeing Arix, he provocatively waved his card, which also had two badge stamps, in front of her.
"Arix, you might as well give up now," Drexel taunted with a smug laugh.
"Don’t you think it’s a bit early to be saying that, dude?" Arix retorted, flashing her own two-badge card.
The surrounding students, unintentionally caught in their verbal crossfire, silently hugged their badge-less cards and sadly moved away from the pair.
After a brief comparison of their cards, Arix and Drexel snorted coldly at each other and put away their cards. Then, they turned their attention to the Holographic Training Center.
"Why don’t you go in first?" Drexel offered, his politeness obviously feigned.
"Thank you, I will," Arix replied, not really appreciating his insincerity, and walked into the Holographic Training Center with a forced smile.
Drexel paused, a bit taken aback by Arix’s blunt demeanor. Then he shook his head with a smirk and followed her inside.
Upon seeing them coming in, the instructor at the Center pointed to two small rooms and said, "Stay inside for half an hour, and you’ll earn your badge."
"Alright," Arix and Drexel responded.
They entered their respective rooms, and as soon as they did, the instructor shut the doors behind them.
Arix was shocked to find that the small room was a Connective Device, where her Psychic Incarnation was sharing experiences and pain with a soldier who had been captured by criminals.
The gruesome details of the torture—the flaying, nose cutting, eight fingers chopped off, eyes crushed, and five ribs smashed—were vividly felt by Arix. The soldier had been forced to stay awake throughout the ordeal with the help of stimulants, denying him even the mercy of unconsciousness.
When the half-hour was up, the instructor opened the door. He found Arix with clenched fists, her lips bitten to bleeding.
"Time’s up, you can come out now," the instructor stated calmly.
Arix ignored him, her eyes bloodshot, and asked hoarsely, "Is this person still alive?"
The instructor finally looked at Arix properly, affirming firmly yet soothingly, "Alive! He’s now happy, with a wife and children."
"That’s good," Arix said, her tense emotions relaxing as tears uncontrollably streamed down her face.
Drexel came out of his pod and immediately rushed to his sister’s. After giving a respectful military salute to the instructor, he hugged Arix, offering silent comfort.
At that moment, the competition meant nothing to Drexel; his sister’s well-being was all that mattered.
Arix didn’t resist; she cried heart-wrenchingly in her brother’s arms, releasing all her feelings of helplessness.
After a while, her emotions finally stabilized.
Together, they walked out of the Holographic Training Center, their cards newly stamped with the badge.
"Arix, I concede. You win this time; let’s withdraw," Drexel said, unable to bear the thought of his beloved sister undergoing more suffering.
Arix’s tears nearly broke his heart, and he didn’t want to feel so helpless again. To him, her tears were the most potent weapon—hitting straight to the heart with overwhelming force.
But Arix was not moved by his words; instead, her anger surged from zero to a hundred. "Drexel! How dare you say that? That’s almost insulting to me!" she demanded, her eyes flaming with fury.
"I—I meant it for your good..." Drexel stammered, taken aback by his sister’s explosive anger.
Although frightened, he still tried to explain with a tinge of hurt in his voice.
For the first time, Arix lost control of her emotions in anger, "For my good? How could you say that? Are you trying to make me feel guilty? In the future, you won’t just be my brother; you’ll be an admiral of the Fifth Legion, an admiral of the entire Alliance. I want to be your companion, not a burden that drags you down, understand?"
"But you are my only sister; I can’t bear to see you going through that much," Drexel replied weakly. Then, fearful of making his sister even angrier, he nervously glanced at Arix a few times.
"Ha, I was just making a presumption. Do you really think I’d just be your companion? No, I’ll be much more than that," Arix said sarcastically. Then she turned and walked away.
Before she left, Arix coldly dropped another line, "If one day you become weaker than me, I wouldn’t mind taking someone else as my companion, or even my brother."
Now it was Drexel’s turn to explode in anger, and the more he thought about it, the angrier he got.
"What the hell, Arix! What do you mean? Besides me and Kellan, who else do you want as your brother?" he shouted after Arix. "Just because you’re better than me? I’ll show you in a minute. I’ll be your brother, being stronger than you for now and forever!"
As Arix walked away, she didn’t look back. She raised her hand and waved it behind her, as if to say, "We’ll see about that."
Out of Drexel’s sight, the corners of Arix’s mouth curled up slightly in a smirk.

chapters.title: Chapter 62: The Ultimate Plan
chapters.content:
Chapter 62: The Ultimate Plan
Arix enjoyed showing off, but she regretted it later. She wished she hadn’t said anything to Drexel.
After dealing with the third badge point, Arix wanted to give up. But she had already bragged to Drexel.
So, she had to keep trying.
Arix sighed deeply and looked at the fourth badge point on the card.
This badge point was behind the training base.
Arix saw many dirty, injured students coming from the badge point. Her throat felt tight, and she swallowed nervously, scared as she watched each student walk by.
The more she looked, the more frightened she felt.
’Why is a simple competition so dangerous? Why are they looking at me with pitiful gaze?’
Arix felt like crying. She looked away, afraid she would lose the courage to move forward if she kept looking.
The closer she got to the badge point, the more numb she felt.
When she finally reached the badge point and saw the grinning instructor, Arix wore a blank, emotionless face.
"Hey, another one! Don’t look so serious. Don’t worry, this is going to be easy for you," the instructor said with a smile.
If she hadn’t seen all those injured students, she might have believed him.
Later, she realized that the instructors who smiled the most were usually the toughest.
"You just need to walk up this path to the top of the hill. There, you’ll find the guy with the badge. See? Simple," the instructor said sincerely, his face looking honest.
No wonder so many students came here! They must have been fooled by his Oscar-worthy performance, thinking this one was easy
Arix nodded coldly and started up the hill.
The path was eerie and quiet, with only a few crows cawing, making it feel like night.
Arix stayed alert, watching her surroundings.
"Bang!"
"Ouch! It hurt!" Arix gasped in pain as she held her head; she had been hit by a rock.
Before she could check around, more rocks flew at her.
"Damn! Can’t you just wait for a sec?" Arix yelled. She quickly put up a psychic power shield to block the rocks and sighed in relief.
But it would take at least two hours to reach the top, and she couldn’t keep her psychic power up that long.
Arix thought for a moment and started calling Vita in the psychic world.
"Vita, can you help me knock away these stones?" Arix asked.
"Sure," Vita agreed without hesitation.
"I can help too!" Cupid said eagerly, not wanting to be left out.
Arix didn’t want Cupid’s help because Cupid used too much psychic power, even though his attacks were the strongest. She wanted to save her psychic power, so she chose Vita instead of using the psychic power shield.
But she didn’t want to say this directly to Cupid. After thinking for a moment, Arix said gently, "Cupid, let Vita handle the simple things. I’ll call you when it gets tough, okay?"
Cupid, feeling proud as if he was stronger, blushed and nodded. "Okay, Arix. Just call me if you need me."
"No problem," Arix said, relieved, and promised cheerfully.
After calming Cupid, Arix instructed Vita to knock away the attacking stones. Then she quickly ran towards the top of the hill.
Along the way, besides stones, there were deep pits on the ground, choking ropes from above, and various other traps...
After running halfway up the hill, she heard gunshots.
Arix skillfully dodged a few bullets and looked towards the source of the gunshots.
She saw a few figures quickly leaving.
Arix frowned. If she wasn’t mistaken, those people looked like soldiers from the Fifth Legion.
It seemed this badge point challenge was getting more interesting.
Meanwhile, a few Fifth Legion soldiers were discussing Arix.
"Sergeant, this kid is too strong! We can’t stop her at all."
"And her psychic power seems endless. We’ve been draining it for so long, but she’s not showing any signs of exhaustion."
"Yeah, she’s almost at the top. If this continues, we’ll be the first squad to be beaten by a student in history."
"Sergeant, what should we do next?"
The soldiers looked at their sergeant, waiting for his decision.
The sergeant listened to his team and was silent for a moment. Finally, he spoke with a determined and serious look, "It seems we have to initiate the ultimate plan!"
"What’s the ultimate plan? I don’t know about it."
"Yeah, sergeant, when did we get an ultimate plan?"
The soldiers were confused and asked their sergeant.
"The ultimate plan is..." The sergeant said mysteriously, looking at his teammates.
The sergeant suddenly opened his opticomputer. He operated it with a blank expression and said, "The ultimate plan is, of course, to call for backup. Only a fool would keep fighting a losing battle."
The Alliance soldiers were all speechless, watching their sergeant call for backup right in front of them, for the fear of a younger.
For some reason, they all felt like children who, unable to win a fight, had run home to call their brothers and sisters. It was a bit embarrassing, but they didn’t seem to have other options.
The backup arrived very quickly.
In less than three minutes, three young lieutenants silently appeared.
The leader was a young woman with a delicate face, but that pretty face seemed cold. The other two were also young, and they both seemed very dangerous.
When the soldiers and the sergeant saw the backup, they immediately saluted and shouted, "Sir!"
They seemed very respectful; they didn’t underestimate the young reinforcements because of their age.
The three lieutenants returned the salute. Then the only female, Rhea, spoke calmly, "Tell me, why did you call us?"
"Lieutenant, we had a top student. We couldn’t stop her, so we requested your support," the sergeant said, feeling a bit ashamed.
"Oh? Show me her file," Rhea said, her cold eyes showing a hint of interest.
"Yes, ma’am!" the sergeant said. Then he opened his opticomputer and projected Arix’s file as a hologram.
"Huh, it’s Arix. I’ve been wanting to meet her," Rhea said with a cold smile, her face becoming even colder, as if she had met an enemy.
The Alliance soldiers and the sergeant suddenly felt uneasy, as if they had unintentionally brought a serious enemy to Arix.
"Tane, Novak, let’s go!" Rhea said. Then the three of them rushed towards Arix’s location.
The remaining soldiers and the sergeant looked at each other, awkwardly. After a while, one of the soldiers hesitantly said, "I have a feeling this lieutenant wants to settle a personal score with Arix."
"You have a ’feeling’? That expression on her face was clear as day!" the sergeant sighed.
The soldiers exchanged glances. Then one of them curiously asked, "Sergeant, you know something about it, don’t you?"
"I just remembered," the sergeant said, rubbing his forehead, "Arix is the student who sent Captain Cantet to the hospital a few days ago. lieutenant Rhea is his sister, and she’s known for being very protective of him."
Hearing this, the soldiers immediately understood what was happening. They suddenly all felt sorry for Arix.
Meanwhile, Arix was nearing the mountaintop, but before she could celebrate, she suddenly stopped and looked warily in a certain direction.
"Vita, switch to Cupid," Arix thought.
"Okay," Vita said. The Psychic Incarnation around Arix changed to Cupid.
"Arix, where are the bad guys?" Cupid shook excitedly. To others, it looked like Arix was controlling psychic power that swirled around her.
"Just be careful. They’re already here," Arix said. As soon as she spoke, three high-ranking Alliance officers appeared in front of her.
"Are you Arix?" Rhea looked Arix up and down with disdain.
"Yes, I am. Who are you?" Arix asked, confused.
She had sensed a deep hostility even before these people arrived, which is why she had switched from Vita to Cupid. She expected to encounter insectoids, but instead, it was a strange young woman filled with intense hostility towards her.
"Hmph! As long as you’re Arix, that’s all that matters. I don’t want to accidentally hit the wrong person," Rhea said. Then she stopped paying attention to Arix and turned to her companions, "I can handle this alone. You two stay out of it."
Tane and Novak exchanged a glance and nodded, stepping back from the battlefield.

chapters.title: Chapter 63: Competition Over
chapters.content:
Chapter 63: Competition Over
Without wasting any more words, Rhea moved like lightning towards Arix, her psychic power forming into blades aimed at Arix’s limbs.
She wouldn’t forgive anyone who bullied her brother.
Just as Reah was very protective of Cantet, Cupid was protective of Arix.
Anyone who bullied Arix was a bad person in Cupid’s eyes. And bad people deserved to be punished.
Cupid began to turn deep red. He shifted from a harmless little beast to almost a bloodthirsty monster.
Facing Rhea’s psychic power and the "bad person," Cupid protected Arix, using his psychic power like a whip. He not only shattered Rhea’s psychic blades but also lashed at Rhea’s abdomen.
This was the first time Arix saw Cupid in combat, and she was surprised by his strength. If Sophia and Vita joined in, the other two lieutenant wouldn’t stand a chance either.
While Arix felt at ease, Rhea kept trying various attacks after dodging the strike to her abdomen. But every attempt was blocked by Arix’s psychic power.
Rhea’s eyes were almost freezing over, especially when she saw Arix watching the fight as if it were a show. She gritted her teeth in anger and intensified her attacks.
Watching from the side, Tane and Novak were amazed by Arix’s combat abilities. Rhea had recently graduated as a top student from the Hecaris Military Academy, but now she couldn’t defeat this freshman?—That’s absurd.
Arix, however, wasn’t feeling as easy as she seemed. As Rhea’s attacks got fiercer and fiercer, Arix’s physical power could no longer sustain Cupid’s intense actions.
"Cupid, use your strongest attack to knock her out," Arix said, trying to ignore her body’s discomfort.
"Okay," Cupid understood Arix’s situation. If this continued, Arix’s body might collapse first. So, Cupid didn’t hold back and used his strongest attack, hitting Rhea and making her fall unconscious instantly.
As Rhea fell, Tane and Novak caught her and checked her condition. After confirming she was not seriously hurt, Tane looked up at Arix and said, "You won. You can go."
Arix retracted Cupid and nodded at them expressionlessly. Then she continued towards the mountaintop.
Once she was out of their sight, Arix immediately coughed up a large mouthful of blood.
"It seems that Star-Class physical power is still a bit too much for me," Arix muttered, wiping the blood from her mouth with her sleeve, feeling a bit frustrated.
She wiped the blood from her mouth and placed her right hand on her left wrist, feeling her pulse for a moment.
When her pulse slowed down, she breathed a sigh of relief and put her hand down.
She joked to herself, "Maybe this is what they mean by ’if you don’t treat it, it heals on its own.’"
Ever since her physical power upgraded, Arix felt not only stronger in battle but also noticed that her body healed faster. This was just Star-Class physical power. If she upgraded to Supergiant-Class physical power in the future, she might become an unstoppable force.
Arix thought about this for a while. Then she looked firmly toward the top of the mountain. It was time to get the fourth badge. With that thought, she continued climbing.
The journey was unusually calm. There were no traps, no ambushes, and no harsh instructors. Before long, Arix successfully obtained the fourth badge.
On her way down, Arix saw some freshmen near the exit, laughing happily.
"Looks like the instructor wasn’t lying. It might really be easy; see, she already came out," one said.
"Yeah, the instructor didn’t seem like someone who would lie," another agreed.
One cautious student asked Arix, "Did you get the badge?"
Arix realized the student was talking to her. She raised an eyebrow but said nothing, just showed the card with the four badge symbols on it.
The cautious student sighed in relief, thanked Arix, and headed toward the mountain top with the others, thinking maybe he was too suspicious.
Arix stayed there for a moment, feeling sympathetic for the students climbing the mountain. Then she quickly left, still nervous about being an impostor. She worried the students’ angry spirits might come looking for her if she stayed too long.
Arix thought to herself,
’Even dragon slayers become dragons eventually. I can’t believe I’m loving fooling others around now.’
Once she confirmed the area was safe, Arix slowed her pace and laughed at her childish behavior. Feeling better, she took out the card and looked at the location of the fifth badge.
"Training ground?" Arix was confused. She rubbed her eyes and looked again to make sure she saw it correctly.
’That’s the starting point. How could it be a badge location?’
Curious and puzzled, Arix decided to go back to the training ground to find out.
When Arix returned to the training ground, she easily found the fifth badge point by following the hints on the card. She was surprised to see that the instructor at this badge point was none other than her own instructor, Ortiz.
Ortiz saw Arix and smiled with a mix of surprise and satisfaction. "You came back quite fast. Is it just my badge that you need now?"
"Yes, it’s just the last badge left. Sir, tell me how I can get the badge from you," Arix said carefully, ready for a challenge.
"Take out your card," Ortiz said with a mysterious smile.
Arix almost thought she had misheard but instinctively handed over the card. In the next second, the missing badge symbol appeared on her card, completed by Ortiz’s badge.
The card then transformed, showing the number 8 on the front and the dire wolf emblem of the Hecaris Military Academy on the back.
"Sir... is this... kind of cheating really okay?" Arix stammered nervously, looking at the changed card in shock.
Ortiz, veins popping on his forehead, couldn’t hold back and knocked Arix on the head. "Gosh, why do you think we’re cheating? Am I really that bad in your eyes?"
Arix, holding her head in pain, pouted but dared not argue. She thought to herself,
’Sorry, but I thought you might be.’
She never said it out aloud, though.
"The fifth badge point can be the hardest or the easiest," Ortiz said, feeling the need to explain for the sake of his reputation.
Arix listened carefully.
"For the fifth badge point, the main task is to earn the instructor’s approval. Understand?" Ortiz said.
Arix nodded. She finally understood. This point was designed to ensure that even if a student couldn’t get any badges, they would still get one as a consolation.
No wonder this badge point seemed like a freebie compared to the first four. The academy was kind, but only to a certain extent.
After this, Arix had a lot of free time. She just had to stay at the training ground and wait for the competition to end. During this time, she saw many familiar faces returning, most of them looking battered and exhausted.
Even Drexel returned with a gloomy face, looking as if he had been through a rough time. He looked even more frustrated when he saw Arix.
Drexel was so disappointed at himself that he felt like coughing up blood. Even getting the easy badge from the instructor didn’t improve his mood much.
Not giving up, Drexel walked over to Arix and asked cautiously, "Arix, did you get all your badges?"
Arix smiled slightly and nodded, pretending to be modest. "Yes, and I finished eighth, so dear, you lost."
Drexel’s expression became even gloomier. After hesitating for a moment, he asked, "Arix, how did you get through the badge point in the cafeteria?"
This question darkened Arix’s face as well. Drexel didn’t need to ask further to know he had touched a sore spot.
But Drexel felt his pain was worse. He would lose his opticomputer from now on. At this moment, he felt a strange sense of desolation, as if he had lost everything.
In this competition, the hardest badge points were the cafeteria and the mountain top. If they had a choice, both Arix and Drexel would choose to tackle the mountain top ten times rather than go to the cafeteria once again.

chapters.title: Chapter 64: Sister Gwen
chapters.content:
Chapter 64: Sister Gwen
After the training competition ended, the next two days were the much-anticipated weekend rest days for the students.
On Saturday, nearly all the students chose to go to the bedmaker to retrieve their opticomputers. Then, they contacted their family and friends.
Arix also went to the bedmaker and got back her opticomputer. In addition to the one she won from Drexel in the bet, Arix now had two opticomputers.
However, since Drexel’s opticomputer was a bit shady, Arix decided not to use it and instead hid it in her Space Button.
But Arix was overjoyed to see her own opticomputer, treating it like a long-lost girlfriend, even giving it a little kiss.
As for who to contact first?
Arix had already decided—it had to be Sister Gwen and the seven little darlings!
After returning to the dorm with the opticomputer, Arix found that her roommates were all having video calls with their own friends and family. Everyone was considerate enough not to disturb each other.
Arix walked quietly to her bed, sat down, and started contacting Sister Gwen.
First, Arix turned on the opticomputer. Her fingers swiped down the virtual screen for a while before finding Sister Gwen’s contact icon. Arix tapped the video call button.
The ringing didn’t last long. Sister Gwen, far away on Planet Waste, quickly answered the call.
Seeing the familiar, kind face on the 3D virtual screen, Arix beamed and sweetly called out, "Sister, it’s me, Arix."
"I knew! Arix! How was training? Were you good? Did you hurt yourself? Was it tough?" Sister Gwen asked with concern.
Arix patiently answered each question.
Sister Gwen was delighted by the answers but then sighed a bit, saying, "Arix, tell your mom not to send me more stuff. The storage is already full."
In fact, Fleur’s packages were just fine, but Sister Gwen was used to being frugal, so she couldn’t bear to use most of the things, and they just kept piling up.
Arix’s eyes sparkled with amusement. Pretending to be troubled, she said, "But if Mom doesn’t send stuff, she’ll be upset. What should we do? Sister, maybe you could work on using up some of the stuff in the storage?"
Sister Gwen saw right through Arix’s little trick and chuckled, "I’m not senile yet, you little rascal. Fine, fine, let her send what she wants. I will just enjoy it for once."
"That’s the right way to think. We’re not around to take care of you. If you don’t even care about yourself, we’ll be so worried," Arix said, her tone full of affection.
"Here we go, you and your endless reasoning. I can’t win against you," Sister Gwen said with a teasing smile.
"That’s because what I say makes sense!" Arix replied with a playful hum, feeling quite pleased with herself.
Then Arix remembered that she hadn’t seen the seven little ones today and asked with some confusion, "Sister, where are the kids? Why haven’t I seen them today?"
"They’re still in class next door," Sister Gwen replied, her tone softening as she talked about the children.
"That’s fine, studying matters most. I’ll see them next time." Arix continued chatting with Sister Gwen for a while longer before ending the video call.
Arix spent the rest of the morning video chatting with her family. When her roommates went to the cafeteria for lunch, Arix hesitated for a moment before clicking on the icon for her puppy friend.
In no time, the 3D virtual screen lit up, and Cassian’s voice came through.
"Arix, how have you been lately?" Cassian asked with concern.
"Not good. The training is tough and exhausting, and there are no fluffy creatures to cuddle," Arix complained, hinting at something.
"Poor you. Why don’t you come to the Empire? I’ll take care of you, and you can cuddle with me," Cassian joked, but there was a hint of seriousness in his tone.
Arix burst out laughing at his words. "You don’t have to sell yourself like that."
"So, will you come?" Cassian asked hopefully, as if he had a tail, it would be wagging.
"No, I actually like the Alliance. How about you come to the Alliance? I’ll take care of you. I can groom you and give you massages every day. What do you think? Want to consider it?" Arix said, raising an eyebrow playfully.
"I’d love to, but I can’t leave the Empire right now. Unless you’re not afraid of being chased, how about we elope together?" Cassian’s eyes sparkled with excitement.
Hearing the word "chased," Arix’s smile froze. She suddenly remembered that the guy on the other end was the crown prince of the Empire. If she really ran off with the future Alpha, it wouldn’t just be a matter of being chased. There could be a full-blown war between the Alliance and the Empire.
The more she thought about it, the more horrifying it seemed. Arix shuddered and quickly said with righteous conviction, "Cassian, we are the pillars of the Empire and the Alliance’s future. We can’t abandon our responsibilities for our own needs! That would be wrong!"
Arix’s passionate speech left Cassian stunned. But thinking about his countless citizens, he realized Arix was right.
"Arix, you’re right. I was being narrow-minded," Cassian admitted seriously.
"It’s okay. Admitting your mistakes and correcting them is the greatest good," Arix said, breathing a sigh of relief as she realized she had successfully talked Cassian out of his crazy idea.
Inwardly, she patted herself on the back. She had just preserved the peace between the Empire and the Alliance!
"Your Highness, Your Majesty is looking for you," the voice of the Minister of Internal Affairs suddenly sounded outside Cassian’s room.
"You should go," Arix said considerately, not waiting for Cassian to speak first.
"Alright, Arix, goodbye," Cassian said reluctantly.
"Goodbye," Arix replied before ending the video call.
Staring at the darkened screen, she felt her stomach rumble with hunger. Deciding not to contact anyone else for now, Arix got up and headed to the cafeteria.
After eating, she returned to her dorm and started watching a live stream by a mecha maker.
As usual, Arix couldn’t help herself when she got excited or saw something interesting during the stream. She showered the streamer with gifts, causing her support to flood the chat. Before she knew it, Arix had become the top supporter for several novice mecha builders.

chapters.title: Chapter 65: The Insectoid’s Peculiarity
chapters.content:
Chapter 65: The Insectoid’s Peculiarity
While the students were enjoying their weekend, the air in a certain room at the Fifth Legion Hospital was getting awkward.
"You mean it came to you on its own, and Arix didn’t attack you on purpose?!" Rhea stared wide-eyed, a bit exasperated as she pointed at Cantet in shock.
"Yeah? Who told you that Arix attacked me on purpose?" Cantet asked, confused.
He wondered if someone was trying to harm his sister by misleading her into confronting Arix.
Rhea was speechless and accused, "Every time I asked you, you were dodging the question, so I thought you were scared of the Kering family and didn’t dare to say it."
"Come on, if I were really afraid of the Kering family, would I have competed with Kellan for so long?" Cantet felt a bit guilty at first but then puffed out his chest and retorted.
But then his gaze started to avoid hers again.
Afraid his sister would misunderstand further, Cantet decided to explain, "I tried to hypnotize Arix to see if I could get some dirt on Kellan. Who knew her psychic power level was higher than mine? If my psychic power hadn’t escaped quickly, I’d be in worse shape than just lying in bed for half a month."
"Hah! Now you’re proud of it?" Rhea rolled her eyes and then glared at Cantet, gritting her teeth, "Why didn’t you just explain this from the beginning?"
Hearing his sister’s accusation, Cantet’s eyes looked a bit pitiful, "How could I just tell everyone about such an embarrassing failure? It’s so humiliating."
"So, to save your face, now I’m in the hospital too. Are you happy now?" Rhea glared at Cantet, who was in the bed next to her.
Cantet turned over, showing his back to Rhea, pulled the blanket over his head, and muttered, "Fine, fine, I’ll tell you next time, okay?"
"You’re still hiding? Does it help? Now think about how to apologize to Arix." Rhea looked at the hiding Cantet, annoyed.
"But we’re the ones injured and in the hospital. Why should we apologize?" Cantet peeked out from under the blanket, looking defiant.
Rhea laughed angrily. She grabbed a pillow and threw it at Cantet, scolding, "Oh, you’ve got guts, Cantet. Blaming the victim now? If you weren’t my brother, I’d smack you."
"Fine, fine, I’ll apologize, okay?" Cantet caught the thrown pillow and reluctantly agreed.
Then he carefully handed the pillow back to his sister.
"Hmph! That’s more like it," Rhea said with a satisfied grunt.
Rhea placed the pillow back and lay on the bed in a comfortable position. She casually asked, "How should we apologize? Should we buy a gift?"
"Seriously, does an apology need a ceremony? Girl, keep it simple, please," Cantet was almost breaking down.
No one knew who put his sister and him in the same hospital room. He felt like he was being pranked.
At the legion hospital, Arix sneezed several times. Rubbing her nose, she thought,
’It’s getting colder; maybe I should wear an extra layer tomorrow.’
Meanwhile, at the border where the Fifth Legion was located...
The insectoids launched another swarm, attempting to invade the Alliance’s planets.
Facing the fierce and relentless attack from the insectoids, Kellan led a mothership and twelve warships. They floated firm at the border, like a barrier, keeping the terrifying swarm outside the Alliance territory.
In the mothership’s main control room, Kellan observed the large virtual map and commanded the battle mechas on the carrier deck. He coordinated their attacks and retreats based on real-time battlefield information.
"501 Mecha Team, support 601 Mecha Team, over."
"503 Mecha Team, retreat from the battlefield, 603 Mecha Team, fill in, over."
"505 Mecha Team, watch out, another batch of insectoids incoming, over."
"505 received, over."Kellan finished directing the mecha teams and then began commanding the twelve warships.
"All warships, increase firepower! Activate particle beams, activate particle beams!"
"Ship 1, received, over."
"Ship 2, received, over."
"Ship 3, received, over."
The power of the particle beams was equivalent to modern nuclear bombs. Following the commander’s orders, all warships activated their particle beams.
Accelerators on the warships generated high-energy particles, which then gathered into dense beams. These beams were launched consecutively, hitting large areas of insectoids.
Time passed minute by minute, and by late afternoon, the swarm started to retreat from the Fifth Legion border.
As the insectoids fully withdrew, everyone finally relaxed, breathing a collective sigh of relief.
In the mothership’s main control room, Kellan handed over command to other officers. Then, exhausted, he left to rest in their quarters with his deputy, Basell.
Walking down the corridor of the mothership, Kellan suddenly asked, "Basell, have there been any unusual activities from the insectoids recently?"
"Sir, the insectoids have been persistently trying to invade the Alliance. Just today’s attack is the third this week. I’m afraid they’ll keep attacking," Basell reported the current situation.
"What about the other legions?" Kellan asked after a moment of thought.
"Though they also face insectoid swarms, they aren’t nearly as frequent as what the we’re experiencing," Basell replied, still somewhat puzzled.
Hearing this, Kellan rubbed his temples, forming a suspicion in his mind.
It seemed likely that the insectoids had learned about the Alliance having a Supergiant+ psychic power user—his sister, Arix. For now, they were launching open swarm attacks. But if these direct assaults failed, Kellan feared the insectoids might resort to more covert tactics next.
After all, it was much easier to eliminate a major threat before it fully matured.
In contrast to the gunfire and explosions at the border, the training base was peaceful and calm.
Arix yawned as she got out of bed, stretched lazily, and went to the sink to freshen up.
After washing, she felt much more awake and carried the basin back to her dormitory. Just as she was about to put the basin down, her opticomputer on her left wrist suddenly rang.
"Hmm?" Arix was puzzled for a moment. She put the basin into the cupboard and then opened the virtual screen of the opticomputer.

chapters.title: Chapter 66: Double-standard Sims
chapters.content:
Chapter 66: Double-standard Sims
Seeing that it was a video call from Smis, Arix quickly answered without delay.
"Good afternoon," Sims greeted, his eyes shadowed with dark circles. Despite his exhaustion, he forced a smile for his favorite little Moon Pie.
"When was the last time you slept?" Arix asked with a mix of concern and reproach as she looked at Sims on the virtual screen.
"Not long, just two days," Sims immediately explained, seeing that Arix was unhappy.
His explanation only made Arix’s expression darker.
"Is the Chemistry Department busy again?" Arix asked, her face serious.
She knew firsthand how demanding the Chemistry Department could be. When things got busy there, it was like people were treated like beasts of burden.
Although Arix was just asking, she was already certain of the answer.
Sims opened his mouth to respond but couldn’t find a way to argue. Finally, he admitted with a sigh, "Yes, it’s very busy. Recently, the insectoids have been aggressively attacking the Alliance’s borders for some unknown reason. Although the casualties aren’t high, the demand for potions has been increasing."
"I’m going to ask my instructor for leave right now. Wait for me," Arix said, starting to head out of the dormitory. She suddenly paused and turned back to Sims, asking, "By the way, should I bring my cousin along?"
"You mean Varden? No need. He came here last night," Sims said, then turned the screen to show Varden, who was busy working nearby.
In the video, Varden’s hair was messy, and his dark circles were so pronounced that even his glasses couldn’t hide them.
But when he heard Arix’s words, Varden still took a moment to look up. He looked at Arix and said, "Yeah, thank you for wanting to assign me more work, I guess?", his voice dripping with sarcasm.
His glare scared Arix a bit, and she quickly turned off the opticomputer.
She patted her chest, still feeling nervous. She was glad she hung up fast, or else Varden might have crawled out of the screen to hit her.
In the Chemistry Department, Varden looked at the suddenly dark screen and shook his head with a mix of frustration and amusement. "Varden, be gentle with girls, would you? Or you may be alone for the rest of your life," said Sims.
He saw his beloved Arix looking scared, and he immediately felt sorry for her and complained to Varden.
"Grandpa, does she look scared to you? She’s clearly feeling guilty," Varden replied, looking helplessly at his grandfather. It seemed like his grandpa favored Arix so much that he almost thought Arix was his real granddaughter.
"Even so, be nice to Moon Pie. She’s suffered too much when she was a kid, after all. You should be more gentle," Sims said, looking at Varden as if he didn’t understand.
"Then what about cousin Jane? She’s also a girl. Why don’t you treat her gently?" Varden retorted, staring straight at Sims.
"Jane is an exception. Look at her. Does she seem like a girl to you? As a child of our family, she doesn’t study potions and instead went to other department. And not just any department, but the Mecha Combat Department! She’s like a wild tiger, always fighting," Sims said through his grifted teeth.
Before meeting Arix, Jane was his ideal apprentice, but she insisted on joining the combat department.
"They’re both girls. Why make exceptions? Grandpa, you’re being unfair," Varden said with disdain.
"You cheeky boy, are you itching for a beating? How dare you talk to your grandpa like that?" Sims glared at him.
"...," Varden chose to stay silent. He didn’t want to provoke his grandpa any further.
Seeing his grandson back down, Sims snorted in satisfaction. "Arix should be here soon. I’ll go meet her. You keep making potions," Sims said, his tone softening. Then he happily walked out of the Chemistry Department.
Varden watched his grandpa leave and rolled his eyes. Then he focused on making potions.
Outside the Chemistry Department, Arix peeked inside cautiously, afraid of being caught by Varden. After a while, she didn’t see any sign of him and felt relieved. She patted her chest again and walked inside.
"You’re here!" Sims said, looking up from helping a chemist with potion problems. He spotted his beloved Arix and greeted her warmly.
"Grandpa Sims! Long time no see. Did you miss me?" Arix said with a big, playful smile.
"Of course I did! From now on, just call me Sims. It sounds closer," Sims replied, walking over and gently patting Arix’s head with a kind smile.
"Okay," Arix nodded obediently. Then she continued, "Would you take me to the potion room? I want to start making potions right away."
