The third was the Tiger Legion, led by tigermen. Most of the Empire’s priests came from the tiger clan, and they were the only ones the dragonkins dared not provoke.
The fourth was the Phoenix Legion, led by birdmen. They were generally indifferent to everything except insectoids, which they loved to study and find new ways to eat.
The fifth was the Merman Legion, led by mermen. Simple-minded and strong, they were close to the dragonkins and often used by them as the front line in battles.
The sixth was the Elf Legion, led by elves. They were the pacifists of the Empire, often at odds with dragonkins but close to the tigermen.
"Arix, if you ever encounter dragonkins, be very careful. They are all bad news," Mama Tiger warned.
"Okay, Mama Tiger," Arix nodded obediently.
"And remember, this planet is under the jurisdiction of tigermen. Since you are a tigerman cub, you can ask them for help if needed. They should assist you as a fellow tribe member," Mama Tiger added, worrying over every detail to ensure Arix’s safety.
"Got it," Arix said, feeling deeply touched by Mama Tiger’s clear love and concern. She nuzzled Mama Tiger’s neck with her small head.
Mama Tiger felt Arix’s affection, stopped, and nuzzled back lovingly. The sunlight filtered through the leaves, casting a warm glow on the two of them, making the moment feel timeless.
Unfortunately, beautiful moments are fleeting, and before they knew it, they had reached the edge of the forest. Arix jumped down from Mama Tiger’s back, lingering with her for a bit longer before finally saying, "Mama Tiger, I have to go now."
"Take care and stay safe," Mama Tiger said, raising a big paw to gently rub Arix’s head.
"Okay," Arix said as she looked at Mama Tiger one last time before turning and walking away.
After a few steps, Arix suddenly heard Mama Tiger call out. She stopped and turned, thinking there was something Mama Tiger had forgotten to tell her.
"Arix!" Mama Tiger sat down, looking at Arix tenderly.
"Mama Tiger, what’s wrong?" Arix asked, puzzled.
Mama Tiger smiled, her eyes soft and tender. She let out a light growl, then turned and disappeared back into the forest.
"Thank you for saving my little ones."
Mama Tiger had long realized that, since only Arix and the scent of the two poachers were outside the cave, it must have been Arix who had saved her cubs, not someone else Arix had claimed.
Hearing Mama Tiger’s words, Arix’s pupils constricted, and a wave of sentiments surged in her heart. Tears began to flow down her cheeks as she watched the direction Mama Tiger had left.
Then, resolutely, she turned and ran forward.
She couldn’t stay any longer; otherwise, she would find it too hard to leave.
As Arix ran, crying, she made a firm decision in her heart. In the future, she would ensure that the Empire’s Celesterrors were also protected.
Though Celesterrors were fierce on the outside, they were pure and smart inside. They deserved to be treated kindly.

chapters.title: Chapter 98: Purity of Bloodline
chapters.content:
Chapter 98: Purity of Bloodline
Arix had no clue how long she’d been running. When she finally spotted the city walls, she took a deep breath and slowed down.She found a tree to hide behind and peeked out at the city gate.
Two knights in full armor stood guard at the entrance, with a few soldiers managing the entrance fees. A line of therianthropes waited, each using an opticomputer to pay a credit point before entering.
Arix held back, watching the therians with interest. She remembered reading on an opticomputer that the purer a therian’s bloodline, the more human-like their transformation. Therians with less pure bloodlines kept more of their animal traits.
She spotted a child with animal ears and a fox tail waiting in line.
To Arix, the child was adorable, but the other therians seemed to view him with disdain. As the child’s turn came to enter, a burly therian kicked him aside and cut in line.
The other therians didn’t react. They were used to this and didn’t show any sympathy. The line-cutter had only a slight therian feature at the corner of his eye, showing his high bloodline purity. No one wanted to mess with him over a low-purity child.
In fact, many thought this was just the way things should be. To them, therians with low bloodline purity didn’t deserve to stand with the rest. The poorly dressed child seemed used to this treatment. He quietly got up and moved to the back of the line.
Arix frowned but didn’t jump in. She had the power to help, but how could she make sure the bully wouldn’t take it out on the child later? Sometimes, trying to help could make things worse.
If she got the chance later, she might teach that therian a lesson.
Arix despised bullies. She dealt with them whenever she could.
But right now, her main goal was to find an opticomputer and contact her parents in the Alliance, who were probably worried sick.
She looked down at her own fluffy white fur and small wings. If she went out like this, she’d be caught in no time.
"Sophia, can I retract these wings?" Arix asked in her mind.
"Just think about it," Sophia replied calmly.
"Thanks, Sophia," Arix said. She then thought,
’Retract, retract.’
A faint white light flashed, and her wings disappeared into her body.
Arix twisted her body left and right, making sure her wings were really gone. Then she let out a joyful howl.
Next, she spotted a nearby coal pile. She closed her eyes, took a deep breath, and rolled in it several times. The once cute little white tiger was now like a filthy, unrecognizable stray cat.
Happy with her new look, Arix relaxed and waited by the roadside, keeping an eye out for a chance to sneak into the city.
After a bit, an elderly therian pushing a two-wheeled cart full of vegetables slowly came by. Arix’s eyes lit up, and she quickly burrowed into the pile of vegetables, hiding quietly.
Luckily, the therian inspections here weren’t as strict as those in the Alliance. The old man paid the fee, the soldier at the gate glanced at the vegetables, and let him through.
Once inside, Arix breathed a sigh of relief. As they passed a dim alley, she quickly slipped out and hid in the shadows. Everything was going according to plan. Now, she needed to find an opticomputer to contact her parents and let them know she was safe.
New opticomputers had psychic power bindings, acting like password locks that were impossible to bypass. Older models, though, were much easier to hack. Arix had already figured out where to find one.
It didn’t take long for her to choose a target—a poor elderly therian who rarely used his opticomputer, usually leaving it on his bed. Arix waited by the window, and when the old man lay down to rest, she whispered an apology in her mind.
She then snuck into the room, grabbed the opticomputer in her mouth, and dashed to the basement.
Once she confirmed it was safe, she turned on the device and dialed her mother’s number. A video call request was sent.
Back at the Kering Family home...
Ever since they heard Arix might have died, the whole household had been drowning in sorrow.
The masters of the house were heartbroken, and even the butler and maids were visibly upset.
The death of a 15-year-old girl, even if she were a stranger, would make anyone sad. But this was their young lady, their sweet and unfortunate daughter. Everyone felt a deep sense of loss.
Fleur, after hearing about her daughter’s disappearance yet again, had locked herself in her bedroom, silently crying while holding Arix’s belongings.
"Arix..." Fleur whispered hoarsely.
"Ma’am, there is an incoming video call from an unknown opticomputer number. Would you like to accept it?"
The opticomputer on Fleur’s nightstand suddenly rang, its soft sound breaking the silence of the room.
Fleur glanced at the opticomputer. Assuming it was another marketing call, she ignored it, continuing to reminisce about her daughter.
"Ma’am, there is an incoming video call from an unknown opticomputer number. Would you like to accept it?"
The opticomputer kept ringing. Fleur frowned and finally picked it up, answering the call. As soon as the video connected, a small, pitch-black animal appeared on the screen. It looked like a stray cat.
Fleur’s gaze remained indifferent. Since her daughter disappeared, she felt detached from the world. Everything seemed dull and lifeless to her, unable to stir any interest.
However, when Arix saw her mother’s haggard appearance, she immediately panicked. She even forgot she had transformed into a therian and quickly let out a howl, "Awwooo(Mom, are you okay)?"
Fleur seemed to get it, her body trembling all of a sudden. She stared at the stray cat in the video, her eyes wide with disbelief.
"Arix?" she called out, her voice a mix of exhausted sorrow and ecstatic joy.
Arix was just as shocked that Fleur could understand her.
But there was no time to dwell on it. She quickly reassured Fleur, "Mom, don’t worry. I fell into a wormhole that took me to the Empire. But I’m safe now. Please, don’t worry."
Fleur smiled in relief, but tears still fell. How could she not know if her daughter was truly safe? Arix wouldn’t be in this state if she was fine.
"Mom, why are you crying? I really am safe. Please, don’t cry," Arix said, clumsily trying to wipe away Fleur’s tears on the virtual screen.
Of course, it didn’t work since it was just a screen. Yet, Arix’s attempt made Fleur laugh through her tears. "I’m not crying; these are happy tears. My silly Arix."
Seeing her mom laugh, Arix felt better. Then, she asked, "Mom, how can you understand me? Are you a therian too?"
Arix wasn’t expecting much when she asked, but Fleur nodded, her face a mix of emotions. "My parents were from the Empire’s Tiger Clan. Your grandfather was the clan’s strongest tigerman. They fell in love and had me. But one day, your grandmother got very sick and was near death. To save her, your grandfather joined the Moon Goddess Temple and became a priest. Priests belong to the Moon Goddess for life, so they can’t marry or love anyone again. If they do, both lovers are hunted by the temple. That’s why your grandparents were separated. Heartbroken, your grandmother took me to live in the Alliance, but she still passed away when I was eighteen."
Hearing this, Arix fumed. "Mom, can we destroy the Moon Goddess Temple? Banning love? So old-fashioned! Ridiculous!"
Fleur laughed softly, calming her down. "Arix, your grandparents weren’t wrong, and neither was the Moon Goddess Temple. The temple just offered a choice, and your grandfather made his. There’s no right or wrong in that. Your grandmother got to live a few more years because of it. We shouldn’t destroy a place that helped us."
"But the Moon Goddess Temple kept Grandpa and Grandma apart," Arix argued, still upset.
Fleur spoke softly, trying to calm Arix down. "But think about it. If the Moon Goddess Temple hadn’t saved Grandma, Grandpa couldn’t have been with her."
"Alright, fine. If I had been there, they wouldn’t have had to part," Arix muttered under her breath.
"Arix, let the past stay in the past. The best ending is when no one regrets their choices. Now, let’s focus on you. Stay where you are, and I’ll have my cousin Sunak come to pick you up," Fleur instructed.
Although Arix had no idea who that was, she nodded obediently.
"Good girl," Fleur said with a smile before ending the call.
Arix then sent videos to other family members. Sadly, none of them could understand what she was saying, not even Kellan.
Luckily, she could still type with her paws; otherwise, she wouldn’t have been able to assure them she was safe.

chapters.title: Chapter 99: Getting Saved
chapters.content:
Chapter 99: Getting Saved
When it was Drexel’s turn, Arix decided to keep her identity a secret to tease him a bit. As soon as the video connected, however, she saw Drexel’s scruffy face and dark circles under his eyes.
Arix started to cry.
"Awooo..." she whimpered.
Drexel frowned, feeling his hallucinations getting worse. Ever since Arix went missing, he often felt like she was calling him or thought he saw her waiting for him.
Rubbing his temples in exhaustion, he looked at the stray cat on the virtual screen, which seemed to be crying.
"Hey, little thing, do you need something?" Drexel’s voice was hoarse, but he tried to speak gently.
His question only made Arix cry harder. She felt guilty for wanting to tease her brother, knowing he must be worried sick about her.
Large tears rolled down Arix’s cheeks as she cried out, "AWWWWOO(I’m Arix! You don’t understand me, do you? I’ll send you words)."
Drexel looked up, surprised at the tiger on the screen. This time he was sure he wasn’t hallucinating. It seemed like the little cub was really talking and claimed to be Arix.
"If you’re really Arix, nod your head and raise a paw," Drexel said, staring intently at the black stray cat on the screen.
Arix quickly did as he asked. Drexel jumped up, looking like he’d just gotten a shot of adrenaline. He grabbed the opticomputer and ran outside, eager to share the good news with their parents.
As he reached the living room, he saw their parents and older brother were also there.
Excitedly, he shouted, "Mom, Dad, Kellan, it’s Arix! Look, it’s Arix!!!"
To Drexel’s surprise, his parents and Kellan remained calm, nodding to indicate they already knew.
Drexel was so confused.
’Why isn’t anyone excited?’
Thinking they hadn’t heard him correctly, Drexel repeated, "Mom, Dad, Kellan, this is Arix! Arix!!!"
This time, Fleur, feeling a bit impatient, replied, "We know. We found out a while ago."
Drexel stood there dumbfounded for a moment, then, realizing what was happening, his expression turned fierce. He looked at Arix on the virtual screen with a menacing grin, "Arix? So I was the last to know?"
Arix: .....
’I think I’m in trouble.’
Arix blinked nervously. Trying to act casual, she used her paw to smooth the fur on her ear, playing up her stray cat persona to avoid Drexel’s questions.
"Come on, stop pretending," Drexel said, clearly irritated but with a hint of laughter. "Using your paw like that, isn’t that kind of dirty?"
’Dirty?’
Arix’s eyes went wide, like she’d been struck by lightning. Her heart sank.
’No one should call a cute cub dirty!’
Fuming, she ended the video call, not wanting to see Drexel’s face any longer. Drexel, staring at the suddenly dark screen, looked confused. Everything seemed fine a moment ago.
Nearby, Kellan chuckled. "That’s what you get for calling a girl dirty. It’s like telling a guy he’s useless."
Drexel rubbed his nose, feeling guilty. But he was relieved to know Arix was okay.
Meanwhile, Arix tried to reach Cassian, but the video call wouldn’t connect. After several attempts, she gave up and sent a message instead, letting him know she was safe.
Having contacted everyone she could, Arix returned the opticomputer to the old therian and waited outside by the gate for the legendary Sunak to arrive.
Half an hour later, a young man with silver hair and blue eyes, dressed in an Empire captain’s uniform, appeared. Arix looked at his white hair and blue eyes, matching her own.
This had to be her savior, Sunak!
Excited, Arix stood up, ready to greet him with a loving hug. But he walked right past her.
Arix was stunned.
’Am I wrong? Or is his vision that bad?’
"Where’s my cousin’s daughter? I don’t see her." The silver-haired, blue-eyed man looked around, confused.
Arix sighed.
’Yep, this was definitely Sunak.’
As Sunak walked further away, Arix finally shouted, "I’m over here!"
Sunak turned at the sound of her voice, finally spotting the little black furball squatting by the gate.
"Arix?" Sunak called uncertainly.
"Yep," Arix responded coolly.
Sunak’s face lit up with excitement. He rushed over to pick her up, but at the last moment, he hesitated, pulled back his hands, and awkwardly cleared his throat.
"Uh, Arix, what’s with this look? It’s... unique," Sunak said, trying to hide his distaste. But his eyes kept straying from the soot-covered Arix.
With a vein popping on her forehead, Arix jumped straight into Sunak’s arms and rolled around a few times on purpose.
Sunak was speechless. The urge to drop her crossed his mind.
But his clothes were already dirty, and dropping his niece on the ground wouldn’t fix that. Resigned, Sunak held the filthy Arix and headed back to his fleet.
He had been in the middle of a mission when he got a distress call from his cousin. Since it was on his way, he asked his admiral for leave to pick up his niece.
Arix, snug in Sunak’s arms, was carried onto the Empire’s space carrier.
"Arix, you need to behave on the carrier. Once I finish my mission, I’ll take you home," Sunak coaxed, as if she were a child.
"Don’t worry, Uncle Sunak. I’ll be super well-behaved," Arix said, puffing out her little chest with determination.
Sunak patted Arix’s head, thinking his niece seemed better-behaved than the boys back home.
He found a resting room for Arix and waited outside while she took a bath, planning to take her to report to the admiral afterward.
Arix bathed quickly. Before long, she pushed open the door and jumped out of the bathroom, shaking the water off her fur.
Seeing the safe and comfortable surroundings, Arix decided to let out her small wings. Keeping them tucked in all the time was uncomfortable.
"After a bath, you’re much cuter," Sunak said with a satisfied smile, reaching to pick up Arix and blow-dry her fur.
But this time, Arix turned the tables. She quickly jumped away from Sunak’s bear hug, looking at him with disdain. "Don’t hug me, you’re dirty!"
Sunak was taken aback. He looked down at his soot-covered uniform and felt amused.
"You’ve got some nerve complaining. Who’s little troublemaker doing this?" Sunak said irritably.
Arix’s eyes darted around, pretending not to understand what Sunak was saying.
Sunak rolled his eyes but didn’t argue with the young one.
He took out a new opticomputer and Space Button from his Space Button and placed them on the bed.
"These are your opticomputer and Space Button. The fur dryer is over there. Use it before you get on the bed. I’m going to take a shower," Sunak instructed carefully.
The fur dryer was a must-have in the Empire. Whether furry or not, all therians liked to use it. It was great for drying fur, skin, or scales.
Seeing the opticomputer and Space Button, Arix’s high-and-mighty demeanor vanished. She smiled like a pleased puppy and said, "Alright, Sunak, go take your shower."
Sunak, looking at his niece’s sudden change in attitude, snorted.
With a resigned smile, he took off his jacket and headed into the bathroom.
Arix’s smile vanished as soon as Sunak stepped into the bathroom. She swiftly opened the fur dryer, hopped in, and pressed the button. Warm air surrounded her, drying her fur in no time.
Once done, Arix jumped out of the dryer and onto the bed, opening her new opticomputer. She followed the setup instructions, binding it with her psychic power. Then, she entered Fleur’s opticomputer number and initiated a video call.
The call connected quickly. Before Fleur could speak, Arix let out a cute whine, "Mom, do you miss me?"
Fleur chuckled but didn’t respond immediately. Thaddeus leaned into the frame with a big grin, "Sweetheart, do you miss your dad?"
Arix nodded enthusiastically, her tiny voice sweet as she replied, "Yes, I miss you both so much!"
This adorable display made Thaddeus and Fleur beam with joy, their faces lighting up with smiles.

chapters.title: Chapter 100: Pontifex of the Future
chapters.content:
Chapter 100: Pontifex of the Future
The three of them chatted for a bit, exchanging greetings until they were about to end the video call.Fleur gave a final reminder, "Arix, I asked our people, and the blessing ceremony is next month. You should stay in the Empire and have fun with Sunak this month. I’ve already taken care of your leave from the military school. Come back to class when your therian transformation is over."
"Okay, I got it. Bye, Mom," Arix said obediently, nodding her little head and giving a small howl.
After Fleur ended the call with a smile, Sunak came out of the bathroom. He was still damp, and he casually asked, "Were you talking to your mom?"
"Yeah, she said some ceremony is next month, and she was afraid I’ll have to be in your care this month," Arix explained with a small howl.
"She’s always so considerate. I love kids and we’re gonna have so much fun." Sunak said nonchalantly as he walked into the drying box. He lay down on the drying chair for a few minutes and came out completely dry.
Arix, thinking about her own physical power accident, kept quiet.
"Come on, I’ll take you to meet our admiral. We should report your presence to him, especially given your special status," Sunak said, picking Arix up and carrying her toward the admiral’s meeting room.
’Admiral?’
Arix remembered that people at this rank were usually old grandpa types. The Empire’s admiral was probably a respected elder therian as well.
"By the way, Arix, when you meet the admiral, don’t do anything disrespectful. If you annoy him, he might not let you stay on the mothership," Sunak warned.
"Hmph, no way," Arix huffed arrogantly. All the elders at home adored her because she was polite and talented. All the older loved her!
Arix’s assumption was just partly right; when she actually met the admiral, she quietly took back her words.
The person in front of her, with snow-white hair and an icy, ethereal demeanor, was the last person Arix would consider as an admiral before.
Arix turned her head to look at Sunak, incredulously howling, "Is he really the admiral??"
Sunak, not knowing why Arix was asking this, nodded affirmatively.
Once she was sure there was no mistake, Arix turned back, carefully observing the Empire’s admiral.
He looked to be around just twenty years old, with chiseled features and an exceptionally handsome face. His slightly prominent brow bone framed a pair of ice-blue eyes colder than millennia-old glacier, and his thin lips added to his cold demeanor. His entire look exuded a ’keep away’ vibe.
He was cold, but really good-looking.
Arix’s heart was pounding wildly. Since arriving in the interstellar era, this was the second exceptionally handsome male she had encountered.
The first one she met was Cassian, and the other one was the Empire’s admiral in front of her.
If Cassian was like the god of the sun—noble, handsome, and gentle—then the admiral before her was like the moon in the deep night. He was so graceful that any closer look at him felt like a desecration. Even one extra glance seemed disrespectful.
Sunak had no idea that Arix was so mesmerized that she was almost drooling. He respectfully addressed the admiral, "Sir, this is my niece Arix. She is the granddaughter of the Fifth Legion admiral from the Alliance. She’s a special kid, so I brought her to report to you."
Hearing she was the Fifth Legion admiral’s granddaughter, Scion’s emotionless eyes, as cold and deep as a frozen pond, finally looked at the little one before him. His gaze softened a bit when he saw that Arix was just a cub. "No problem, just take good care of her."
"Yes, thank you, sir. I’ll take my leave now." Sunak placed his right hand on his chest in salute. Then he turned and carried Arix out of the meeting room.
On the way back to the resting quarters, Arix looked up and asked, "Sunak, the Empire’s admiral is so young. And why does he seem so distant? Did he have a rough childhood?"
As Arix asked, her mind had already conjured up dozens of dramatic scenarios, mostly involving childhood trauma or later life events, with family harm being the most likely cause.
"Give me a break," Sunak rolled his eyes. "The admiral’s status in the clan is second only to the Pontifex. Even the clan leader treats him with utmost respect. As for his personality, most pontifexs are like that."
"Pontifex? But isn’t he the admiral?" Arix asked, her eyes widening in surprise.
"He was, well, sort of. The admirals were raised to be the Pontifexs. There’s currently no one qualified to lead the Tiger Legion, so he’s temporarily acting as admiral. When the Pontifex steps down or a suitable therian is found to replace the admiral, the current admiral will return to the Moon Goddess Temple as the Pontifex’s successor," Sunak explained in rare detail.
"Okay," Arix’s heart, which had been racing like a deer, suddenly came to a halt.
To Arix, a pontifex was akin to a pastor from her past life. She never imagined someone as hot as the admiral would choose such a restrictive path.
Sunak noticed the disappointed little tiger in his arms. He raised an eyebrow with a light, knowing smile.
The admiral was perfect in many ways, but that face of his was a real troublemaker. It was better to give Arix a heads-up for peace of mind.
Having been around the admiral for a long time, Sunak was well aware of how attractive the admiral was to females, from toothless old ladies to toothless toddlers. No one could resist the admiral’s charm.
Admiral Scion was the kind of man who could make even the most confident playboy feel inadequate and teary-eyed. However, he had one major flaw: his future role as the Pontifex.
Any woman who liked the admiral would instantly give up once she learned he was destined to become the Pontifex. This tactic had never failed Sunak. No woman would want to fall for a man who was fated to devote his life to the Moon Goddess.
Arix had no idea what Sunak was thinking. After sulking for a bit, she put the matter out of her mind. Right now, her only focus was on food. She had only nibbled on some vegetables and an apple since morning, and her stomach was practically empty.

chapters.title: Chapter 101: The Starship Carrier
chapters.content:
Chapter 101: The Starship Carrier
"Uncle Sunak, I’m hungry," Arix said, whining a little.
"Alright, let’s go get some food. You can meet everyone along the way," Sunak said with a gentle smile, affectionately ruffling Arix’s little head.
With that, they stopped chatting and headed straight for the military cafeteria.
The cafeteria of the Empire and the cafeteria of the Alliance have their unique vibes.
If the Alliance’s cafeteria is all about complicated cuisine, then the Empire’s cafeteria is a buffet of all kinds of raw foods. Think medium rare steak, fresh salads, fruits and nuts—all in one place.
Arix had a hunch that this variety might be due to the Empire’s diverse therian soldiers. Herbivores stick to fruits and veggies, carnivores go straight for the meat, and omnivores, like rabbit, dog, and cat therians, munch on a bit of everything.
Empire soldiers are super friendly to kids, so when they spotted Arix, they couldn’t help but gather around, eager to pet the little one and ask questions.
"Wow, Sunak, who’s this cute little one?" A rabbit therian soldier exclaimed, eyes sparkling as they admired Arix.
"This is my cousin’s child. She’s busy, so I’m helping out for a month," Sunak replied, grinning.
"We’re on a mission. Isn’t it risky to have a kid around?" a fox therian soldier asked, still gently rubbing Arix’s head.
"It’s okay, this mission isn’t tough. Once it’s done, I’ll take her back to the clan," Sunak assured them with a calm smile.
"It’s rare to see such a beautiful young one. Her bloodline must be very pure, right?" Another soldier chimed in, eyes bright with curiosity.
"We’ll check when we get back to the clan. But she’s hungry now, so I have to go," Sunak said, finding an excuse to leave.
"Alright, don’t let the little one go hungry," the soldiers agreed, stepping aside reluctantly.
After their meal, Sunak took Arix to the resting room. He left a quick note saying he had some business to attend to, and told Arix to play alone and not wander off. Then, he hurried out.
Arix waited until Sunak left. She then jumped off the bed, opened the door, and slipped out. After all, this was a starship carrier—too exciting to miss out on exploring.
The starship carrier is a massive space-aircraft combo. It usually doesn’t operate solo but with other warships, forming a fleet that can search, track, lock onto, and attack enemy targets within thousands of kilometers.
It looks like a huge, dark polyhedron. Its deck was on one of the surface. The deck wasn’t a channel just for annihilation spacecrafts but also for mechas. So, there was bound to be lots of mecha to see. If lucky, Arix might even catch a mecha fight.
Arix’s eyes sparkled with excitement, quickly darting through the starship carrier’s corridors.
The busy Empire soldiers thought the little one was just playing and didn’t pay much attention. They even kindly pointed out places where she could find fun things to do. Arix responded with a sweet little howl of thanks.
But when everything seems to go smoothly, surprises are bound to happen.
Turning a corner too quickly, Arix collided with someone and, being so light, she was sent flying. Before she knew what happened, she was caught by someone using psychic power and then held in his arms.
"Awwo?" Arix rubbed her little head, wincing from the collision. Looking up in confusion, she saw who it was and froze in fear.
"Ad...admiral?" Arix stammered, trembling all over. Her voice shook, and even her little paws were quivering.
’Oh no,’
she thought.
’Will I be thrown off the starship carrier? Sunak has warned me repeatedly not to bother the admiral.’
"Sir, are you okay?" Chris, the admiral’s aide, asked anxiously.
"I’m fine," Scion replied, waving off his concerned aide. Then he looked down at the little one in his arms.
Seeing Arix’s fear, Scion gently rubbed her head and softly asked, "Where’s Sunak? Why are you running around alone?"
Realizing the admiral wasn’t mad, Arix breathed a sigh of relief. "Sunak went to do something. I just wanted to explore the starship carrier. Can I, Admiral? If not, I’ll go back to the resting room," she said, her ears drooping, showing how much she didn’t want to.
Looking at the adorable little one from his own clan, Scion’s cold eyes softened. He patted Arix’s head and asked, "Do you want to go around with me?"
"Really?" Arix tilted her head, looking at Scion in disbelief.
"Of course," Scion confirmed with a nod.
"Wow, that’s awesome!" Arix exclaimed, bouncing happily in Scion’s arms.
Watching the joyful little one, a small smile appeared on Scion’s face.
For the rest of the afternoon, Arix stayed in Scion’s arms, following him everywhere.
When Scion was busy, he would put Arix down to play on her own. Arix behaved well, showing interest mainly in the machinery without causing trouble.
Scion felt a rare warmth toward the well-behaved young one. By the time he returned Arix to the resting room, their bond had grown closer.
"Can you take me to hang out again tomorrow?" Arix asked sweetly. She rubbed her head against Scion, reluctant to part so soon.
Scion smiled slightly and nodded, "Sure."
"Great, you promised, no backing out!" Arix cheered, jumping out of Scion’s arms and heading back into the resting room.
As Scion looked at his now empty arms, a strange sense of emptiness washed over him. He closed his eyes, and when he opened them again, he was back to being the cold admiral. "Let’s go," Scion said calmly to his aide.
"Yes, sir," Captain Chris replied respectfully.
Just as Arix returned to the room and saw Sunak, her smile froze. She stood nervously against the wall, looking ready to bolt at any moment.
"Had a lot of fun, huh? What did I tell you about running around? You almost explored the entire starship carrier," Sunak said, giving Arix a death glare.
He had figured it out by now: this little one had the most obedient face but the most rebellious heart.

chapters.title: Chapter 102: Everybody’s Favorite
chapters.content:
Chapter 102: Everybody’s Favorite
Arix’s eyes darted around nervously. Then, with a bit of hesitation, they shuffled over to Sunak’s side.
Rubbing their furry body against Sunak, Arix spoke in a sugary, pleading voice, "Sunak, don’t be mad. I was just bored in the room and needed a little fresh air."
"And besides, I’m still just a little cub. If I stay cooped up all the time, I’ll get depressed and lose my fur." Arix’s voice mixed soft pleading with a touch of stubbornness. Her eyes welled up with tears, making them look even more pitiful.
Sunak clenched their fists, trying to stay firm, but he couldn’t resist for long. He sighed and scooped Arix up into his arms, "Arix, you need to remember you’re still a cub and have to listen to the adults, okay?"
’But I’m over eighteen now!’
Arix complained inwardly, but she kept an innocent and obedient expression on their face, nodding dutifully.
Sunak looked at Arix, seeing an expression that said,
’I’ll listen, but I’ll definitely do it again.’
Frustrated, Sunak ruffled Arix’s hair roughly until Arix squirmed and almost nipped at them.
"Going out is fine, but you have to tell me first. If I can’t find you, I’ll get worried, got it?" Sunak tried to sound stern.
"Got it, got it," Arix pouted, using their paws to smooth their ruffled fur.
"You cheeky brat. Alright, go play, I’m leaving." With a final playful ruffle of Arix’s fur, Sunak slipped out the door.
"Awoo!" Arix growled in frustration, baring her teeth, wishing she could bite Sunak for that.
Three days passed with Arix following Scion around, exploring every place of the starship carrier. During that time, the Empire soldiers grew fond of the adorable cub, often stopping to ruffle Arix’s head whenever they saw her.
Today, however, felt different.
The soldiers were in a hurry, and even when they saw Arix, they didn’t stop to ruffle her head. Instead, they all told Arix to go back to their room and stay safe.
Arix nodded obediently, planning to find Scion to ask what was going on. But when she reached the conference room, she saw Scion and the others in an urgent meeting.
Having no other choice, Arix turned around and went back.
On her way back, Arix ran into Sunak. As soon as he saw her, he picked her up and started running toward the lounge, his voice filled with urgency, "Arix, it’s too dangerous outside. Stay in your room and don’t wander around."
"Sunak, what’s going on? Can I help?" Arix asked, her worry evident.
"Our mission was to eliminate the insectoid harassing the border, but it turned out to be a full-blown swarm!" Sunak’s eyes were a mix of emotions Arix couldn’t quite decipher—anger laced with a sense of deep despair.
Arix could tell from his face that things were very bad. Otherwise, Sunak wouldn’t be so serious, even feeling guilty and blaming himself.
"Arix, I really shouldn’t have bought you to the front line. If it weren’t for me, you wouldn’t be in this danger." Sunak’s voice wavered with remorse.
Seeing Sunak so down, Arix nuzzled his neck with her furry head, trying to comfort him, "It’s okay, Sunak. Don’t be scared. We’ll do our best together."
Sunak, touched, sniffled and rubbed his head against Arix’s, "Yes, we’ll do our best together. Plus, we have the admiral. As long as he’s okay, we’ll be fine."
Arix felt something was off about that statement...
Sure enough, the next second, someone came rushing over, stopping Sunak and saying urgently, "Sir, Admiral Scion is in trouble! He had a sudden psychic power rampage during the meeting!"
"What!" Sunak was so shocked he forgot he was holding Arix and took off with the messenger.
Being carried along, Arix, with eyes filled with a resigned look of ancient wisdom, thought,
’Could you guys stop jinxing things during emergencies?’
Arix sighed inwardly, planning to go see the situation. If it was a psychic power issue, she might be able to help a little.
The three of them moved quickly, soon arriving at a quarantine room. Outside the room, three Empire officers stood anxiously.
"Vice Admiral De’an, Rear Admiral Frepe, Captain Chris, Lieutenant Commander Lancelot, how’s the admiral?" Sunak asked urgently.
"It’s not good. The admiral’s psychic power is very strong, and after the rampage, it’s even more terrifying. Not only doctors, but even we can’t get close, so there’s no way to treat him," Captain Chris replied, his brow furrowed in worry.
"How did this happen? The admiral was fine. How could his psychic power suddenly go out of control?" Sunak was nearly frantic with worry.
The insectoid swarm was already pushing them to the brink, and now their leader, the admiral, was in crisis too. Internal strife on top of external threats was driving them toward disaster.
De’an, the highest-ranking officer among them, punched the wall in frustration. "Damn it! Those bastards gave us false information, and I suspect they’re behind the admiral’s psychic power rampage too."
"Without key evidence, suspicions don’t help. The urgent thing now is to find a way to save the admiral," Rear Admiral Frepe said, rubbing his temples in exasperation.
"To save the admiral, we need to subdue him first. But the admiral has Supergiant-Class psychic and physical power. Unless Prince Cassian is here, who else can subdue him?" Lieutenant Commander Lancelot had lost hope.
"Even if we subdue him, what then? This is a psychic power rampage! Unless we have the newly developed psychic power treatment potion from the Alliance, there’s no hope. But where can we find such a potion now?" Captain Chris grabbed his hair in despair, blaming himself. As the admiral’s aide, he had failed to protect him. If the admiral couldn’t be saved, he felt guilty for the rest of his life.
"Hmm? You need a Psychic Healer?"
The sweet, childlike voice suddenly caught everyone’s attention, and they all turned eyes toward it.
Arix stood there, her expression serious yet calm.

chapters.title: Chapter 103: Saving The Admiral
chapters.content:
Chapter 103: Saving The Admiral
Sunak glanced around, trying to figure out who was speaking. Suddenly, he realized everyone was staring at him. He looked down and saw that Arix was with him.
Recalling what the little cub had said, Sunak quickly covered Arix’s mouth and scolded, "Arix, this isn’t the time for jokes. I gave you the Space Button you’re using and I know what’s insdie. Where did you get a psychic power healing potion?"
"Mmmph... mmph..." Arix tried to explain, but his mouth was tightly covered.
The Empire officers, hearing Sunak’s scolding, averted their gazes in disappointment. They had wanted to tell Arix not to joke in such a serious situation but felt awkward since Arix was just a cub.
With collective sighs of disappointment, everyone resumed their discussion.
Vice Admiral De’an said calmly, "If this continues, the admiral’s life will be in danger. We must subdue the admiral first. At least let the military doctor alleviate the psychic power rampage; only then will there be a chance for treatment. As for who will subdue the admiral... it should be me. My psychic power is the strongest among us. I’ll do my best."
His indifferent tone and expression masked the danger he was about to face—subduing someone whose psychic power level was higher than his own during a rampage. If Vice Admiral De’an did it, the best outcome would be severe injuries, and the worst would be dying alongside Admiral Scion.
"No! We need you to fight against the insectoid swarm. Precisely because your psychic power is the strongest among us, you can’t take the risk. I’ll go and do it," Rear Admiral Frepe said.
Although this would put both him and the admiral in danger, Rear Admiral Frepe had to think about the safety of the 50,000 Empire soldiers on the starship carrier and warships. Losing another leader would cause internal chaos before the insectoid swarm even struck.
Vice Admiral De’an considered this point. He then clenched his fists, closed his eyes, and finally forced out a word thought his teeth, "Fine!"
"Rear Admiral Frepe, I’ll go with you. If anything happens to the admiral, I wouldn’t be able to live with myself," Captain Chris said firmly.
Rear Admiral Frepe was silent for a moment, then he clasped Captain Chris’s shoulder with a carefree smile, "Alright, we’ll go together."
With his mouth covered, Arix watched the Empire officers meticulously plan their potential deaths. Feeling speechless and slightly annoyed, Arix suddenly unleashed her own psychic power.
In an instant, a powerful surge of psychic power knocked Sunak away and forced everyone else to take a step back under its pressure.
The sudden reversal brought a moment of stunned silence to the scene.
After a while, Vice Admiral De’an twisted his stiff neck and looked at Sunak, sprawled on the ground. He asked cautiously, "Is her psychic power Supergiant+?"
Sunak, equally shocked by the unexpected turn of events, couldn’t close his dropped jaw. Hearing Vice Admiral De’an’s question, he quickly shook his head. "I don’t know. My cousin didn’t tell me anything about her. But judging by the power... maybe?"
Vice Admiral De’an wiped his face in exasperation. He walked over and squatted in front of Arix, speaking in a gentle tone, "Arix, right? Is your psychic power really Supergiant+?"
Arix, squatting on the ground, nodded obediently.
"Can you help us subdue the admiral?" Vice Admiral De’an asked, hopeful.
Arix nodded quickly. "Sure, it won’t be as hard as you said."
Vice Admiral De’an shut his mouth in shock.
Great, just today, he was outdone by a little cub.
"Is that so... Well, we appreciate it. Time is of the essence. Can we start now?" Vice Admiral De’an quickly regained his composure and looked at Arix for her consent.
"Okay," Arix nodded.
Without further ado, Vice Admiral De’an picked Arix up and headed toward the confinement room. The other officers exchanged glances and followed, even Sunak, who had been on the ground, got up and trailed behind.
They all gathered at the door of the confinement room, their eyes turning to Arix. She gave a firm nod, signaling them to open the door.
Vice Admiral De’an took a deep breath. Then, without hesitation, he flung the door open. Immediately, a terrifying surge of psychic power burst out from the room.
The officers instinctively recoiled, but at that moment, Arix suddenly flew out of Vice Admiral De’an’s arms, her small wings flapping.
A wave of psychic power, equally strong as that from the confinement room, erupted from Arix. In the blink of an eye, she formed a golden psychic power shield in front of her, blocking the incoming attack.
A terrifying roar echoed from the confinement room, and moments later, a large tiger emerged, its blood-red eyes fixed intently on Arix and the others.
"Scion?" Arix tentatively called out, hoping there was still some consciousness left in Scion.
Scion’s response was to open his massive jaws and lunge at them.
’Alright, no need to hold back now,’
Arix thought to herself.
Arix initially felt embarrassed about being harsh to someone she knew, but seeing that Scion had lost all reason, she felt no guilt about taking action.
The battle between them was completely one-sided. Although Arix was tiny, not even as big as Scion’s head, she easily overpowered him.
By the end, she was standing triumphantly on Scion’s head, looking down at him with satisfaction as he lay bound by her psychic power.
The little cub scolded him like an unruly patient, puffing up her cheeks and saying, "When you’re sick, you should behave. Only bad kids cause trouble for others."
Outside the confinement room, the Empire officers watched with complicated feelings as their admiral was reprimanded by a little cub.
However, instead of intervening, they collectively and eagerly pulled out their opticomputers to record the scene. This was prime blackmail material!
After they had recorded enough things, Vice Admiral De’an and the others finally turned their gaze to Sunak, subtly hinting that he should step in. After all, Scion was their admiral, and some dignity had to be preserved.

chapters.title: Chapter 104: Psychic Healer
chapters.content:
Chapter 104: Psychic Healer
Sunak took a deep breath, rolling his eyes before clearing his throat. "Arix, that’s enough. Let the medics check on the admiral now," he instructed.
Arix, hearing Sunak, finally stepped away from Scion and obediently left the confinement room.
"Sunak, still need a Psychic Healer?" Arix asked, sounding casual.
"Where did you get...," Sunak began, but before he could finish, Rear Admiral Frepe clamped a hand over his mouth and dragged him away.
Vice Admiral De’an nodded approvingly at Frepe. Then he turned to Arix with a smile that hinted at mischief. "Do you have a Psychic Healer?" he asked gently.
"Nope," Arix replied, shaking her head honestly.
Vice Admiral De’an was momentarily at a loss. This wasn’t part of the plan. The next step should’ve been this young one pulling out a psychic healing potion to save their admiral. It made perfect sense. But reality, it seemed, had other ideas.
It was silly to pin all hopes on a cub, De’an realized. Just as he was about to give up, Arix spoke again.
"I don’t have one, but I can make a psychic power healing potion. As long as I have the necessary ingredients, I can whip it up," Arix said nonchalantly, as if talking about making lunch.
The Empire officers were stunned. Psychic power healing potions were incredibly rare, often bought at outrageous prices from black markets or auctions. Yet, here was this kid claiming she could make one!
All eyes turned to Sunak, seeking confirmation.
"Captain Sunak, is she serious? Frepe, let him speak," De’an ordered.
Frepe, realizing his error, quickly released Sunak and apologized, "Sorry, buddy, forgot myself there."
Sunak just stared back, speechless. It seemed like they wanted him to talk when it suited them, but gagged him when it didn’t...
The Empire officers, feeling Sunak’s accusing gaze, shifted uncomfortably. Some stared at the floor, others at the ceiling, while a few coughed awkwardly and turned away.
Sunak rolled his eyes, clearly frustrated. "I’ve known my niece for about as long as you guys have," he muttered irritably. "How would I know? But I heard the person who developed the Psychic Healer is named A... Arix, is that really you?"
Arix looked around at the incredulous faces and asked, puzzled, "Sunak, you know my name. Didn’t you realize it yet?"
Sunak felt like shouting,
’How was I supposed to know a little cub like you could create the Psychic Healer!’
But before he could say anything, the other Empire officers eagerly pushed him aside.
Vice Admiral De’an’s eyes lit up as he picked Arix up, and the officers crowded around her, all clamoring for the potion.
"Little Arix, when you have time, could you make some for me too?" Vice Admiral De’an asked with a kind, gentle smile.
Arix nodded without hesitation, finding it an easy task.
Seeing this, the other officers quickly started flattering her, also asking for the potion. Arix agreed to each of them, winning their hearts and instantly becoming the small cub everyone’s fond of.
After sending Arix into the lab, Vice Admiral De’an and the others suddenly turned their heads in unison, staring quietly at Sunak.
Sunak was taken aback. "You’re scaring me, guys! Please don’t look at me like that!"
Clearing his throat, Vice Admiral De’an spoke seriously, "Sunak, don’t you think we should discuss the cub’s identity?"
"Yeah, let’s not even talk about her Supergiant+ psychic power. Just consider the Psychic Healer potion. If Arix is indeed the one who developed it, the Alliance must be crazy to let such a treasure run around freely," commented Lieutenant Commander Lancelot in amazement.
"The Alliance is so stupid on this. I suggest Arix switch her nationality to us," Captain Chris’s eyes gleamed, thinking it was a great idea.
"Exactly, and Arix is originally a therian cub. Her bloodline is pure. How could she be one of the Alliance people? She’s definitely one of us! The Alliance can’t possibly have a therian cub, can they?" Rear Admiral Frepe’s confidence grew as he spoke, and the other officers nodded in agreement.
Sunak sighed deeply, feeling the absurdity of the situation. "Arix’s mother is the daughter of His Holiness, and her father is a Vice Admiral of the Alliance."
"His Holiness? As in His Holiness of the Empire? Well, that just made things even easier. As for her father... a Vice Admiral, you say? That’s nothing to be afraid of. I’m a Vice Admiral too," Vice Admiral De’an puffed out his chest, letting out a proud humph.
"But, Arix’s grandfather is the admiral of the Fifth Legion of the Alliance, commanding an entire legion’s worth of soldiers. Moreover, he is the current head of the Kering family, one of the five major families. The five families have always stuck together. Do you think you can take on all five families?" Sunak said as his voice grew increasingly sympathetic.
The more beautiful their earlier visions, the harsher the reality they now faced.
Sunak’s words deflated the Empire officers. The air became instantly gloomy and depressive.
If it were just about taking a Vice Admiral’s cub, they might have had a chance. But taking on the cub of one of the five major families? Forget it.
With their spirits clearly dampened, Sunak began to wonder if he’d been too harsh. After all, it was natural to like such a cute cub.
Scratching his head, Sunak tentatively offered some comfort, "Arix isn’t from the Empire, but don’t forget, her mother is one of our tigermen. So, doesn’t that make the Tiger Legion her home?"
Vice Admiral De’an’s eyes widened, a spark of hope reigniting.
Rear Admiral Frepe’s face lit up. Captain Chris’s excitement returned, and Lieutenant Commander Lancelot’s jaw dropped in realization.
"That’s a wake-up call!" The Empire officers suddenly got excited.
"Yes, she’s definitely ours," Rear Admiral Frepe’s eyes sparkled, and he stood up straight with renewed energy.
"Who would’ve thought, at such a crucial moment, Sunak, your brain would work so well. Well done! You really did a good job this time," Vice Admiral De’an said with a smile, giving Sunak a pat on the shoulder.
Captain Chris and Lieutenant Commander Lancelot also gave Sunak a thumbs up, showing their admiration.
Sunak, not expecting such praise for his casual remark, scratched the back of his head shyly and joined in the laughter.
...

chapters.title: Chapter 105: Saving Scion
chapters.content:
Chapter 105: Saving Scion
In the Pharmacy Room, Arix, with a serious expression, was carefully mixing medical ingredients for Scion.
Scion’s psychic power had almost reached Supergiant+ level, so ordinary psychic power healing potions couldn’t completely cure him.
Arix had stepped on his head earlier, and it wasn’t for fun. She was closely examining his condition, so she could provide the right treatment.
The only hassle was that Arix was still in her beast form, which meant she had to hop around to select medical ingredients instead of simply reaching out to grab them. Her hands had turned into small paws, making it hard to grasp anything.
With a deep sigh, Arix resignedly used her psychic power and her mouth alternatively, to carry each ingredient to the lab table one by one.
If someone were watching, he’d probably be charmed to death by the cute sight. Nothing could be more adorable than a little creature seriously at work.
Arix placd the last ingredient on the table and rechecked everything to ensure it was correct. Then, she finally let out a sigh of relief. Now all that was left was the catalyst.
Thinking of this, Arix turned to look at Cupid, who was digesting the Insectoid Core on the table.
"Cupid, is the Supergiant-Class Arix Crystal ready?" Arix asked.
"It’s ready," Cupid replied with a cute nod, then he walked over to Arix and squatted like a cat doing its business.
Soon, a fiery red Arix Crystal, still steaming, was placed on the lab table by Cupid.
"Thanks, Cupid," Arix said, controlling the twitching at the corner of her mouth as she thanked Cupid for the fresh crystal. Fortunately, she wasn’t the one who had to drink the potion, so there was no psychological trauma.
But Arix silently vowed to protect her psychic world, making sure she never had to drink a psychic power healing potion.
With all the necessary ingredients ready, Arix took out a box from her Space Button that Vice Admiral De’an had given her earlier.
"Cupid, could you help with these cores too?" Arix asked gently.
"Sure thing!" Cupid’s eyes lit up at the sight of the Insectoid Cores. He eagerly ran over, picked up a core from the box.
Then, he lazily lay on the table, holding the core in his little paws and munching happily.
Arix watched Cupid with a fond smile. Moments later, she turned her attention back to making the psychic power healing potion. Due to the inconveniences of her therian form, she decided to use her psychic power to control the medical ingredients and equipment.
Luckily, she had practiced materializing her psychic power before, so she was quite skilled at controlling it.
She crushed the necessary ingredients, put them into test tubes, boiled them for the required time.
She used her psychic power to separate impurities from the potion, and extracted the pure liquid. She repeated this process for each ingredient.
Finally, Arix poured the liquidized Arix Crystal into the mixture.
As the light blue potion turned pitch black, she smiled with satisfaction.
She poured the potion into a vial and sealed it. Tadaaa—the healing potion was complete.
"Cupid, we’re heading out. I’ll put the cores away for now. You can have them later in the resting room," Arix said gently to Cupid.
"Okay," Cupid replied cutely. He then transformed into a beam of fiery red psychic power and returned to Arix’s psychic world.
Arix put the Insectoid Core and the Arix Crystal back into her Space Button. Then, carrying the potion vial in her mouth, she jumped off the table like a cotton ball and walked to the door.
She leaped up, used her front paw to unlock the door, and walked out of the pharmacy room.
"Finally out, little Arix! You did great."
Vice Admiral De’an and the others gathered around as soon as the door opened, showering Arix with concern and warmth.
Arix felt a bit overwhelmed, sensing their unusual enthusiasm.
She didn’t think much of it, assuming they were just thrilled about the potion.
Arix placed the vial on the floor and said in a cute voice, "The potion is ready. Let’s give it to the admiral quickly."
"Yes, yes, let’s not delay," Vice Admiral De’an said, scooping Arix into his arms and holding her close.
Captain Chris picked up the psychic power healing potion, and together they hurried towards the confinement room.
Following behind, Lieutenant Commander Lancelot had an odd expression since he first saw the potion. He had once seen a psychic power healing potion, and he remembered it being light blue. Though he had heard that stronger potions were darker, he had never seen one turn black.
’Is the potion supposed to be this color?’
The more Lancelot thought about it, the more worried he became.
He discreetly grabbed Sunak’s wrist and, after some serious consideration, he whispered, "Sunak, do you think there’s a problem with this potion? I remember when I saw it in some Alliance news, the psychic healer’s potion was light blue..."
Sunak had been feeling uneasy from the start. Hearing Lancelot’s concern only made his anxiety worse, causing his eye to twitch nervously. However, since this potion was made by his dear niece, Sunak couldn’t let anyone doubt her abilities.
He swallowed to ease his tension and pretended to speak with a certain tone, "My niece is the one who developed the psychic power healing potion. Now, other Alliance chemists can make the potion too, but they can’t do it with some ingredient Arix provide. She invented the potion, so it’s not surprising that her version is unique."
"Really? Well, that does make sense. Considering she’s the researcher behind the psychic healer’s potion, it’s normal for her creation to be different," Lancelot replied, nodding in sudden understanding and belief.
Sunak, hiding his guilt, could only muster a weak smile and nod in agreement.
At the confinement room door, Vice Admiral De’an and Arix exchanged a resolute glance and nodded at each other.
Determined, De’an stepped into the confinement room. The other Empire officers, seeing this, exchanged nervous looks before quickly following inside.

chapters.title: Chapter 106: Fighting Back
chapters.content:
Chapter 106: Fighting Back
The fierce tiger in the confinement room had vanished. Maybe it was Arix’s psychic power that suppressed it, giving Scion a moment of clarity to return to his human form.
The officers of the Empire, seeing their admiral back to normal, were thrilled. They hurried over, showering him with concern and care.
"Admiral Scion, are you alright? How are you feeling?" Captain Chris asked, his voice a mix of excitement and worry.
"I’m fine. What’s going on outside?" Scion wasn’t worried about himself. He was more concerned about the battle outside.
"Vice Admiral Klaus is in the control room, directing the mecha squads and fleets. Luckily, things are under control for now, so there’s no immediate danger," Captain Chris explained with respect.
"Good to know," Scion replied calmly.
"Admiral Scion, why did your psychic power go out of control so suddenly? There were no signs, and we still have no clues," Vice Admiral De’an asked, his voice tight with concern.
"No need to investigate. I know who did it, and I’ll handle them personally when we return," Scion said, his eyes cold and his tone menacing.
"Understood," Vice Admiral De’an hesitated, wanting to avenge the admiral himself, but seeing Scion’s resolve, he reluctantly agreed.
"Arix, since Admiral Scion is awake, you can withdraw your psychic power now," Vice Admiral De’an said, patting Arix on the head.
"Okay!" Arix moved her tiny paws, and pulled it back into her psychic world.
Scion, finally free, looked at the little cub in surprise.
’If I guessed right, this seem like Supergiant+ level psychic power.’
He couldn’t help but wonder if the Alliance was overconfident in the Empire, not fearing they might exploit this situation.
"Admiral, here’s the potion to treat your psychic power outbreak. Please drink it now so we can all relax," Captain Chris remembered the task at hand, quickly handing the psychic power treatment potion to Scion, his tone full of concern.
"Who made this potion?" Scion took the potion, surprised. There shouldn’t be any psychic power treatment potions in the legion at this time.
"Little Arix personally made it for you," Captain Chris emphasized the word "personally," highlighting Arix’s effort.
Scion’s surprise deepened. Raising an eyebrow, he looked at Arix and smiled, "Thank you, Arix."
As Scion expressed his gratitude, a rare smile appeared, making him look as elegant and beautiful as a snowdrop on a mountaintop.
"You’re welcome, you’re welcome," Arix blushed, hiding in Vice Admiral De’an’s arms, shyly waving his paw.
After thanking Arix with a smile, Scion finally looked down at the psychic power treatment potion in his hand.
Scion first opened the potion’s seal and took a sniff. The strong, pungent smell made him catch his breath.
After a brief hesitation, he decided to drink it all in one go.
At first, Scion only frowned, finding the taste peculiar. But within seconds, his face turned an alarming shade of green. The bitter and astringent flavor hit him like a wave, making his mind feel muddled, almost like experiencing electroshock therapy.
Scion covered his face with his hands, struggling to suppress a groan. It took him a good while to recover and lower his hands. If he hadn’t felt the potion working in his psychic world, he would have thought he’d ingested a biochemical weapon instead of a treatment potion.
"Admiral, what’s wrong? Are you feeling unwell?" Captain Chris asked, noticing the change in Scion’s expression.
Scion shook his head and sighed. "I’m fine. I just realized that there are things in this world more terrifying than death."
"Huh? What could be more terrifying than death?" Captain Chris was stunned. Did the admiral mean the insectoids? But they didn’t seem scarier than death.
Scion didn’t answer Chris’s question directly. Instead, he said something cryptic that left Captain Chris puzzled for a long time. "You’ll understand once you drink Arix’s potion," Scion remarked calmly, though his eyes showed a trace of lingering fear.
Captain Chris was so confused.
’Can the cub’s potion actually make someone smarter? If so, I definitely want to try it!’
Captain Chris’s eyes lit up at the thought.
After a while, Scion stood up, his voice icy as he said, "We’ve delayed long enough. It’s time to complete our mission."
Vice Admiral De’an and the others instantly looked excited, smiling broadly. They placed their right hands over their chests and bowed respectfully. Then, in unison, they shouted, "Yes, sir!"
Before the officers set out, Arix, looking pitiful, was handed over by Vice Admiral De’an to another Empire soldier.
"Arix, we’re going to fight the insectoids next. You’re still a cub, so it’s too dangerous for you to come with us. Be good and wait for us in the rest area," Vice Admiral De’an gently coaxed.
Arix pouted, turning his head away in displeasure with a small humph.
Vice Admiral De’an was about to say more when Scion interrupted. "Arix, do you want to come to the front lines with me?" Scion asked casually.
Before Arix could answer, the Empire officers erupted in protest.
"Sir, I don’t think that would be a good idea. Arix is still too young. Children shouldn’t be exposed to such things," Vice Admiral De’an, slipping into his protective brother mode, argued.
"Yeah, if something happens, my cousin will kill me," Sunak added to the opposition.
"Little Arix is indeed still too young," even Captain Chris, who usually followed the admiral’s orders without question, hesitated this time.
Scion remained calm despite everyone’s concerns. He said lightly, "No need to worry, she’s stronger than all of you."
The Empire officers, feeling both speechless and slightly humiliated by the implication, stood in stunned silence.
As the Empire officers felt in utter silence, Arix almost couldn’t help laughing out.
Then, without hesitation, she leaped into Scion’s arms, exclaiming excitedly, "Can I come with you when you pilot the mecha later, sir?"
Scion glanced down at the eager youngster in his arms, a small smile playing on his lips. "Sure."
"Yeah! This is awesome. You’re so nice to me, even nicer than Drexel!" Arix shouted, her voice brimming with excitement and joy.
Scion kept smiling, gently patting Arix’s small head before carrying her outside.
Behind them, the Empire officers exchanged glances, shaking their heads or shrugging helplessly, and finally, they resigned themselves to following along.

chapters.title: Chapter 107: Mecha Samurai
chapters.content:
Chapter 107: Mecha Samurai
On the deck of the starship carrier, Arix was nestled in Scion’s arms. She looked up in awe at the battlefield between the Empire and the insectoids.
Through the energy shield of the starship carrier, Arix saw countless insectoids swarming toward the fleet in the vast expanse of space.
Compared to the few small insectoids she had seen before, the ones outside the energy shield were like their parents. They weren’t just terrifyingly numerous; they were also several times larger. The most frightening sight was three insectoids, each as large as the starship carrier.
Just how big was the starship carrier? It was the size of hundreds of football fields!
If the insectoid swarm were like green beans, then these three special insectoids were like eggs in comparison—completely unmatched by the regular insectoids.
After marveling at the insectoids, Arix turned her gaze toward the Empire.
If the insectoids won by sheer numbers, the Empire relied on quality. The Empire’s main combat force was the starship carrier. Surrounding it were nine slightly smaller military warships, which operated under the starship carrier’s command.
These warships could search, track, lock onto, and attack insectoids within a range of several thousand kilometers. Their powerful particle beam weapons and super electromagnetic cannons could wipe out thousands of insectoids in a single shot.
The only downside was that the long charging time for these weapons allowed some insectoids to breach the starship carrier’s protective circle.
This was when the mechas came into play.
In the starry space, over a thousand mechas were fighting. Pilots wielded heavy swords, pulse guns, and various other weapons, fiercely killing any insectoid that entered the starship carrier’s protection zone.
Watching the mecha pilots battle the insectoids with such fervor, Arix felt her own blood pumping. She couldn’t wait to pilot a mecha herself and charge into the insectoid swarm.
Unfortunately, she was still just a student and hadn’t even started her mecha pilot classes.
Fighting in a mecha, or even controlling one to walk, was out of the question for her right now.
The more Arix thought about it, the more disheartened she became, her ears drooping in frustration.
"Arix, are you scared?" Scion noticed the youngling’s low spirits and asked with a slight smile.
Arix shook her head, replying in her soft, childish voice, "Not scared, just very curious. I’ve never seen such big insectoids before."
"Then let’s take a closer look," Scion said mysteriously.
He retrieved a pure white mecha from his Space Button. The mecha was about 15 meters tall and holding a long sword.
Arix gazed at the towering mecha, swallowing hard in excitement before asking eagerly, "Scion, is this your mecha? What’s his name?"
Scion’s expression softened as he looked at the mecha. "His name is Samurai. He’s been with me since I was little. He’s my important partner."
"Scion, you’re so lucky! I want a mecha that can be my partner too," Arix said enviously, nearly drooling with excitement.
Scion chuckled and patted Arix’s furry little head. Then he looked up at the mecha and said, "Samurai, get ready for battle."
As soon as Scion finished speaking, the massive mecha moved, kneeling down and extending his free hand towards Scion.
"It’s an honor to fight with you, master," Samurai’s mechanical voice carried a knightly reverence.
Scion nodded and, holding Arix, stepped into Samurai’s hand.
Once they were securely in place, Samurai carefully lifted them into the cockpit located in his chest. Standing tall, Samurai then turned his gaze towards the distant insectoids.
Inside the mecha’s cockpit, Arix nestled obediently in Scion’s arms, eyes wide with excitement as she took in the surroundings.
The cockpit resembled an airplane’s, though it was smaller and filled with virtual buttons, giving it a much more high-tech feel. Unlike an airplane, the front wasn’t transparent glass but a virtual screen, where Samurai’s avatar now appeared.
To Arix’s surprise, Samurai’s avatar looked like a child of about five years old. The avatar stared at Arix curiously, his voice now youthful and inquisitive, quite different from the mature tone outside. "Master, who is this little one?"
Scion’s gaze softened as he replied, "This is Arix. She’s a friend and wants to learn about the mecha."
Arix smiled shyly at the AI. "Hi, Samurai! You’re really cool!"
Samurai beamed, his childlike enthusiasm evident. "Hello, Arix! It’s nice to meet you. Are you ready to see what a mecha can do?"
Arix’s eyes sparkled with excitement as she nodded eagerly. "Yes, please!"
Scion chuckled at her enthusiasm. "Alright, Samurai. Let’s show her the ropes."
With that, Samurai activated his systems, the cockpit lighting up with displays and controls.
Arix watched in awe as the mecha moved with precision and power, his every step shaking the ground beneath them.
Scion expertly maneuvered Samurai, demonstrating basic movements and combat techniques.
Arix soaked in every moment, her initial frustration forgotten as she marveled at the mecha’s capabilities.
This was just the beginning of her journey, and she couldn’t wait to take her own steps towards becoming a mecha pilot.
But before Scion could respond, Samurai seemed to have a revelation. "Oh, I get it! This is your little cub, right, Master?! But wait, Master, when did you get a mate? How come I didn’t know?"
A vein throbbed on Scion’s forehead, his childhood friend bonds seemingly evaporating. He coldly uttered one word, "Mute."
Samurai was muted immediately.
’Master! Are you angry? So I am right! She IS you little cub!’
Although the language system was disabled, Samurai continued to spam messages on the virtual screen:
"Master, master, I was wrong."
"Master, please turn the voice system back on, I won’t talk nonsense anymore."
"Master, do you have a new cub and don’t want your old Samurai anymore?"
"Master! Master..."
Seeing the continuous barrage of messages, Arix burst into giggles. "Scion, I think Samurai knows he was wrong. How about turning the voice system back on?"
Samurai looked at Arix gratefully, then made a pitiful face, as if to say,
’If you don’t unmute me, I’ll cry.’
With two cute faces pleading, Scion rubbed his temples in frustration. He then warned Samurai coldly, "If you speak nonsense again, I’ll remove your voice system entirely and make you a mute mecha."
On the virtual screen, Samurai finally looked scared, shrinking back and miming a gesture of sealing its lips.

chapters.title: Chapter 108: First Mecha Experience
chapters.content:
Chapter 108: First Mecha Experience
Samurai was crafted by the mecha master, Valport. When he made it, Valport noticed Scion was just a kid. So, he made Samurai’s avatar to match Scion’s age, hoping it would be a buddy for him.
Years flew by. Scion grew older, but Samurai stayed the same—a cheeky, chatty kid. Scion thought about asking Master Valport to tweak Samurai’s avartar, but there was something special about the little guy.
From a trusted childhood friend to someone Scion saw as a younger brother, Samurai had been a constant. Sometimes, Scion even felt like a worried parent.
Samurai had been with him through the mundane and the thrilling, protecting him all the while. Their bond, forged over years, was unbreakable.
Scion had decided to keep Samurai just as it was, so regrets were pointless. He wasn’t one to linger on what-ifs. With a deep sigh and a resigned smile, he said, "Unmute."
Once the language system kicked in, Samurai straightened up. It knew Scion didn’t tolerate nonsense.
Samurai grumbled to itself but then spotted the little kid in Scion’s arms. Curious, he asked, "Hey, little one, who are you?"
"Hello Samurai, I’m Arix. It’s great to meet you. I may need your help today," Arix said, eyes shining with excitement and a bit of shyness.
Don’t be fooled by Samurai’s childish looks—it was a real Supergiant-Class mecha. Most people never even saw one. Even military students had to wait until they graduated and joined a legion to see a real one.
"Don’t worry, I’ll protect you today," Samurai declared, chest puffed out in a big brotherly way.
"Thank you, Samurai," Arix replied, full of admiration.
"Hahaha! No problem at all!" Samurai laughed, proud as could be.
"Alright, time to start the battle," Scion interrupted. He knew these two could chat forever and never get to the fighting part.
"Okay, let’s go! Time to fight the insectoids. Master, get ready, we’re establishing the psychic link," Samurai said, buzzing with excitement at another chance to shine.
Arix’s eyes sparkled, as she was about to see a Supergiant-Class mecha in action. If her classmates at the Hecaris Military Academy knew, they’d be so jealous.
Scion wasted no time. He placed Arix on his shoulder and sat in the pilot seat. Slowly, he channeled his psychic power into a larger button on the control panel until it lit up.
Scion closed his eyes and waited. As he connected his psychic power to the mecha, Samurai’s serious voice filled the cockpit.
"System, connected."
"Energy, sufficient."
"Power, normal!"
"Green across the board."
...
"Mecha self-check complete, all systems go. Master, I’m ready for the battle."
Scion opened his eyes slowly. The mecha began to move, whirlwinds forming under his feet, propelling him toward the insectoids.
When they reached a special trio of insectoids, Samurai halted.
Like a real samurai, the mecha raised its longsword high and swung it down. A light blade, hundreds of meters long, slashed through the air. The massive insectoid in the middle was sliced in half before it could react.
The other two special insectoids, seemingly intelligent, screeched angrily at their companion’s death. Countless other insectoids swarmed toward the pure white mecha as if commanded.
Facing the oncoming wave, Scion remained calm. He activated the mecha’s energy shield, blocking the attacks.
He then maneuvered Samurai to leap into the air, performing a sword flourish.
A light blade, 50 meters wide, swept through the air, clearing a 100-meter radius of insectoids in front of the mecha!
A single strike from Scion was as powerful as a particle beam. Arix, watching, finally understood the true might of a mecha. No wonder pilots were revered. A single pilot could rival a battleship.
Of course, it was also because Scion was insanely powerful.
...
In the starship carrier’s Control Room...
With the admiral on the battlefield, Vice Admirals Klaus and De’an felt at ease, so they left command to other officers. They watched the real-time battle feed side by side.
Seeing Scion clear a 100-meter radius of insectoids with one strike, they were awestruck.
"No wonder he’s the admiral. His destructive power is incredible," Klaus admired.
"The admiral has always been strong, and Samurai seems even stronger now. Valport must have made some special modifications," De’an said, enviously touching his Space Button, which housed his own mecha.
"Well, Scion is Valport’s godson, after all. Too bad Valport isn’t taking any more godsons, or I’d try my luck!" Klaus, now over fifty, said with a mischievous grin, stroking his chin.
De’an Vice Admiral rolled his eyes and scoffed, "Let’s not even go there. You’re ten years older than Valport. Think you can compare to our admiral in looks? He became Valport’s godson. You? You’d be lucky to be his janitor."
Klaus Vice Admiral, feeling indignant, huffed, "What if Valport appreciates my humor? Looks are temporary. A hundred years from now, we’re all just bones."
"Even as bones, Admiral Scion’s will look better than yours," De’an Vice Admiral sneered.
"Hey, De’an! Are you looking for a fight today? Let’s step outside and see who can kill more insectoids," Klaus Vice Admiral challenged, rolling up his sleeves.
"Bring it on! Like I’m afraid of you!" De’an Vice Admiral shot back, taking off his neatly pressed coat.
The Empire officers in the control room inwardly rolled their eyes, used to these two high-ranking officers bickering over the smallest disagreements. As long as they didn’t cause trouble for everyone else, it was a blessing.
Chapter 123 Competition
Before they could leave, Vice Admirals Klaus and De’an suddenly remembered something crucial—As Scion wasn’t in the Control Room, they had to stay behind to keep everything running smoothly.
This posed a problem. If they didn’t compete today, they’d feel uneasy, but they couldn’t abandon their sense of duty either. Sharing a quick glance, they both had the same idea.
"Captain Chris!" Vice Admiral Klaus called out sharply.
"Captain Sunak!" Vice Admiral De’an echoed.
Captain Chris and Captain Sunak exchanged nervous looks. Reluctantly responding, they heard exactly what they feared.
"You two go out and kill insectoids. Whoever kills the most gets this Star-Class energy stone," Klaus declared, showing a purple crystal.
"Hah, getting cheap on us? I have a Subgiant-Class healing potion for the winner," De’an added, flaunting a green potion.
Captain Chris was not thrilled. He didn’t really want it.
However, Sunak’s eyes lit up at the sight of the prizes. He wasn’t interested in them for himself, but he knew Arix would love them. Imagining her sweet, excited face made him grin.
His sudden laughter drew the attention of almost everyone in the control room. They likely thought he had lost it. Captain Chris looked at him like he was crazy.
Everyone knew this competition wasn’t a joke. The loser would endure intense training under the victorious Vice Admiral, which usually ended in some painful "friendly sparring."
Many soldiers in the Tiger Legion had faced this "friendly sparring.", often leaving with bruised faces.
But De’an didn’t mind. He figured if Sunak was laughing, he must be confident, which meant De’an was destined to win.
Vice Admiral De’an chuckled, but Vice Admiral Klaus wasn’t amused. He turned to Captain Chris, narrowing his eyes with a creepy yet kind smile, staring silently.
The message was clear.
Captain Chris felt a shiver down his spine and quickly stood at attention, promising to Klaus, "Sir, I won’t let you down."
"Good! That’s the spirit of a true warrior of the Empire. I have high hopes for you," Vice Admiral Klaus finally smiled and nodded.
Captain Chris cursed inwardly but kept a polite smile on his face.
Sunak and Chris placed their right hands over their chests, saluting Vice Admirals Klaus and De’an with the traditional Empire gesture before leaving the main control room together.
As soon as they stepped out, Captain Chris’s smile vanished. He turned to Sunak, curiosity clear in his voice. "Sunak, what were you thinking back there, smiling so happily?"
"That’s a secret," Sunak replied, chuckling playfully.
Chris’s curiosity only deepened. He raised an eyebrow and guessed, "Does it have something to do with your little niece? Are you planning to give her the spoils of victory?"
Sunak was annoyed. He hated Chris for being so smart sometimes. Honestly, the most frustrating people weren’t just the smart ones or the strong ones. It was the ones who do both. They were smart and strong, and that was just infuriating!
Seeing Sunak’s annoyed expression, Chris knew he had guessed right. His smile turned mischievous. "I thought this would be boring, but now it seems interesting. Just imagine your niece receiving the gift and sweetly calling me ’Uncle Chris.’ That would be quite delightful."
Sunak was furious. It was bad enough that Scion always tried to steal Arix’s attention, and he couldn’t do anything about it. But now, a fellow officer was trying to do the same? No way!
With a cold laugh, Sunak retorted, "Already dreaming of victory? It’s been a while since you’ve been away from the admiral and piloted a mecha. Don’t end up needing my help halfway through the battle with the insectoids. That would be quite embarrassing."
Chris shot back, "Funny, I could say the same to you. Remember who saved you when you were running for your life from an insectoid? If it weren’t for me, you might already be fertilizer for some flower garden."
"Bah!" Sunak glared at Chris.
"Hmph!" Chris lifted his chin arrogantly and snorted at Sunak.
The two continued bickering as they made their way to the carrier’s deck, where they quickly deployed their mechas. They both scrambled into their mecha cockpits like mice evading a cat.

chapters.title: Chapter 109: Cassian In Danger
chapters.content:
Chapter 109: Cassian In Danger
Meanwhile, Samurai, having just dispatched three leading insectoids, was returning to the starship carrier. As he landed on the deck, two Star-Class mechas appeared nearby.
Scion emerged from the cockpit, holding Arix. He glanced disinterestedly at the two mechas before turning away.
After landing, he put Samurai back into his Space Button and headed toward the carrier’s interior.
"Those two getting into their mechas just now, were they Sunak and Captain Chris? Are they also going to hunt insectoids?" Arix asked, looking up adorably.
Scion ruffled Arix’s hair, his tone carrying a hint of something deeper. "Something like that."
"Will it be dangerous?" Arix asked, worried about Sunak.
"No," Scion replied calmly, reassuring her.
