"Then it’s fine," Arix said, feeling relieved. Suddenly, she felt incredibly sleepy. Ever since she had turned into a youngling, she had been getting sleepy very easily. Sometimes, she even felt drowsy halfway through a meal.
A wave of sleepiness hit her hard, and her brain started to shut down. She yawned, adjusted herself into a comfortable position, and nestled into Scion’s arms, falling into a deep sleep almost instantly.
As Scion continued walking, he suddenly heard the soft sounds of her snores. He glanced down to see the little one sleeping adorably and vulnerably in his arms.
This sight brought a gentle smile to his lips, and his heart softened. His steps became lighter, as if trying not to disturb her slumber.
Chapter 124 Imagination
The sound of laughter from outside disturbed Arix’s sleep, waking her up.
Still feeling groggy, she sat up halfway, using her furry paws to rub her eyes.
As she became more alert, she noticed she was back in the lounge. Remembering the face she saw before falling asleep, she guessed it was Scion who had brought her back.
Just as she thought of him, Scion pushed the door open and walked in.
"Scion, what are you doing here? Is everything okay?" Arix tilted her head, letting out a puzzled whimper.
Usually, Scion was busy, and it was Arix who sought him out when she was bored. This was the first time he came to see her on his own.
"Sunak had something to take care of and asked me to look after you for a few days," Scion said. He silently told a little white lie, as he remembered the two people with bruised faces still soaking in the treatment pods.
"Oh," Arix thought Sunak had gone on a mission and didn’t think much of it.
Seeing that she had just woken up, Scion came over and picked her up. Then, he brought her to the bathroom, helping her brush her teeth and wash her face.
Arix wanted to do it herself but, seeing Scion’s stern face, she kept quiet. She decided to just let it be—after all, she was just a cub now.
After freshening up, Arix returned to her bed, only to find two items placed in front of her. One was a Star-Class energy stone, and the other was a Subgiant-Class healing potion.
"What are these for?" Arix asked, confused about why Scion had brought these things and placed them before her like gifts.
"The energy stone is a gift from Captain Chris, and the potion is from Sunak," Scion explained, seeing the little cub’s confusion.
Hearing that Captain Chris had sent it, Arix didn’t understand why they would give her gifts for no reason, but she didn’t question it and accepted them.
She thought she could make some psychic power healing potions later and give them as return gifts.
She put the presents into her Space Button and then heard the laughter from outside the room again. "Is there something good happening today? Everyone seems really happy," Arix asked curiously.
"Yes, there is. Tonight, there’s a celebration. Arix, do you want to go and see?" Scion gently patted Arix’s fluffy little head, his eyes soft.
"Sure, but before we go, I want to stop by the lab," Arix remembered a promise she had made and thought it would be nice to add to the celebration with her contribution.
"Alright," Scion said without asking why. He then simply picked Arix up and headed straight to the lab.
Arix worked quickly this time, managing to make 50 psychic power healing potions within about an hour. She put the potions into her Space Button, pushed open the door, and walked out.
But as soon as she stepped out, she froze. Besides Scion waiting for her, there was a handsome man dressed in an expensive suit, arguing with Scion.
"I don’t feel comfortable letting her go alone. We’ll be at the Imperial Nexus in a few days; she can go then," Scion said coldly, rejecting the man without room for debate.
"But this is His Highness! How can we make His Highness wait?" Duke Glendale was furious, looking like he wanted to punch someone, though he knew he wouldn’t want to beat Scion.
"That doesn’t mean we can let our tiger cub take risks," Scion replied, still indifferent.
"How could you..." Duke Glendale pointed at Scion, looking like he wanted to curse but didn’t dare. It was a pitiful sight.
However, when Duke Glendale saw Arix, his anger subsided, and a knowing smile appeared on his face. "What if Arix wants to come with me willingly?"
"That’s impossible. Arix wouldn’t listen to you," Scion said, his eyes showing rare mockery.
"Don’t be so sure," Duke Glendale said with a confident smile. Then he pretended to shout loudly, "Prince Cassian is in danger!"
Arix, who had been walking leisurely, immediately changed her expression. She flapped her little wings anxiously and flew over.
"Who did you say is in danger?!" Arix’s psychic power started to stir from her anxiety, and a terrifying mental pressure filled the corridor.
Duke Glendale’s eyes widened in fear, his legs trembling. This overwhelming power, he was familiar with it and he knew it was Supergiant+. He had heard rumors of someone in the Alliance possessing this power, but he never imagined it was Arix.
He thought Cassian was foolish but now it turned out he himself was the stupid one. If a bit of trick could win them the Alliance’s top genius, it was a major victory.
Duke Glendale thought about Cassian, who was in a coma now, and then he came up with an idea.
Noticing Arix’s worried expression, Duke Glendale couldn’t afford to delay. He feigned uncertainty and asked, "Are you Miss Arix Kering?"
"Yes, I am. What happened to Cassian? What’s going on?" Arix asked, her voice tense.
She had seen Cassian before falling into the black hole and thought it was just a hallucination. But later, when she couldn’t contact him, she began to feel uneasy.
She knew Cassian must be in trouble; otherwise, he wouldn’t be unreachable.
Seeing Arix’s concern, Duke Glendale decided to continue with his act. Sighing dramatically, he said, "Prince Cassian has been injured from falling into the wormhole, and he hasn’t fully healed. And twice, my lady, twice did he force himself to use psychic power for your sake, Miss Arix..."
"...Especially after witnessing you fall into the wormhole, His Highness fought fiercely with those two insectoids for your revenge. His leg was broken, his arm was fractured, and his psychic world is on the verge of collapse. Ah, my poor Prince Cassian! His life is truly full of hardships!" Duke Glendale said emotionally, even pulling out a small handkerchief to dab at imaginary tears in the corners of his eyes.
The more Arix listened, the guiltier she felt. Her ears drooped, her heart heavy. She had no idea that Cassian had suffered so much because of her.
’Quispe! Hardy! I swear, I will get back at you and avenge Cassian!’
A cold glint flashed in Arix’s eyes as she silently vowed revenge in her heart.

chapters.title: Chapter 110: Protecting The Princess
chapters.content:
Chapter 110: Protecting The Princess
Duke Glendale could sense the moment was ripe to get a bit more sympathy for Cassian from Arix. But before he could speak, he caught sight of Scion’s fierce glare.
Duke Glendale shut his mouth in fear.
’Misjudged.’
He’d forgotten the overprotective one was still here.
He might be able to fool Arix, but the second Scion caught wind of it, his plan would crumble.
In the Empire, severe injuries or even missing limbs were common. Cassian wasn’t even missing any limbs.
Duke Glendale shrank back, not daring to utter another word.
But Arix was oblivious to all this. Her anxiety was evident as tears formed in her eyes.
"You came to find me? Is it because I can save Cassian?" Arix asked, staring intently at Duke Glendale.
"Yes, exactly. Prince Cassian has Supergiant+ psychic powers, so regular healing potions won’t work. Admiral Thaddeus suggested finding you, so here I am." Duke Glendale dropped Admiral Thaddeus’ name to show he had her father’s approval, hoping to avoid any moral pressure on the young one.
He sneaked a glance at Scion’s face. Seeing him more displeased than before, he quickly looked away.
"Then what are we waiting for? Let’s go!" Arix, filled with worry for Cassian, had forgotten about Scion in her haste.
"Arix," Scion finally spoke up.
Arix paused, then hurried over to Scion. She handed him all the potions she had just prepared.
"Scion, these are for Vice Admiral De’an and the others. Please give the potions to them. Also, I need to leave for a bit. If Sunak comes back, tell him I’m at the Imperial Nexus, at the palace." She explained before turning to leave.
But as soon as she turned, Scion grabbed the back of her neck.
Arix was shocked and puzzled.
"Scion? What is it?" Arix turned back and asked.
"Does Cassian really matter that much to you?" Scion asked, eyes lowered to hide his expression.
Arix nodded firmly, "Cassian is my best friend. He’s hurt, and I’m very worried. So, I must go. Also, if you were the one that’s gotten hurt, I’d do the same for you."
Hearing her words, Scion’s eyelashes trembled. He quickly let go of her neck, as if burned, and turned away to hide his reaction. He coughed, "Alright, I understand. But I’ll go with you."
Arix was momentarily surprised but then nodded, thinking Scion didn’t want her to go alone. She didn’t think much more about it.
While Arix didn’t think much of it, Duke Glendale, well-versed in matters of the heart, noticed Scion’s reddening ears.
Duke Glendale’s pupils suddenly shrank. He swallowed hard, realizing he might have stumbled upon a shocking secret.
’Could it be that Admiral Scion was falling for Arix?
—
No way!’
He had to inform Cassian. He couldn’t let his poor prince suffer both physically and emotionally. It was his duty to safeguard the Empire’s future princess.
Duke Glendale’s eyes lit up with a newfound sense of justice. At that moment, he felt like the beacon of righteousness shining on the mothership. He vowed to defeat the evil admiral and protect the weak, innocent princess for his ailing prince.
"What are you standing there for? Aren’t you rushing to save Prince Cassian?" Scion was already holding the young one, ready to leave.
After taking a few steps, he noticed that Duke Glendale was still standing there, lost in his thoughts.
Scion’s icy voice jolted Duke Glendale back to reality. Instinctively, he responded with a sycophantic smile, "I’m setting off right away..."
He hurriedly followed Scion, feeling a pang of guilt for lying. But he had no choice, as he was a weak old man, while Scion was the Empire’s admiral, capable of taking down an insectoid with a single blow.
Two hours later...
The three arrived at the gates of the Imperial Nexus after making about nine jumps through the warp machine.
As soon as they disembarked, Arix and Duke Glendale were a mess, though Scion looked merely a bit unwell.
Arix immediately vomited, even expelling bile from her stomach. After throwing up, she felt slight relief but still shuddered at the memory of the warp machine ride. It felt like being tossed around inside a washing machine for two hours.
If it weren’t for her decent psychic power, she would have been in the same dire state as Duke Glendale, who seemed to have nearly thrown up his heart and lungs. Arix glanced at him and silently muttered an amen.
Ordinary people could only handle three jumps at most in a warp machine. Even Arix could only manage eight, but her concern for Cassian pushed her to endure nine.
Duke Glendale, accustomed to frequent travels, managed to stretch his limit to nine jumps too.
After resting for a bit, Duke Glendale managed to summon the energy to contact his butler, instructing him to come to the gate to pick them up.
Ten minutes later, Butler Dawson personally arrived in a luxurious carriage, stopping right in front of them.
"Your Grace, Lady Arix Kering, and Admiral Scion, please board the carriage." Butler Kasem respectfully greeted Arix and Scion as he descended from the carriage. He placed his right hand on his chest as he bowed first to Duke Glendale.
"Thank you," Arix said in her small, soft voice, waving a tiny paw from Scion’s arms.
"It’s my honor, my lady," Butler Kasem replied, his face full of respect and kindness as he looked at her.
Scion, with a cold expression, nodded at Kasem before carrying the little Arix into the carriage.
Duke Glendale quickly followed and instructed, "Straight to the palace."
"Yes, Your Grace," Butler Kasem responded respectfully. He then cracked the whip in the air, urging the horses toward the palace.
Imperial Nexus had a unique look, almost like something from a different world, yet it also felt like ancient Greece.
Lining the streets, you’d find plenty of potion stores, mecha shops, Psychic Ware stores, and material shops.
The real eye-catchers were the fancy restaurants. At the doors of these restaurants, you’d see cat-eared maids and wolf-eared butlers inviting people inside.
Arix felt a strong pull to enter, not for the food, but because those maids and butlers looked more appealing than any dish.
’The people of the Empire sure know how to live it up!’
Arix silently gave them a thumbs-up in his mind.
Their carriage moved quickly, reaching the palace gates in under half an hour.
Since carriages weren’t allowed past the gates, Arix and his companions had to get out. After a quick security check, they were let inside the palace grounds.
As they walked along the palace path, Arix nestled in Scion’s arms, taking in Cassian’s residence.
It was clear this place was made for royalty—grand and luxurious. Every building and feature screamed extravagance but didn’t feel too much.
The gardens were perfectly designed with fountains, pools, sculptures, and nurseries blending seamlessly with the palace.
They walked for what felt like forever before stopping. Arix then realized they had arrived at Cassian’s chambers.
Andor, the royal chamberlain, was waiting outside. He hurried over, bowing respectfully with his hand over his chest, "Your Grace, Admiral Scion, and... this must be Lady Arix Kering."
Duke Glendale and Scion gave short nods in return, while Arix responded enthusiastically, "Yes, I’m Arix. Do you know me?"
"His Highness mentioned a lot about you, my lady," Andor replied with a knowing smile.
Arix was about to say more, but Scion, looking a bit annoyed, carried her inside without another word.
Arix rolled her eyes and stopped.
’So, no talking for the little one? Can’t even chat a bit?’
Arix saw Scion’s expression and decided to keep her thoughts to herself.
Inside Cassian’s chambers, besides Cassian lying unconscious on the bed, there were only two other people in the room—a handsome man in luxurious clothes, the ruler of the Empire, Alpha Leonidas, and a beautiful woman beside him, Cassian’s mother, Alpha Leonidas’ mate, and the Empire’s sole Luna, Amethyst.
"Greetings, Your Majesty," Duke Glendale and Scion placed their hands over their chests and bowed respectfully.
Arix joined in with a cute howl.

chapters.title: Chapter 111: Helping Cassian
chapters.content:
Chapter 111: Helping Cassian
Alpha Leonidas gave Arix a brief glance and a slight nod.
Luna Amethyst had her eyes on Arix the moment she walked in.
"Arix, right? Cassian talks about you often. This is our first meeting, and I’m Cassian’s mother. It’s a pleasure to meet you." Unlike the aloof Alpha Leonidas, Luna Amethyst radiated warmth and cheer. Her gaze was soft as she looked at Arix.
Though worried about Cassian, Arix managed to keep her anxiety in check. She bowed her little head respectfully, "Thank you, Your Majesty. I’m honored."
"You can call me Auntie Amy. And Arix, may I hug you?" Luna Amethyst’s eyes sparkled as she looked at the adorable young cub before her. She was determined to bond well with her ’future daughter-in-law.’
Luna Amethyst’s smile grew even kinder, and Arix found herself admiring Cassian’s beautiful mother. So, when Luna Amethyst asked for a hug, Arix shyly glanced at her and then nodded, feeling a bit embarrassed but willing.
In the next moment, Arix was enveloped in a soft, warm embrace. As she enjoyed the comfort, she couldn’t help but think that Cassian must have had a very cozy childhood.
Luna Amethyst hugged and petted Arix for a while, clearly delighted. Once she had her fill, she reluctantly released Arix and said, "Arix, I like you so much. Would you consider staying in the Empire? I can have Leonidas make you the only princess of the Empire."
Alpha Leonidas, hearing his mate’s playful offer, finally looked over. Instead of reprimanding her, he gave Luna Amethyst a fond look and nodded at Arix, signaling his agreement.
"Thank you, Auntie Amy. But I have to return to the Hecaris Military Academy in the Alliance next month, so I can’t stay here for too long," Arix replied, touched by their kindness but politely declining their offer.
"That’s a pity, but make sure to visit me often," Luna Amethyst sighed with genuine regret but remained cheerful as she gently patted Arix’s head. She was confident that one day, Arix would be part of their family.
"Of course, I will. I like you too, Auntie Amy," Arix said sweetly.
"My little Arix, you’re such a little sweet girl," Luna Amethyst said, beaming with joy. She even planted a kiss on Arix’s forehead.
Seeing the two getting a bit too affectionate, Duke Glendale, worried about his young prince, finally spoke up, "How about we check on His Highness first?"
The room fell silent. Luna Amethyst and Arix exchanged awkward glances, both coughing nervously before putting on serious expressions.
"Arix, could you help Auntie take a look? It seems my Cassian is unwell," Luna Amethyst said, trying to appear stern as she carried Arix to Cassian’s bedside.
"Alright, I’ll check now," Arix responded, her cute face turning serious as she let out a soft howl.
Duke Glendale rolled his eyes secretly but refrained from pointing out their obvious awkwardness.
Before starting the treatment, Arix made sure to check Cassian’s body first. Then, using her psychic power, she carefully examined his condition.
The verdict? Cassian’s body was fine, but his psychic world was on the brink of collapse.
Seeing Cassian’s psychic world riddled with cracks hit Arix hard. She remembered that time with the Hecaris wormhole. Back then, Cassian’s psychic world probably hadn’t healed either, but he still chose to help her, supporting the psychic barrier together, even though it worsened his own injuries.
Now, he nearly shattered his psychic world seeking revenge.
’Cassian, you’re not a fool, so why do something so reckless for me again? Is it worth it?’
Arix’s eyes stung with tears.
With a heart full of sorrow, she gently nuzzled Cassian. She then started transferring Vita’s psychic power into his crumbling psychic world.
"Vita, I really need your help this time," Arix’s voice, for once, held a plea.
"Okay," Vita’s gentle voice resonated in her psychic world.
Arix and Vita’s consciousness entered Cassian’s psychic world together.
Unlike the psychic worlds of the Alliance people, where psychic power appeared as diamond crystals, therian psychic incarnation had consciousness represented by small, animal forms.
To Arix’s surprise, Cassian’s psychic incarnation was actually awake!
Yet, he showed no fear or concern for the collapsing psychic world around him. He lay sprawled on the ground like a pancake, muttering something.
Arix had seen her own psychic incarnation turn into an animal form, so she wasn’t surprised.
She was just a bit angry that, Cassian hadn’t even noticed someone had invaded his psychic world and was just lying there, doing nothing to heal it.
Psychic worlds can self-heal, albeit slowly, but it’s better than doing nothing. Yet Cassian didn’t care at all, letting his psychic world continue to crumble.
What hurt Arix the most was that she almost cried for this guy, while he was there not caring about his own injuries.
Vita seemed to sense something and said sympathetically, "Arix, take it easy on him. He’s still a patient, after all."
Arix’s eyes turned cold, and with a wicked smile, she said, "I’m his doctor now, aren’t I? Vita, you go heal his psychic world. I’ll give his brain some treatment."
"Alright," Vita replied, seeing that Arix couldn’t be persuaded. She could only look at Cassian with pity.
Then, flapping her wings, she began mending the cracks in the psychic world.
The unusual activity finally caught Cassian’s attention. Just as he was about to look up, he saw a white furball charging at him.
Cassian’s eyes sharpened, and he leaped back to avoid the sudden attack. Just as he was about to counterattack, he realized his assailant was a tiger cub.
"Who are you?" Cassian paused his attack, staring in confusion at the little furball before him.
"Hmph!" Arix sneered, not surprised that Cassian didn’t recognize her.
After all, few people knew she had turned into a therian. She had tried to tell Cassian before but couldn’t get in touch with him.
She’d worried about him for so long, and look at what she found out today— Cassian was slacking off! She swore to the Moon Goddess that she’s definitely give him a lesson today.
The more she thought about it, the angrier she became. Instead of answering his question, she bared her little fangs and lunged at him.
Cassian looked helplessly at the tiny cub attacking without warning and threatened. "I’m in a bad mood right now. If you keep this up, I won’t go easy on you!"
Arix sneered internally. She didn’t use psychic power but went at him with teeth and claws. Her fierce gaze and actions almost made Cassian think he had stolen the cub’s food or something. Otherwise, why would a bottle-sucking cub be chasing and biting him?
He ran, she chased.
"Enough, you little brat! I’m only going easy on you because you’re small, not because I’m afraid! If you keep causing trouble, I’ll fight back!" Cassian was angry now, his light golden eyes flaring with anger.
Arix bared her teeth in disdain, ignoring Cassian’s threats, and lunged at him again.
Cassian sighed, seeing no other choice but to fight back.
So, the two little furballs wrestled, punching and kicking each other for quite a while.
It wasn’t until Vita finished mending the psychic world that the two cubs were still at it.
"Arix, the psychic world is repaired. Shall we leave now?" Vita asked, a bit exasperated, seeing the two cubs still fighting.
Cassian’s movement froze just as he was about to counterattack. He couldn’t believe he just heard that name.
Taking advantage of Cassian’s distraction, Arix bit his neck and started smacking his butt with her paw. Strangely, Cassian didn’t resist; instead, he shyly buried his face under his paws.
Arix looked puzzled.
’Did I hit him so hard he got stupid?’
Cassian, on the other hand, was blushing much, screaming internally.
’Arix actually bit my neck! Is she proposing to me?’
In the Empire, the rule was that if a male therian wanted to court a female therian, he could choose to fight her. If he won, he could bite her neck. So, biting a therian’s neck in the Empire signified both courtship and the intention to mate.
But Arix didn’t know any of this. After spanking Cassian, she felt much better.
Arix released Cassian’s neck. She gave him one last haughty snort before exiting the psychic world with Vita.
Still in place, Cassian blushed furiously for a while before finally lifting his head. His golden eyes, shimmering with a watery glow, shyly looked in the direction Arix had left.
Cassian knew Arix probably didn’t understand the meaning behind biting someone’s neck, but he couldn’t help feeling a rush of joy and excitement.
Now, it was his turn to leave. He had been hiding in his psychic world, afraid the outside world no longer had Arix in it. But now that Arix was alive and had shown such a gesture, there was no way he could let her off the hook.
After all, he was an innocent, pure-hearted wolf. She had ruined his purity, and she had to take responsibility for that!

chapters.title: Chapter 112: A Jealousy Alpha
chapters.content:
Chapter 112: A Jealousy Alpha
Arix’s mind snapped back to reality.
As soon as she remembered the mess from the psychic world, she smacked Cassian on the head with her paw. But the second she did, she realized Cassian’s parents were right there.
Her paw froze. She quickly switched to a gentle pat, rubbing his head softly instead. Everyone around noticed but acted like they didn’t see a thing.
Luna Amethyst turned and chuckled. She then coughed to cover it up and, with a kind smile, picked up Arix. "Arix, is the healing done?" she asked, gently stroking Arix’s back.
Seeing that no one called her out, Arix sighed with relief. She nuzzled against Luna Amethyst and said in a cutesy voice, "Don’t worry, Cassian is fine now."
"Good, on behalf of Cassian, thank you, Arix." Luna Amethyst’s voice was sweet and soothing, her eyes as gentle and captivating as a spring lake.
Arix got lost in her beauty, even drooling a bit. She thought,
’Such a beautiful Luna...’
Meanwhile, Alpha Leonidas watched with a hint of jealousy, because her wife was seldom so kind and gentle to him.
With a stern face, he said, "Amethyst, they’ve had a long journey. They should go back and rest, especially the little cub who needs plenty of sleep."
Snuggled in Luna Amethyst’s soft, fragrant embrace, Arix felt so peaceful.
’Gosh, Alpha Leonidas, you’re a grown man, how can you be jealous of a little cub? Can’t she hold me a bit longer?’
Though frustrated, Arix didn’t dare confront Alpha Leonidas. She just burrowed deeper into Luna Amethyst’s arms, pretending not to hear him.
Luna Amethyst, sensing his jealousy, gave Alpha Leonidas a knowing and slightly annoyed look. Only when he sheepishly turned away did she snort.
"Arix, ignore this old man. Would you stay with Auntie for a few more days?" Luna Amethyst’s face softened into a doting smile as she looked at Arix.
Arix was about to agree when Scion’s voice cut in.
"Sorry, Luna Amethyst. Everyone back at the clan is waiting for Arix. If she’s done here, I’ll take her back now," Scion said, cold yet polite.
"Fine," Alpha Leonidas quickly agreed.
Luna Amethyst rolled her eyes, speechless. She had seen dads sabotage their sons, but never like this. A rare chance for her son to bond, wasted by his own father.
Since Alpha Leonidas had spoken, Luna Amethyst couldn’t argue. She sighed inwardly, thinking,
’Son, you’ll have to woo your bride yourself. Your mother did her best.’
With a helpless sigh, Luna Amethyst handed Arix over to Scion. She gently patted Arix’s head and said, "Arix, come visit me often, okay?"
"Okay," Arix nodded obediently, rubbing her head against Luna Amethyst’s palm for comfort.
Luna Amethyst’s heart melted at Arix’s cuteness.
Scion was patiently waiting aside. After the two said goodbyes, he finally took Arix in his arms and left the palace with Duke Glendale.
Shortly after they left, Cassian woke up. The first thing he did was look around anxiously, but there was no sign of Arix.
Thinking it had all been a dream, he let out a depressed howl and slumped back, looking completely defeated.
Luna Amethyst covered her eyes, embarrassed by her son’s cluelessness. "Arix has already left. If you go now, you might catch up with her," she said. She pretended to be annoyed but, she was unable to hide her concern.
As soon as she said that, the previously listless Cassian sprang to life and disappeared in a flash.
Watching the empty bed, Luna Amethyst shook her head and turned to Alpha Leonidas with a look of disdain. "Look at what you’ve done to our son. He’s so foolish that I almost don’t want to admit he’s mine."
Alpha Leonidas didn’t dare argue; he just smiled and kept quiet.
Seeing that Amethyst was still upset, he changed the subject. "Amethyst, do you want that little cub to be Cassian’s mate?"
"Yeah, got a problem with that?" Luna Amethyst looked questioningly at Alpha Leonidas.
"But she’s from the Alliance," Alpha Leonidas pointed out the crux of the matter.
The Alliance and the Empire, while not mortal enemies, had been at odds for a long time. Even if they agreed, the other ministers in the Empire would likely oppose it.
After all, Luna was supposed to the role model of all females of the nation. Allowing an outsider to take such a position would surely cause an uproar within the Empire.
Hearing this, Luna Amethyst’s eyes, usually soft like spring, instantly turned cold. Her voice icy, she said, "I don’t care if she’s from the Empire or the Alliance. As long as my son likes her, she can even be a non-human. If anyone objects, I’ll beat them into submission."
Alpha Leonidas didn’t argue. Instead, he gently put his arm around his wife’s shoulder and said affectionately, "Amethyst, you’re as intimidating as ever."
"If I weren’t, how could I have become your wife so smoothly?" Luna Amethyst poked Alpha Leonidas’s chest with her finger, her tone teasing.
Luna Amethyst’s background wasn’t great. When she was young and fell in love with Alpha Leonidas, many ministers opposed their relationship.
Fortunately, she had excellent abilities. Whenever a minister objected, Luna Amethyst would find their sons or daughters, who were also her classmates. She’d spar with them daily, always giving them a thorough beating.
This not only vented her frustrations but also kept her actions within the bounds of sparring, avoiding any serious repercussions.
As for retaliation, no therian in the Empire dared to touch Leonidas’s woman.
Getting beaten up by Luna Amethyst might result in some injuries, but if Alpha Leonidas got involved, several lives wouldn’t be enough to cover the cost.
In the end, Luna Amethyst got what she wanted, but the ministers of the Empire were left pulling their hair out.
Each time they returned home, they were greeted by their battered and bruised sons and daughters, who would desperately beg them to stop picking fights they couldn’t win.
As a result, no one dared to oppose Amethyst becoming Luna. The ministers had learned their lesson well.
Thinking back on those days, Leonidas’s lips curled into a smile, and his eyes were filled with even deeper affection for his wife.
With her small hand constantly poking at his chest, Leonidas felt his breath quicken.
He swallowed hard, then swiftly scooped Luna Amethyst into his arms, disappearing from the room in a flash.

chapters.title: Chapter 113: The Tiger Clan
chapters.content:
Chapter 113: The Tiger Clan
In the carriage on their way back, it was just Arix and Scion. Duke Glendale had gone off to attend to other business right after they left the palace.
Maybe it was because she was going to meet family, but even though the carriage wasn’t speeding, Arix felt like the trip was over in no time.
The thought of meeting all those family made Arix a bit nervous. The fear from her last encounter with them still lingered, and now she had to face it again.
Plus, she wasn’t sure if her tiger clan relatives would accept her, considering she wasn’t from the Empire.
With a mix of nerves and anticipation, they finally arrived at the gate of a grand estate.
"Arix, are you scared?" Scion asked. He noticed the little cub hiding in his arm was peeking out with just her eyes. He remembered how this little cub had been so brave on the battlefield surrounded by insectoids.
Now, heading home, she seemed to have lost her nerve.
If he didn’t know better, Scion might have thought the cub in his arms had been swapped.
"I’m not scared, what’s there to be scared of..." Arix gulped, trying to sound brave.
"Arix, your legs are shaking. Not very convincing," Scion said plainly, looking at the trembling cub in his arms.
Arix smiled awkwardly.
Seeing that she couldn’t find the words to argue, Scion gently rubbed her head in a rare show of affection. "Don’t be afraid. I’m here."
Arix looked up unintentionally and saw Scion’s rare smile. His handsome face with that smile felt like a gentle autumn breeze over a calm lake. It wasn’t overpowering, but it reached deep into her heart.
THUMP HUMP THUMP...
Her tired heart sprang to life and started jumping wildly. But just as quickly as it revived, it died again when Arix remembered that the person in front of her was destined to become the Empire’s future Pontifex.
It was like a bucket of ice water had been dumped on her, extinguishing any budding feelings she had. Arix reminded herself that if she didn’t want to end up like her grandparents, she couldn’t entertain such thoughts.
With a sigh, she weakly replied to Scion, "Okay," and slumped in his arms, feeling downcast.
However, Scion’s comfort had worked. This tough love meant she wasn’t as scared of meeting her relatives anymore.
After all, what could be more heartbreaking than seeing your dream guy destined to become a cold and nonsexual priest?
When the two entered the estate, Arix saw the tiger clan already waiting in the living room.
The members of the tiger clan were all strikingly good-looking. With their signature silver hair and blue eyes, they had an innate air of cool nobility. Even if they were to wander the streets, no one would ever mistake them for ordinary people.
The leader of the tiger clan was a robust middle-aged man, and the highest-ranking members were the five elders standing beside him. Then there were the dozen or so aunts and uncles, followed by numerous cousins whom Arix didn’t recognize.
When Scion appeared, everyone except the clan leader and the elders placed their right hands on their chests. They respectfully greeted him with an Empire salute. "Admiral Scion!"
At this moment, Scion set aside his usual aloof demeanor and returned the greeting politely.
After exchanging pleasantries, the oldest elder looked kindly at Arix and then asked Scion, "Is this Vezgor’s granddaughter?"
"Yes, this is Arix. Arix, these five elders are your grandfather’s brothers. They have six brothers in total. And this is our patriarch, your uncle," Scion patiently introduced each one.
Scion’s gentle and patient manner surprised the clan leader and the five elders. They exchanged astonished looks, thinking the same thing: it seemed Scion liked the little cub a lot.
After the introductions, Arix, with a nervous yet sweet tone, greeted everyone one by one. Her adorable demeanor quickly won over the elders’ hearts. They eagerly filled Arix’s Space Button with useful and interesting trinkets from their personal collections.
"Arix, dear, you’re so cute. You should visit me often," one enthusiastic woman said. She was one of Arix’s aunts. She rubbed Arix’s hair and gave her a kiss on the cheek.
"Do remember to come to my house. The grapes in our garden are ripe and incredibly sweet," another man said, patting Arix’s head. According to Scion, he was one of Arix’s uncles.
"Arix, this is my lollipop. Want to have a try?" said a young girl. She was one of Arix’s cousins and she was just three years old. She was now in her beast form, offering Arix a lollipop covered in saliva.
Seeing the drool-covered lollipop, Arix’s eye twitched, and she politely declined with a forced smile.
This family reunion lasted about half an hour, during which Arix got to know everyone.
Finally, the eldest elder called over his grandson and sternly instructed, "Targon, show your cousin around."
"Yes, Grandpa," Targon replied. He was a young man of about fifteen, with the silver hair and blue eyes typical of the tiger clan, and he exuded a sunny disposition.
Scion had some discussions to handle with the elders, so he gently placed Arix into Targon’s arms. Rubbing her head, he said, "Go hang out with your cousin, Targon. I’ll come find you when I’m done."
Arix, understanding that the adults had things to talk about, obediently nodded and responded, "Okay, Scion."
With a slight smile, Scion nodded gently before heading off with the elders towards the meeting room.
Targon, now tasked with looking after Arix, looked at her with some surprise. "You and Scion are pretty close now, huh? That’s kind of a big deal in this clan, you know. He’s always so cold to us, and this is the first time I’ve seen him smile."
"Well, what can I say? I’m just adorable," Arix replied, lifting her small chin proudly.
Targon chuckled, finding her amusing. He ruffled her fluffy head and said, "Alright, you’re the cutest. So, where does my adorable little cousin want to go today?"
Arix blinked, recalling all the gifts she received earlier. An idea quickly formed in her mind. She looked up at Targon and said, "To the materials shop."

chapters.title: Chapter 114: Poor Targon
chapters.content:
Chapter 114: Poor Targon
In the bustling streets of Imperial Nexus, Targon and Arix were browsing a store filled with raw materials.
They wandered through the aisles, listening to the salesman’s enthusiastic introduction to the medical ingredients on display.
Targon, though not interested in the slightest, showed no sign of impatience. He followed Arix, moving from one display case to another, gently accompanying her.
Arix carefully examined the medical ingredients and seemed quite pleased. She nodded with satisfaction and turned to the helpful salesman. "I’d like to buy these medical ingredients. Can you get them ready for me?"
"Of course, esteemed customer. What do you need?" the salesman replied with a polite smile.
Arix began listing her items, "One kilogram of Uncaria, five kilograms of Gynostemma, one kilogram of Eclipta, three kilograms of Polygonum, and two kilograms of Borax..."
The salesman diligently noted each item on his opticomputer and quickly calculated the total. He then informed Arix respectfully, "My lady, your total is 350,000 credits. Will you be paying via cash or card?"
Arix didn’t bat an eye at the price. She turned to Targon and asked, "Cousin Targon, will you pay by transfer or card?"
Targon looked stunned. "Aren’t you the one buying these?" he asked, bewildered.
"Yes, but I don’t have any credits," Arix replied, her tone innocent yet firm.
Targon was at a loss for words. This little cub was more like a little devil.
Half an hour later, they left the store, Targon looking like a wilted flower as he patted his now-empty wallet. He had just spent a small fortune, wiping out several months’ worth of budget to please his cousin.
Arix, feeling accomplished, patted her Space Button and then gave Targon’s arm a comforting pat. "Don’t feel bad. I’ll give you a surprise when we get back, and you’ll think it was worth it."
"Hum?" Targon muttered, too exhausted to argue. Trusting a kid’s promise seemed crazy.
But as he looked at his cousin, he thought maybe it was worth it. Money could be earned back, but time with Arix was rare.
Curiosity got the better of him. "Arix, why did you buy so many medical ingredients?" he asked, glancing at her.
"To make potions, of course," Arix answered matter-of-factly.
"Really? You can make potions?" Targon asked, surprised.
"Yes, it’s not hard at all," Arix said, as if it were the simplest thing in the world. For her, making potions was as easy as eating and drinking.
Targon remained skeptical, thinking his little cousin might just be a bit too confident.
Not wanting to crush her enthusiasm, Targon switched the subject. "So, where do you want to go next?"
"Let’s wander a bit more before heading back," Arix said. It was a rare chance to visit the Empire, and she didn’t want to waste it.
"Alright, but just so you know, we’re only looking. I’m out of money," Targon warned, giving her a heads-up.
"I already bought everything I needed, but huh... you’re poorer than I expected," Arix remarked, her tone almost sympathetic.
Even the least wealthy person in her household, Drexel, probably had millions of astrocredits from their interstellarnet store dividends.
Targon felt a surge of frustration. Spending his money and then calling him poor—this little rascal was something else!
He ruffled Arix’s hair vigorously, feeling slightly better afterward.
Arix didn’t resist, sensing her cousin’s need to vent. Letting him have this small victory, she allowed her hair to get mussed.
As evening approached, they began heading back home. Just as they reached the front door, Targon suddenly stopped in his tracks. "Prince Cassian, what are you doing here?" he asked, surprised.
Hearing the name Cassian, Arix finally looked up at the entrance. There stood a striking young man with snow-white hair and golden eyes, looking like the sun god Apollo himself.
’Wow, so handsome!’
Arix’s eyes sparkled, but she quickly shook her head to snap out of it. No, she was still mad at him.
She turned her head away, deliberately ignoring Cassian.
Cassian hadn’t anticipated his well-thought-out charm offensive to fail so quickly. He had spent considerable time preparing to see Arix.
Thinking back on why Arix might be upset, Cassian concluded it was probably because he hadn’t been taking care of his health. That had to be why she was so mad.
With softened eyes, Cassian walked up to Targon and asked gently, "May I hold Arix?"
"Uh... okay," Targon hesitated for a moment but then handed Arix over without much fuss.
Cassian was the strongest of their generation in the Empire, and Targon idolized him. Everyone admired Cassian, so Targon assumed his cousin would be happy too.
Arix, now feeling trapped, remained silent.
’Seriously? He just handed me over like this? Doesn’t he see I’m still mad?’
Arix grumbled inwardly but maintained a cold expression to preserve her dignity.
"Arix," Cassian said softly, holding her gently.
Arix, resting her head on his shoulder, closed her eyes with a haughty air. When Cassian called her name, she just twitched her ears and turned her head away, still ignoring him.
"I’ve missed you so much," Cassian said, his voice filled with restrained longing.
Those simple words made Arix’s cheeks flush bright red. She lifted her paw and protested by tapping his arm.
"If you really missed me, why did you stay hidden in the psychic world and not come out? Do you know how worried I was?" Arix, perched on Cassian’s arm, complained non-stop.
"I was wrong. I won’t do that again," Cassian admitted immediately. No matter what happened, in his eyes, Arix was always right.
"Hmph," Arix snorted, clearly pleased.
Seeing Arix’s anger melt away, Cassian seemed to relax completely. He held her close, his voice filled with deep relief. "Arix, I’m so glad you’re safe. I could’ve been lost in that world forever."
Feeling Cassian’s genuine concern, Arix’s lips curved into a soft smile. She gently reassured him, "Are you silly? I’d always try everything to get you out."
"Yeah, I know you will," Cassian agreed, not arguing. He felt like a wandering soul who had finally found its home.

chapters.title: Chapter 115: Cassian Meeting Scion
chapters.content:
Chapter 115: Cassian Meeting Scion
Targon lingered nearby, observing the scene unfold for what felt like forever.
He wanted to say something but hesitated. He felt overwhelmed, like he’d eaten a huge ostrich egg, or worse, been force-fed one. The guilt gnawed at him,
’Did I really just give Arix to someone else?’
As he pondered whether to try and fix things, a sudden chill ran down his spine. Targon froze and slowly turned around, dreading what he might see. There, standing in the doorway, was Scion.
No one knew for how long he had been standing there.
Scion’s eyes were locked on the two embracing. He didn’t move or speak, but Targon could feel the coldness radiating from him. Trembling, Targon managed to whisper, "Cousin Scion..."
But Scion paid no attention to Targon. His gaze stayed on Arix and Cassian. "Arix, it’s getting dark. Time to go back," Scion said, though his eyes were fixed on Cassian.
Arix lit up at the sound of his voice. "Scion! Are you done with your work?" she asked, excitement evident in her tone.
"Yes, it’s time for dinner. Let’s head home," Scion replied, his voice warm as he looked at Arix. Then he turned to Cassian, his tone turning cold and businesslike. "Your Highness, you should return early too. It’s not safe out here."
Cassian’s arms tightened around Arix for a moment before he let go, handing the little cub to Scion. He reached out to ruffle Arix’s hair but stopped when Scion’s hand intervened.
"Your Highness, Arix is a girl. It’s better to keep some distance," Scion said, his face unreadable.
Cassian’s eyes darkened briefly, but he pulled his hand back. He gave Arix a gentle smile. "Arix, I’ll come to see you again tomorrow."
"Okay!" Arix chirped, waving her little paw from Scion’s arms.
The moment Scion had Arix, his polite demeanor towards Cassian disappeared, replaced by a frosty look. Without another word, he turned and walked out the door with Arix.
Arix wanted to say a proper goodbye to Cassian but found herself cut off by Scion once again. Used to this, she simply pouted a bit, not complaining.
Targon watched as Scion and Arix left without even acknowledging him. He then glanced at Cassian, who remained standing there. Targon felt invisible, like a ghost in a scene meant for four people.
"Does Scion really care for Arix that much?" Cassian asked, staring after the pair with a strange expression.
Targon looked around to make sure no one else was nearby before finally confirming that Cassian was indeed talking to him.
Feeling moved that someone had remembered him, he poured his heart out. "Yeah, he really cares about Arix. You know, I stay by his side a lot, and I’ve never seen him smile. But today, I saw him smile at Arix several times. He even came to pick her up just now. Normally, he wouldn’t care if we didn’t come home."
He wanted to continue, but Cassian interrupted, "Enough, you don’t need to say more."
Cassian’s lips held a smile, but the chill emanating from him was no less than Scion’s earlier.
Targon shivered, feeling as if winter had come, making him freeze multiple times today. He resolved to have a bowl of ginger soup when he got home to warm up.
"Um, if you don’t need anything else, Your Highness, I’ll head back now," Targon said, wrapping his clothes tighter around himself, feeling that he might catch a cold if he stayed any longer.
"Yes, thank you for today," Cassian replied with a forced smile before turning to leave. As he turned, the smile vanished from Cassian’s face.
’Scion, huh?’
Cassian recalled Duke Glendale’s words earlier today.
At first, he didn’t believe it. After all, anyone could have designs on Arix, except for Scion, who was never on his radar. But witnessing Scion’s actions just now forced him to accept the reality: Scion might indeed have feelings for Arix. Perhaps even Scion himself hadn’t realized this yet.
Watching Scion, who was no less capable than himself, Cassian felt a deep sense of jealousy. But thinking about Scion’s future as the Pontifex, Cassian’s lips curled into a strange smile. A man destined to devote his life to the Moon Goddess—if he lost to such a rival, he might as well step outside and let an insectoid finish him off now.
Meanwhile, Targon, seeing the now-empty doorway, felt an overwhelming sense of loneliness. He closed the door and hurried to catch up with Scion and the others.
"What’s holding you back there, Targon?" Arix said. She perched in Scion’s arms, looking at Targon with some disdain as he finally caught up.
"You have Scion to carry you; I don’t," Targon replied, his tone dripping with jealousy.
"What are you talking about? Sorry, can’t hear ya," Arix teased, sticking out her tongue at Targon before deliberately snuggling closer to Scion.
Finally, she flashed a mischievous smile at Targon, showing her teeth in a way that invited a playful scolding.
The flames of frustration in Targon’s heart flared up instantly, reaching towering heights. He wanted nothing more than to grab the little cub and give her a good spanking.
However, just one more look at Scion’s impassive face doused Targon’s fury as quickly as if he’d been hit with a fire extinguisher.
With a deadpan face, Targon silently mouthed to Arix, "Just you wait!"
"Hahaha!" Arix laughed uncontrollably at Targon’s frustrated expression, knowing his desire to smack her was tempered by his fear of Scion. She laughed so hard that she almost exposed her belly.
Scion glanced down, noticing the little cub’s exposed belly. He gently covered it with his sleeve. "Arix, stop messing around. And never expose your belly to an ’enemy’ like this," he said softly.
"Okay, Scion," Arix replied obediently, settling back down.
Scion patted her head gently and continued walking towards the main hall. The family gathered there for their weekly dinner, and today happened to be the day.
The hall was already filled with many members of the family. They all seated around a long, wide wooden table, chatting as they waited for the food to be served.
Scion found his seat and sat down with Arix in his arms. "Arix, did you have fun today?" asked one of her grandfather’s brothers. The old man was sitting at the head of the table, looking kindly at her.
"Yes, I had a lot of fun. Targon took me to play, and there were so many fun things to do," Arix responded sweetly.
"That’s good. Arix, you should consider this your home. Don’t feel shy or reserved," the old man said with a warm smile.
"Okay, thank you," Arix nodded her little head adorably.
Sitting aside, Targon felt a pang of sadness and grabbed a drumstick for himself. He thought to himself,
’Clearly, I’m the most miserable one today. Why didn’t Grandpa care about me too?’
But he had come to realize that Arix must have some sort of magical charm. With her around, even his dearest Grandpa treated him as if he were invisible.

chapters.title: Chapter 116: Misguided Path
chapters.content:
Chapter 116: Misguided Path
After everyone enjoyed their lively meal, the maids swiftly cleared the table, replacing the leftovers with fresh plates of fruits and milk.
Arix assumed they’d leave after eating, but when no one moved, she stayed put, curious.
Krylak, the tiger clan patriarch seated at the head of the table, spoke up with a serious tone. "Now that we’re all here today, I’d like to make an announcement. The annual family bloodline test will be held three days later, at noon time. Please bring all your untested clan members from each territory to participate."
Everyone except Arix seemed to expect this and nodded calmly.
While Arix wondered how the bloodline test would be conducted, Krylak continued. His voice now carried a chilling edge that sent a shiver down Arix’s spine.
"There’s something else you might not know yet," Krylak said, his tone mixing anger and complexity. "My nephew, Scion, the pride of our tiger clan, nearly died on the battlefield due to someone’s vile intervention."
Krylak’s words struck like lightning, shocking everyone into a flurry of whispers.
"My god, someone tried to harm Scion? Are they trying to make an eternal enemy of our clan?"
"And Scion is the future Pontifex! Who would be so foolish to target him, risking the wrath of the Moon Goddess Temple?"
"Exactly! Do they even realize how crucial the Pontifex is to the Empire? He’s vital for our cubs’ transformation into their beast forms. The audacity, it’s unimaginable, lawless!"
The hall buzzed with disbelief. No one could fathom someone daring to target the future Pontifex.
If this news spread, it would incite the entire Empire of Sacred Moonlight to fury.
Arix could understand; it was like trying to harm a revered veteran in the old world; the whole nation would erupt in rage.
Some of the more protective tiger clan members were furious, banging the table and demanding to know which clan dared plot against their pride.
"Krylak, tell us who dared to harm Scion. We’ll grab our weapons and take them out now," one hot-tempered member demanded angrily, barely restraining himself from flipping the table out of respect for their family.
Krylak had anticipated the clan’s fury, but the real tragedy lay in the fact that the mastermind wasn’t an external enemy, but a traitor within their own ranks.
Krylak’s eyes grew dim for a moment before he turned his gaze towards the fifth elder, who had been sitting silently in his chair.
"Uncle Velkor, you tell them," Krylak said, then closed his eyes wearily.
At these words, the entire hall fell silent, as if someone had collectively gripped their throats. Everyone turned their incredulous eyes towards their revered Velkor.
"Impossible! It can’t be my grandfather. He’s dedicated his whole life to the clan. How could he possibly harm Cousin Scion?" Velkor’s grandson, Torvak, stood up in a frenzy, furiously denying the accusation.
He couldn’t believe it. He knew better than anyone how much his grandfather had sacrificed for the clan. There were countless times when Velkor had risked his life but said that his injuries were worth it, that they were honorable.
Such a man, who had devoted his entire life to the family, would never be the one to plot against Scion. Even in death, Torvak wouldn’t believe it was true.
"Sit down, Torvak. What Krylak said is true," Velkor, in contrast to his agitated grandson, accepted the situation calmly.
When he had made his move against Scion, he had already prepared himself for the consequences, even if it meant dying alongside Scion.
The only thing he couldn’t let go of was his innocent and naive grandson, which was why he had endured the pain of betraying the clan and clung to life.
"No! No! This isn’t true! It can’t be true!" Torvak felt as if the very essence of his existence had been ripped away upon hearing his grandfather’s words.
Stumbling, he fell to the ground, shouted one last denial, and then turned and ran out in a daze.
"Tarvok!" Targon called out, worriedly watching his friend run off in distress. He then turned to his grandfather. After receiving a nod of approval from the elder, he immediately chased after Torvak.
Velkor watched his grandson’s despairing expression, feeling as though a thousand knives were simultaneously stabbing his ordinary, tender heart. The excruciating pain in his chest made him open his mouth several times, yet no sound emerged.
Finally, he closed his eyes and took a deep breath. Then he turned his gaze to Krylak and said, "Krylak, I will accept whatever punishment you deem fit. I only hope that, considering my lifelong dedication to the clan, you can show mercy to Torvak. He has only a month left to live."
Velkor’s face had always carried a look of grim determination, but now, as he spoke his final words, tears streamed down his cheeks.
"Who gave you the poison?" Krylak asked, cutting straight to the point, not ready to agree to anything just yet.
"The ninth elder of the Dragon clan," Velkor confessed without hesitation. "He has a cure for my grandson, Velkor. If I eliminated Scion, he promised to treat him. I couldn’t resist the temptation."
"You made a very unwise move, you know that?" one of the elders said. He closed his eyes in anguish, unable to bear the sight of his brother’s downfall.
The other three elders also closed their eyes, powerless to change the fate of the fifth elder. The crime of plotting against the clan’s prodigy carried only one sentence: death. Even an elder was not exempt.
Everyone in the hall already knew the fifth elder’s fate. Many began to sob quietly, the weight of the situation heavy on their hearts.
But none of them would plead for the fifth elder. It wasn’t out of cold-heartedness, but because forgiving him would mean betraying Scion, who was utterly blameless in all this.
Krylak took a deep breath, his face somber as he looked at Velkor. "You knew the consequences. Yet, for your grandson, you chose this path."
Velkor nodded, his tears still flowing. "Yes, I did. And I accept my fate. But please, consider my grandson’s innocence in all this."

chapters.title: Chapter 117: Taking Punishment
chapters.content:
Chapter 117: Taking Punishment
Among everyone present, Krylak was suffering the most. The words stuck in his throat for a long time before he finally forced them out, his voice trembling.
"Velkor, for plotting against the clan’s prodigy, Scion, you are hereby stripped of your elder status, expelled from the tiger clan, and denied entry into the ancestral tomb after your death. You will not receive worship from future generations. Additionally, you will be sent to the Moon Goddess Temple for sacrifice tomorrow."
After uttering the last two words, Krylak seemed to have exhausted all his strength and collapsed into his seat, saying no more.
Torvak, who had run out of the hall earlier, had been eavesdropping outside. When he heard the truth, tears streamed down his face, and it felt like all his strength had been drained. He clung desperately to his mouth, forcing himself to listen until he heard the word "sacrifice."
That was the breaking point. He coughed up a mouthful of blood and collapsed in a faint from the overwhelming grief.
"Velkor!" Targon held his friend’s weak shoulders and called out anxiously.
When Torvak didn’t respond, Targon quickly picked him up and ran toward the clan physician’s residence.
Inside the hall, Velkor seemed to sense something and looked toward the entrance. He saw the glaring pool of fresh blood on the ground.
With trembling hands, he clenched his eyes shut and rasped, "Torvak, I accept my guilt and punishment."
"Velkor, I will take care of Torvak. The underworld is dark; if you’re afraid, just wait for me there. I don’t think I can get over with this easily, so I may see you there very soon. When the time comes, I’ll come find you," the Grand Elder, his hair and beard white, spoke with tears in his eyes.
Velkor’s lips quivered, and he managed a feeble smile. "Thank you, but I wish you a long life. Just live your life to the fullest, for yourself and for me."
Arix, having observed the whole scene, felt sympathy for Velkor but didn’t speak up for him.
She knew all too well how dire Scion’s situation had been. If she hadn’t been there, the best Scion could have hoped for would have been death from a psychic power overload. Her heart had grown cold.
To her surprise, Scion suddenly spoke, "I didn’t die, so a sacrifice is unnecessary. The fifth elder has dedicated his life to the clan. Let his merits offset his faults."
With that, Scion stood up and picked up Arix. Then he left, not sparing another glance at Velkor’s fate.
The tiger clan members, hearing this, shook their heads with mixed emotions and began to leave as well.
Velkor stared in disbelief at Scion’s departing figure. Then, trembling, he stood up to the direction Scion had left.
He bowed three times, deep enough that he could barely stood straight again. Then he lifted his head, speaking to the darkness, "Scion, I’m sorry for doing all that to you. I know I don’t have any chance to see you again in this life, so let’s meet in our next life, and I’ll make amendments for my wrongdoing."
The turmoil ended with the Fifth Elder being expelled from the Tiger clan, set to leave alone the following day.
After regaining consciousness and learning of the events, Torvak dragged his ailing body to Scion’s villa and begged at the door. He was filled with both guilt and desperation.
"Scion, Torvak is still kneeling outside. Should we get someone to help him up?" Arix asked. She was leaning on the windowsill, looking at Torvak who had been kneeling for hours.
"Let him be," Scion replied coolly.
Scion continued to address various issues and requests from the Tiger Legion, leaving Arix feeling neglected. She pouted and turned back to observe Torvak at the villa entrance.
"Vita, do you know what illness Torvak has?" Arix asked absentmindedly.
"I haven’t examined him, so I can’t be sure, but it looks like premature aging," Vita responded, then gave a tentative guess.
"Premature aging?" Arix blinked in curiosity. "You mean, like, bad-in-bed kind of aging?"
Vita was silent for a moment before rubbing his forehead and replying, "It does affect that aspect, but it’s not just that."
"Oh, so it does affect that. Poor Torvak," Arix said sympathetically, looking at Torvak.
"Arix, let’s be serious," Vita said, both exasperated and indulgent.
"Sorry, my bad," Arix giggled playfully, sticking out her tongue.
After the playful exchange, Vita noticed Arix still gazing at the person below and seemed to understand something. He asked cautiously, "Arix, do you want to help him?"
"Yes, he is family after all. Plus, as a healer, I can’t just ignore a patient in need," Arix said, feigning helplessness while glancing at the young man cloaked in darkness below.
Torvak was stubbornly kneeling on the cold ground, despite knowing Scion wouldn’t see him. He was just trying to express his sorry in the most earnest way he knew.
It was foolish, but also endearing.
Arix watched Torvak, a smile tugging at her lips.
"Then go ahead," Vita said, always supporting Arix’s decisions one hundred percent.
"Alright." Having made up her mind, Arix jumped down from the windowsill, ready to head outside.
"Where are you going?" Scion had just finished a task and looked over at the little cub who had reached the door.
Arix froze mid-step, then turned and answered obediently, "I want to check on Torvak."
Scion was silent for a moment, then resumed his work. He asked casually, "When will you be back?"
"Not sure, it might take a while," Arix replied honestly after thinking for a moment.
"Take your time," Scion said, his tone softer. "Just make sure he understands his place in all this."
"Alright!" Arix beamed, showing her little sharp teeth. Just as she was about to step outside, Scion’s indifferent voice stopped her in her tracks.
"Do your best."
Arix’s eyes widened in surprise, then she smiled slightly and responded, "Okay."
She continued out the door, while Scion put down his work and slowly walked to the window. He looked down at Torvak, still kneeling at the villa entrance.
After a moment, Scion lifted his hand and opened his opticomputer. Scrolling through countless contacts, he selected one without a name, bearing a completely black avatar.
"By dawn tomorrow, I want to hear about the death of the Dragon clan’s ninth elder," Scion sent the message coldly.
The response came instantly: "As you wish, sir."
Scion calmly shut down his opticomputer, then silently gazed at the full moon outside the window.

chapters.title: Chapter 118: Arix Being Afraid
chapters.content:
Chapter 118: Arix Being Afraid
At the villa’s entrance, Torvak knelt, his posture rigid. His face, cold and thin, reflected a mix of guilt and gratitude.
He knew this act of kneeling was a bit much and would likely make Scion uneasy, but he felt lost on how else to repay him. He always saw himself as a burden, never truly helpful.
This time, the burden felt even heavier because, due to him, his respected grandfather almost became the one who get Scion killed.
Thinking about it, Torvak’s head drooped in shame. His once-clear eyes grew clouded with sadness.
Tears began to fall, heavy and uncontrollable. The thought that he should be the one to die consumed him.
Just then, Arix reached out a paw and placed it on his arm, checking his pulse.
In the midst of his sorrow, Torvak noticed the warm paw on his arm, offering comfort. He looked up, puzzled, and saw a small cub smiling at him. "Hi, Torvak."
For a moment, Torvak stared blankly before he remembered this was his cousin, Arix, who had just arrived.
Embarrassed that she saw him crying, he quickly wiped his tears and tried to smile. "Hello, Arix."
Arix, seeing the young man smiling through his tears and even with a snot bubble, couldn’t hold back her laughter.
"Stop making me laugh; I can’t check you properly," she giggled.
Torvak blinked. Seeing the cub Arix laughing so hard, he turned his head in embarrassment, scratching his neck shyly.
Arix’s interruption had stopped his tears. He thought about how much his cousin liked this little cub.
’Maybe Scion sent her here?’
The more Torvak thought about it, the brighter his eyes became.
He looked expectantly at the little cub.
After finishing her laughter, Arix noticed Torvak’s hopeful gaze. She didn’t need to guess what he was thinking. Even though she came to treat Torvak by herself, it could be seen as having Scion’s implicit consent. So, she nodded.
"What did Scion ask you to do?" Torvak asked eagerly.
’To treat you, of course!’
Arix frowned slightly as she thought about the cause of Torvak’s illness. She started taking out her treatment tools, beginning with a scalpel.
’What else do I need? Let me think.’
While Arix was thinking, Torvak’s eyes were fixed on the scalpel. ’Is Scion implying I should take my own life to atone? Makes sense. If I had died earlier, I wouldn’t have been a burden to Grandfather and Cousin Scion.
Unconsciously, Torvak’s hand grasped the scalpel. Slowly, he began to move it toward his neck.
Arix had just taken out a vial to collect some blood when she noticed the scalpel was missing.
She looked around, puzzled, but it was nowhere to be seen.
Then, a glint caught her eye. Looking up, she saw Torvak poised to slit his own throat.
Her fur stood on end as she jumped up and swatted the scalpel out of his hand. "What are you doing? Are you crazy? You’re going to kill yourself over something so minor?" she yelled, her voice a mix of anger and fear.
"But... the scalpel was right in front of me. I thought it meant I should take my own life," Torvak replied, looking hurt and confused.
Arix was speechless. Sometimes, being naive could easily turn into being foolish, and this guy was a prime example.
She almost had a medical disaster on her hands, not because of her treatment but because of his misguided actions.
Taking a deep breath to calm herself, Arix managed to suppress the "colorful" language she wanted to use.
"Torvak, just put your hand out. Now, have you considered that, it’s possible that the scalpel was meant for drawing blood?" Arix used her psychic power to control the scalpel and made a small cut on Torvak’s finger.
Once the vial was filled with blood, she applied some ointment to his wound.
Watching his finger heal quickly, Torvak realized he had misunderstood the situation. He coughed awkwardly and asked, "So, what does Cousin Scion need my blood for?"
"It’s not Scion who needs your blood, it’s me," Arix explained patiently, fearing that if she didn’t clarify, Torvak might misunderstand again and cause more trouble. "I need your blood to study why you’re aging prematurely."
Torvak seemed to feel quite embarrassed knowing that his secret had been found. Hearing Arix’s explanation, he almost choked on his own spit and coughed violently.
Finally catching his breath, he blushed and protested loudly, "I am not! Don’t say such things."
Arix nodded, trying to keep a straight face. "Right, you don’t."
Torvak puffed out his cheeks in anger. Huffing, he turned away in a fit of rare bad temper.
Arix gathered the materials she needed and was about to leave. But seeing Torvak, still adorable even while sulking, she softened. "Torvak, you should go back early too. I believe Scion has never blamed you guys." With that, Arix turned and walked away.
Torvak, still kneeling, froze at Arix’s words. Even though he didn’t get up, the heavy burden on his chest that made it hard to breathe seemed to lift with her voice.
His lips curved slightly, and his usually clear eyes no longer appeared so dim.
Torvak looked up at the villa, focusing on the only window still lit. He spoke loudly, as if talking to himself, "Scion, thank you for forgiving Grandpa. I’m sorry for the harm Grandpa and I caused you, but in this lifetime, I probably won’t have a chance to repay you. If there is a next life, I want to be your mecha to repay and protect you!"
With that, Torvak bowed heavily three times. Then, he turned back and left the villa’s entrance.
Standing by the window, Scion silently listened to the young man’s words. Then, with a rare hint of disdain in his tone, he closed the curtain and muttered, "Not necessary."
The next morning, Arix, who had worked all night, stumbled out of the lab, her eyelids heavy. She was so exhausted that she nearly fell.
Staying up all night was like hell for a little cub like her; it was no less challenging than her previous physical power training.
But, she finally managed to make the detox potion for Torvak.
Creating the potion wasn’t the issue; it was the interstellar virus that had evolved unexpectedly.
Can you imagine the frustration? Arix dropped the antidote into Torvak’s poisoned blood, saw it turn back to a healthy red, and then, just like that, it turned black again, becoming resistant to her antidote.
Talk about a slap in the face!
Her determination hardened. If she didn’t create an effective antidote by the end of the night, she’d admit defeat to the virus.
So, she spent the entire night watching the blood change from red to black and back again.
When the blood finally stayed red, Arix almost thought she was dreaming.
After checking multiple times to make sure it was real, she nearly cried from relief.
At last, she could sleep.
But before that, knowing Torvak might leave the clan today, Arix wanted to hand over the potion to Scion to ensure she could rest peacefully.
She staggered all the way to Scion’s room, even bumping her forehead somewhere, leaving a small bump.
Scion sensed her approaching and opened the door just as she reached it.
"Arix, you took your time," Scion said, his voice carrying concern rather than blame.
Arix barely lifted her eyelids. She handed over the detox potion from her Space Button, and placed it on the floor.
"Torvak’s detoxification potion, Scion, please give it to him," she managed to say before collapsing and falling asleep right there.
Scion’s heart tightened. He quickly picked her up, checked her condition, and sighed with relief when he saw she was just asleep.
Looking at the exhausted Arix, he felt a mix of helplessness and fondness. He gently patted her head.
Seeing the small bump on her forehead, he paused, then took out some ointment and gently applied it to the bump.
After finishing, Scion used his psychic power to pick up the potion from the ground without giving it a second glance.
He first went into the room, gently placed Arix on the bed. He covered her with a small blanket, making sure she wouldn’t catch a cold.
Only then did Scion turn his attention to the potion in his hand. It was still a dark, black liquid, but this time it had a hint of red compared to the psychic power healing potion he had drunk before.
Thinking about the last time, Scion’s eyes flashed with curiosity as he opened the bottle cap.
Before he could even get close to smell it, a bitter, acrid, and slightly spicy scent hit his nose.
Scion quickly put the cap back on, his expression showing rare sympathy.

chapters.title: Chapter 119: Tarvork Cured
chapters.content:
Chapter 119: Tarvork Cured
At the entrance of the clan estate, Krylak, the leader of the Tiger clan, stood with four elders. They were bidding farewell to Velkor.
Surprisingly, Torvak was also there.
At this moment, Krylak put his hand on Torvak’s shoulder and said, "Are you sure about this? Won’t you reconsider?"
"Thank you, but I want to spend my remaining time with my grandfather," Torvak replied, looking at his grandfather standing beside him. He then smiled and shook his head at Krylak.
Velkor did not object and affectionately patted Tarvok’s hair with a kind smile.
Seeing the determination in both the grandfather and grandson, Krylak did not argue further. He sighed and said, "Alright, here are two spacecraft tickets to Planet Sapphire and some supplies. Please accept them as my final gesture of help."
Hesitating if he should take the two tickets and the Space Button handed to him, Torvak glanced at his grandfather.
Velkor nodded, indicating he should accept them.
Torvak then took the tickets and Space Button, expressing his gratitude to Krylak, "Thank you."
Krylak smiled and nodded. The four elders also took out their prepared Space Buttons and handed them to Torvak.
Feeling touched, Torvak and Velkor accepted everyone’s kindness. After a few more words, Velkor prepared to leave with Torvak.
Just then, Scion’s servant hurriedly arrived.
Seeing that Velkor and the others had not yet left, the servant breathed a sigh of relief.
"Young Master, the admiral has something for you," the servant said, handing the black potion to Torvak.
"Is this really from Cousin Scion?" Torvak exclaimed joyfully.
Everyone present was equally surprised, staring at the potion in the servant’s hand in astonishment.
"Yes, Admiral Scion gave it to me and said it would treat you. He said you should drink it now. It will cure your illness," the servant said, trying to relay the admiral’s message succinctly.
The crowd fell silent at these words.
Even Torvak was stunned.
If it hadn’t been the admiral who said this, no one would have believed the potion could do magic.
But Velkor heard it clearly. He excitedly took the potion, opened the bottle, and quickly handed it to Torvak, saying, "Drink it, now."
Torvak still found it hard to believe he could be saved, but hearing his grandfather’s words, he nodded in a daze.
He took the potion and, under the expectant gazes of everyone present, drank it all in one go.
"How do you feel? Do you feel any better?" Velkor asked, looking at Torvak with concern.
Torvak frowned, not answering his grandfather’s question. His mind was full of how awful the potion tasted.
But thinking that this potion could cure the illness that had plagued him for years, he forced himself not to throw up.
As the horrible taste finally faded, before he could say anything, he began to vomit black blood, mouthful after mouthful.
This dreadful scene alarmed everyone, who quickly gathered around in worry.
Krylak immediately picked Torvak up and rushed back to the estate to find a doctor.
Lying in Krylak’s arms, Torvak actually didn’t feel any discomfort, except that he couldn’t stop vomiting blood.
And strangely enough, the more he vomited, the better he felt.
Although Torvak was puzzled, seeing the worried looks on everyone’s faces, he wanted to reassure them that he was fine.
But with his mouth continuously spewing black blood, he couldn’t say anything.
Moreover, his blood-soaked appearance scared everyone into moving even faster, leaving no time to notice his attempt to speak.
...
Dr. Morkai of the Tiger clan was lounging in his garden, enjoying a peaceful breakfast. He took a sip of goat milk, closed his eyes, and let the rich, creamy flavor spread across his taste buds.
After finishing his milk, he picked up a golden toothpick, speared a small blueberry, and popped it into his mouth. The sweet and tangy taste made him squint with delight.
The weather was perfect, and so was his mood.
As the only doctor in this clan, this was the kind of life he felt he deserved.
Thinking about Torvak, the little rascal leaving the clan today, Morkai couldn’t help but feel a bit of satisfaction. Yet, he also felt a wave of joy.
That little troublemaker had been a thorn in his side for over a decade.
No matter what Morkai was doing, there was always a patient named Torvak who was disrupting his peace.
For example, whenever Morkai finally managed to fall asleep after struggling with insomnia, frantic knocking would sound outside his bedroom.
"Dr. Morkai! Help! Torvak has passed out!"
Morkai would open his bloodshot eyes, and glare towards the door like a ghost. Then, he’d take a deep breath, and grudgingly get up to make a house call.
Another time, just as Morkai speared a piece of meat with his fork during a meal, someone would burst in out of nowhere, grab him, and run while explaining anxiously.
"Dr. Morkai, sorry to bother you, but saving a life is urgent! Torvak is in critical condition!!"
With a blank expression, Morkai would listen while still managing to eat the meat on his fork.
But the most annoying time was when he was in the middle of relieving himself, and the knocking started on the bathroom door.
"Dr. Morkai! Help! Torvak is vomiting blood!"
Morkai’s hand stopped, and he let out a furious roar.
Remembering these bitter moments, Morkai quietly speared another blueberry, trying to let the sweetness comfort his wounded heart.
But before he could put the blueberry in his mouth, there was a knock on the door.
Morkai frowned, puzzled as to who would need a doctor so early in the morning.
"Dr. Morkai! Help! Help! Torvak is vomiting a lot of blood!!!" Krylak shouted anxiously.
Snap—!
The golden toothpick in Morkai’s hand broke. He looked up at the sky with lifeless eyes, took a deep breath, then got up to open the door.
What he saw was Torvak, covered in blood.
Morkai’s frown deepened, and he quickly set aside his complaints to examine Torvak’s body.
It didn’t take long before Morkai suddenly looked up, his eyes filled with shock and disbelief, staring at Torvak.
"Dr. Morkai, how is Torvak?" Velkor asked worriedly.
Morkai frowned, staying silent. He then stood up and led the way, saying, "Come with me to the treatment room for a detailed examination."
Velkor and the others, without any doubt, quickly followed.
Half an hour later...
Morkai stared at the virtual screen with a mix of emotions. The health report displayed a single short line: "Healthy, slight anemia."
He knew what each of those words meant, but together, they formed a conclusion that baffled him. Torvak was really healed.
’Is the person who treated him a genius, or am I just not good enough?’
For the past decade, Morkai had scoured countless ancient texts, yet he had never found a way to save Torvak.
’So how did this mystery person manage to do it?’
He wondered.
Confounded, Morkai turned to Velkor and asked, "Has Torvak received any treatment recently?"
Velkor shook his head, then tentatively added, "Recently, besides from you, Torvak hasn’t received any treatment from others. But just now, after drinking the potion sent by Admiral Scion, he started vomiting black blood continuously. So, what’s wrong with Torvak?"
"The admiral, huh." Morkai lowered his eyes, deep in thought. After a while, he looked up at the group and said, "Torvak is fine now. I mean, he is completely cured."
Everyone was stunned, exchanging looks of disbelief. Velkor, in particular, asked with difficulty, "Are you serious? Is Torvak really cured?"
"Yes," Morkai nodded affirmatively.
Upon receiving this confirmation, Velkor burst into tears, collapsing to his knees and crying out in regret, "It was Scion who saved Torvak! Gosh... He saved Torvak. Look at what I’ve done to him!"
The person he had wronged save his closest kin. That was no better than a direct slap on his face, although that also made him glad.
The others present understood the gravity of the situation. Apart from a heavy sigh, they remained silent.
Morkai’s feelings were different from theirs. He found them noisy and irritating. Besides his curiosity about the admiral’s potion, his mind was only on the breakfast he had yet to finish in the garden.
Thinking about the blueberries still waiting for him, Morkai mercilessly issued an order to leave, "Since it’s all good now, take him out."
Ignoring their reactions, Morkai left the treatment room.
Krylak and the four elders were left staring at each other. They sighed and stayed behind.
Back in his garden, Morkai resumed his small breakfast, savoring the delicious bites while watching the birds flit among the flowers. His soul felt lighter, and even the frustration from earlier melted away.
After finishing his meal, Morkai leisurely turned on his opticomputer and initiated a video call to Scion.
"Uncle Morkai," Scion answered quickly.
"Torvak is fine now. By the way, the potion you gave him, who was the Master Chemist that made it?" Morkai asked, curiosity piqued.
"It wasn’t a Master Chemist," Scion replied calmly.
Morkai looked at Scion in surprise and asked, "Then who was it?"
Scion remained silent, just looking at him quietly.
Morkai understood that this was something he couldn’t talk about. He pouted and said, "Then can you at least get me a potion for my own research?"
"No," Scion said with a poker face, continuing to look at him quietly.
