"Looks like the Celesterrors are getting the news," Arix muttered, then moved forward to see more of what was happening.
The sudden disappearance of the gods had caused even the lower-ranking Celesterrors to sense something was off.
After asking around, they were plunged into despair. Some were collapsing, some were swearing, and others were weeping.
Arix moved quietly, witnessing the hopelessness among the Celesterrors.
Those who had accepted their fate were silently saying goodbye to their friends and family. Others, in sheer panic, began to harm themselves—plucking their fur, tearing off their scales, or bashing their heads against trees until they bled.
Seeing this chaos, Arix felt deeply troubled. She glanced up at the sky and sighed softly.
Then, she soared into the air, transforming her small body into a gigantic full moon that appeared in the sky.
Taking a deep breath, she addressed all living beings on the ground, "I am Sylvana. Before dusk today, I will take you away from this place. Bring your family and friends and gather here. Remember! Come here before dusk. When the moon rises, it will be your time to leave. Do not be late!"
Arix’s voice, filled with divine power, echoed in the ears of all living beings.
The Celesterrors, upon hearing the message, went from disbelief to pure joy. As soon as Arix finished speaking, the entire ancient Earth was in an uproar. All living beings began to move in a grand migration toward Arix’s location.
Arix repeated her words three times before stopping. Then she looked down.
By now, countless beings had already gathered below. As soon as they saw Arix, they knelt down in unison, shouting excitedly, "Thank you, Sylvana, for saving our lives!"
Seeing so many Celesterrors bowing to her, Arix remained calm on the outside but felt a bit flustered inside. She couldn’t help but worry if any of her ancestors were among the kneeling Celesterrors. That would be super awkward!
Suppressing a twitch at the corner of her mouth, Arix coughed lightly. Then she spoke majestically to the Celesterrors on the ground, "No need to kneel. Help me calm the other beings instead."
The Celesterrors seemed to notice that Arix didn’t like such formalities. They exchanged glances before lowering their heads respectfully and saying, "Yes."
Following this, the leaders among the Celesterrors began to soothe and organize their groups. Before long, the once chaotic crowd of Celesterrors returned to order, and the later arrivals were properly arranged.
Arix let out a sigh of relief upon seeing the situation stabilize.
As dusk approached, the area within a thousand-mile radius was densely packed with beings. All of them looked up at Sylvana in the sky with hopeful eyes. This was their hope and their last lifeline.
Arix glanced at the sky, then looked down once more at the beings below. She closed her eyes and took a deep breath. Then, she suddenly opened her eyes and began to dance the Sylvana Dance.
Yes, it turned out that the Sylvana Dance was a sacrificial dance, but the sacrifice was Sylvana herself.
Arix’s dance wasn’t as graceful as Scion’s; in fact, it was somewhat awkward. But with each step she took, the ground beneath her lit up, making the dance appear even more sacred than a beautiful performance.
As Arix danced, the once serene and peaceful sky gradually turned blood-red, and the ground shook as if an earthquake were happening.
A foreboding sense of doom hung over every being’s heart. They knew this was a sign of the impending disaster.
The trembling beings suppressed their instinct to flee, their hopeful gazes fixed on the sky.
Upon seeing the white silhouette in the sky, they finally relaxed a bit. Sylvana was fighting for them, so they couldn’t afford to hold her back.
Just before the great disaster struck, Arix finally finished the Sylvana Dance. She looked at the beings below one last time, then her lips parted, and an ancient, incomprehensible chant echoed in the sky.
"God of gods, mother of all, I, Sylvana, offer my blood, flesh, and soul. Let heaven bear witness, I shall not regret."
As her voice fell, every step Arix had taken during the dance began to glow brilliantly.
In the blink of an eye, a massive magical array formed, expanding until it enveloped all the creatures below. It only stopped once everything was covered.
A huge moon rose from the horizon, larger than ever before. As the creatures realized what was happening, they found themselves bathed in bright moonlight, slowly lifting off the ground.
When all the beings were safely transferred, the sky turned a deep blood-red. Countless meteors began tearing through the clouds, crashing toward the earth with terrifying force.
Seeing the world now devoid of life, Arix let out a relieved sigh. Exhausted, she began to fall from the sky. As she fell, Arix—no, Sylvana’s body—started to gradually disappear.
Just when Arix thought she would die alone, a distant tiger’s roar echoed through the sky.
"Sylvana, you idiot! Your solution was to sacrifice yourself? Are you out of your mind!!"
Arix heard a noise and strained to look over her shoulder, only to see a tiger charging desperately towards her. Tears welled up in her eyes for reasons she couldn’t understand, and she whispered, "Cupid..."
Just before she hit the ground, the tiger caught her. As Arix’s body started to fade, panic filled the tiger’s eyes.
In disbelief, he asked, "What did you sacrifice? Where is your soul? Why is it disappearing so quickly?"
"Had no choice," Arix weakly pushed at the tiger, "Not enough flesh and blood, had to give up my soul too. I’m dying. Leave me, go!"
"Sylvana, I can’t leave you," the tiger said quietly, shaking his head.
"Are you stupid?!" Arix, if she had the strength, would have knocked on the tiger’s head like her brother used to.
"You think you’re the only one who can be foolish?" the tiger huffed.
"You knew you’d die." Arix’s vision blurred, and her voice wavered.
The power of the sacrifice was eating away at Sylvana’s soul. Arix felt her senses dulling, her consciousness slipping. In her last moment of awareness, she weakly murmured, "Go... go..."
When Arix’s consciousness plunged into darkness, she found herself floating out of Sylvana’s body, now in soul form. She looked at the tiger and saw his mouth moving, chanting something.
"God of gods, mother of all, I offer my flesh and soul in exchange for Sylvana’s life, without regret."
Understanding his words, Arix panicked and tried to stop him, but her soul couldn’t touch the tiger. "No! How could you be so foolish..." Arix cried, but it was useless.
She collapsed to the ground, watching helplessly as the sacrificial power consumed the tiger. Unlike Arix’s despair, the tiger seemed content, as if he had achieved his goal.
Seeing Sylvana stop fading thanks to his sacrifice, a satisfied smile crossed his face. With his now-transparent head, he gently nuzzled Sylvana and, in a soft voice, said, "Sylvana, you want to save the world, but I want to save you..."
Before he could finish, the tiger closed his eyes and fell beside Sylvana, powerless. Arix’s eyes widened, tears streaming uncontrollably. She reached out with her transparent hand, gently touching the tiger, who had lost half of his soul.
Seeing the tiger and Sylvana, both having lost half of their souls, Arix suddenly understood everything. "So, the tiger and Sylvana each gave up half of their souls. That means I am both Sylvana and the tiger," Arix said, her voice trembling.
She then looked at the tiger’s soul, which seemed to be split into three parts. At that moment, something clicked for her. With a mix of crying and smiling, she called out, "Cupid, Vita, Sophia, come back."
At her words, the tiger’s soul, which had left its lifeless body, floated out and flew into Arix’s forehead like a bird returning home.
...

chapters.title: Chapter 151: The New Arix
chapters.content:
Chapter 151: The New Arix
The instant the souls merged, Arix woke up on the sacrificial altar.
Still shaken from her recent despair, she took a moment to gather herself.
The priest nearby didn’t seem to notice Arix’s distant gaze. With a detached expression, he said, "Follow me."
Arix, still dazed, looked at him for a moment before her eyes regained focus. She silently nodded and then glanced back at the bustling crowd below the altar. A sense of relief washed over her as she saw their joyous faces.
This world was at peace, and the people were safe.
Arix smiled softly before turning away and leaving the sacrificial altar. She quietly followed the priest to a room.
He opened a wardrobe and said, "Go inside and transform into your human form. Do you have clothes?"
"Thank you, pontifex. Yes, I do," Arix replied politely.
"Good, go on in. I’ll wait outside," he said, his attitude softening at Arix’s politeness.
Arix nodded and entered the wardrobe room alone. It was simple, with just a changing area and a full-length mirror. She stood before the mirror, silently looking at her tiger form.
"Cupid, Vita, Sophia," she called out in her mind.
This time, they responded quickly. Cupid appeared first, worriedly asking, "Arix, what’s wrong? You seem upset."
Vita and Sophia, sensing Arix’s distress, also emerged from the psychic world. Seeing the three small tigers sitting in a row, Arix’s nose tingled, and tears streamed down her face.
Her vulnerability startled Cupid and the others. They quickly surrounded her, even Sophia awkwardly trying to comfort her. "Don’t cry. Tell us who hurt you, and we’ll beat them up," Sophia offered.
"Yeah! Whoever dares to bully Arix, we’ll fight them!" Cupid said, waving her paws angrily.
Vita said nothing, gently patting Arix, but the murderous glint in her eyes was the most frightening of all.
Arix, feeling deeply moved, nuzzled the three little tigers and said, her voice choked with emotion, "No one dared to bully me. I just missed you all so much."
Her affectionate words made the three tigers blush instantly.
Cupid, in particular, started spinning in circles out of happiness, moving so fast that he became a blur.
Sophia turned her head away, her face flushed, and said with a proud tone, "Next time you miss us, just tell us directly. No need to hold it in."
Vita, sensing that Arix might be crying for another reason, chose to stay silent and not spoil the moment.
Arix nodded, wiped her tears, and changed the topic with a smile, "I just received the blessing, and now I can transform back. Cupid, do you want to see?"
The three little tigers exchanged glances, their eyes shining with excitement as they all said in unison, "We do!"
Arix’s lips curved into a gentle smile as she looked at the three little ones and said, "Wait for me a bit." Then, she turned and went into the small cubicle.
"What do you think Arix will look like when she gets her human form back?" Cupid asked, feeling both bored and curious, glancing at her two companions.
"No idea, but she definitely won’t look the same as before. After all, her therian genes have been unlocked," Sophia replied with her usual calmness.
"I bet she’ll have features of the Tiger clan, like silver hair as bright as the moon and blue eyes like the sky," Vita said with a soft smile.
"Well, that’s a given for the Tiger clan. No need to guess that. I’m wondering if Arix’s ears will turn into beast ears. That would be so cute!" Cupid wiggled her little butt in excitement.
Sophia and Vita imagined it for a moment and then both swallowed, giving a unanimous response, "That would be nice! Tiger ears are the cutest."
Their imaginations went a bit further, and they all ended up picturing a flat chest.
The three little ones exchanged glances, instantly understanding each other’s thoughts. Then they all sighed in unison.
"Arix will definitely still be flat-chested," Cupid sighed regretfully.
"It would be nice if she had a bit of Luna Amethyst’s genes," Sophia said, thinking of the woman with a generous bosom, feeling a bit envious on Arix’s behalf.
"Flat is good too, at least it won’t be a burden in a fight," Vita tried to console with positive words.
"True, at least she saves on fabric," Sophia added, trying to suppress her guilty conscience.
"And she won’t have to worry about being squished while sleeping," Cupid said, tears streaming down her face like a waterfall, sympathetically.
Just then, as the three little ones were still chatting, the door to the small cubicle opened.
The three little tigers immediately straightened up, sitting obediently with innocent, pure looks on their faces, staring at the cubicle.
When Arix walked out, their eyes widened in shock.
’Who is this little fairy?’
Arix, rarely seen in a long dress, had her silver-moon-colored hair cascading down like cloud, elegantly tied up with a noble ribbon. She looked both graceful and coldly stunning.
Her blue eyes, like ice crystals, seemed to ripple like water, captivating anyone with a single glance, like the deep-sea mermen.
Her nose, firm and straight, had the delicate beauty of a woman with a hint of masculine boldness.
Her slightly thin, soft cherry lips were a vivid gem-like red, more delicate and bright than the petals of the most beautiful rose.
"How do I look? Pretty?" Arix asked, her fair little face smiling.
Her big eyes curved slightly, like the afternoon sun, dazzling enough to make one feel a bit dazed.
Arix’s stunning appearance, paired with her melodious voice, left the three little ones completely enchanted. They gazed at her, practically dropping their jaws.
"Even if she’s a bit flat, she’s so beautiful that it doesn’t matter," Cupid said, holding her face with both paws, eyes full of red hearts.
"Yeah, definitely," Vita added, blushing and coughing lightly.
"Right," Sophia stammered, her face turning red.
"What are you whispering about?" Arix asked, looking at the three little ones suspiciously, sensing they weren’t up to any good.
Cupid, Vita, and Sophia exchanged guilty glances and then shook their heads vigorously, denying in unison, "Nothing, nothing at all. We weren’t talking."
"Really? Maybe I misheard. Cupid, Vita, Sophia, go back to the psychic world. I need to go out," Arix said, thinking about the pontifex waiting outside and not wanting to delay any further.
"Okay," they replied and quickly retreated to the psychic world as if chased by devils.
This obvious guilty behavior made Arix narrow her eyes and raise an eyebrow in thought. It seemed they were indeed talking about her behind her back. But she let it go, thinking how cute they were.
Arix shook her head and opened the door, stepping out. "Sorry to keep you waiting," she said with a smile.
"No problem, let’s go," the priest said, eyes widening in awe at Arix’s beauty before his face turned pale. He stammered his words and then hurriedly led the way, as if chased by a devil.
Arix was utterly confused.
’Why does he seem afraid of me?’
...
Arix walked into the testing room.
Seeing another person enter, the elder priest in the testing room first admired the girl’s looks and then smiled warmly. "Place your hand here, please."
"Okay," Arix nodded politely and placed her hand on the testing device. The device scanned her hand with a purple light, absorbing a bit of her psychic power.
Shortly after, the virtual screen displayed the words "testing in progress."
Soon, the screen showed two lines of results representing physical power and psychic power.
Psychic Power: Supergiant++
Physical Power: Supergiant Class
Seeing the line for her psychic power, Arix frowned slightly in displeasure.
’Why did my psychic power increase again? Is that really a good thing?’
However, her physical power seemed more unpredictable, having impressively risen by two levels!
Looking at her physical power, Arix felt a bit of comfort in her otherwise bad mood.
She nodded in satisfaction, deciding to treat herself to some delicious food as a reward for her new achievements.

chapters.title: Chapter 152: Joining The Moon Goddess Temple
chapters.content:
Chapter 152: Joining The Moon Goddess Temple
Arix stayed calm, but the old priest beside her was so shocked he stood up. He rubbed his eyes and checked the screen several times to make sure he wasn’t mistaken.
"Young lady, would you consider joining us at the Moon Goddess Temple?" The old priest, looking excited, couldn’t hold back his invitation.
Arix’s face darkened as she decisively shook her head. "Sorry, I’m a soldier of the Alliance."
"No problem, the Moon Goddess Temple doesn’t mind," the old priest said with shining eyes. Not only didn’t he mind Alliance soldiers, he wouldn’t even mind a spy.
Arix’s mouth twitched, thinking, "Just because you don’t mind doesn’t mean I don’t."
Seeing that the old priest wasn’t going to give up easily, Arix decided to use her trump card.
"I’m already in love," Arix said, her face showing a shy and hesitant expression.
The old priest choked a little. But considering Arix’s talent, he still probed, "Can you break up?"
Arix was speechless.
Considering the priest’s earnest attitude, she might have really fallen for it. But sorry, she didn’t want to spend the rest of her life loveless.
Arix cursed inwardly, but had to keep up the appearance of a love-struck fool.
She cried out dramatically, "No, without him I can’t live. I love him so so much. We have the sweetest love in the world. I want to be with him forever!"
Arix forced herself to say those mushy things, feeling like she was going to throw up.
She wasn’t sure if she had grossed out the priest, but she certainly had herself.
Even though these love-struck words almost made Arix puke, the old priest seemed touched, lost in memories of his youth.
After a long sigh, he said regretfully, "There was once a love before me that I didn’t cherish. Young lady, maybe you’re right! Brave love, go for it! Good luck!"
Arix awkwardly smiled, "Thank you so much! I’ll be going now! Goodbye, sir!"
After thanking him, Arix didn’t wait for the old priest’s response and fled the room as if chased by ghosts.
She ran too fast, not paying attention to her surroundings, so she suddenly collided with someone.
A bit stunned, Arix looked up to see Scion’s face, as if carved from ice and snow.
"Scion? What are you doing here?" Arix blinked, curious.
Hearing the voice, Scion looked over, surprised to see the beautiful and otherworldly face of a young woman.
Scion’s eyes showed a hint of surprise, but he quickly composed himself, helping Arix to stand. He cleared his throat and said, "I was waiting to go back with you."
"Oh, that’s sweet. Scion, you’re so nice," Arix said.
Scion’s lips curved into a faint smile as he gently ruffled Arix’s hair, like he always did. "It’s getting late. Let’s head back."
"Okay." Arix nodded. The two of them headed back to the Tiger clan’s platform.
As they appeared before the crowd, a hush fell over the area. The Empire people, who had been chatting and joking, froze at the sight of them. Some dropped what they were holding, some rubbed their eyes in disbelief, and a few even fainted for no apparent reason.
Arix was initially confused, but after glancing at Scion’s strikingly handsome face, she understood.
Arix didn’t realize she was also causing a stir. She had spent a long period looking gaunt and skeletal, so she thought her appearance was ordinary and wouldn’t cause such a reaction.
Scion, looking at the beautiful Arix beside him, assumed it was her causing the commotion. He pulled her closer protectively, not suspecting himself at all. He had always had a strained relationship with strangers—men either envied or resented him, and women tended to avoid him once they knew his identity, as if being near him would bring misfortune.
If anyone knew what the two of them were thinking, they would laugh at this absurdity, since they were clearly blind to the reality of their own attractiveness.
When they reached the Tiger clan’s platform, Arix was surprised to see Cassian there as well. Cassian initially cast a disdainful glance at Scion, then quickly switched to a charming smile, looking at Arix in awe. "Arix, you look even more beautiful than before."
Cassian’s attractive smile and gentle expression made him seem like a breath of fresh spring air, warm and vibrant like the sun.
"Thank you, Cassian." Arix was pleasantly surprised but happy to see him.
Cassian’s smile was kind, but his tone carried a hint of subtle mockery as he asked, "Scion, what are you doing here? The ceremony isn’t over yet, is it?"
It was as if he was reminding Scion to be mindful of his age and status and not to harbor inappropriate thoughts.
Scion’s eyes turned icy. He knew Cassian was deliberately reminding him of his future role as the Pontifex.
Scion’s mind played with a cold, amused smile, but his face stayed calm and indifferent. "You Highness, only the current Pontifex can end the ceremony. And unfortunately, I am not the Pontifex yet. You’re still young, Your Highness. You still have a lot to learn."
Cassian’s smile stiffened. His biggest sore spot was his youth, with his face and body not yet fully developed. That’s why Arix never had that kind of interest in him. Even if he flaunted his looks, Arix only saw him as a handsome little boy.
Cassian suddenly felt a pang of jealousy for his father’s broad shoulders and eight-pack abs. Whenever his father showed off, his mother would gaze at him with starry eyes, unable to look away.
He pinched his still-soft stomach, feeling even more dejected. Looking at the defeated young wolf, Scion’s lips finally curved with a hint of satisfaction.
Arix stood off to the side, sneaking a glance at Cassian and then at Scion. The sudden silence between them felt heavy.
She couldn’t shake the feeling that Cassian and Scion had somehow slipped into some sort of combat mode. The tense air around them was so thick it scared off the nearby Tiger Clan members, who didn’t dare approach Arix to question her test results.
Only Drexel, always the carefree one, walked over and threw an arm around Arix’s shoulder, grinning widely. "Wow, Arix! You’ve really blossomed!"
"Nothing special, just average. By the way, have you upgraded your psychic or physical power levels?" Arix appreciated beauty in others but was immune to her own.
"Yep, I did. I’m now a Supergiant+." Drexel’s smug smile made him look like he was asking for a punch.
"Psychic power?" Arix asked, intrigued.
"You think upgrading psychic power is easy? It’s not like picking apples. I only managed to level up my physical power." Drexel tried to sound humble, but the pride was obvious.
Arix secretly rolled her eyes at Drexel, who looked ready to float away with pride, but she still clapped politely. "Drexel, that’s amazing. So your physical power is Supergiant+ now. I don’t think anyone in the Alliance has reached that level yet."
"Keep it low-key, Arix. What about you?" Drexel asked, looking hopeful.
Hearing this, the nearby Tiger Clan members perked up, listening intently.
"I leveled up too. My physical power is now Supergiant-Class. You don’t have to worry about me anymore." Arix smiled with a sibling’s warmth.
From now on, she wouldn’t be in life-threatening danger because of her physical power.
Drexel was momentarily stunned, then he pulled Arix into a tight hug, murmuring with pride, "Arix, I’m so proud of you."
Unbeknownst to Arix, Drexel’s relieved heart caused his once calm psychic world to stir.
Sheer, who was napping in Drexel’s psychic world, felt the shift. He opened his eyes, glanced around, but then he sighed, and went back to sleep. "This place is expanding."
After the blessing ceremony, Arix and the others took a beast-drawn carriage back. Unlike the journey there, the atmosphere in the carriage was now awkwardly quiet.
Arix glanced to her left at Cassian, then to her right at Scion.
Inwardly, she cursed Sunak for being so sneaky. No wonder there had been an empty seat earlier, yet he didn’t sit with them.
He must have seen this coming.
And these two, obviously at odds, still chose to sit together. Why?
Fortunately, Drexel, blissfully unaware, broke the silence. He looked at Cassian curiously and asked, "You’re the crown prince of the Empire, right? Is it really okay for you to just come along with us?"

chapters.title: Chapter 153: Leaving The Empire
chapters.content:
Chapter 153: Leaving The Empire
Scion lifted his gaze to Cassian, clear disdain in his eyes.
Cassian believed that if he didn’t show any embarrassment, the awkwardness would fall on others.
Ignoring the stares, he turned his face to a more flattering angle and, while answering Drexel, he kept his eyes on Arix. "I’ve already gotten my parents’ permission. Besides, Arix is heading back to the Alliance tomorrow. As her closest and most trusted friend, how could I miss her farewell party?"
His words sounded perfectly reasonable, and Arix was genuinely touched. She responded warmly, "Thank you, Cassian. You’re my best and dearest friend too, and Scion, you’re like a brother to me."
Cassian’s heart sank; he felt like he had shot himself in the foot.
’Does Arix misunderstand something?’
He wanted a relationship far beyond mere friendship!
Scion, watching the whole scene unfold, looked at Cassian with a hint of glee. The mocking curve of his lips was the most irritating part. Cassian, feeling a vein pop on his forehead, mouthed sarcastically at Scion, "Brother."
Scion ignored Cassian’s sarcasm; he only needed to keep an eye on this budding romance, ensuring Arix wasn’t led astray.
Cassian, on the other hand, was irked that a male who was as powerful as him kept hovering around Arix. That made him feel threatened. Thus, the two began exchanging hostile glances again.
Arix, the focus of their rivalry, was somewhat used to their antics. Weren’t she worried about being rude, she might have pulled out some cookies to munch on while enjoying the show.
After returning to the Tiger clan, Arix had no time to dwell on these matters.
The farewell banquet hosted by the clan was the grandest event in recent years, with every clan member who could make it in attendance.
As the stars of the day, the siblings were made to drink quite a bit.
Arix didn’t hold her liquor well; her head was spinning when Cassian suddenly took her by the wrist and gestured towards the balcony.
Thinking Cassian had something to say, Arix followed without resistance.
On the balcony, Arix pressed her temples, surprised by how potent the alcohol felt, even with her physical and psychic power struggling to cope.
"Arix..." Cassian, having drunk quite a bit himself, blushed as he awkwardly called her name.
"Hm?" Arix responded softly, looking at Cassian with confusion, patiently waiting for him to speak.
In the moonlight, Arix’s face looked almost divine, like a goddess. Her clear, delicate eyes added an extra layer of beauty. Cassian was instantly captivated, his cheeks flushing red, and the shyness in his golden eyes deepening.
"Um, I was thinking... since you’re going back to the Alliance... I wanted to ask you... if you..." Cassian awkwardly began, his voice shaking with nervousness. But before he could finish, a cold voice interrupted.
"Arix, Drexel is looking for you," Scion’s chilly tone cut through the night.
Scion stood at the balcony door, staring coldly at Cassian, his gaze full of warning.
Arix, tipsy from the night’s drinks, missed the thick tension between Scion and Cassian.
When she knew Drexel was looking for her, she hesitated, remembering Cassian had something to say.
Turning back to him, she asked, "Cassian, what did you want to tell me?"
Cassian forced a smile, hiding his inner turmoil. "Nothing important. Just wanted to remind you to be safe heading back tomorrow."
"Thanks," Arix replied, wincing from her headache. She decided to find Drexel as soon as she could before crashing in her room for the night.
Once Arix left, the balcony’s air turned icy. Cassian’s smile vanished as he glared at Scion with cold, golden eyes. "The mighty Empire Admiral and future Pontifex of the Moon Goddess Temple, have feelings for someone? Guess how people would react to that?"
"Prince Cassian, mind your words. Arix is like a sister to me," Scion replied, his gaze equally frosty.
Cassian scoffed, "A sister? Arix might see you as a brother, but do you really only see her that way?" His tone dripped with sarcasm as he locked eyes with Scion.
Scion paused, then said calmly, "Rest assured, Your Highness, Arix is just a sister to me."
Before Scion could finish, Cassian unleashed a terrifying psychic blast, slamming Scion against the wall. Scion crumpled to the ground, groaning but didn’t retaliate. Instead, he wiped the blood from the corner of his mouth in silence.
"Scion, if you like her, go after her boldly. Even if I lose to you, I’ll accept it. But who are you fooling with this pitiful act? I’m glad Arix only sees you as a brother. If she fell for someone like you now, it would be almost insulting," Cassian spat bitterly before storming off the balcony.
Out of Scion’s sight, Cassian smirked to himself. He was sure that Arix would surely only have eyes for him in the future.
He couldn’t allow Scion to keep playing the martyr in front of her. If Scion ever became Arix’s chosen one, where would Cassian find solace?
After Cassian left, Scion remained on the balcony alone. He opened his palm and quietly stared at the red mark in the center.
Then, he looked up at the full moon in the sky, and Cassian’s words echoed in his mind. Yes, it wasn’t others holding him back, it was himself.
But what use was it to know that? He couldn’t even guarantee his own future, let alone someone else’s. Instead of hurting her in the end, it was better to hide away.
The next day...
Arix and Drexel were saying goodbye to the people of the Tiger Clan.
"Drexel, Arix, make sure to come back to the Empire during your break!" Krylak said, his eyes misty with tears, clearly reluctant to see them go.
"Sure," the siblings nodded obediently, afraid that Krylak might start crying at any moment.
"These two Space Buttons are gifts from the clan. Just accept them. Don’t say no to me," Krylak said as he thrust the buttons into their hands, not giving them a chance to refuse.
Arix and Drexel exchanged glances, feeling awkward but accepting the gifts.
Seeing that they accepted, Krylak felt much happier. If they had said no to his love, it would have hurt his feelings.
"Alright, I won’t keep you any longer. Be safe on your journey," Krylak said, his voice choked with emotion.
The siblings, feeling a bit overwhelmed by the Tiger Clan’s emotional farewell, quickly said their goodbyes and headed on their way back to the Alliance.
...
In the space station...
Arix sat quietly in the waiting area, reading her mecha extracurricular book while waiting for Drexel to buy the tickets. However, a lone beauty often attracted unwanted attention. At that moment, two sleazy therian men approached her, looking to make a move.
"Hey there. It must be lonely all by yourself. How about some company?" they said, their intentions clear from their lecherous eyes.
Arix initially didn’t want to bother with these pests, but as they got closer, the air around her seemed to grow more foul. She looked up coldly and said, "Leave in three seconds, and I’ll let you go intact."
The two therians were stunned for a moment before laughing. Arix’s harmless appearance made them doubt she could be any threat.
In fact, they looked even more excited after hearing her words.
When they stepped within a meter of her, Arix lifted her hand indifferently. With a swift downward motion, two terrifying waves of psychic power slammed the therians heavily onto the ground.
Looking at the two who would definitely need a year to recover, Arix nodded in satisfaction. She then resumed reading her mecha book.
Arix’s swift action sent a clear message, causing several therian men who had thought about intervening to reconsider and stay quiet. The commotion quickly drew the attention of a few police officers.
After reviewing the footage and talking to witnesses, the officers pieced together the story.
Worried that Arix might be shaken, they approached her to offer some reassurance.
"Thank you, but I’m okay. My brother will be back soon," Arix said, blinking her eyes politely in gratitude.
Despite her reassurances, the officers were still concerned about the seemingly fragile young woman. They decided to have a female officer stay with Arix for added comfort and safety.
At first, Arix tried to decline their offer, but the determined looks on their faces made her sigh and give in. She knew Drexel would return soon, and it wouldn’t take much longer.
So, with the policewoman by her side, Arix continued reading her book in peace.

chapters.title: Chapter 154: Funny Flight
chapters.content:
Chapter 154: Funny Flight
Not long after, Drexel returned with two ship tickets in hand. As he approached, the policewoman scolded him, "How could you leave your sister alone to buy tickets? Two thugs came by and harassed her!"
Drexel, scratching his head, looked puzzled. "Oh, are those thugs okay? Do we need to compensate them?"
The policewoman’s anger flared. She felt sorry for Arix, such a sweet girl, stuck with a clueless brother like him.
Instead of worrying about his sister, the boy was concerned about the thugs!
After some stern criticism, Drexel finally admitted he was wrong.
Satisfied, the policewoman huffed and turned to Arix gently. "I’ll leave now. If you run into any danger again, don’t count on your brother. Call the police right away."
She cast another disdainful glance at Drexel before shaking her head and leaving.
Arix smiled and waved goodbye to the policewoman, then she couldn’t help laughing out once she was gone.
"Ready to go, Mr. Unreliable?" Arix teased, raising an eyebrow.
Drexel was at a loss for words.
’Why do I always get hurt in these situations? Never mind, I’ll just quietly cry for a bit.’
Feeling rather emotional, Drexel hugged himself pitifully.
Then, he took Arix to board the best spaceship at the space station.
As soon as they stepped on board, they were greeted by luxurious decorations and elegantly dressed high society folks.
One perk of traveling with the elite is that they usually have manners, or at least they pretend to. But this was quickly proven wrong.
Thanks to their good looks, as soon as the siblings walked through the ship’s lobby, countless wealthy businessmen and their wives turned their gazes on them with obvious interest.
Those lecherous looks made Drexel’s face darken immediately.
It wasn’t entirely the businessmen’s fault. The siblings’ plain attire made them look out of place on such a high-end ship.
Moreover, every flight had its share of gold-diggers who, despite their humble origins, bought expensive tickets just to mingle with the rich.
Just imagine, if one of them managed to hook up with a wealthy and attractive person on the ship, they could potentially climb the social status ladder dramatically.
Because of this frequent occurrence, the businessmen had a bit of a preconceived notion.
If the siblings knew they were mistaken for gold-diggers just because they weren’t flaunting wealth, they would probably want to gouge out their eyes and donate them to someone really in need.
From the ship’s lobby to their cabin, Drexel noticed he was constantly ogled by numerous wealthy women. The most infuriating part was their lingering gazes on his certain, unspeakable area.
Seeing Drexel shaking with anger, Arix secretly chuckled. She leaned in and whispered, "If you meet a good person, start a family. If you meet an influential person, build a career. If you meet a wealthy woman, you get both. Why don’t you just go along with it?"
The more Drexel listened, the darker his expression became, almost ready to give his sister a lesson in love. But then, a thought crossed his mind, and he smirked, letting out a cold laugh.
He immediately switched to a tender, lovelorn expression, gazing at Arix with nauseating affection.
This made Arix shiver. She knew her brother too well; he was about to cause a scene.
Sure enough, Drexel raised his pinky, gently patting Arix’s shoulder with exaggerated shyness.
In a high-pitched, coquettish voice, he said, "Oh, darling, how could you say that? Aren’t I still your sweetie? Darn it, you’re so annoying!"
Apparently not satisfied, Drexel continued in the same tone, "Darling, I’m out here with you. Won’t your boyfriend get mad at me if he knows? What if he gets upset? I’m so scared, boo-hoo-hoo. But for you, my darling, I’m not scared at all because I love you the most, mwah!"
As he said this, Drexel leaned in for a playful, macho cuddle, nearly knocking Arix over. By the time he finished, the air in the lobby had turned deathly silent, followed by the sounds of people retching.
Arix, who had taken the brunt of this display, was completely stunned. In that moment, she learned the ultimate lesson: when you’re so nauseated that you can’t throw up anymore, you’ve reached a new level of disgust.
Drexel, sensing his performance hadn’t quite hit the mark, turned his gaze towards the vomiting businessmen and the horrified ladies in the lobby. Once again, he raised his pinky in a delicate manner and, in a syrupy voice, said, "Ladies and gentlemen, don’t you think I’m just adorable?"
To cap it off, Drexel puckered his lips and blew a disgustingly exaggerated kiss, sticking out his butt.
SNAP... RIP...
Finally, someone in the lobby couldn’t handle Drexel’s over-the-top antics and fell off their seats. As bodies hit the floor, the wealthy ladies and gentlemen fled back to their cabins, as if they had seen a demon in the flesh.
Looking at the now-empty lobby, Arix gave Drexel a thumbs up and said, "When it comes to getting people sick, you’re always the best, Drexel!"
Drexel narrowed his eyes, and his mischievous fingers twitched uncontrollably. Seeing Drexel about to raise his pinky again, Arix shivered and quickly apologized in terror, "For god’s sake, stop doing that. I’m sorry for whatever I’ve done, OK?"
Only then did Drexel let out a satisfied humph and continue walking toward their cabin. As he led the way, he sighed dramatically, "I’ve sacrificed so much to protect my chastity."
When they reached their cabin, Drexel unlocked the door and took a look around.
The place had two bedrooms, a kitchen, a bathroom, and a cozy living room. It felt like a fancy apartment, all stylish and well-decorated.
Drexel nodded, clearly pleased with what he saw. Turning to Arix, he said, "You hang out in the living room for a bit."
Arix nodded, a bit confused but silent, waiting as Drexel asked.
Drexel headed straight to one of the bedrooms, and soon the sound of things being taken apart echoed from inside.
"What are you doing?" Arix asked, unable to curb her curiosity. She peeked into the bedroom to find Drexel removing the handle of a bedside table. She blinked, wondering if Drexel was finally showing his wild side.
"Just hold on," Drexel said, his voice tight with controlled anger as he worked faster. Soon, Drexel emerged from the room holding tiny, mini-sized cameras.
Arix’s face darkened as she quickly grasped what those cameras were for. "Can we figure out who did this?" she asked, her voice seething.
"Let’s worry about that later. First, we need to find all the cameras. Arix, open the opticomputer, and I’ll guide you through it," Drexel said, helping Arix install an anti-surveillance app.
The app opened to a compass-like interface. Following the arrows, they tracked down more cameras.
After a hectic search, Arix and Drexel sat in the living room, staring at the dozen or so cameras on the table. "Should we report this?" Arix asked, her icy eyes now glinting with anger.
"Not yet," Drexel replied, shaking his head with a cold smile. "Whoever messed with my sister is in for some payback."
Arix raised an eyebrow, recognizing that Drexel was about to get crafty. But this time, she was excited. "What do you need me to do?" she asked, eager.
"Find me ten of the scariest videos, the ones with the best jump scares," Drexel instructed. As his fingers flew over the virtual screen, lines of code appeared in a blur.
Arix nodded and began hunting for the scariest videos she could find. Meanwhile, Drexel kept working on tracing the cameras’ owner.
In no time, Drexel’s virtual screen displayed details about an unfamiliar middle-aged man. He saved the man’s information and looked up at Arix. "Arix, are you done?"
Arix nodded. "I’ve sent the videos to your opticomputer. Check if they’re good."
Drexel reviewed the scary videos, choosing the most terrifying ones. Then, he hacked into the voyeur’s opticomputer.
As some indescribable files popped up, Drexel quickly looked away, muttering "gosh" quite a few times.
Arix remained composed, because the videos were all women’s.
However, knowing their purpose still made Arix grit her teeth in anger. She looked at Drexel, eyes blazing. "What about the videos of the victims?"

chapters.title: Chapter 155: Videos Disappearing
chapters.content:
Chapter 155: Videos Disappearing
"We’ll delete them all after we deal with him," Drexel assured. He wouldn’t let those videos keep circulating, knowing the harm they could cause. The resolve in his eyes grew even sharper.
"So, what’s your plan?" Arix asked, her eyes gleaming with curiosity.
Drexel hesitated, his cold demeanor faltering. "It’s not really something for girls to hear. Just wait for the result if you’re curious."
Arix pouted but had a good idea of his plan. Her curiosity won out. "Tell me, and I’ll increase your share of the potion shop profits by 5%."
Drexel swallowed hard, tempted. "You sure you want to know? It’s kinda gross."
"Spill it," Arix insisted, confident she could handle it.
"Alright, just a moment." Drexel adjusted the opticomputer to mute and pulled out a cloth strip from his Space Button, tying it tightly over his eyes. Arix watched silently.
"Arix, you can see the rest for yourself. I won’t go into detail," Drexel said. He opened the unspeakable files and embedded the scary videos into all the existing ones.
Once done, Drexel exited the opticomputer and removed the blindfold, looking at Arix. "Got it?"
Arix touched her nose, impressed, and gave a thumbs up. "I heard if men got terrified while entertaining themselves... they’d have trouble getting it work ever again."
"Wow... how did you know that? But... yeah, that’s true," Drexel replied with a sinister smile.
Arix asked, "Are you sure it will work?"
"I’ve checked. He usually watches those files around 9 PM every night. I’ll keep a close eye on him, and once it works, I’ll call the police right away. Then I’ll destroy the videos," Drexel said seriously. He wasn’t one to joke about such matters.
"Alright, you keep an eye on him. I’m heading back to the bedroom," Arix said, feeling the weight of an early morning. She could use a nap.
"Sure, go ahead," Drexel replied, waving his hand. He opened his opticomputer again, and after a few quick operations, a live feed from the middle-aged man’s home surveillance system appeared on the virtual screen.
On a distant planet named Haranu, a neatly dressed middle-aged man slowly opened the door of his house. He scanned the room to make sure no one was there, then breathed a sigh of relief and placed his briefcase on the hall cabinet.
Shedding his disguise of a presentable suit and leather shoes, he reverted to his true self—a greasy, repulsive man.
He immediately headed to his secret haven. After a rough day at work, he was ready to blow off some steam in his private sanctuary.
An unpleasant smile crept across his face as he thought about it.
He quickly walked to the sofa. Unable to contain his excitement, he quickly opened his opticomputer. He projected a video from a hidden file onto a massive screen in front of him.
As he watched the young bodies on the screen, his excitement grew, and he began to engage in unspeakable acts.
As the strange and unspeakable noises in the room grew louder, the man descended into madness.
Suddenly, with a terrifying, piercing scream, a zombie with a face full of maggots and blood appeared on the virtual screen.
Her chin was missing, and where her eyes should have been were two horrifying blood holes.
The skin on her face was severely decayed, giving off a thick stench of rot and blood.
Fat, white maggots squirmed on her face, ready to drop off with the slightest movement.
This grotesque and terrifying scene made the man’s pupils shrink and eyes widen in fear.
A heart-wrenching scream echoed through his secret haven but stopped abruptly. He fainted from fright, his partially clothed body looking even more ugly and disgusting.
In the now silent secret haven, only an appliance camera was flashing a red light. Far across billions of light-years, Drexel watched the events unfold with cold indifference.
After the man passed out, Drexel, concerned for his well-being, kindly notified the interstellar police to ensure he didn’t catch a chill due to his lack of clothing.
Not wanting to risk anything happening to him before the police arrived, Drexel watched over him diligently.
Once the police arrived, Drexel turned off the remote surveillance.
With a sense of a job well done, Drexel slipped away quietly, leaving no trace.
When Arix woke up, it was already 10 PM. After freshening up, she eagerly headed to the living room.
"How did it go? Did we succeed?" Arix asked, her voice filled with curiosity and urgency.
Seeing Arix awake, Drexel put down his game controller with a smug expression. He then opened his opticomputer and turned the virtual screen towards her.
On the screen, numerous trending searches about the middle-aged man were displayed, their popularity rivaling even Arix’s previous gossips.
Arix quickly sat beside Drexel, scrolling through the screen with her finger.
Dominating the trending topics were all posts about the pervert with the mini cameras.
- "You’re being watched!"
- "Camera’s in most secret places!"
- "Beware of the electronic peeping Tom!"
- "Cameras found in major starship cabins!"
- "Haranu planet apprehends a criminal! Charged with installing nano cameras in starship cabins!"
- "Man finds cameras in starship cabin. His remark? Thank goodness I don’t have a girlfriend!"
As Arix scrolled down, she felt both repulsed and intrigued. By the time she finished reading, she breathed a sigh of relief, feeling like her eyes needed cleansing.
"So, how do you like the result?" Drexel asked, a proud smirk on his face, like a dog waiting for praise.
Arix nodded emphatically, giving him a thumbs up. "It’s incredibly satisfying. You did great!"
"Huh!!" Drexel laughed, flipping his hair with a self-satisfied grin.
"By the way, did you make sure to erase the victim’s videos?" Arix asked, concerned about any loose ends.
"Once the police finalize the charges, those videos will be automatically destroyed. If anyone tries to repost them, their opticomputer will be toast," Drexel replied, a cold smile playing on his lips.
"That’s a relief!" Arix said, completely at ease now. Hugging Drexel’s arm, she cheerfully said, "Come on, you worked hard today. Let me treat you to a late-night snack."
"Wow, you treating me snacks? That’s rare. Let’s go, I’m starving," Drexel replied happily, letting Arix cling to his arm.
The siblings, now in high spirits, walked to the dining hall, laughing and chatting along the way.
Haranu, the star where the middle-aged man lived, became the focus for the interstellar police handling the case.
After everything was settled, the police wanted to identify the victims in the videos to offer some compensation. However, as soon as they opened the files, all the videos vanished as if haunted.
At first, the police thought it was just a malfunction with their office opticomputer. They figured the archives should still have copies, so they asked a colleague in the archives to send the files over.
But as soon as the files were transferred, the opticomputer got hit by an incurable virus and completely crashed.
Before the officer could lament the loss of his brand-new opticomputer, his colleague from the archives rushed over in a panic. "Kaith, do you still have those videos? The ones in the archives just disappeared all of a sudden."
Kaith said nothing, simply handing over his broken opticomputer. The realization dawned on both of them as they exchanged glances.
Finally, the colleague sighed, "Looks like some top-notch hacker doesn’t want those videos to remain in this world."
Kaith rubbed his temples and said helplessly, "Well, it’s not necessarily a bad thing."
Maybe those victims didn’t need any compensation. Perhaps it was better for them not to know the truth and endure the pain it would bring.
Sometimes, the truth can be more devastating than a lie, cutting deeper than any knife.

chapters.title: Chapter 156: No Loose Ends
chapters.content:
Chapter 156: No Loose Ends
In the restaurant on the spaceship...
When the siblings stepped in, the buzz of lively chatter and the clinking of glasses came to an abrupt halt. All eyes were glued to Drexel. But this time, they weren’t just looking at him. They were watching him, like they’d spotted a real troublemaker.
Seeing the curious and anxious faces around, Drexel felt a rush of excitement. The wealthy businessmen and ladies present suddenly felt a wave of tension, ready to flee at a moment’s notice.
Arix, equally on edge, quickly grabbed Drexel’s arm. "Drexel, let’s be decent. Even if they were wrong before, they deserve a chance to be forgiven."
Seeing the concern in his sister’s eyes, Drexel sighed and decided to hold back. The room exhaled a collective sigh of relief as the tension eased, and conversations resumed.
The spaceship’s restaurant was set up buffet-style. After finding a seat, Drexel and Arix went their separate ways to gather their favorite foods. Drexel headed straight for the roast beef with red wine sauce, while Arix joined the group of ladies, picking a few desserts and fruits.
"Hey, did you hear? Tonight at 11 PM, the Empire is going to announce a new law banning the sale and hunting of Celesterrors," one well-connected lady said, flaunting her insider knowledge.
"Really? Is the Empire trying to follow the Alliance’s example? Why suddenly introduce a Celesterror protection act?" another lady asked eagerly.
"I heard it’s because someone saved Prince Cassian, and Alpha Leonidas granted that person a wish. Instead of choosing to become a Duke, that person wished to protect the Celesterrors," the first lady explained, with a hint of regret in her voice.
"Yeah, what a waste! If only that opportunity had been given to me," the second lady sighed.
Hearing the conversation, Arix was first taken aback. Then she remembered Mama Tiger, and a warm smile spread across her face.
"It’s not a waste at all," Arix thought silently. She picked up her tray and headed back.
"Why are you eating so little? You’re already so thin, and you’re still picky," Drexel grumbled when he saw the small selection of desserts and fruits on Arix’s tray. He then forked a piece of steak from his own heaping plate and placed it on hers.
"Just woke up, no appetite. If I can’t finish it, you’re on clean-up duty," Arix grumbled, eyeing the steak that was nearly the size of her face. She felt stuffed just looking at it.
"Fine, I’ll handle the leftovers," Drexel said, rolling his eyes. He started eating at lightning speed, as if delaying was an offense to the food.
Arix sighed and picked up her knife and fork, ready to tackle the enormous steak. But just as her knife touched it, the spaceship began shaking violently.
The restaurant erupted with the sounds of plates and glasses shattering.
Wealthy businessmen and ladies screamed in terror, their faces turning pale. The elegance and composure they had moments before vanished. They scurried around like frightened mice or huddled together, trembling.
The businessmen fared slightly better than the pampered ladies. Though clearly scared, they managed to contact the captain to find out what was happening.
The captain tried to calm the passengers while muttering curses under his breath.
They were near the Alliance border, and now a Supergiant-Class insectoid had appeared. The ship’s top security, the Maple Mercenary, consisted only of Planet-Class mecha pilots. They were utterly incapable of protecting the ship or even saving themselves.
As the captain grew more frantic, a crew member, panic-stricken, ran up to him. "Captain, bad news. The Maple Guard stole all the escape pods and left."
"What did you say? Not a single escape pod left?!" The captain looked at the crew member in disbelief.
The crew member nodded, despair written all over his face.
After confirming the news, the captain shoved the crew member aside and sprinted to the escape pod bay himself. Finding it empty, he angrily punched the wall and gritted his teeth. "The Maple! If I survive this, I’ll destroy your reputation!"
"Captain, the Maple only has eight people. Why did they take all the escape pods?" a terrified and confused crew member asked.
"Why else? They don’t want us surviving and seeking revenge, tarnishing their reputation in the mercenary world. So, they cut off our only hope of survival," the captain replied, struggling to keep his anger in check.
Suddenly, an idea struck him, and he opened his opticomputer.
As he suspected, the Maple had installed a signal jammer on the ship. Now, calling for help from the Alliance or even contacting the Fifth Legion was impossible.
Despair washed over the captain as he closed his eyes, feeling the weight of the hopeless situation.
"Captain, what do we do now?" the young crew member asked, tears streaming down his face.
The captain opened his eyes and looked at the young crew member. He wanted to say there was no hope, but seeing the crew member’s youthful face, he couldn’t bring himself to do it.
Finally, the captain sighed, "Go tell the other crew members to find the signal jammer."
"Okay!" The crew member nodded and ran off without hesitation.
After the crew member left, the captain opened his opticomputer again, preparing to inform the passengers of the situation.
He hoped that someone among them could delay the insectoid long enough for the Fifth Legion to arrive.
In the spaceship’s restaurant...
Unlike the panicking businessmen and ladies, Arix and Drexel’s first move was to protect the food on their plates. Once they confirmed the food was safe, they both sighed in relief.
"Arix, from my experience, we should eat quickly. We probably won’t get another chance," Drexel said, shoveling steak into his mouth while reminding Arix.
Arix nodded, and they both dug in, eating their steak directly and quickly.
Just as they finished, the ship’s captain appeared on all the screens throughout the spaceship.
The captain looked serious, with barely hidden panic in his eyes. Arix and Drexel exchanged glances, both realizing things were bad.
The captain bowed apologetically. Then, with a look full of guilt, he said, "Ladies and gentlemen, due to an attack by a Supergiant-Class insectoid, this ship can no longer move forward, or return."
"Right now, the ship has a temporary energy shield holding off the insectoid’s attacks, but it will only last another 10 minutes. We have requested help from the Fifth Legion, but it will take them an hour to get here. We have to hold out on our own for that hour. I ask any capable passengers or mecha pilots to come to the front of the ship to help delay the insectoid. Thank you."
The restaurant erupted in angry shouting.
"You know it’s a Supergiant-Class insectoid! Going there is just suicide! Do you think we’re idiots?"
"Yeah, we paid for this! Why should we go? What about the security? Aren’t they mercenaries?"
"Why don’t we use the escape pods? Yes! Let’s escape in the pods!"
As the passengers were about to take action, the captain spoke again.
"I’m very sorry. Due to the selfish actions of the Maple, they have taken all the escape pods and fled. I apologize deeply for this. Once again, I ask any capable passengers or mecha pilots to come to the front of the ship to help delay the insectoid. Thank you," the captain explained, trying to calm the passengers.
With the harsh truth revealed, the passengers couldn’t muster the courage to face reality, let alone fight back.
In the midst of this despair, Arix and Drexel moved. They headed firmly towards the front of the ship.
"Where are you going?" the people around them, though guessing their intent, asked in disbelief.
Drexel turned to look at the dining hall. This time, he didn’t have his usual playful smile. Instead, he saluted them solemnly.
"I am a reservist of the Fifth Legion and a military student at the Hecaris Military Academy. I apologize for the earlier joke. You are civilians, and it is my duty to protect civilians. Goodbye, everyone," Drexel said with a smile.
After saluting with Arix, they quickly ran towards the front of the ship.
The people watched in stunned silence as the siblings left. The restaurant fell quiet again, broken only by a few stifled sobs.
"They are still just children," one lady choked out.
Most of the wealthy people fell into deeper silence, some bowing their heads in shame. A few, after a long pause, stood up and headed towards the front, including the fawning lady.
Before leaving, she turned to the others and said, "If the kids aren’t afraid, why should we be? Those who aren’t cowards, follow me!"

chapters.title: Chapter 157: Fighting The Insectoid
chapters.content:
Chapter 157: Fighting The Insectoid
When Arix and Drexel arrived, quite a few people were already there. Besides the captain and crew, there were about ten others with cold expressions, clearly seasoned fighters.
To the siblings’ surprise, three of these people had a military bearing, indicating they were from a military background. Arix and Drexel exchanged a look; they hadn’t seen these people on the ship before.
"They were probably in their cabins all this time," Drexel whispered to Arix.
Arix nodded in agreement.
The captain, initially pleased to see more people, sighed in disappointment when he realized they were just children.
"Kids, go back. This mission doesn’t include children," the captain said irritably. His tone wasn’t friendly, but his concern for the siblings was evident. He didn’t want to see them sacrifice themselves needlessly.
The others didn’t object either, especially the three military-looking individuals who nodded in agreement.
Facing the skepticism and concern of the group, Drexel stepped forward and solemnly saluted. "Thank you all, but my sister and I are both reservists of the Fifth Legion and military students at the Hecaris Military Academy. When civilians are in danger, our duty doesn’t allow us to flee."
Drexel’s expression was serious, his eyes showing firm resolve.
Arix also nodded firmly, showing that she shared her brother’s intent.
Seeing the young siblings, the captain’s lips trembled with complex emotions, and tears began to stream down his cheeks.
He turned away and wiped his eyes, feeling a bit ashamed. Then he turned back, looking at the siblings with a serious expression, and said, "Alright! Thank you both!"
Drexel and Arix hung back for a moment, exchanging looks as the three military guys smiled and waved them over. Nodding in sync, the siblings walked up to them.
The leader, a middle-aged man, stepped forward with a warm smile, extending his hand. "Hi there, I’m Captain Sentance of the Alliance’s First Legion. These are my buddies, Lieutenant Commanders Gillian and Clayton. Nice to meet you."
Drexel shook his hand politely. "Hello, sir, I’m Drexel, a student at Hecaris Military Academy, and this is my sister, Arix. It’s a pleasure to meet you."
At the mention of Drexel’s name, the officers just paused. But when Arix’s name came up, they looked like they’d just seen a god. Their eyes widened with shock and fear, not because of Arix herself, but because she was here. The future of the Alliance was standing right in front of them, in danger. It was more terrifying than facing a Supergiant-Class insectoid.
Seeing their panicked expressions, Arix tilted her head, curiosity piqued. "Are you guys okay?"
Despite their internal turmoil, the officers managed to keep calm smiles. "We’re fine, just surprised to see you on this ship. Didn’t the Fifth Legion arrange a battleship to escort you?"
Arix scratched the back of her head, a bit embarrassed. "Oh, a battleship isn’t necessary. I’m just a military student. That would be overkill."
Sentance immediately shook his head. "Miss Kering, you invented the psychic power healing potion. It’s saved countless lives. Many of our retired comrades are back in service because of it. They owe you a lot."
"Really? I’m glad I could help," Arix said, her face lighting up with genuine happiness.
The officers, moved by her kindness, felt even more upset. They silently vowed to complain to their superiors.
The Fifth Legion was negligent for not providing a bodyguard and letting Arix travel alone on this shabby ship. The thought of it made their hearts ache.
’Oh, our poor Miss Kering!’
they lamented inwardly.
Drexel, who was actually sent by the Fifth Legion to look after Arix, felt a bit left out. "What about me? Am I invisible here?"
Captain Sentance turned to Arix with a serious expression. "Miss Kering, you are a hero to our First Legion. If you ever face danger, hide behind us. We will protect you with our lives," he said, saluting her with determination.
"No, I can take care of myself," Arix quickly responded, shaking her head. Though she wasn’t a mecha expert yet, she wasn’t helpless.
Sentance frowned, clearly troubled. Drexel, noticing he was being ignored again, forced a polite smile. "Captain, don’t worry. I can protect my sister."
Sentance, snapping back to reality, remembered that Drexel, brother of the Fifth Legion’s admiral, was also present. His expression turned even more serious.
Arix represented the future hope of the Alliance, and Drexel was the future of the Fifth Legion. They couldn’t risk losing either of them. The loss of either would be catastrophic.
Turning to his comrades, Sentance said, "You two will be responsible for protecting Mr. and Miss Kering. They must not come to any harm!"
Gillian and Clayton nodded solemnly. "Yes, sir!"
Drexel, still confused about being included, shrugged. "Why am I getting dragged into this too?" But he decided it was okay. With Arix protected, he could relax a bit.
He turned to Arix. "Arix, you haven’t piloted a real mecha yet. During the fight, stay back."
"Okay, I understand," Arix replied, feeling a bit down despite knowing Drexel was right.
Just then, a warm hand landed on Arix’s head. She looked up to see Drexel gently patting her hair, his eyes soft. "Don’t be discouraged. I believe you’ll be a better mecha pilot than me someday."
"Drexel..." Arix began, touched, but Drexel suddenly burst into a triumphant laugh. "But that’s a long way off. Accept it, Arix. You’re just weaker than me, hahaha!"
Arix’s touched expression vanished. She grabbed the hand on her head and, with a swift motion, threw Drexel over her shoulder.
"Ow, ow, ow! It hurts!" Drexel rubbed his butt, looking betrayed. "Arix, you tigress! You’re trying to kill me or what?"
Arix squinted her eyes, her smile growing even sweeter. "What did you just say? Did I hear ’tigress’?"
Seeing his sister’s smile, which reminded him of a dangerous Chomper, Drexel felt a chill down his spine. He nervously shook his head. "No, no, no. You heard wrong. You’re so gentle and cute, how could you be a tigress?"
Arix gave a cold laugh and was ready to give Drexel another "loving lesson" when the captain’s voice rang out, calling for assembly.
"Heroes, please come over and prepare for departure!"
Hearing this, Arix snorted and decided to leave Drexel alone for now. The three officers, who had watched the entire scene, exchanged amused glances before turning their heads away, smiling to themselves.

chapters.title: Chapter 158: Doubts
chapters.content:
Chapter 158: Doubts
Drexel saw this and sighed with relief. He quickly slipped to Captain Sentence’s side, as if he had seen a savior.
He was so eager that it seemed like he couldn’t wait to fight the insectoids.
Captain Sentence thought the same and looked at Drexel with some emotion, saying, "Young man, you’re still young. Don’t push yourself so hard. We adults are here to help."
Seeing Captain Sentence misunderstanding, Drexel silently screamed in his mind,
’Compared to Arix, Supergiant-Class insectoids are nothing!’
But he didn’t dare say this out loud. If Arix heard, he wouldn’t make it back to the Alliance standing up.
Drexel forced a very reluctant smile and nodded to Sentence, pretending to agree.
Sentence, thinking Drexel had listened to his advice, smiled back with satisfaction.
He felt even more that Drexel was truly a kind, brave, and humble young man.
When everyone was ready for the battle, Captain Sentence invited everyone over.
Everybody hoped Sentence would lead the battle, but Sentence shook his head and said, "I only took the lead before because there was no suitable person. Now that the right person is here, I don’t need to show off."
As Sentence finished speaking, everyone looked over curiously.
They were all wondering who Sentence was talking about.
"Mr. Kering, come over here," Sentence said, looking at Drexel, who was standing by and watching the show.
Drexel’s jaw dropped.
Under the skeptical and disapproving gazes of the crowd, Drexel calmly stood next to Sentence.
Actually, it wasn’t just the crowd; even Arix was a bit surprised.
She looked at Gillian beside her and asked worriedly, "Are you sure you want him to do that? After all, he’s still a student."
Gillian smiled and said, "Miss Arix, you probably don’t know much about the heirs of the five major families, do you?"
Arix nodded. She didn’t know much because Drexel usually seemed carefree, making it easy to overlook his abilities.
But thinking about the battle with the insectoid crown prince, Arix hesitated.
Even she couldn’t beat Quispe, but Drexel could suppress him. Clearly, he wasn’t weak.
Gillian had heard that Miss Kering from the Kering family had been lost on Planet Waste for nearly ten years and was only recently found.
If she had lived in such an isolated place, it was normal not to know these things.
Seeing Arix still deep in thought, a hint of pity flashed in Gillian’s eyes. He gently explained, "The heirs of the five families are not only skilled in military tactics but also possess great combat abilities. So, Miss Kering, you don’t need to worry. Plus, we’re here. We won’t let anything happen to your brother."
"Thank you, sir," Arix gratefully replied. Then, she turned her gaze to Drexel, standing at the front of the crowd.
At that moment, Drexel was facing everyone’s doubts. It wasn’t that they had anything against him personally; they just didn’t want to trust their lives to a child.
"Captain Sentence, it’s not that we doubt you, but this is too much. He’s barely even an adult. How can we trust a kid to lead us?" said a space mercenary with a large machete, full of skepticism.
"Yeah, this is a battle, not child’s play. We can’t risk our lives on this kind of joke. If this is the case, I’m not going," a businessman added, who was already regretting his impulsive decision to join.
"Captain Sentence, you should lead. We trust the Alliance military more," the leader of the mercenaries said coldly.
"Yes, Captain Sentence, you should take charge," Captain Sentence started to persuade.
He even thought to himself that Sentence was being childish.
Facing the crowd’s doubts, Sentence didn’t respond immediately. Instead, he looked at Drexel and asked, "Mr. Kering, what do you think?"
"Sir, you can call me Drexel," Drexel smiled at Sentence. Then he turned to the crowd and said, "My name is Drexel Kering, the heir of the Kering family of the Alliance. Are you still worried?"
Drexel’s voice wasn’t loud, but it struck the crowd like thunder.
They might not know Drexel’s name, but the title of an heir of one of the Alliance’s five major families was enough to shock them.
An heir of the five major families also meant the future admiral of one of the Alliance’s five great legions.
If he wasn’t qualified to lead, then no one in the world would be.
The crowd swallowed hard, and their attitudes changed instantly.
"So you are the young master of the Kering family. My apologies for the misunderstanding. Why didn’t you say so earlier? We were worried for nothing," the mercenary with the large machete said, smiling awkwardly.
"Yes, it’s an honor to follow your command. I hope you can give me an autograph afterward. I’ll cherish it as a family heirloom," the businessman said, transforming from a critic to an eager follower.
"It’s an honor to fight by your side," the mercenary leader said to Drexel, nodding in approval.
"With Mr. Kering here, not even ten Supergiant-Class insectoids would be a problem..." One man began to flatter Drexel, but his friend quickly covered his mouth and dragged him away.
With everyone on the same page, Drexel used his opticomputer to create a temporary channel, adding everyone’s numbers.
Drexel gave his first order: everyone needed to get into their mechas and prep for battle.
Hearing his youthful yet energetic voice in their headsets, the group no longer feared facing a Supergiant-Class insectoid. Instead, they were filled with determination.
After all, this young man was the future admiral of the Alliance. Fighting alongside him today would be a great story to share with friends later!
When everyone took out their mechas, Drexel and Arix unveiled their impressive Supergiant-Class mechas, gifted by Luna Amethyst.
As Drexel and Arix displayed their mechas, a wave of envy swept through the crowd.
Drexel’s mecha, an ice-blue giant with a long spear, immediately locked onto him. It knelt, extended a hand, and in a cool yet respectful mechanical voice, said, "Master, my name is Blue Raven. I am pleased to fight with you."
Drexel, grinning, kissed its fingers and replied, "Hello, Blue Raven. I’m Drexel. The honor is mine."
Meanwhile, Arix eagerly held her mecha’s Space Button.
She summoned a fiery red mecha, brandishing a sword. It also knelt before her, despite its fierce appearance, and said in a cold voice, "Master, my name is Star Dust. I am pleased to fight with you."
"Thank you, Star Dust. I’m Arix. It’s an honor to fight with you." She shook the finger of the mecha, which was as thick as her waist.
With introductions done, Arix and Drexel exchanged a look and a nod before entering their mecha cabins.
Inside her cabin, Arix saw Star Dust’s AI on a screen. The AI appeared as a young woman, around 15, dressed in a red combat suit and wielding a large machete, exuding a silent but lethal vibe.
After greeting each other again, Arix linked her psychic power with Star Dust’s AI. Star Dust’s voice then resonated in the cabin.
"Psychic system, connected!"
"Energy system, sufficient!"
"Power system, normal!"
"Mecha self-check complete. Everything is normal. Please prepare for battle, Master."
"Star Dust, start the energy system and get ready for battle," Arix instructed, verifying the mecha with her psychic power.
"Yes, Master," Star Dust replied.
The energy system roared to life, converting energy stones into power.
Arix was all set. Once everyone was ready, Drexel’s voice came through the wireless headset.
"Captain, open the front hatch of the spaceship. Over."
"Received, opening the hatch. Over."
"Roger, over."
As the spaceship’s hatch slowly opened, the Supergiant-Class insectoids outside grew more agitated, claws ready, attacking the ship’s energy shield.

chapters.title: Chapter 159: Death Sting
chapters.content:
Chapter 159: Death Sting
Facing the massive scorpion-like insectoid in front of him, Drexel held back from charging in recklessly. Instead, he activated his mecha’s radar to scan the creature. Once the scan finished, essential details popped up on the screen.
Type:
Mutant
Alliance Name:
Death Sting
Class:
Supergiant-Class
Length:
1598 meters
Width:
358 meters
Notes:
Death Sting is violent and easily angered, attacking all nearby creatures, including its own allies.
With this information, Drexel issued his orders.
"Heavy armor mecha pilots, cover the snipers. Snipers, use your rifles to target its head from a distance. Combat mechas, get in close to deal extra damage and keep it distracted. Over."
"Heavy armor, understood. Over."
"Sniper, understood. Over."
"Combat, understood. Over."
Once everyone acknowledged, Drexel’s focus intensified. "Move out! Attack!"
Leading the charge, Drexel controlled his mecha to leap forward, delivering a powerful blow to the insectoid’s head with his spear.
This sneak attack enraged Death Sting, a creature already on edge.
Death Sting screeched, abandoning its assault on the spaceship to pursue Drexel.
Drexel quickly maneuvered his mecha, darting away with agility. He kept just out of reach, circling the giant insectoid and occasionally striking with his spear.
The combat mechas joined Drexel, hitting Death Sting whenever it got too close to him, drawing its attention away. The insectoid’s shell was incredibly tough; only Drexel’s mecha could inflict serious damage, while the others left minor marks.
Luckily, Death Sting’s aggressive nature worked in their favor. It focused on whatever attacked it, making their tactics effective—something that wouldn’t work with other insectoids.
While Drexel and the combat mechas risked everything to distract Death Sting, the sniper mechas took shots at its head from a distance with their ion guns. =
However, their firepower was insufficient. Though they managed to cause some damage, it only made Death Sting angrier, increasing the danger for the combat mecha pilots.
Realizing the strategy was faltering, Drexel quickly issued another command. "Arix, their firepower isn’t enough. You need to take over the long-range sniping on its head! Over."
"Understood. Over." Arix acknowledged, though her confidence in her shooting skills was low. Still, her Supergiant-Class mecha was their best chance for a decisive shot. She couldn’t afford to fail.
Star Dust’s sword morphed into a sniper energy gun. Arix gripped the joystick, focusing the scope on Death Sting’s head. But the creature’s relentless thrashing made it difficult for her to get a clear shot.
Watching Drexel take another blow, Arix’s frustration boiled over. Her eyes reddened, and she bit her lip until it nearly bled. She had to steady her aim.
Just when Arix felt completely hopeless, something stirred deep within her soul. It felt like a pair of glowing eyes slowly opened, ancient and wise, peering through the darkness.
These eyes seemed to understand Arix’s dilemma and flickered slightly. In an instant, Arix knew what Death Sting’s next move would be.
With a calm composure, she pulled the trigger and fired her beam cannon at a spot just a meter in front of Death Sting’s head.
At first, everyone thought Arix had missed her shot, even Drexel. He was ready to console his sister when Death Sting moved forward to attack.
Right then, Arix’s beam cannon struck its head dead-on, killing it instantly.
Death Sting fell, drifting into the vastness of space.
All the mecha pilots were left speechless.
After a long silence, Drexel suddenly yelled, snapping everyone out of their shock.
"Oh damn! That Insectoid Core is worth a billion astrocredits! Save it!"
The pilots snapped out of their daze and rushed toward the insectoid’s body. Arix, still in her mecha, was bewildered. She realized this wasn’t a fluke—she had just predicted the future!
This ability felt oddly familiar, and she thought of Sylvana.
’Do I possess Sylvana’s power now? Can I see the past and predict the future? Can I win the lottery?’
Excited, Arix opened her opticomputer and tried her luck on a lottery website. She promptly lost 1000 astrocredits.
With a sigh, Arix covered her forehead with her hand. She felt foolish. Maybe it was just luck. Everyone has strong intuition sometimes.
Snapping out of her daydream, Arix saw Drexel running after the Insectoid Core.
’Hasn’t he learned his lesson yet? Why is he chasing after it again?’
When everyone finally returned to the ship with the Insectoid Core, Drexel got an earful from Arix.
"Arix, cut me some slack, will you? Everyone’s watching," Drexel said, wincing in pain, no longer the confident leader he usually was.
The crew watching them smiled at the sibling’s antics. They pretended not to notice, averting their gazes.
They tried to act like they weren’t listening, but their ears were clearly tuned in.
"Miss Kering, carry on. We didn’t see anything," the captain joked, smiling now that the crisis had passed.
When the captain made his joke, Drexel wasn’t amused. He shot the captain a betrayed look and complained, "Captain, you’re abandoning me pretty quickly, aren’t you?"
"Haha!" The crew burst into even louder laughter.
Arix laughed too, shaking her head. She let go of Drexel’s ear, no longer angry.
The moment was filled with laughter and jokes, easing the tension.
The Fifth Legion, which was scheduled to arrive in an hour, showed up ten minutes early.
As their battleship approached, the captain opened the front hatch to welcome the Alliance soldiers. Soon, two rows of well-trained soldiers stood in the front chamber.
Arix’s excitement soared when she saw the officer leading the Fifth Legion. She wanted to run up and hug him but felt too shy since he was busy talking to the captain. She pouted and waited patiently.
When Thaddeus finished his work, he immediately scanned the crowd for Arix. Despite the changes she had gone through, he spotted his beloved daughter right away.
"Arix, come here," Thaddeus called out with a big smile, opening his arms.
"Dad!" Arix beamed and ran into Thaddeus’s arms.
Thaddeus’s serious expression softened as he hugged his daughter. "Arix, did you miss me this past month?" he asked gently.
"Yes, I did! I lost several pounds because I couldn’t see you," Arix said, pouting while hugging his arm.
Seeing her round face, Thaddeus laughed and pinched her cheek, not pointing out her little lie.
"Dad! I missed you too!" Drexel, who had been hiding from his sister, now ran excitedly towards Thaddeus.
But before he could get close, Thaddeus stopped him with a hand and frowned, "Aren’t you a bit too old for this?"
Drexel was stunned, looking at Arix, who was only a year younger. He didn’t dare to say anything and just stood to the side, feeling left out.
Once everything was settled on the spaceship, Thaddeus took his daughter back to the battleship. After a few steps, he remembered his son and turned to look at Drexel, who was sulking in a corner.
Thaddeus sighed, shaking his head, and called out, "Drexel, let’s go home."
"Hey! I’m coming!" Drexel shouted excitedly, no longer sulking in the corner. He jumped up, eager to leave the ship with his dad and sister.
But just before he left, Drexel stopped. He turned back and tossed the Insectoid Core to Sentance. His face was a mix of emotions as he said, "Split this Supergiant-Class Insectoid Core among everyone who helped today."
Drexel quickly turned and walked away, almost as if he feared Sentance might refuse.
Sentance stood there, holding the Insectoid Core in shock. After a moment, he smiled and shook his head, saying, "They’re both such good kids."

chapters.title: Chapter 160: Wrong Gift
chapters.content:
Chapter 160: Wrong Gift
Out of the captain’s sight, Drexel felt a sharp pang in his chest. He was heartbroken.
He had just given away 100 million astrocredits.
Arix noticed what happened and gave her brother an approving thumbs up. "You did the right thing," she said. "I saw their mechas were badly damaged. With that Insectoid Core, they should have enough money to fix them."
