The training ground was located in the basement of the Department of Combat building. When they arrived, Jonna opened the door to a dimensional training room.
Unlike the empty Dimensional Battlefield, this room was packed with all sorts of training obstacles and traps.
There were things like a mountain of ice, a sea of fire, and various other challenges.
The difficulty levels ranged from Basic to Hell, with the room Jonna selected being at the Basic level—just right for the freshmen.

chapters.title: Chapter 189: Competing With Drexel
chapters.content:
Chapter 189: Competing With Drexel
After guiding the students into the room, Jonna pulled out a long table from her Space Button, setting up dozens of bottles filled with colorful juices.
"Ma’am, what’s all this?" one student asked curiously.
Arix glanced at the bottles, recognizing the contents by their colors and smells.
’All mentors had their tricks!’
Arix thought to herself.
With a kind smile, Jonna explained, "I used to be a top nutritionist. These juices are great for your health. Students who don’t pass the course can drink a cup to help them recover."
"She is so nice! I suddenly don’t miss Marlone anymore," one student exclaimed, feeling touched.
"She is awesome, giving us juice."
"The colors are so pretty, they must taste great too."
Jonna smiled but didn’t respond to the compliments.
Then, she blew a whistle hanging around her neck, and once the students quieted down, she took on a more serious tone, "Now, everyone, get in your mecha. You have to navigate five obstacles. If you can’t finish in 20 minutes, you’ll fail. If you take more than 40 minutes, you’ll be demoted to Class A. Now, get ready!"
"Yes, ma’am!" the students shouted back, each retrieving their mecha or renting one from the school.
Most students at HMA came from Planet Waste and couldn’t afford their own mecha. Fortunately, those without could rent one from the school for about 100 astrocredits per use. Even though higher-level mecha cost more, it was still much cheaper than buying one.
Arix chose not to use her Supergiant-Class mecha, preferring to save her Star Dust for more critical situations than mecha training.
But Arix didn’t go for a rental mecha. Instead, she pulled out a prize she’d won during the entrance exam competition—a Comet Class mecha that had been sitting unused in her Space Button. As soon as she climbed into the cockpit, Arix noticed a clear difference between this one and her usual Star Dust mecha. The Comet Class was more complex to operate and not nearly as agile. Still, it would do for training.
Once everyone was ready, Jonna raised her hand and then dropped it sharply, shouting, "Start!"
With that, all the students charged ahead. Arix piloted her Comet Class mecha towards the first obstacle—a thousand-meter-long sand field. She noticed whirlpools in the sand, capable of trapping any mecha that stepped into them.
Most students, realizing the danger, opted to fly rather than walk.
Arix took a moment to assess the situation, seeing no easy way around the whirlpools.
She followed suit, activating her mecha’s flight mode. However, just ten meters in the air, flashes of light suddenly appeared.
Giant light blades sliced through the air toward the flying students, including several targeting Arix’s mecha.
Arix’s face tightened with concentration. She quickly tapped on the virtual keyboard, maneuvering the mecha through a series of tricky moves to dodge the blades.
Not all the mechas were as fortunate; some were struck, while others, piloted by panicked students, fell into the sand. Then they were swallowed up and reappear at the starting point.
Having dodged the first wave of attacks, Arix felt a pang of sympathy for her classmates caught in the sand traps but kept moving forward.
Thanks to the training she’d had from Elio and her recent battles with insectoids, Arix’s mecha piloting skills had significantly improved.
This level-one difficulty course wasn’t too daunting for her, and she soon cleared the first obstacle, reaching the second: a two-kilometer obstacle course.
The course looked deceptively calm, making Arix more cautious.
With a name like "obstacle course," it had to be hiding something tricky.
She swallowed hard and took a few tentative steps forward.
Everything seemed fine, so she began to relax—only to be hit by a massive force in the lower back, sending her and her mecha flying through the air.
’What the heck! A sneak attack? So unfair! No honor at all!’
Arix thought, cursing internally as she was hurled through the air.
Arix was on high alert, ready for the next trap.
She barely managed to twist her body and evade it just in time.
Before she could even catch her breath, the floor vanished beneath her feet. In a flash of panic, she made her mecha soar upward.
No time for relief, though—two massive wooden logs came swinging down from above. Arix reacted instantly, kicking them away with both feet and using the momentum to leap to safety.
The challenges kept coming: falling rocks, hidden snares, sharp blades, and more. But Arix pushed through and finally reached the end of the second level in one piece.
It was only in the safety zone that she allowed herself to relax a bit. She glanced around and noticed only a handful of her classmates had made it this far.
The biggest shock, though, was seeing Drexel already at the end of the third level. What seemed like brutal obstacles to everyone else looked like a walk in the park for him. He dodged every trap with such ease.
Arix felt a surge of determination and decided to skip resting. She quickly flew to the third level, an underwater tunnel.
Before diving in, she took a defensive stance, then passed through the light screen and cautiously entered the tunnel.
Within seconds, a sudden pressure dragged her to the seabed. Dizzy and disoriented, she opened her eyes only to find herself back at the starting point.
Arix: "Darn it!"
With a 12-minute countdown ticking on her wrist, Arix bit back her frustration. She raced through the earlier obstacles again and reached the third level once more.
This time, she switched tactics and activated her mecha’s shark mode.
In shark mode, her mecha neutralized the pressure, moving through the tunnel like a deep-sea creature.
Invisible ice spikes tried to catch her off guard, but she dodged them with ease, thanks to her prep work. She soon passed through the light screen and emerged from the underwater tunnel, arriving at the fourth level: the gravity track.
Arix expected Drexel to have finished the fourth level by now, but he was only halfway through.
This gave Arix a boost of confidence, especially since the fourth level focused on psychic power—an area where she rarely lost.
Without hesitation, Arix enveloped her mecha in a psychic power shield and stepped into the fourth level.
Immediately, a crushing gravity bore down on her. She increased her psychic power output, keeping the pressure manageable, and calmly walked to the finish line.
Arix completed the level with a confident smile. Psychic power tests were a breeze for her!
In the fourth level, Arix breezed past her fellow students, leaving them both amazed and a bit envious. It was like sipping an ice-cold soda on a winter day—refreshing yet a bit painful.
While Arix could sense their envy, she kept her eyes on the prize: catching up to Drexel.
As she passed Deanna, Arix slowed down just long enough to give her an encouraging thumbs-up.
"Keep going, Deanna!" she cheered.
Deanna nodded and controlled her mecha to return the thumbs-up.
With a quick wave, Arix continued her race.
Arix overtook a few more students and finally caught up to Drexel.
She playfully wagged her finger at him, catching him off guard, before striding past him with her chin held high.
Drexel wasn’t annoyed by her teasing; instead, he found her antics amusing.
But Drexel wasn’t going to make it easy for her. He narrowed his eyes and suddenly dropped the psychic power shield around his mecha. Relying on his physical strength, he surged ahead.
Arix was stunned for a moment but quickly regained her composure.
She wasn’t about to be outdone. She strengthened her psychic power shield and picked up speed.
Drexel noticed her sudden burst of energy and smiled, pushing himself even harder.
The siblings raced side by side, nearing the exit together.
But then, Arix made her mecha fly, leveraging her strong psychic power to zip through the finish line light screen, winning by a narrow margin.
Drexel was left just behind her, his impressive physical strength unable to match Arix’s psychic power, which allowed her to defy gravity and fly—a rare skill indeed.
"Nice job, Arix!" Drexel called out, giving her a thumbs-up even though he had lost.
"Just okay," Arix replied with a cheeky grin. She then turned her gaze toward the fifth level.
The next challenge was a lava track.
Arix and Drexel exchanged a knowing glance before both took off, racing toward the entrance of the fifth level together!

chapters.title: Chapter 190: Chasing In Lava
chapters.content:
Chapter 190: Chasing In Lava
As soon as Arix stepped onto the track, she felt like she’d been thrown into a furnace.
Inside her mecha’s cockpit, the heat seeped through. It was like being in a sauna, with the air itself burning hot.
Ahead of her, a sea of flames raged, with lava erupting and splashing everywhere. Arix swallowed hard and quickly activated her mecha’s energy shield, dodging stray lava bursts while keeping a close eye on Drexel in front of her.
Drexel moved through the lava like he was born for it, handling the intense environment with surprising grace.
’Man, he makes it look so easy,’
Arix thought, a mix of envy and admiration bubbling up. She tapped a few buttons, steering her mecha to leap over a sudden wave of molten rock.
As they progressed, the lava’s fury intensified, transforming from small streams into massive, fiery waves.
Even Drexel began to struggle, his mecha’s energy shield draining quickly under the relentless heat. The energy gauge on his screen was dropping fast.
Drexel was having a tough time, and Arix was really feeling the pressure. Her face flushed, breath heavy, sweat pouring down her skin—she felt like a Thanksgiving turkey.
"Arix, do you need help?" Sylvana, her fluffy companion, perched on her shoulder. Her voice sounds full of concern. The extreme heat was so intense that even within Arix’s psychic world, Sylvana felt it.
"No, it’s just training. I’m okay," Arix insisted, shaking her head.
She knew if she relied on Sylvana now, it would defeat the purpose of the exercise. This was real combat training, and she had to push through it on her own to learn.
"Alright, but I’ll stay here with you. Call me if you need anything," Sylvana said, refusing to leave her alone in such harsh conditions.
"Thanks," Arix smiled, giving Sylvana a gentle pat before refocusing on her controls.
In the blazing, apocalyptic landscape, Arix and Drexel pushed their mechas to the limit, leaving trails intertwined and yet distinct.
Despite their best efforts to dodge, some lava still struck their mechas, leaving marks for the test evaluation.
But there was a silver lining: the finish line was in sight.
Both Arix and Drexel noticed it and pushed their machines harder, racing toward the end.
Just then, however, as Arix picked up speed, she failed to avoid a sudden burst of lava. It hit her cockpit directly, and the impact left her momentarily stunned.
Arix was engulfed in a wave of scorching heat, almost unbearable.
Despite quickly using her psychic power to shield herself, the temperature around her was like being trapped in an oven. The intensity was too much, and Arix’s consciousness faded for a moment.
In that brief lapse, her Comet Class mecha lost its pilot’s control and began to plummet toward the lava below.
"Arix!" Sylvana, glowing with golden light, sprang into action.
At the same moment, Drexel, having just turned back, saw Arix’s mecha descending dangerously close to the lava.
"Arix!" Drexel’s heart skipped a beat. He was right on the brink of crossing the finish line but immediately turned around to save her.
Luckily, they were close enough that he reached her just in time, grabbing her mecha and tossing it over the finish line with all his strength.
As Arix soared through the air, a whirlwind of emotions hit her. She felt guilty, like she was holding Drexel back, especially now when he could have won but instead came in second because of her.
For the first time, a deep urge to become stronger settled in her heart—not to surpass anyone, but to stop being a burden to Drexel.
This newfound resolve burned brightly within Arix as Drexel prepared to cross the finish line himself. But then, another cry for help rang out from behind.
Drexel glanced back and saw another unfortunate classmate teetering on the brink of falling into the lava. He gave a casual thumbs-up as encouragement and then crossed the finish line without hesitation.
The unlucky guy was frustrated.
Falling into the lava only meant a reset to the starting point; they’d learn and grow stronger from the experience, Drexel believed. But Arix was special; he cherished her deeply. He’d rather endure hardship themselves than let her suffer.
Feeling pleased with his actions, Drexel cracked a smile. If the situation had been different, he might have taken a moment to admire himself in a mirror.
’Today’s a good day to feel proud of myself,’ he smirked.
As Arix safely crossed the finish line, Sylvana finally felt relieved. Watching Drexel exit the lava track, Sylvana mused,
’When there’s no real danger, Drexel can be a handful, but when there is, he’s the most reliable.’
"Yeah, he’s always there when it counts," Arix nodded, warmth spreading through her at the thought of Drexel’s concern.
She decided that once they got back, she’d find a way to show her appreciation for all he’d done.
Chapter 239 Magical Juice
"Arix, if there’s nothing else..." Sylvana said as she said goodbye.
"Alright, Sylvana, see you later," Arix replied with a smile and a nod as Sylvana returned to the psychic world. Then, she opened the hatch and jumped out of the cockpit.
Arix reached for her Space Button, ready to store her mecha. Just then, someone handed her a glass of water.
"Thirsty? Have a drink," Jonna said kindly, smiling.
Arix was so parched that she didn’t notice who gave her the drink. She took the glass without looking and drank it down.
Immediately, a strange taste hit her—numb, fishy, spicy, and bitter—all at once.
She felt like throwing up, but Jonna’s voice stopped her.
"This is my special nutritious juice made. Wasting it will cost you 10 credits and a thousand astrocredits," Jonna said, still smiling, but with a cold tone that made Arix shiver.
Arix felt hopeless. She closed her eyes and swallowed the juice.
Jonna finally smiled in satisfaction, patting Arix on the shoulder. "Not bad. You’re the first one out. Keep up the good work."
Arix, still feeling queasy from the taste, looked at Jonna with a pitiful expression. "Ma’am, why did I have to drink it just because I was the first out?"
Jonna blinked innocently. "I know, but you didn’t refuse, so I thought you liked it."
Arix was speechless. If Jonna weren’t her mentor, she would definitely argue with her.
"Okay, enough chatting, another one is coming out," Jonna said, nervously touching her nose and making an excuse to leave.
Arix watched as Jonna went off with the juice, offering it to other unsuspecting students one by one. The trick was the same, but surprisingly effective; nearly every student drank the juice without hesitation.
As she watched her classmates holding their throats, trying not to vomit, Arix wondered if the fifth challenge involved fire because Jonna wanted everyone to be thirsty so that they couldn’t resist the drink.
She clicked her tongue in amazement at Jonna’s cunning.
When all the students were gathered, Jonna had managed to make the whole class miss their former mentor, Marlone.
Although Marlone trained them harshly, he never did anything as sneaky as making them drink weird juice.
Thinking about the juice’s taste, all the students in Class S shivered.
"Arix, did you drink it too?" a Class S student asked, looking hopeful.
Arix glanced at him, puzzled by the question. She nodded. "Yes, I did. It didn’t taste good."
"Really! Got it, thanks, Arix," the student said, suddenly excited. He then went to chat with the others, looking like a wilted plant brought back to life.
Curious, Arix watched him for a while and noticed that he seemed to be saying something to each student.
After talking to him, each student also seemed to perk up.
Wondering what was going on, Arix decided to use her psychic power to secretly find out.

chapters.title: Chapter 191: Psychic Incarnation
chapters.content:
Chapter 191: Psychic Incarnation
"I’ve found something good about our new mentor," the Class S student said with relief. "At least she’s not like Marlone, who had double standards. Even Arix had to drink the juice today."
"Really? That makes me feel so much better! Thanks for telling me," another student responded, their previously dull eyes lighting up with excitement.
The news spread quickly among the classmates, and the reaction was the same all around. Everyone went from feeling down to suddenly motivated and energized.
Soon, the entire Class S had a new attitude. They stopped seeing Jonna as an intimidating figure and began to respect and even like her. They appreciated that she treated everyone equally, unlike Marlone, who had clear favorites.
Those who had experienced Marlon’s favoritism felt a sense of relief. For example, even though Arix had the same achievements as the rest of the class, Marlone would only give others a simple "Well done," while Arix got extensive praise, sometimes even involving compliments to her family.
This kind of favoritism left a deep sense of unfairness among the students. So, seeing Jonna’s fair treatment today made them feel it was worth it.
They decided that even if they had to drink strange juice every day, it was a small price to pay compared to dealing with Marlone’s favoritism.
That shocked Arix for a bit. But if that was what made everyone happy, she decided not to accept it and just see it as a good deed. She shook her head and turned her attention to Jonna, who was calling everyone to gather.
"I’m not satisfied with today’s training," Jonna began, her sharp gaze landing on five students who had their heads down. "Especially those who took more than 40 minutes. There are five of you."
The rest of the students kept quiet, knowing that these five might be demoted to Class A.
"But," Jonna continued, pausing to get everyone’s attention, "since it seems like you all enjoyed my juice, I’ll let it slide this time. But remember, there won’t be a next time."
The five students sighed in relief and thanked Jonna, while the rest of the class applauded, genuinely happy for them.
The training session ended on a positive note, and the new mentor, Jonna, had successfully integrated with the group.
Despite the odd juice, all the students gave her positive reviews.
...
A month had passed. Besides attending her classes, Arix spent all her time researching her new Psychic Ware, which could help ordinary people form Psychic Incarnation.
With Talrin’s notes, Arix had a rough idea of how to proceed, but she felt like something was missing when carving the Psychic Ware. Without figuring this out, Arix was sure she couldn’t create the Psychic Ware she wanted.
She held the Insectoid Core in one hand and the carving tool in the other but hesitated. After thinking for a long time without any new ideas, Arix decided to seek help from the four experts in her psychic world.
Hearing Arix’s request, Sylvana brought Cupid and the others out. The four of them sat around the table. Cupid enthusiastically asked, "Arix, is there a problem we can help you with?"
Arix nodded, looking serious. "I have a problem and need your advice."
Cupid smiled warmly and said, "Arix, tell us, we’ll definitely help." Sylvana and the others nodded in agreement.
Seeing everyone was willing to help, Arix thanked them and explained her problem. "According to Talrin’s notes, to give someone a Psychic Incarnation, their psychic power must be completely condensed in the psychic world. This part is actually simple; the Psychic Ware can act as a medium. But the problem is, the Psychic Incarnation formed this way has no consciousness. It’s still just psychic power, only in a different form," Arix explained.
Then she looked at Sylvana and the others, asking, "What do you think?"
Sylvana and the others lowered their heads, deep in thought.
Cupid wanted to contribute, but after thinking for a while, he just got more confused. He scratched his bright red hair. Unable to say anything, he finally looked at Sylvana with sad puppy eyes, clinging to her arm.
Sylvana smiled and patted his head comfortingly.
Vita and Sophia looked at Cupid with disdain.
Sophia then looked at Arix and said, "You’re right, it’s still like psychic power. In other words, it’s just a materialized form of psychic power, not a true Psychic Incarnation."
Hearing Sophia’s words, Arix suddenly understood. It felt strange because this method was more like creating a psychic weapon.
She opened her palm and materialized a scalpel, then changed it to look like Cupid and the others. Everything looked the same but lacked the crucial element of life. The question was, how could she give it that life?
As Arix pondered, Sophia suddenly spoke up, "I have an idea."
"What idea?!" Arix’s eyes lit up with excitement as she looked at Sophia.
Sophia raised an eyebrow, smiling mischievously. "The method is simple, but it might require Vita to sacrifice a bit."
As soon as she finished speaking, everyone turned to look at Vita.
Vita wasn’t as clever as Sophia, but Sophia had made it clear enough for him to understand.
"Do we really have to do this?" Vita asked, feeling a bit resigned. Sophia smirked mischievously and said, "This is the simplest method. Don’t you want to help Arix?"
Arix also realized what was happening and felt a bit guilty and embarrassed, rubbing her nose. This method indeed required Vita to sacrifice a bit more.
"What exactly is this method? Why is everyone being so secretive?" Cupid pouted, feeling left out as everyone else seemed to understand something he didn’t.
Sylvana, not wanting Cupid to be upset, whispered the method to him.
After hearing it, Cupid rolled his eyes at Vita and said, "So it’s just about making Vita Crystal? I thought it was something big. Vita, you’re being dramatic."
Vita rolled his eyes, thinking,
’Of course, you wouldn’t understand; you’ve already got used to that process.’
Since Cupid had already spilled the beans, Vita couldn’t stay silent any longer. Resigned, he said to Arix, "I can provide Vita Crystal, but let’s be clear: I can only supply 300,000 pieces a month, no more."
Arix quickly nodded, worried that Vita might get too embarrassed and do something drastic.
Vita sighed in relief, then seemed to sink back into his thoughts.
Sophia chuckled quietly to herself before turning to Arix and saying, "Now that we’ve solved the problem, let’s head back."
"Okay," Arix nodded, watching them return to the psychic world. She then turned to Vita, who was still sitting in the chair, and asked with concern, "Vita, is there something else?"
Vita blushed, then hesitated before stammering, "Arix, if you want, I... I can make more Vita Crystal."
Arix was surprised for a moment, then she felt a warm and bittersweet sensation in her heart.
She walked over and hugged Vita, saying, "300,000 is enough, thank you, Vita."
Vita hadn’t expected the hug, and after a brief pause, he gently patted her. "No worries, I’m glad I can help you."
Arix’s smile deepened as Vita ruffled her hair. With Vita and the others around, she felt like she had a safe harbor—a sense of security, comfort, and belonging.

chapters.title: Chapter 192: New Contest
chapters.content:
Chapter 192: New Contest
Vita hugged Arix for a while, then he took the Space Button loaded with Insectoid Cores back to the psychic world.
After saying her goodbyes to Vita, Arix glanced at the time on her opticomputer.
With only thirty minutes left before the Department of Combat class started, she knew she had to hustle.
Remembering the punishment for being late—downing a glass of juice—Arix quickly gathered her things and left her dorm.
Today’s class was back at the dimensional training ground, but the difficulty had been bumped up to level two. Despite the increased challenge, everyone moved faster than ever, eager to avoid the dreaded juice penalty.
By the end of the session, Jonna reluctantly put away a large table covered with juice glasses.
Instead of dismissing the class like usual, Jonna’s tone grew serious, "I have an announcement. The new mecha tournament is set for six months from now. The Alliance’s national team will be selected from the five military academies, with six spots available per school. Final spots will be decided based on competition."
Jonna explained further, "The selection process is straightforward: the top six students who can pass level-three difficulty at the training ground will be chosen. Anyone interested in competing, please raise your hand to sign up."
Excitement buzzed through Class S.
The new mecha tournament was a huge event, with teams from all over the universe participating. A strong performance could mean better resources, while a poor one could spell trouble, especially for smaller countries.
The stakes were high—even for major powers like the Alliance and the Empire, showing weakness wasn’t an option.
"Ma’am, I’m signing up," Drexel declared. As the heir to one of Kering family and the top student in the Department of Combat, he felt it was his responsibility.
Jonna nodded and took a note on her opticomputer. Turning to the rest of the class, Jonna asked, "Alright, Drexel’s in. Who’s next?"
"Ma’am, count me in," Arix said, raising her hand.
"Okay, Arix is signed up too. Who else? Hurry up and sign up," Jonna urged, jotting down more names.
After Drexel and Arix, other students eagerly crowded around Jonna to register.
Once everyone had signed up, Jonna gave a final reminder, "Today is Friday. The competition kicks off next Monday at 8 AM. Don’t be late! And remember, it’s not just our class competing; other classes will be there too. Don’t embarrass us, or you’ll be stuck drinking juice every day!"
Hearing Jonna’s clearly threatening words, the students swallowed nervously and shouted in unison, "Understood, ma’am."
"Alright, you’re dismissed." Jonna smiled with satisfaction, then turned and left the training ground.
As soon as the teacher was gone, the students started chatting about weekend plans. Some wanted to stay and train at the school, while others were eager to meet friends outside.
A few, who missed their parents, had already bolted off.
After saying goodbye to his friends, Drexel approached Arix. "Arix, are you heading home now?"
"Yeah, but I need to stop by the dorm first to grab a few things," Arix replied. She had packed earlier, but in her rush to leave, she had forgotten some essentials.
"Okay, I’ll come with you to the dorm, and then we can head home together." Drexel seemed like he wanted to say something but was holding back.
Arix nodded, said her goodbyes to Deanna and the others, and then left with Drexel.
As they walked, Drexel couldn’t keep quiet any longer. "Arix, the mecha tournament will be dangerous, are you sure you want to take part in it?" His voice was full of concern and reluctance.
Drexel hadn’t competed in the tournament before, but he had seen many broadcasts of past events. They were always intense and sometimes dangerous, with a 10% mortality rate among students, despite the organizers’ rules against killing. Those deaths were "accidents," but that didn’t make them any less real.
The thought of Arix facing such dangers made Drexel’s heart sink.
Arix noticed his worry and felt a warm sense of gratitude. She reached out and held Drexel’s hand, speaking gently, "You heard it too. Both you and I were pre-selected. Even if I hadn’t signed up, I would still have to compete."
"If you don’t want to participate, it’s okay. Plus, Mom and Dad would be so worried if you do,+" Drexel said, his voice carrying a rare hint of authority as the family’s heir.
Arix was touched but shook her head. "Some things can’t be avoided just because we don’t want them to happen. If I don’t go, someone else will. Wouldn’t they be in danger too? Wouldn’t their families worry?"
Drexel wanted to argue, but Arix continued, "The main reason I want to participate is that I don’t want to be a spoiled kid who does nothing. I want to get stronger, strong enough to protect the people I care about," she said seriously.
After speaking, she looked up at Drexel carefully, her eyes full of anticipation and nervousness.
Seeing his sister’s determined expression, Drexel fell silent, feeling very conflicted. It was like watching a fledgling bird learning to fly—knowing it would be dangerous but understanding it had to happen.
’If birds don’t learn to fly, they lose their surviving skills and can’t escape from danger,’
Drexel pondered this and thought.
’If I were her, would I do the same?’
The answer was a definite yes.
He let out a deep sigh and gently patted Arix’s head, saying, "You’ve passed my test, but convincing Mom and Dad will be a whole different challenge."
Arix, reminded of this, felt her spirits sink like a deflated balloon.
Unlike Drexel, Thaddeus and Fleur wouldn’t be as understanding. Young folks could get each other, but parents are always wary about their kids taking risks.
Arix suggested, "Should we just keep it a secret like we did with the Dragon clan last time?"
Drexel shook his head gently, reminding her, "Unfortunately, once you’re selected for the national mecha team, parents get notified. And with Mom and Dad’s influence, they could easily pull you out."
Arix frowned, "Why can you join, but I can’t?"
Drexel smiled at her and patted her head again, explaining, "Because I’m the heir to the Kering family and the future Fifth Legion Admiral of the Alliance. Once I graduate from Hecaris Military Academy, I’ll be a Rear Admiral. It’s like I’m already ’married’ to the Alliance, so I get some perks, right?"
Arix felt torn. She should feel bad for him, but it almost sounded like he was showing off. After a moment, she shrugged and said, "Whatever, we’ll deal with it later. Maybe Mom and Dad will agree."
Drexel chuckled, "Yeah, keep dreaming."
Arix pouted and, not wanting to argue, headed towards the house. As they reached the door, PO greeted Arix warmly. But when he saw Drexel, he seemed to show a brief look of disdain.
Soon, PO quickly switched back to a polite smile for Arix, ignoring Drexel entirely.
Drexel noticed this and rubbed his chin, thinking the robot was acting a bit strange, almost like he had emotions. He shook his head, dismissing the thought.
’No way a robot could have feelings,’
he thought. Figuring it was just his illusion from being tired, he decided to unwind with some games on the interstellarnet later.
With that, Drexel pushed the thought aside and followed Arix into the house.
"Wait for me in the living room; I’ll be right back," Arix said to Drexel before heading upstairs.
"Sure," Drexel responded, grabbing an apple from the coffee table and lounging on the sofa, munching on it leisurely.
"Do you need any help, master?" PO, the robot, asked Arix eagerly as she climbed the stairs.
"No need, I’m just grabbing something," Arix called back, disappearing at the top of the stairs.
"Okay..." PO murmured, sounding a bit disappointed, and stayed behind in the living room, awkwardly facing Drexel.

chapters.title: Chapter 193: Discrimination
chapters.content:
Chapter 193: Discrimination
Drexel, sprawled out on the sofa, looked bored as he chewed his apple. He eyed PO, remembering the last time he got in trouble for teasing the robot, so he decided to keep quiet and just watched him.
PO noticed Drexel’s gaze and felt annoyed. He even thought that Drexel looking at him might somehow make him less clean. If he weren’t waiting to escort Arix out, PO would’ve left the room.
"Hey, why are you called PO? The name doesn’t sound that great. How about I give you a new one?" Drexel suggested, trying to start a conversation.
PO rolled its eyes, pretending to be a robot that didn’t understand Drexel’s words.
Ignoring Drexel didn’t deter him, though. He continued, "How about ’PP’ or ’OO’? Isn’t that better than PO?" He looked quite proud of his suggestions, raising an eyebrow.
"Beep! Drexel, you have been deducted 5 points," an opticomputer announced suddenly.
"What? 5 points! That’s harsh," Drexel exclaimed, suddenly upset. Earning those 5 points required attending five classes and getting good evaluations. He’d worked hard for a month to accumulate just a few points.
Grinding his teeth, Drexel fought the urge to swear. "PO, don’t you think it’s unfair to deduct points without a good reason?" he asked, forcing a polite smile even though he was fuming inside.
PO glanced at him and replied in a cold, mechanical voice, "You disrupted the campus assistant’s mental well-being by insulting him. Therefore, you lost 5 points as a penalty."
"Wait, you’re a robot! How can you have mental well-being?" Drexel was stunned, staring in disbelief as he felt his worldview crumble.
"Beep! Drexel, you have been deducted 1 point," the opticomputer announced again.
Drexel looked down at his opticomputer, watching his score drop from double digits to single digits. A cold wave of shock washed over him.
"Why did you deduct points this time?" Drexel sounded like a young man being unfairly treated, his voice filled with frustration.
"You displayed discrimination towards a intelligent being, affecting his mental well-being," PO responded coldly.
Drexel zipped his mouth in no time.
Drexel and PO were staring each other down when Arix arrived with what they needed.
Arix looked confused and a little defensive as she saw how close Drexel was to PO. "What are you doing?" she asked, squinting like she thought Drexel was up to no good.
Drexel felt a bit insulted by Arix’s protective stance. After all, he was the one feeling offended in this whole situation.
Just as Drexel was about to say something, PO noticed the tension and hurried over, gently grabbing Arix’s hand. His screen displayed a sad face as PO said, "Master, are you leaving now? Can I come with you?"
Arix immediately shifted her focus to PO, hugging it and feeling a bit guilty. "Sorry, PO. I asked the president, and unless there’s an emergency, I can’t take you out of the school. Please stay home for two days; I’ll be back soon."
"Okay, Master, come back soon," PO replied, trying to be brave despite his sadness as he let go of Arix.
Arix hugged PO tighter, feeling sorry for him.
Meanwhile, Drexel stood off to the side, puzzled.
’Why is the robot acting so emotional? Shouldn’t I be the one feeling upset?’
For the first time, Drexel felt genuinely confused by the situation. After comforting PO, Arix and Drexel finally left. Once they were out of sight, Drexel turned serious and said, "Arix, there’s something odd about PO. I think he might have his own consciousness."
Arix laughed, clearly not buying it. "You’re overthinking! There’s no way a robot like that could be conscious."
"But what if there is? Remember, there are mechanical lives in this world," Drexel insisted, though he knew it sounded far-fetched. He just couldn’t shake the feeling that something was off about PO.
"For a mechanical life to exist, it would need to be a level-eight mecha. Do you really think PO looks like a level-eight mecha?" Arix replied, rolling her eyes.
"Well, no, not really," Drexel admitted, starting to doubt his theory. After all, PO seemed too delicate to even fend off a low-level insectoid, let alone be a level-eight mecha.
"Okay, enough with the wild ideas. Get your Lev out, let’s go home," Arix said. She had to meet Thaddeus later and didn’t have time for Drexel’s theories.
"Fine, fine, I get it," Drexel said, eager to get home and log in. He quickly brought out his Lev, and once they were both inside, they sped off toward the Kering family estate.
As they pulled up to the gate, they saw Fleur waiting.
"Mom, did you miss your little darling?" Arix exclaimed, jumping out of Lev and running to Fleur, acting all sweet.
Fleur chuckled, patting Arix’s head affectionately. "What do you think? Why else would I be out here?"
Arix giggled happily.
Drexel, putting Lev away, noticed something off. "Mom, where’s Dad? I don’t see him," he asked, confused.
Arix glanced at Fleur, also curious.
"The Military Research Institute sent some people over. They’re checking on your dad’s health. They’re all in the living room right now," Fleur explained, not missing a beat.
"Let’s go check on him," Arix said, feeling a pang of worry since it had been nearly a week since she’d last seen Thaddeus.
Fleur nodded and led her children into the living room. Inside, they found Quillan, head of the Alliance Military Research Institute, busy examining Thaddeus with a range of instruments.
"Sir, is there any chance to restore my Psychic Incarnation?" Thaddeus asked, his tone hopeful yet strained as he went through the tests.
Quillan sighed and shook his head. "Admiral Thaddeus, with our current technology, we haven’t found a way to revive a lost Psychic Incarnation."
Thaddeus’s shoulders slumped. "I see..." His voice was heavy with disappointment, the reality setting in that his Phantom might never return.
Quillan tried to offer some comfort. "Don’t give up hope, Admiral. Perhaps we’ll soon overcome this barrier with new advancements."
"Thank you," Thaddeus replied, though his expression was still clouded with sadness.
Just then, Arix and her family arrived.
"Hello, sir," Arix greeted warmly upon seeing Quillan, a familiar face from her past.
"Ah, little Arix! You’ve grown and become even prettier," Quillan greeted back, smiling widely.
"Thank you, sir. You look good today," Arix replied, her voice sweet.
Quillan chuckled, appreciating the compliment even though he knew it was just flattery. But then he remembered the seriousness of Thaddeus’s condition, and his smile faded slightly.
He turned to Arix, his expression thoughtful. "Arix, your father’s physical health is stable, but we’re at a loss on how to restore his Psychic Incarnation. Do you have any insights?"
Quillan knew of Arix’s work in the psychic field and thought she might have some new ideas.
Arix’s face turned serious. "There might be a way, though it’s still untested. I think there’s a good chance we could revive Dad’s Psychic Incarnation."
"Really?" Thaddeus immediately perked up, looking at his daughter with a mix of anxiety and hope. He had resigned himself to the idea that her earlier reassurances were just to comfort him. But now, hearing her speak with such confidence, it felt like a lifeline.
Quillan was equally surprised, his eyes wide with curiosity and excitement. "Arix, are you serious?" His voice carried a blend of shock and seriousness.
If what Arix suggested was true, it could be as groundbreaking as the discovery of the psychic power healing potion.
This freew(e)bnovel.(c)om

chapters.title: Chapter 194: Awakened Ware
chapters.content:
Chapter 194: Awakened Ware
Arix looked into the eager eyes staring back at her and nodded with determination. "I’m serious. I wouldn’t joke about something like this."
Hearing her confirm it, Quillan and Thaddeus lit up with excitement. Thaddeus even started to cry quietly, murmuring, "This is great, just great..."
Quillan, trying to keep his cool despite his excitement, asked carefully, "Arix, how do we go about this? Do you need us to do anything?"
Arix hesitated, unsure whether to share that she could grant ordinary people the ability to have Psychic Incarnation. Since discovering this power, she’d worried someone might misuse it. But thinking of the many Alliance soldiers who had given their lives, she began to doubt her silence.
Psychic Incarnation was like a double-edged sword. It had its risks, but it could also strengthen the Alliance and reduce casualties. Plus, once they rescued Phantom, the truth would come out anyway. It seemed wiser to let the leaders handle it.
With her decision made, Arix looked at Quillan and said firmly, "I can handle it myself. Only the Psychic Ware I create can bring Psychic Incarnations back."
"Really? Well, okay then," Quillan replied, a little disappointed there wasn’t more he could do to help.
Then his eyes brightened with an idea. "Can I watch?"
Arix shook her head, looking apologetic. "I’m sorry, but Psychic Ware isn’t solely my creation, so I can’t make that call. But I can ask my partner what he thinks."
Quillan nodded, understanding. "No worries, I was getting ahead of myself. Let’s focus on restoring your father’s Psychic Incarnation for now."
Arix nodded, agreeing. She then thought about the Psychic Ware that could create Psychic Incarnation.
After a moment’s hesitation, she decided to wait until her father recovered before revealing this information. She also needed to consult Talrin, her research partner, as she couldn’t have developed the Psychic Ware without him.
After considering it, Arix addressed everyone, "I’m going to start carving the Psychic Ware now. It will take about an hour."
"Take your time. Even if it takes all day, that’s fine," Quillan said warmly, smiling.
Thaddeus and Fleur nodded encouragingly. "Arix, do your best. It’s okay if it doesn’t work out," they reassured her.
Drexel remained silent, wrestling with his thoughts. First, there was the psychic healing potion, and now this Psychic Ware that could restore Psychic Incarnation.
’Is there anything Arix can not do?’
Even though they had the same parents, he felt so different. Drexel worried that if Arix kept being so amazing, he’d end up feeling inadequate.
Arix didn’t really mind whether Drexel gave her encouragement or not. After saying goodbye to her parents, she was ready to head to her room and start carving the Psychic Ware.
As she walked by Drexel, he suddenly grabbed her wrist.
"Drexel?" Arix looked at him, puzzled.
Drexel held her gaze for a moment with a complicated expression. Then, he smiled and encouraged her, "Good luck, Arix."
He released her hand, and Arix smiled back. "Thanks, I’ll do my best," she replied before heading to her room.
Once his sister was out of sight, Drexel slumped onto the couch. In his mind, he asked his Psychic Incarnation, "Sheer, why is my sister so smart and talented?"
The big tiger in his psychic world had been napping. Hearing that question, he lazily opened one eye and teased, "Because when your mom was giving birth to you, all the intelligence went to your sister."
Drexel sighed internally.
’Yeah, forget I asked. Just go to sleep.’
In her bedroom, Arix sat at her study desk. She took out a Vita Crystal and a knife from her Space Button, placing them on the desk.
Before starting, she took off her opticomputer and set it about a meter away on the desk. She tapped the screen and sent a video call request to Talrin.
After a few rings, Talrin answered with a smile on his face. "Arix, what’s up?"
"Talrin, I’m about to start carving the Awakened Ware," Arix said, her voice steady.
Awakened Ware was the name she and Talrin had given to the Psychic Ware capable of creating Psychic Incarnation.
Hearing this, the smile vanished from Talrin’s face, replaced by a look of surprise. "Are you sure, Arix? This is serious stuff."
Arix felt a bit exasperated. Did she really seem like someone who would joke around about something this important?
"Talrin, I’m serious. I’m starting the carving right now," Arix said, showing him the Vita Crystal and the carving knife in her hands.
Talrin was silent for a moment, then finally spoke, "I’m sorry, Arix. I just didn’t expect we’d see the creation of the Psychic Ware capable of producing Psychic Incarnation so soon. It’s... surprising."
Arix nodded, understanding his reaction. Then she remembered something and asked, "Talrin, I’m thinking of sharing the method to create Psychic Incarnation with the Alliance. What do you think?"
"I have no objections. I never intended to keep it a secret. But Arix, make sure to mention my name when you announce it. My new association depends on it," Talrin said with a big grin.
Seeing him so excited, Arix couldn’t help but smile too. "Of course, Talrin," she agreed, feeling a little lighter.
After Arix and Talrin hashed out their plan, Talrin knew it was time to wrap things up.
"Alright, that’s settled then. I won’t keep you any longer, Arix. I’ll hang up now," he said, realizing Arix’s first Awakened Ware was likely for someone special, so he didn’t want to overstay his welcome.
"Okay, goodbye, Talrin," Arix replied politely.
With a nod and a smile, Talrin ended the call on the opticomputer and started to head upstairs. Just then, a delivery robot showed up at the newly patched door, which was held together with wooden planks.
The robot gave a polite knock on the door and said in a mechanical yet courteous voice, "Hello, Mr. Talrin, you have a package."
Curious, Talrin went to accept the package, wondering if it was from his master or fellow disciples. But when he opened it, he found some Vita Crystals and a blueprint for Psychic Ware inside.

chapters.title: Chapter 195: Saving Thaddeus
chapters.content:
Chapter 195: Saving Thaddeus
A mix of emotions crossed Talrin’s face as he pulled out the blueprint. He knew right away that Arix had sent it. In that moment, he felt grateful that his master had chosen Arix as an apprentice. Even someone as hard to impress as Talrin had to admit, Arix was incredibly thoughtful and a true gem.
Meanwhile, Arix sat staring at the dark screen, feeling a sense of relief. Now, with Talrin’s support, she could work on the Awakened Ware without the worry of getting caught. She decided to reveal everything once she solved her father’s Psychic Incarnation issue.
Determined, Arix wasted no time. She picked up a carving knife and started engraving runes into the Vita Crystal.
The Vita Crystal was essential because it held Vita’s psychic power, symbolizing healing and rebirth. Only an Awakened Ware made from Vita Crystal could awaken a Psychic Incarnation; using a regular Insectoid Core, no matter how well carved, wouldn’t do the trick.
After about half an hour, Arix set down the carving knife, pleased with the results.
The runes on the Awakened Ware began to glow, emanating a sense of spring and renewal just by holding it. However, this was just the first step; the Awakened Ware could awaken the Psychic Incarnation but couldn’t revive it fully.
Arix didn’t hesitate. She pulled out a scalpel from her space and made a swift cut on her palm, letting her blood drip onto the Awakened Ware.
As the golden-tinged blood flowed, Arix felt a swirl of emotions. Though she hadn’t received the complete Divine Beast heritage, she had spent a month contemplating how to revive her father’s Psychic Incarnation, and this method had naturally come to mind.
Sylvana’s blood could revive all spiritual entities.
As the blood covered the blueprint, the Awakened Ware started to emit a bright golden light.
Once she confirmed it was successful, Arix quickly retracted her hand and applied ointment from her Space Button to stop the bleeding.
After treating her hand, Arix picked up the Awakened Ware, now infused with a lot of her blood. She cradled it in her palm, taking a moment to admire it.
Unlike the typical Awakened Ware, this one, enhanced with Sylvana’s blood, had an ethereal transparency and beauty. It looked less like a piece of technology and more like a rare artifact from a mystical world.
The realization of the cost to create this piece made Arix shiver. For the first time, she felt grateful for her background. If she had still been as poor as when she first arrived, she might have ended up as a mining slave in some distant star system. The thought made her shudder, so she quickly shook it off and took the Psychic Ware, leaving her bedroom.
In the living room, Thaddeus, Fleur, and Quillan were anxiously waiting, while Drexel casually munched on an apple.
"Mom, Dad, don’t worry. Arix will be fine," Drexel said, glancing at the overly anxious family. He didn’t see why they were so tense; after all, it wasn’t like Arix was giving her life or something.
"What are you talking about? We’re not nervous," Fleur shot back, as she and the others turned to give Drexel a disdainful look.
Drexel noticed Fleur’s fingers almost digging into the table; Quillan was pacing back and forth, and Thaddeus was looking like he might crush his own knees.
Drexel rolled his eyes and continued eating his apple.
After about ten more minutes, they heard footsteps on the stairs. Everyone turned expectantly as Arix finally came into view.
As Arix went down the stairs, Quillan eagerly asked, "Arix, did it work?"
Both Thaddeus and Fleur looked over, noticing their daughter’s pale lips, their expressions quickly shifting to concern.
Drexel, who had stopped munching on his apple, asked worriedly, "Arix, why do you look so pale?"
Quillan, noticing Arix’s condition as well, quickly moved to check her wrist. However, Arix hid her arm behind her back, smiling reassuringly. "I’m fine, just a bit tired from carving the Psychic Ware," she explained.
Quillan looked surprised but didn’t push further. Thaddeus and Fleur, on the other hand, were clearly worried.
"Arix, go rest. We can wait a day or two," Thaddeus said seriously, concern evident in his voice.
Fleur, feeling Arix’s cold forehead, added, "Why are you still eating? Help your sister to her room to rest!" she scolded Drexel.
"Oh, right, I’m coming," Drexel responded, quickly tossing his apple aside and moving to support Arix.
"No, really, I’m fine, Mom and Dad," Arix insisted, wanting to proceed with the treatment for her father.
But Fleur was having none of it. "I know if you’re okay or not. Go rest, or I’ll have to get strict with you."
Arix, seeing the serious look on her mother’s face, decided not to argue. She knew her mom was truly worried.
As Drexel helped her to her room, Arix turned to Quillan, saying, "Sir, my partner in the Psychic Ware research is Talrin. We developed the Psychic Incarnation together. You can ask him for more details. We’re willing to share the blueprint for this one, which we called Awakened Ware. Wait, let me finish..."
"Alright, got it, now go rest," Quillan interjected, both amused and concerned as Arix was led away.
"Okay, goodbye, sir," Arix waved as Drexel guided her to her room.
With Arix settled, Quillan said his goodbyes to the Kering family and hurriedly left. He immediately bought a spaceship ticket to Mulado, only to realize the journey was too slow. He later switched to a Space-jumper ticket.
While waiting during a transfer on the Space-jumper, Quillan began researching Talrin. To his surprise, he discovered Talrin’s extensive report from the military. He hadn’t expected Arix’s partner to be such a significant figure.
This revelation made things a bit awkward. Quillan had planned to have the Psychic Ware Association collaborate with Talrin on researching the Awakened Ware, but he hadn’t realized Talrin was the head of the New Psychic Ware Association.
The old and new associations were known for their rocky relationship. Quillan felt a twinge of embarrassment for the old association but quickly reassured himself, thinking, "It’s not my problem. I’m just an innocent, powerless director. It’s up to them to figure out how to get along with each other."
With that, Quillan informed the Alliance president, the admirals of the five great armies, and the old Psychic Ware Association about the Awakened Ware, leaving the next steps in their hands.

chapters.title: Chapter 196: The Blueprint
chapters.content:
Chapter 196: The Blueprint
Just as Quillan anticipated, the admirals of the great armies were immediately alarmed upon receiving the information.
There was a closely held secret that most ordinary people were unaware of, but those in high positions knew very well: only those with Psychic Incarnation could control level-eight mechas.
The five major families had been using their Psychic Incarnations as keys to operate their respective level-eight mechas since ancient times.
While ordinary individuals with Psychic Incarnation couldn’t command the level-eight mechas, members of those families could. After all, many families had siblings who could inherit this ability.
Moreover, even if someone wasn’t from one of the five great families, possessing a Psychic Incarnation still allowed their mecha to reach a higher level of power.
If Awakened Ware could be mass-produced, it could potentially enable future mechas to be upgraded and modified based on these Psychic Incarnations.
And most crucially, once Awakened Wares were released, the Alliance’s overall strength would undoubtedly soar.
In stark contrast to the excitement among the Alliance’s upper ranks, the air in the old Psychic Ware Association’s conference room was tense and heavy. The Psychic Ware Grandmasters and the association’s president were all glaring at Bryndel.
Bryndel, feeling the weight of their stares, cautiously glanced around before quickly lowering his head in fear. He sat silently, not daring to speak.
The silence stretched on until Seldner, known for his hot temper, finally broke it. "Bryndel, how did you manage to let our Psychic Ware Association’s genius get scooped up by that upstart association?" he demanded angrily. "Now the entire Alliance knows that the Awakened Ware was developed by them. What does that do to our legitimate Psychic Ware Association’s reputation?"
Bryndel kept his mouth shut, feeling the heat of the blame. He thought to himself that it wasn’t entirely his fault his apprentices were so promising.
Thrynn, another senior figure, added with biting sarcasm, "We gave you the chance to mentor apprentices, and look what happened. You’ve basically handed our talent over to the upstarts. I’m starting to wonder if you’re working for them."
Bryndel internally sighed. He knew Thrynn had been unhappy about him taking on Arix as an apprentice from the beginning, and now she was also indirectly blaming the president for putting him in this position.
Other Grandmasters in the Psychic Ware association started to question what was happening, and the murmurs in the conference room got louder.
Clearly, they weren’t happy.
They felt the spotlight should’ve been on their official association, not on some unknown group that somehow snagged the Awakened Ware results.
The grandmasters in the Psychic Ware association were seething with anger, barely able to breathe from the frustration. And poor Bryndel, who was now the focus of all those stares, felt incredibly wronged.
’The Awakened Ware is Arix’s invention, so why are these old-timers acting like it’s stolen from them?’
He didn’t dare voice his thoughts, though, because it might cost him dearly in that tense room.
Just as the Grandmasters seemed ready to scold Bryndel, the association’s president, Zorix, finally spoke up. "Everyone, please calm down," he said, clasping his hands in front of him with a serene expression, like nothing could faze him.
The room quieted down, though the Grandmasters still eyed Bryndel warily.
Zorix, choosing to keep things simple, continued, "This isn’t Bryndel’s fault, nor the fault of the small association you mentioned. Arix did a fantastic job developing the Awakened Ware, but let’s not forget, Talrin had been researching this for decades. Not too long ago, if I remember correctly, many of you laughed at him for being overly ambitious."
As Zorix finished, the room fell silent. No one had believed that a Psychic Ware capable of awakening a Psychic Incarnation was possible, and they had even mocked Talrin behind his back for dreaming too big.
Now, with the tables turned, those past laughs only deepened their embarrassment.
The Grandmasters exchanged glances, no longer angry but clearly uncomfortable. The idea of this groundbreaking invention being in the hands of a smaller, often dismissed association didn’t sit well with them. They wondered if they really had to swallow their pride and ask for cooperation.
Seldner, in particular, looked furious. He was too proud to ask that small group for anything. But as much as Seldner resisted, some of the other Grandmasters couldn’t hold back their questions any longer.
"President Zorix, who are we going to send to the New Psychic Ware association to ask for the Awakened Ware’s blueprint?" one eager Grandmaster asked.
Zorix didn’t respond directly but instead posed a question of his own. "Any volunteers?" His words were met with silence once again.
All the Psychic Ware Grandmasters felt a twinge of guilt.
Some stared up at the ceiling, others looked down at the floor, and a few just zoned out entirely.
The rivalry between the two Psychic Ware associations had been going on for ages, and almost everyone there was a veteran of the Psychic Ware association. Disputes and harsh words were the norm, but having to ask for cooperation now felt like a real blow to their pride.
Noticing the awkward silence, Bryndel, who had been standing quietly in the corner, timidly raised his hand and said, "Maybe I should go?"
The moment he spoke, all eyes turned to him. But this time, the looks weren’t angry; they were more like expressions of realization or even relief.
’Of course! How can we have forgotten about him?’
"President Zorix, I suggest Bryndel go. After all, he’s their master, so he’s got a better shot at getting the blueprint," Seldner said, his eyes lighting up with sudden enthusiasm. He even looked at Bryndel with a newfound friendliness.
Bryndel thought to himself, "Seriously? Just say it without that creepy look."
"I agree, Bryndel is the best choice," Thrynn nodded, thinking the plan made sense. The other Psychic Ware Grandmasters quickly voiced their agreement as well.
With everyone on the same page, Zorix nodded in approval and announced, "Alright, it’s decided. Bryndel will go."
The decision was made without any objections. As the Psychic Ware Grandmasters settled on this plan, Zorix turned his cold gaze to Bryndel, smiling in a way that was both kind and slightly threatening, "Bryndel, you won’t let us down, will you?"
Bryndel could only roll his eyes. With a deep breath, he patted his chest and promised, "Don’t worry, I’ll get it done."
"Good, then this meeting is adjourned. Everyone can go," Zorix said, finally showing a smile.
As soon as the meeting ended, the Grandmasters practically rushed Bryndel out of the building, not giving him a moment to collect himself.
Standing alone at the entrance of the Psychic Ware association, Bryndel watched the Grandmasters enthusiastically see him off.
With a sigh, he turned and set off alone towards the New Psychic Ware association.

chapters.title: Chapter 197: Bryndel’s Visit
chapters.content:
Chapter 197: Bryndel’s Visit
Right now, the New Psychic Ware Association is surrounded by military Levs and warships due to the Awakened Ware incident.
Many of the poorer civilians from the Alliance had never witnessed such a scene. They stayed far back, secretly observing the spectacle.
Fortunately for them, the main gate of the Psychic Ware Association had been broken, giving them a clear view of everything happening inside the hall.
Inside the grand hall, the president of the New Psychic Ware Association, Talrin, was warmly serving tea to each visitor.
Quillan, the representative of the visitors, politely accepted a teacup. He smiled as he took a sip, but his eyebrows immediately furrowed from the bitterness. Calmly putting down the teacup, Quillan thought to himself,
’That’s some real bad tea. Is he unhappy with us?’
However, he quickly dismissed the thought.
’A president who can’t even afford to fix the gate probably doesn’t have bad intentions. Maybe he’s just broke.’
With that thought, Quillan smiled again and politely addressed Talrin, "President Talrin, I believe you know why we’re here today. What do you think?"
Talrin nodded and replied, "For the sake of Arix, I agree with the matter. But..." He trailed off, looking troubled.
Seeing this, Quillan smiled understandingly and said, "If you have any difficulties, please let us know. We will do our best to help."
Talrin pretended to be shy and said, "This is a bit embarrassing."
"Not at all. We would feel uncomfortable taking you and Arix’s research results for free," Quillan replied politely.
Encouraged, Talrin continued, "Now that you said so... Speaking of this Awakened Ware, I’ve spent almost 20 years on it. I won’t talk about the hardships, but as you know, our New Psychic Ware Association is struggling. So, I hope you can agree to three conditions from me in exchange for the research results."
Talrin hinted with his eyes at the nearly collapsing association, showcasing his month-long effort of not rebuilding to earn some sympathy.
Thinking this, Talrin’s lips curled slightly.
Quillan lowered his eyes and thought for a moment, then said hesitantly, "Could you please tell me your conditions? I am not the decision-maker of the Alliance and cannot decide alone."
"Of course, my conditions are very simple. The first condition is that I hope the Alliance officially recognizes the existence of the New Psychic Ware Association," Talrin said passionately.
He was tired of people calling his association a fake one.
Quillan raised his eyebrows in surprise. He had expected the first condition to be about money. Instead, it was just official recognition from the Alliance. This condition was not only reasonable but surprisingly simple.
"President Talrin, I can agree to this condition on behalf of the Alliance. However, you understand that once you are officially recognized, you’ll also be bound by official regulations. Are you still willing?" Quillan looked directly at Talrin, his tone serious.
Talrin nodded confidently, a smile on his face. "The greater the restriction, the greater the protection. Being bound by the Alliance is an honor."
"Alright, what’s the next condition?" Quillan asked, seeing Talrin’s swift agreement.
"The second condition is..." Talrin glanced around his association before continuing, "Rebuild the New Psychic Ware Association here using the best building materials."
"Agreed! What’s the third condition?" Quillan replied quickly, feeling almost embarrassed by how reasonable and simple the conditions were.
For the third condition, Talrin’s expression turned serious. "The third condition is for the Alliance to establish a Psychic Incarnation Protection Law, granting them equal human rights."
Hearing this, Quillan’s expression finally changed. This was a significant request, one he couldn’t agree to directly.
"President Talrin, I will report your request to the president. I also hope this condition can be fulfilled," Quillan said firmly, looking sharply at Talrin.
Talrin met Quillan’s gaze and smiled, "Thank you, Director Quillan."
After reaching an agreement, Talrin handed over a few Vita Crystals and a blueprint to Quillan. Once he had seen off the Alliance representative with a smile, Bryndel arrived at the new Psychic Ware Association, fashionably late.
"Master? What brings you here today?" Talrin seemed unsurprised by Bryndel’s arrival.
"Just checking to see if you’ve starved to death," Bryndel said, rolling his eyes at his troublesome apprentice.
"Hehe, you always joke around," Talrin said warmly, inviting Bryndel in and serving him tea.
Bryndel eyed the tea suspiciously, then looked silently at his apprentice.
Seeing his master’s murderous look, Talrin swallowed nervously and smiled sheepishly, "Master, I already knew why you’re here. So just get comfortable. President Quillan and I have already reached an agreement."
Bryndel snorted arrogantly, his gaze sharp. "You know what I want, right?"
"Of course, Master. I have it ready for you," Talrin replied quickly, a stark contrast to his earlier hesitation with Quillan. He pulled out a Space Button.
Bryndel’s eyes gleamed with satisfaction at his Talrin’s promptness. He reached for the Space Button, but Talrin held onto it.
"Hmm?" Bryndel’s look turned dangerous, ready to unleash his frustration.
Talrin swallowed nervously. "Master, you’re here on behalf of the old Psychic Ware Association, right? I have three small conditions. Can you agree to them on their behalf?"
Bryndel raised an eyebrow, a smile playing on his lips. "Go ahead, tell me."
Sensing a chance, Talrin’s enthusiasm grew. He moved behind Bryndel and began massaging his shoulders.
Once Bryndel relaxed, Talrin cautiously said, "Master, I’m thinking of you. My first condition is that the old Psychic Ware Association grants you freedom. I know you’ll be free eventually, but until then, I can’t rest easy."
"That’s a good and sweet condition. What’s the next one?" Bryndel asked, enjoying the massage.
"The second condition is money. I don’t need much, just 10 billion astrocredits," Talrin stated calmly.
Bryndel was taken aback, turning to stare at his apprentice. "10 billion? That’s a bit too much... But alright, make it 20 billion. Half for me."
Talrin laughed, agreeing, "Alright, 20 billion it is."
"And the third condition?" Bryndel asked, now in a good mood.
"I want both Arix and me to have a chance to study in the Knowledge Tower for a month," Talrin said firmly.
Bryndel, who had been enjoying the massage, suddenly froze. He quickly pushed Talrin away and moved to the opposite couch.
"Are you trying to get me killed?" he shouted. "If I suggest that to the Psychic Ware Association, they’ll execute me immediately!"
The Knowledge Tower was the most guarded place of the Psychic Ware Association, containing all the ancient blueprints. It was their most prized asset, the source of their power.
Even the elders could only enter once a year for three days. Asking for a month was beyond insane.
"No one in the Alliance would dare harm you now. Besides, it’s not just for me, it’s for Arix too," Talrin said sincerely.
Hearing Arix’s name, Bryndel hesitated for a long time before finally gritting his teeth and saying, "Fine, I’ll try."
"Oh, thank you, Master! I knew you were the best!" Talrin exclaimed, delighted. He started massaging Bryndel’s shoulders again.
This time, Bryndel was scared. He quickly dodged Talrin’s hands and impatiently waved him off, saying, "Stay away from me."
Talrin smiled helplessly and sat down on the opposite sofa, waiting for good news from his master.
Bryndel frowned as he sent the three conditions to President Zorix of the Psychic Ware Association.

chapters.title: Chapter 198: Bringing Back Phantom
chapters.content:
Chapter 198: Bringing Back Phantom
Zorix was silent for a long time after receiving the message. Bryndel could already imagine the president’s furious reaction.
The thought of facing his president made Bryndel dread returning to the association. He feared he would be executed and turned into soup, with only his bones left for Talrin to collect.
The more he imagined, the gloomier Bryndel’s face became. He stared resentfully at Talrin, filled with regret for taking on such troublesome students.
Lorin was always running around, Jorvic was no better, and Talrin was the worst, constantly causing trouble. Only Arix, that sweet piece of candy, gave him a bit of solace.
Sighing, Bryndel shook his head wearily. While they waited tensely, a message finally came from the Psychic Ware Association.
Bryndel hurriedly opened it and read the contents, his changing dramatically.
The association had grudgingly agreed to the first two conditions. The third one, however, was modified: Arix could enter the Knowledge Tower for a month, but Talrin could only go for one day. If Talrin disagreed, the association would call off the deal and find another way.
After hearing Bryndel’s explanation, Talrin smiled slyly and said, "Master, please tell the association I agree to these terms. I originally just wanted to get Arix into the Knowledge Tower. I didn’t expect the association to be so generous."
Bryndel shook his head at his cheeky apprentice and then sent the response to the association. With no objections on either side, the deal was made.
Bryndel looked at his newfound proof of freedom and the 10 billion astrocredits in his account, feeling a mix of surprise and gratitude. Without hesitation, he grabbed the Space Button and left quickly, fearing Talrin might come up with another scheme.
As Bryndel hurried away, Talrin stood at the broken door, waving goodbye. Once Bryndel was out of sight, Talrin lowered his arm. He transferred 5 billion astrocredits to Arix and sent her an email granting her a month in the Knowledge Tower.
After completing these tasks, Talrin whistled happily and walked upstairs with a spring in his step.
...
Morning sunlight spilled into the bedroom, gently waking Arix.
She stretched and yawned, feeling refreshed from a good night’s sleep. She even dreamt about receiving 5 billion astrocredits, vividly recalling the notification sound in her dream.
Thinking it was just a dream, she shrugged it off and headed to the bathroom to get ready.
Downstairs, she found Thaddeus and Fleur cozily seated on the couch. Thaddeus was engrossed in legion work, while Fleur watched TV.
"Good morning, Dad and Mom," Arix greeted them with a bright smile, rushing over for a group hug. Fleur hugged her daughter warmly, her heart melting with affection. Thaddeus smiled at the scene, pulling them both into his embrace.
After a bit, Arix pulled away and looked at Thaddeus. "Dad, let’s save Phantom now," she said eagerly.
"You haven’t had breakfast yet. How about we wait a bit?" Thaddeus suggested, concerned.
"It’s okay, it’ll be quick," Arix insisted with a playful pout. Seeing her determination, Thaddeus sighed and relented. "Alright, alright, we’ll do it your way."
Arix grinned. "Great! Here, Dad, hold this core." Thaddeus took the core, ready for the task.
"Now, close your eyes," Arix instructed. "In the psychic world, use the core’s power to visualize Phantom. Once you see him, keep calling his name. Take your time; we’ll be waiting outside."
In the psychic realm, Thaddeus followed Arix’s guidance. He easily visualized Phantom—a small, black cat with two tails, the size of an ordinary house cat. Her jet-black fur and ruby-red eyes made her look both noble and mysterious.
Seeing Phantom, Thaddeus’s eyes filled with tears.
...
Phantom had appeared when Thaddeus was just six years old.
Initially, he thought she was a lost kitten, but when his hand passed through her, he realized it was unreal; more like a phantom. For a long time, Phantom’s blood-red eyes scared him to tears.
It was Frances who first noticed something was off with Thaddeus. After some gentle questioning, she discovered Thaddeus had awakened his own psychic incarnation.
Seeing her son looking worn out, Frances couldn’t resist giving him a playful flick on the forehead. She then explained the psychic incarnations of the five major families. With this knowledge, Thaddeus realized Phantom wasn’t a ghost and began trying to interact with her.
One day, Thaddeus was attacked by other kids, and Phantom was the first to stand in front of him and protect him.
From that moment, Thaddeus truly accepted Phantom, forming a bond with her. He chatted with Phantom daily, sharing his life.
When Drexel was born, he even brought Phantom to the cradle to watch the baby curiously.
Thinking back on these warm memories, Thaddeus smiled. He began to call out, "Phantom, Phantom, come back..."
With each call, scattered light gathered at Phantom’s forehead.
Thaddeus’s voice grew hoarse, but he kept calling. As the light grew brighter, Phantom slowly opened her eyes, focusing on Thaddeus.
"Meow," Phantom called out, concerned. Her last memory was of Thaddeus being saved by a level-eight mecha. Though she knew Thaddeus was likely safe, she was still worried.
Hearing Phantom’s voice, Thaddeus’s tears flowed. He laughed, then sobbed more intensely. Phantom, thinking she had scared Thaddeus like before, stood nervously aside, unsure how to comfort him without making things worse.
After a while, Thaddeus wiped his tears and opened his arms. "Phantom, come here," he called softly.
With a meow, Phantom leapt into his arms without hesitation. Feeling the reality of Phantom, Thaddeus finally believed she was truly back.
"Meow," Phantom licked Thaddeus’s tears and rubbed against his cheek to comfort him.
Thaddeus petted Phantom and remembered that Fleur and Arix were waiting outside. He gently asked, "Phantom, do you want to meet the one who saved you, little Arix?"
"Meow," Phantom looked up at Thaddeus and nodded slightly.
"Alright, let’s go see her. I remember when you scared Arix to tears as a child," Thaddeus recalled with a hidden smile.
Phantom remembered too and meowed in response.
As the sounds faded, Thaddeus and Phantom left the psychic world together.

chapters.title: Chapter 199: Five Billion
chapters.content:
Chapter 199: Five Billion
In the living room, Arix and Fleur, watched Thaddeus with bated breath. They were so worried about waking him that even their breathing slowed down.
After a while, noticing Thaddeus still asleep, Fleur gestured toward the dining room, signaling Arix to go have breakfast.
Arix wanted to stay a bit longer, but under her mom’s increasingly stern look, she nodded obediently.
Fleur smiled, satisfied, and waved her off. Arix got up carefully and headed to the dining room.
As soon as she walked in, Evelyn, who was busy making strawberry jam, stopped and asked gently, "Miss, what would you like for breakfast today?"
"Evelyn, just some scrambled eggs, please," Arix said as she sat down at the table.
"Okay," Evelyn replied with a warm smile. She then turned to make the meal. A few minutes later, she placed the eggs and juice in front of Arix.
"Thank you, Evelyn," Arix said and started eating.
Watching Arix eat happily, Evelyn said, "Miss, there’s more in the pot. I’ll get you some more when you’re done."
"No need, Evelyn. This is enough," Arix smiled and declined.
"Alright, take your time," Evelyn said and continued making the jam.
Arix nodded with a smile and opened her opticomputer to check out the mecha master’s livestream. But as soon as the screen lit up, she saw a notification of a 5 billion astrocredit deposit in her account.
"Ahh, ahh, ahh..." Arix choked on her eggs in surprise.
"Miss, are you alright?" Evelyn asked, concerned.
Arix struggled to swallow the egg and quickly shook her head, "I’m fine, I’m fine. The eggs were just so delicious, so I ate too quickly."
"Really? Then eat slower, Miss," Evelyn said, still a bit worried but reassured as Arix seemed okay.
"Okay," Arix replied hurriedly and started to check the source of the funds.
Seeing that the transfer was from Talrin, Arix quickly opened his profile and sent a message.
"Arix: Did you transfer the wrong number?"
After a while, Talrin replied.
"Talrin: No, Arix. The old Psychic Ware Association asked me for Awakened Ware. They felt bad about getting it for free, so they gave me 20 billion astrocredits. Master Bryndel took 10 billion, and the other 10 billion is for us to split."
"Arix: This is too much. I didn’t do anything."
"Talrin: I know what you did, so just accept it. If you keep rejecting me, I’ll get mad."
"Arix: Okay, thank you."
"Talrin: Good."
"Talrin: By the way, Arix, the old Psychic Ware Association thought 20 billion wasn’t enough, so they gave you a pass to study at the Knowledge Tower for a month. You can go check it out when you have time."
"Arix: The Knowledge Tower? What’s that?"
"Talrin: Look it up online. I have to go. Bye."
"Arix: Okay, goodbye."
After saying goodbye, Arix searched the interstellarnet for information about the Knowledge Tower.
Knowledge Tower
Country:
The Alliance
Owner:
The Psychic Ware Association
Introduction:
The Knowledge Tower was built by the Rinn family in the early days of the Alliance. It houses the blueprints of all Psychic Ware from ancient times to the present. Therefore, the Knowledge Tower is considered a sacred place for every Psychic Ware Master, but it is also off-limits to everyone. Anyone who tries to enter without the Psychic Ware Association president’s permission can be killed on the spot by the tower’s guardians.
...
After reading the introduction, Arix swallowed nervously. She hadn’t expected such a great gift from her senior brother and the Psychic Ware Association. Studying in the Knowledge Tower for a month would significantly boost her skills in Psychic Ware.
Arix quickly decided to spend her summer break at the Knowledge Tower. After finishing her meal, she put down her spoon and said to Evelyn, "Evelyn, I’m done eating. Thank you for your help."
"Sure. Just leave the plate on the table. The cleaner robot will take care of it," Evelyn replied with a gentle smile.
Arix thanked her again before leaving the dining room to check on Thaddeus.
In the living room, Thaddeus was still in his psychic world, and Fleur was guarding him.
Arix was surprised to see Matis and Kellan had also returned from the military.
"Grandpa, Kellan," Arix said softly, afraid of disturbing her father.
Kellan smiled warmly and nodded at Arix, saying, "Good morning, Arix."
Matis waved Arix over to sit next to him without speaking.
With a big smile, Arix sat next to Matis and said, "I’m so happy to see you at home."
Matis lovingly patted Arix’s head and said proudly, "I know what you’ve done, Arix. You did very well. I’m so proud of you!"
"Thank you. It’s what I should do," Arix said, blushing as she wrapped her arm around her grandfather’s.
Knowing Arix’s shy nature, Matis stopped praising her, worried she would get too embarrassed. He gently patted her head again and said, "You’re such a good kid. If Drexel were half as good as you, I’d be at ease for the rest of my life."
Arix felt a bit guilty at the praise, knowing that Drexel could be even better behaved than she was at times.
Matis suddenly noticed Drexel was missing.
"Kellan, where’s Drexel?" Matis asked, turning around.
Kellan pointed upstairs to Drexel’s room. "He’s still sleeping."
Matis sighed and rubbed his forehead. "Kellan, why don’t you find a Psychic Incarnation for yourself? That way, I’d worry a lot less."
Kellan looked a bit regretful but relieved. "I’m sorry, Grandpa. You know that’s impossible."
Matis gave him a wistful look and then glanced at Arix. He quickly dismissed the idea; he didn’t want Arix to go through those hardships.
Finally, Matis accepted reality and said to Kellan, "I remember you’re about to become their assistant coach. Just take care of your brother during the special training."
Kellan smiled and nodded, "I will, Grandpa."
Arix, listening nearby, blinked in confusion. "Grandpa, is Kellan the assistant coach for the Alliance national mecha team?"
Matis nodded. "Yes."
Arix’s eyes lit up. She hugged Matis’ arm and shook it playfully. "Grandpa, you’ll be by my side whatever I do, right?"
"Of course," Matis said proudly.
"If I try out for the national team, will you support me?" Arix asked sweetly.
Dizzied by Arix’s charm, Matis didn’t catch the details and just agreed, "Of course. I’ll cheer for you."
"Great! Thank you so much. I love you," Arix exclaimed joyfully.
Matis didn’t realize what he’d agreed to; he was just happy to see Arix happy.
"Dad! Arix wants to join the new mecha competition. Wouldn’t that be too dangerous?" Fleur reminded him, not pleased.
